Great fun, thanks to the sparkling dialogue, entertaining performances, and the gorgeous scenery of Paris, London and St. Petersburg.
Suffers from disjointed storytelling and myriad other problems, including a bizarre reliance on modern dance sequences to interrupt the action.

A gripping thriller exploring post-9/11 paranoia.
The cross-cultural backstory behind Autumn, a new French-language feature written, produced and directed by Ra'up McGee, is ultimately more interesting than what's seen onscreen.

This tale of one survivor determined not to let those horrific experiences define her is moving enough to make Forgiving Dr. Mengele a worthy addition to the ever-growing canon of Holocaust-related films.

Gains immeasurably from the extended presence of Travis County D.A. Ronnie Earle.

After six installments, it's not exactly cutting edge.

Fascinating doc provides the story of this pivotal moment in gay rights.

A stylish piece of horror-movie hokum.

Overburdened with disorienting stylistic devices and contrived plot elements that reduce the psychological depth to which it aspires.

[Teghil's] sensitive work goes a long way toward overcoming the unfocused script, which, despite its incisive characterizations, never quite settles into a cohesive tone.
Although less than riveting as a thriller, the film does offer a moving portrait of two aged, emotionally wary people beginning to open up to each other both emotionally and physically.
movie_title: The Other Side of the Street (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Should reasonably please fans of the genre before assuming its place in the horror section of your local video store.
Tells a gripping story that resonates with numerous subtexts.
movie_title: Game Over: Kasparov and the Machine (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Potentially powerful subject matter is given an unconvincingly melodramatic treatment.
Ultimately sinks under the weight of its often pretentious quirkiness, but it does offer some pleasures along the way, especially for nostalgia-minded cinephiles.
Wastes its promising premise with a wavering tone that veers uneasily between camp humor and, pardon the expression, straightness.
A thoughtful, provocative effort that makes up for its narrative failings with its astute philosophical musings.
An appealing lead performance from its leading man and a wonderfully sentimental, if overly familiar, story line are the chief virtues of this French drama.

Although director Balaguero displays a talent for spooky visuals and creating an atmosphere of quietly simmering tension, his screenplay (co-written by Fernando de Felipe) is a compendium of barely connected scenes that ultimately lapse into incoherence.
The first-time filmmaker lacks the stylistic assuredness to put the material over, and the mostly amateurish performances are no help.
A fascinating examination of a mysterious life and the truly bizarre art that it spawned.
movie_title: In the Realms of the Unreal (2005)

movie_review_blurb: The screenplay never quite lives up the cleverness of its premise, with the result that the proceedings never quite gather any comedic steam, though there are amusing moments along the way.

While never fully fleshing out its thesis linking the mythology of popular culture with the false ideals propagated by the regime, it does offer an evocative portrait of a country fiddling while it, and much of the world, burns.

If ultimately the highly talky Saraband comes across as a minor entry in the canon, it nonetheless marks a dignified farewell (and this time it really appears to be one) for one of cinema's greatest directors.

While the film demonstrates some potential on the part of its filmmaker, especially in the acting department, it ultimately lacks the singularity to make it stand out among the glut of similarly themed entries.
Ultimately less reminiscent of similarly themed efforts like Last Tango in Paris than of an explicit health education training film.
An overly ambitious, overly complex and overly long opus that bites off more than it can chew.
Those with negative opinions of Fox News probably never watch it and may find the ample clips on display here eye-opening.
movie_title: Outfoxed: Rupert Murdoch's War on Journalism (2004)

movie_review_blurb: A terrific cinematic essay that will have a very, very long shelf life.
A powerful portrait of the sort of apocalyptic culture clash that is resulting in an increasingly dangerous and fragmented world.
There's no denying the imagination and technical ingenuity on display, but this clearly ranks as one of Maddin's less accessible efforts, which is definitely saying something.
Provides compelling arguments that even those on the right wing of the political spectrum will be hard pressed to entirely refute.
A painfully unfunny, would-be comedy.
Although Criminal retains its source material's cleverness and intricate plotting, something seems to have been lost in the translation.

Even dog lovers, who will no doubt be entranced by the undeniable charms of Weber's frisky menagerie of pooches, will ultimately wish that he had extended his efforts on a coffee-table photography book rather than this confused cinematic tone poem.

Although the positions are by now familiar, especially for those who have seen the previously released films on the subject, there's enough solid and persuasive analysis here to give this effort a fresh urgency.
Manages to be insulting both to slasher movies and lesbians. Where's the gay rights movement when you need it?
Manages to be enjoyable despite its contrivances.
Achieves the dubious distinction of featuring a large gallery of nearly all unlikable characters.
Never manages to reconcile its conflicting tones and ultimately lacks the wit necessary to fuel its outlandish plotting.
A highly awkward blending of gay porn and political satire.

Effectively creates a menacing atmosphere within the gleaming white halls of the hospital in which it is set, but its story line and characterizations lack the sufficient originality to lift the film above its many better predecessors.
movie_title: Qui a tué Bambi? (Who Killed Bambi?) (2004)

movie_review_blurb: A highly effective campaign biography.
movie_title: Going Upriver: The Long War of John Kerry (2004)

movie_review_blurb: An unfortunately muddled portrait of a teenage girl going through a moral and spiritual crisis.
Schultz ... is not able to lift the proceedings beyond melodrama, but he succeeds in imbuing the film with dramatic urgency and has elicited powerful performances from the cast.

While Herzog demonstrates here that he's a perfectly good sport, one can't help think that his time would be far better spent making more films rather than parodying himself in such inconsequential efforts as this.
Saw boasts an undeniably original premise and clever plot machinations that lift it several notches above the usual slasher film level.
It's far too bloody for the art house crowd and too leisurely paced and obscure for more general audiences.
Lundgren's screenplay beautifully juggles the story's alternately comic and poignant elements and renders all three main characters with surprising depth.
Belies its name with its formulaic storytelling and lackluster animation.
Faux silent-film melodrama is mostly a novelty, but the jazz score, performed live by Wynton Marsalis for select engagements, is a real treat.
Despite its imperfections, however, Keep in Touch is intriguing enough to make us want to keep in touch with its tyro director, and particularly its talented leading man.
This mundane doc is cinematic fool's gold.
Displays enough originality to mark its tyro filmmaker, whose only previous credits are as actor and production designer, as a talent to watch.
A familiar tale told with lyricism and sensitivity.

There's no surer ingredient for a feel-good documentary than an inspirational sports story, and filmmaker Dani Menkin delivers one in spades with his recounting of the 1979 European Cup victory by the national Israeli basketball team.
Proves alternately inspiring and depressing even while skirting uncomfortably close to voyeurism.
Incarnate, much like its central character at key moments, barely seems to have a pulse.
As lumbering and slow-moving as the vehicle in which most of its action takes place, Nick Gillespie's horror thriller makes the familiar mistake of confusing obscurity with tension.
There's more ebb than flow in this formulaic indie drama.
The film is engrossing, thanks to the director's skill at delivering sustained tension, and the excellent performances.
Delivering a fully committed, moving performance, Thomas Haden Church makes you pay attention to a figure you would otherwise pass by without a second thought.
Unfortunately, watching Camera Store mainly feels like, well, spending an entire day in a camera store in a nondescript suburban mall.
Longtime fans will want to avoid Contract to Kill and instead dig out their old DVD copies of Under Siege and Above the Law.
An intermittently entertaining but ultimately facile ethnographic portrait.
movie_title: Ghostland: The View of the Ju'Hoansi (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The documentary raises important and substantial questions about an issue that has only become increasingly relevant in recent years.
A fascinating and disturbing true-life tale.
movie_title: Boy 23: The Forgotten Boys of Brazil (Menino 23: Infâncias Perdidas no Brasil) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The Butterfly Room is too ineptly executed to make it little more than a camp curiosity.
A generic, by-the-numbers genre exercise that, for all its talk of blood, is strictly anemic.
Alternately registering as an homage and rip-off of the countless slasher pics that have preceded it, Pitchfork is a strictly disposable affair.
A moving depiction of art transcending life.
Watson is appealing as the spunky heroine, while Doherty only reinforces the film's general derivativeness of better teen comedies with his resemblance to a young Jason Biggs.
You've seen this sort of thriller many times before, and done much better.
This hokey horror film should have stayed cooped up.
The countless devoted fans of Nimoy and his character virtually guarantee that For the Love of Spock will live long and prosper.
The moving performance by Usha Naik in the lead role accentuates the deeply humanistic qualities of this film that has received awards at numerous festivals.
You've seen it before, and done a lot better.

It's all as generic and pointless as it sounds, with tyro filmmaker Nagel unable to muster up the sort of visceral thrills that a John Carpenter or Wes Craven would have been able to deliver in their sleep.
Resembles the sort of bargain basement theatrical production whose audience consists mostly of friends and family members lending moral support.

Channeling the spirit of John Hughes and playing like a tween version of Ferris Bueller's Day Off, Middle School: The Worst Years of My Life delivers an easily digestible and amusing portrait of youthful hijinks.
movie_title: Middle School: The Worst Years of My Life (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The Great Gilly Hopkins has its enjoyable moments - Bates' entertaining, scenery-chewing turn providing many of them - and its themes are refreshingly complex for a film targeted to kids.

Cai's grandmother watches it unfold via an iPad, after which the artist breathlessly asks her, "Isn't your grandson awesome?" It's a beautiful, touching moment that says more about the artistic urge than any scholarly tome ever could.
movie_title: Sky Ladder: The Art of Cai Guo-Qiang (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Ordinary World becomes raggedly enjoyable thanks to the unexpected charms of its leading man

What's truly depressing about the whole enterprise is that Garcia and Bello were pulled into it. Yes, actors love to work and bills need to be paid, but perhaps a fund could be started to spare talented thespians this sort of career embarrassment.
Both Reaser and Thomas provide unexpected depths to what could have been schematic roles, and the younger performers are even better.
This cinematic lecture is unlikely to change many hearts or minds...which is more the pity.

Although there's a long cinematic tradition of mixing comedy with scares to excellent effect - Abbott and Costello Meet Frankenstein being a prime example - this lackluster effort manages to be neither funny nor scary.
movie_title: Tyler Perry's Boo! A Madea Halloween (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A hoary melodrama revealing the filmmaker's inexperience.
It Had to Be You ultimately demonstrates enough cleverness and inventiveness to make it more than a by-the-book entry in a genre that's become more than a little stale.
Aiming for but failing to achieve a Christopher Guest level of spoofery, Ron and Laura Take Back America lives up to George S. Kaufman's quip that satire is what closes on Saturday night.
movie_title: Ron and Laura Take Back America (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Although it will be best appreciated by those already familiar with Babel's life and works, Finding Babel is sufficiently intriguing to provoke the uninitiated to learn more.
The cast is first-rate, and deserves far better material.
There are many powerful moments, and one can't help but empathize with the four women as they experience their travails and triumphs. Their courage is often astonishing, as is their outlook.
This slapdash war movie doesn't do justice to its compelling subject matter.
It's an astonishing tale, even if it's roughly told here.
It's all about as clichéd and predictable as it sounds, although the proceedings are mildly enjoyable in an old-fashioned, Andy Hardy sort of way.
Never rising above the level of generic B-movie, Sleepless represents the sort of disposable fare typically dropped into theaters in January.
Despite its decidedly modest nature, the film... has its charms, thanks in large part to the appealing performances by its two leads.
Donald Cries demonstrates that cringeworthy isn't necessarily the same as funny.
Actor Martinez raises plenty of questions. The problem is that none of them are particularly interesting.
Beautifully photographed by co-director McNicol, the film is a hauntingly evocative portrait of its Southern Gothic-infused milieu.

The screenplay, co-written by Gass-Donnelly with Colin Frizzell, manages to be simultaneously lacking in coherence and utterly predictable, with viewers earning no points for guessing which one of the characters turns out to be the villain.
Director Ben-Shimon's light touch prevents the film from lapsing either into polemics or overly broad comic shtick.
Essential viewing for anyone interested in Israeli history.
While its intriguing setup sounds like it could make for a provocative and original thriller, The Dark Below never lives up to its promise, although it earns points for originality.

Tickling Giants provides a comprehensive examination of Youssef's career highs and lows while providing a vivid personal portrait of its subject whose cheerfulness and resolve began to wither in the face of constant threats to himself and his family.
Delivers much of the same brand of raucous, gay-themed humor that propelled its predecessor to surprising success.
The original title for the second theatrical release from cable channel Syfy was Deep Burial, and that would have been an appropriate fate for this low-budget, sci-fi thriller.

Ojuju overcomes its technical limitations with well-drawn characters and pungently compelling situations. It certainly indicates that its talented filmmaker ... is eminently capable of moving on to bigger and better things.
A cross between home movie and documentary essay, P.S. Jerusalem emerges as a rough-hewn but moving effort that, thanks to the ever-volatile situation in the Middle East, proves unfortunately timely.
The screenplay consistently produces moments that induce chuckles, if not belly laughs. There's also just enough well-earned sentiment thrown in to provide a nice counterpoint to the farcical humor.
Will likely manage the difficult feat of simultaneously alienating fans of the original series and newcomers who will wonder why a buddy cop comedy displays so much homosexual panic.
Betting on Zero is a well-done if not stylistically distinctive nonfiction effort that nonetheless proves fascinating due to its subject matter.
A mediocre effort that nonetheless succeeds in its main goal of keeping its blue characters alive for future merchandising purposes.
The film's hoary, melodramatic plotting and painfully awkward dialogue leave nary a cliché untouched.
Despite its recycled tropes, the comedy-drama manages to be both funny and moving even if its emotional manipulations are fully apparent.

Excellent performances from Michael Shannon, Carla Gugino and young newcomer Taylor John Smith aren't enough to offset the narrative clichés of Bart Freundlich's drama about a high school basketball star struggling with family dysfunction.
Macchio makes for an appealing everyman, and the veteran supporting players project an enjoyment in their stereotypical roles that proves infectious.
Viewers would be far better off rewatching a Mad Max or Rob Zombie movie, or any episode of The Walking Dead, than paying hard-earned money to see Drifter.
American Fable possesses an amorphous, dreamlike quality that proves increasingly irritating as it wears on.
The writer/director [is] so intent on hammering home his thematic points that the situations and characters seem contrived merely to underline them.
The real crime ... is how utterly boring it all is.
The Resurrection of Gavin Stone should satisfy its target heartland audience.

While the human performers are more than adequate, there's no doubt that the canine stars carry the day. Their utter irresistibility helps a long way in terms of getting past the corny plot machinations of A Dog's Purpose.
Devolves into typical teen-oriented, supernatural horror.
A lame would-be comedy that wouldn't be any funnier even if you were smoking the most powerful weed on the planet while watching it, Doobious Sources is a total bummer, man.
Promises, promises.
Strong performances and stunning visuals aren't enough to compensate for the strained Southern Gothic artificiality.
Straining mightily for a Bergmanesque somberness but mainly smacking of pretension, Fall suffers from its overly determined subtlety.
Infusing its nightmarish scenario with bracing doses of satirical humor, Tunnel is smarter and more sophisticated than most Hollywood attempts at the genre.
Sluggishly paced and tonally wobbly, the pic, much like its teenage protagonist, suffers under its own weight.

Resonating with an authenticity borne of the experiences of its director/co-screenwriter Jamal Joseph, Chapter & Verse movingly portrays the plight of a recently released ex-con striving to make a new life for himself on the mean streets of Harlem.
If it had skipped the clichéd supernatural elements to instead concentrate on the relationship between the two central characters, Don't Knock Twice might have emerged as an interesting film.
Despite the strong efforts of everyone involved, Havenhurst proves all too unimaginative in its formulaic recycling of genre tropes.
Too self-consciously arty to appeal to the prurient crowd and lacking sufficient substance for cinephiles, Sex Doll seems to deflate while you watch it.
The film raises more troubling questions than it answers, but it's fascinating throughout nonetheless.
Evanna Lynch shines in this whimsical road trip film that has a compelling backstory.
Depicting the struggles of three undocumented Bronx high school students to avoid deportation, From Nowhere resonates with tender compassion for its characters.

That there's a big difference between Nazi jokes and Holocaust jokes is one of the insights gleaned from Ferne Pearlstein's documentary concerning taboos in comedy, especially those concerning that generally forbidden topic.
Hoult and Jones are unable to breathe much life into their bland characters, and it's ultimately sad to watch the former Hannibal Lecter and Gandhi reduced to playing silly, tough-guy caricatures.
A fascinating if uneven portrait.
movie_title: Mr. Gaga: A True Story of Love and Dance (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It serves as an entertaining salute to an unsung figure whose considerable accomplishments well deserve recognition.
While the film's premise feels all too familiar, its extensive use of well-chosen London locations invests it with a gritty atmospheric flavor.
The film is certainly watchable, thanks to the elaborately staged action sequences and Statham's killer charisma.
Rambling and unfocused, The Tainted Veil fails to do justice to its important subject matter, which the film itself seems to acknowledge toward its conclusion.
It's a shame that this supremely talented duo is participating in such lowest-common-denominator, puerile material.
Director Kamaleshwar Mukherjee's film version of the popular 1937 adventure novel by Bibhutishushan Bandyopadhyay struggles mightily for an epic quality.
Lamb proves itself a deeply intriguing psychological drama that should inspire much spirited debate.
A moving tale of personal redemption is delivered with admirable subtlety and complexity in Stephen Suettinger's directorial debut.
The pic is compelling for the most part, with Jones' riveting performance as the alternately sympathetic and nasty protagonist anchoring the proceedings.
The film is effective for long stretches, mainly due to Rockaway's superb use of his principal setting.
The creepy evocativeness of its superbly utilized setting... and the well-realized creature designs make it a more than respectable horror effort.
Band of Robbers doesn't quite spin its imaginative conceit into comic gold, but it offers some minor pleasures along the way.
It can be definitively stated that Dirty Grandpa is utterly unfunny.
Neither its animation nor voice performances are particularly memorable, but Norm of the North, especially in its early section set in the Arctic, has its appealing moments.
The horror anthology genre gets a shot in the arm with Southbound, an uncommonly cohesive and intelligent example of the form.
The Choice is the cinematic equivalent of staring at a Hallmark Card for two hours.
Much like its characters' romantic lives, How to Be Single is more enjoyable when it's being casual.
One doesn't normally think of Toronto as having particularly mean streets, but they certainly look menacing in Gabriel Carrer's hyper-stylized take on the vigilante thriller.
I Am Thor is an amusing show business tale that is all the more endearing for the respect it shows towards the eccentric and indomitable figure at its center.
Debuting filmmaker Jacob Bernstein delivers a moving biographical portrait of his mother, the late Nora Ephron, in his highly personal documentary.
Oh, dear.
It's rather hard to feel wholly sympathetic towards the quixotic bullfighter who at one point declares, "I've never had a relationship, even with a woman, as intimate as the one I have with a bull."
Despite its non-exploitative approach to its subject, the film... is too schematic and obvious to have the desired impact.
When one of the troubled figures runs fleeing from the stifling environs, it's hard for the viewer not to feel a touch of envy.

While it pales in comparison to such horror anthology predecessors as Tales from the Crypt, Asylum and Creepshow, Tales of Halloween offers enough minor diversions to make it enjoyable late-night viewing.

Failing to live up to it anarchic convictions by adding sympathetic aspects to its central character shortly before the conclusion, Uncle Nick, much like the sorts of holiday celebrations it depicts, is ultimately too strained to be enjoyable.
It's Smith's eccentric oldster who is the film's driving force, and the 80-year-old actress doesn't disappoint. Not surprisingly, she fully exploits the humor in her character's bizarreness.
You've seen it a thousand times before.
It doesn't delve too deeply into its subject's psyche or provide much context for his work, but fashionistas are likely to be entertained.
What viewers will come away with most is a renewed appreciation for the natural beauty of both the western region of the country and the wild animals that inhabit it.
While it doesn't quite manage to sustain that same level of tension throughout, Forever is an intriguing psychological thriller that bears attention.
Cosima Spender's documentary... plays like a classic sports drama thanks to its memorable central characters.

It also suffers from its one-sided perspective which often fails to provide sufficient informational context. But it nonetheless provides a vividly personal account of the country's travails during some of its most tumultuous times.
movie_title: The Prime Ministers: Soldiers and Peacemakers (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The latest advocacy documentary that will either induce you into changing your ways or simply have you curling into a fetal position from despair.
Combining the most clichéd tropes of dysfunctional family comedies and wacky road movies, Ryan Jaffe's debut feature manages to squander the talents of several notable actors.
Emelie serves up satisfying B-movie scares.

As messy and unstructured as the inner life of its central character, Homemakers boasts an uncommonly ragged indie sensibility in its portrait of a disaffected young woman struggling with issues of self-identity.

the film is most successful when it concentrates on its subject's personal life. His candor in discussing his sexuality and other subjects is endlessly refreshing in this era when politicians are mostly defined by their timidity.
movie_title: Compared to What: The Improbable Journey of Barney Frank (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Not being part of the generation that watched the show, I can't vouch for its merits. But it's safe to say that it must be miles ahead of this wan, bloated screen version which forgoes the original's sci-fi and thriller aspects.
The Armor of Light puts a human face on the perpetually divisive topic.
It's an enjoyable enough road movie that, with a running time of a mere 74 minutes, is careful not to wear out its welcome.
The story pretty much goes nowhere, with one key climactic element involving a dramatic episode that's inexplicably not depicted onscreen.
Deeply moving and rambunctiously funny.

[While Brody] delivers a typically intense turn in this Australian thriller, the film doesn't manage to shed its overwhelming air of familiarity and obvious debt to such genre predecessors as The Sixth Sense, among countless others.
Providing a chilling non-fiction parallel to the recent Sicario, Kingdom of Shadows is both heartbreaking and disturbing.
While the violent sequences are very effectively staged, the results are a strange hybrid that doesn't quite work.

Sports and religion are a potent combination, one that siblings Jon and Andrew Erwin (October Baby, Mom's Night Out) exploit to canny effect in their new film based on the real-life Woodlawn High School football team.

What the repetitive film lacks in narrative drive and compelling dialogue it makes up for in technical prowess, with director/editor Orr orchestrating the outrageously violent mayhem with admirable proficiency.
This affectionate portrait includes extensive interviews with Wertmuller, who remains vital in her late 80s, as well as performance footage of her singing her original compositions.
Vardalos and Corbett display the relaxed romantic chemistry that made them so endearing to audiences in the first film.
The latest in a long line of horror films shamelessly ripping off the Brothers Grimm won't leave you believing in fairy tales.
It succeeds on putting a very human face on the dire problem, but the one it's selected is hardly emblematic.
Reveals an insiders' knowledge of the vapid pop music scene, allowing the jokes, even the weaker ones, to land all the harder.

To say that this installment of the latter series is superior to its predecessor is damning it with faint praise, but it's likely to reasonably satisfy tykes (and certain nostalgic oldsters-you know who you are).
movie_title: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Out of the Shadows (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Art Bastard shines brightest not as a biographical portrait -- an aim in which it succeeds only sporadically -- but rather as a showcase for the highly imaginative and thoughtful works by the now 76-year-old, too-little-known painter.
Impressively imaginative and stylish enough to mark its writer/director as a talent to watch.
Traded features nary an original element but nonetheless registers as a solid if minor oater.
What makes the film... as ironically entertaining as it is tragic is its charismatic subject, who is articulate and fascinating even while spiraling downward emotionally.

By the time the film ends, you'll certainly have the feeling of what it must be like to experience life in this bucolic spiritual retreat. Unfortunately, you'll also feel like you've been there for the full five weeks.
If you're able to watch Moyoung Jin's documentary about the day-to-day life of an elderly Korean couple without both laughing and crying, you're not someone I wish to meet.
movie_title: My Love, Don't Cross That River (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Destined to be a cult classic, this sophomore effort by Anna Biller is a heady throwback to the American and European sexploitation horror films of the late '60s and early '70s.

While the performers are appealing, 3rd Street Blackout is a too determinedly quirky affair to fully mine the comic potential of its clever premise. Much like its setting, the film could have used more energy.
It's Hawke who gives the film its dramatic urgency.
Although the film begins promisingly with many amusing moments... it eventually degenerates into all-too-familiar territory.
It's all as clunkily melodramatic as it sounds, with the climactic trial sequences proving particularly slow going.

The legendary creator of the seminal photography book The Americans and such cult film classics as Pull My Daisy and Candy Mountain makes for a highly engaging commentator in Don't Blink: Robert Frank.
It's all awfully dispiriting.
An incisive cinematic portrait featuring commentary by many of his friends and colleagues, as well as extensive archival footage showcasing its subject's magnetic charisma.
Imperium traffics in familiar undercover cop thriller conventions while gaining resonance from its disturbing, timely milieu.
The film is more effective as an emotional appeal for better corporate behavior than a stringent analysis of the complicated scenario.
movie_title: We The People: The Market Basket Effect (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A comprehensive documentary recounting Rabin's life.

More than slightly hagiographic in its approach, and, as its title might indicate, gets too heavy-handed in its moralizing. It also feels much too long - this is the sort of subject for which short films were invented.
movie_title: Streit's: Matzo And The American Dream (2016)

movie_review_blurb: It's all about as predictable as it sounds, but it works anyway, thanks to some snappy dialogue and the engaging turns by old pros Pryce and Collins.
Featuring outstanding performances and making excellent use of its scenic New Orleans locations, the film handles its delicate subject matter with a deeply affecting emotional restraint.
movie_title: Una Vida: A Fable Of Music And The Mind (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Reflecting influences ranging from The Texas Chainsaw Massacre to Rosemary's Baby to -- well, you name it -- Bleed doesn't exactly break any new ground, stylistically or otherwise.
As rip-offs go, it's a well-done, memorable one.
The Boss feels like an elongated sketch.
An evocative portrait of strained friendships and creative turmoil.

The film certainly displays an undeniable verisimilitude... and its striking visuals are bone-chilling enough to make you feel the need to wear a parka, even if watching it in a nicely heated theater.
It's metaphorical aspects like that, and the striking visuals that delineate the stark contrast between the worlds above and below ground, that make Embers memorable.
A cut above.

[Rossi] effectively goes behind the scenes, capturing the complicated logistics that go into the creation of the exhibition and its accompanying gala. The former element provides the film's emotionally richest moments.
Featuring an exciting climax in which Mia, who has gone looking for the missing Fin, plays a vitally important role, the film marks an impressive debut for its writer/director [Ruth Platt].
Ultimately, The Phoenix Incident is more impressive for its ingenious publicity and marketing campaigns, including fake web news sites that went viral, than the quality of the filmmaking.

It might have been more effective as a short film. Still, car aficionados, and anyone interested in the political and social changes in Cuba that will be hastened by the restored relations with the U.S., will find much to appreciate here.
Whitfield and his wife clearly granted unfettered access to the filmmaker, who captures many highly personal, intimate moments that are both joyous and tragic.
movie_title: Be Here Now (The Andy Whitfield Story) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Despite its promising setup, Hostile Border lacks narrative tension, with the screenplay by co-director Kaitlin McLaughlin never quite coming into dramatic focus.
Seen in vintage 8mm home movies, Kitty Genovese emerges as a vibrant, exuberant young woman whose violent death tragically came to overshadow her much too brief life.
The sharply astute, satirical screenplay by Joey and Hanala Sagal and actor Cary Elwes is filled with priceless moments.
Marcie Begleiter's intimate documentary....serves as a valuable primer about [Hesse's] life and artistic legacy.

True to form, the screenplay... is barely coherent in its explication of the convoluted plotline. But it does provide a fair share of hard-boiled, frequently amusing dialogue and a plethora of colorful characters.
Murphy is a revelation.
For all the information presented, the film is insufficient on details, instead stressing the fairly obvious importance of such things as eating natural foods and getting fresh air.
A sharp and funny satire about self-proclaimed spiritual gurus.
Director/screenwriter Khalil Sullins makes an auspicious feature debut with his audacious sci-fi thriller that's as engrossing as it is thought-provoking.

The subject matter's topicality doesn't provide sufficient compensation for the many dull patches in Rucha Humnabadkar's comedy/drama about a young Indian immigrant struggling to get his work visa extended.

The tale is told entirely through Rock's perspective, with no friends, colleagues or talking heads weighing in. But that turns out to be no detriment, since the Cambridge-educated photographer proves a witty and rueful commentator ...
movie_title: SHOT!: The Psycho-Spiritual Mantra of Rock (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A deeply personal investigation into an important subject.
Destined to be forgotten by viewers before the end credits have finished rolling, the film features some pretty people and scenic Virginia Beach locations. But that's pretty much it.
A true crime saga packing an emotional punch.
Unfortunately, the two stories add up to less than the sum of their parts, with the intertwining narratives failing to comment on each other in sufficiently resonant fashion.
Compellingly creepy, I Remember You should well please the many fans of the genre.
Anyone who loves movies is bound to love Saving Brinton.
Depicting the resilience of both the nutria and the Louisianans who've endured their presence for many years, Rodents of Unusual Size proves enjoyably quirky and informative.
Maynard proves as moving as it is informative.

Occasionally gets bogged down in the sort of minutiae that would have been better left on the cutting room floor, but it also provides an insightful depiction of the personal and professional travails that inevitably accompany career success.
Despite its frequently clunky dramaturgy, the film makes some interesting points while providing an excellent showcase for Banks' considerable onscreen charisma.
Although relatively subdued for much of its running time, Slumber eventually devolves into a lengthy, over-the-top climax that's both visually and narratively cheesy.

Chronicling its subject's life and career in fascinating detail, The Newspaperman: The Life and Times of Ben Bradlee will prove catnip to journalism and political buffs, not to mention anyone who cares about the free press and its role in our democracy.
movie_title: The Newspaperman: The Life and Times of Ben Bradlee (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Thankfully devoid of the fantasy elements endemic to so many cinematic versions of YA novels, Kepler's Dream proves a modest but diverting family film charmer.
The film's main draw is its cast, all of whom have seen more illustrious career days but nonetheless can still deliver the goods.

Hollow in the Land traffics in familiar rural thriller territory. But it features an excellent performance from its lead actress and a strong atmosphere of moody tension courtesy of its writer/director.
Provides juicy opportunities for its leads to deliver tour-de-force performances - and they don't disappoint.

Featuring compelling real-life figures who practically invite casting guesses for the inevitable Hollywood dramatization, Killing for Love should easily satisfy viewers who can't get enough of this stuff.
Too subtle for its own good.

Arquette is charmingly endearing as the frustrated Jeanne, Wilson movingly conveys his character's vulnerability as well as his bluster and McLean is terrific as the beleaguered young girl desperate to have a mane like Farrah Fawcett's.
It's Vaughn, still looking dashing despite his obvious frailty, who gives the film its emotional core.
Exuding such a relaxed feel that it's not surprising that its title doesn't appear onscreen until nearly the half-hour mark, Sundowners never strains too hard for its considerable laughs.
Yes, there have been countless Holocaust-themed documentaries released in recent years. But Destination Unknown represents a worthy addition to the canon if only for its historical importance.
While Hello Again has been brought to the big screen, it has not been brought to anything resembling cinematic life.
Unfortunately, for all its social relevance and good intentions, Trafficked mainly proves that university professors don't make the best screenwriters.
A dull, sluggish effort that doesn't avoid a single cliche.
Earth: One Amazing Day proves inspirational in its depiction of the wonders of the natural world.
It will be a miracle if you stay awake.
Despite its many engaging moments, Itzhak will likely prove frustrating for viewers desiring more information.
While the film proves a less than definitive portrait of its subject, it certainly delivers a plethora of fascinating and amusing moments along the way.
movie_title: Joan Didion: The Center Will Not Hold (2017)

movie_review_blurb: In its poetic portrait of a man whose quest to help others has cost him dearly both emotionally and physically, The Departure proves quietly profound.
Te Ata ultimately feels more suitable for classroom than mainstream consumption.
By the time the film reaches its conclusion with a brief snippet of the band's performance, you'll be feeling as bewildered as the North Koreans seen watching it.
More than anything, Killing Gunther demonstrates that Christopher Guest has a lot to atone for with his pioneering of the mockumentary, which has become the lazy, go-to style for low-budget comedies.
Attempting to combine Clueless-style humor revolving around self-absorbed high school girls with slasher film tropes, Tragedy Girls proves neither funny nor scary enough to be distinctive.
Viewers will likely feel the urge to contact a genealogist after seeing Alon and Shaul Schwarz's fascinating and moving documentary about amazing revelations concerning their own family.
Teller, continuing his streak of strong dramatic performances that include Whiplash and Bleed for This, delivers a powerful turn that is all the more effective for its restraint.
Considering the long amount of time since the last installment, you'd think that more effort would have been put into creatively reviving the franchise.
[Offers] enough enjoyable Masterpiece Theater-style moments to entice Anglophiles and those who can never get enough of Ebenezer Scrooge.
While Christian audiences will no doubt embrace this heavily proselytizing drama, secular viewers are likely to feel like they've been accosted by a street corner preacher.
The well-chosen profile subjects prove both engaging and sympathetic in their fears and desires, giving the film a much-needed emotional resonance.
Featuring a terrific performance by Ryan Barton-Grimley in the lead role, Repatriation is a modest indie film worth seeking out.
... it's not the expert commentary, as illuminating as it is, that gives the film its power. Rather, it's the handful of veterans who discuss their emotional struggle...
All of this material proves fascinating. It's a shame, then, that so much of Intent to Destroy plays like a special feature for the DVD edition of The Promise.
Whatever charms the first two movies possessed (and they were considerable thanks to the talented and appealing cast) have been thoroughly lost in this soulless installment.
A hugely charming testament to the kindness of strangers.
This formulaic thriller is m_di_c_e.
One of the best line-ups in this category in years.

Works most effectively in its subtler, more enigmatic moments than when it indulges in familiar horror film conventions. Nevertheless, it does offer a consistent level of tension, a few decent scares and a terrific lead turn by Christie Burke.
Even the actors' fine efforts cannot rescue Looking Glass from terminal murkiness.
The Scent of Rain and Lightning is a well-acted, intelligent thriller that ultimately rewards the viewer's patience even if it too often sacrifices narrative clarity in favor of atmosphere.
Wohl never manages to achieve the proper tonal blend. The result is neither sufficiently funny nor moving, lacking the truly daring humor that might have made the film a bracing dark comedy.
Although not particularly original in its recycling of familiar genre tropes, the stylish film should well satisfy horror aficionados while engaging more general audiences as well.
A fascinating look at an often misunderstood condition.
While Half Magic proves too frivolous to make its satirical and social points fully register, it offers diverting pleasures along the way.
Goes nowhere slowly.
Could use some straightening.
A low-budget film noir that benefits greatly from its tautness and lack of pretension.
Breaking Point benefits greatly from its harrowing footage taken from both news and private sources.
movie_title: Breaking Point: The War for Democracy in Ukraine (2018)

movie_review_blurb: Crudely effective, although you've seen it all before.
Strong performances and atmosphere compensate for the cliched storyline.

The Forgiven tackles its important political and social issues in an overly talky fashion. The film has its merits, but it represents a significant comedown for the director of such classics as The Mission and The Killing Fields.
Replicating the tropes of its predecessor to a slavish degree, The Strangers: Prey at Night pretty much wastes all its inspiration on its punning title.

Designed to offer Western audiences the opportunity to see a Caucasian movie star, and a heartthrob one at that, in an unusual genre setting, The Outsider rarely manages to rise above its audience-baiting concept.
The film doesn't succeed in its ambition to infuse noir tropes with originality.
The next time you're invited to a French dinner party, you might want to give it a pass, if the tedious proceedings in Change of Plans are any indication.
movie_title: Change of Plans (Le Code a Changé) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The darker entries are the most compelling.
An unconvincing treatment of familiar themes.
Ca-Ca Land.
A deeply moving portrait of its truly admirable, complex subject.
But on its own B-movie terms 47 Meters Down works just fine, not wearing out its welcome thanks to its quick set-up, rapid pacing and brief running time.

[Beller's] deep-rooted empathy and compassion is plainly evident in her latest effort, but it's not enough to compensate for the tedium engendered by the meandering debates whose impact ultimately adds up to very little.
Madtown is an intriguing drama featuring well-drawn characters and incisive dialogue.
Lexerot and Roth may be godawful filmmakers, but they certainly have one hell of a Rolodex.
movie_title: Surge of Power: Revenge of the Sequel (2018)

movie_review_blurb: Acts of Violence evaporates from your mind while you're watching it.
Despite its flaws, the film proves very moving at times.
Inside somehow manages to be remarkably devoid of suspense throughout its brief running time.
Unfortunately, settings alone don't make a movie, and this cliché-ridden effort feels indistinguishable from the countless similarly themed horror films that have preceded it.
A mishmash of action movie and buddy cop clichés rendered in incompetent fashion, this wink-wink homage to 1991's Showdown in Little Tokyo makes its inspiration seem like a classic.
A provocative portrait of a journalistic train wreck.
The two leads are both highly appealing, with Roe credible as a country music superstar.
The loser is the audience for Den of Thieves, an over-the-top crime saga mainly indicating that its writer/director has seen Michael Mann's Heat too many times.
Time Share proves a cinematically arresting psychological thriller that succeeds in keeping viewers on edge even if it doesn't give them much to mull over afterwards.
Interminable dull stretches blunt the impact of undeniably exciting action sequences, making the series finale unlikely to leave even fans wanting more.

The mishmash of styles smacks of a "let's throw in everything but the kitchen sink" approach that becomes increasingly tiresome the longer it goes on and feels more like a horror anthology than a cohesive story.
Feiffer's distinctive writing resonates even decades later.
The Misguided ambles along at a languid, uncompelling pace.
It's the cinematic equivalent of listening to opera in an elevator.
Despite his fearsome physicality, Momoa again manages to come off as a relatable everyman, and Lang, as usual, superbly handles his role's considerable emotional and physical demands.
A real-life version of Hollywood boxing-movie tropes.
Veterans Englund and Shaye admirably give it their all, but their best efforts are not enough to elevate the subpar material directed in mechanical fashion by Zariwny.
That its 81-year-old subject is so determinedly old-school in his shoe-leather approach is what makes Hall of Mirrors such fascinating viewing.
Persuade your significant other to watch the film with you. And if he or she doesn't leave you forever after the experience, then you know you have a keeper.
Unable to make up its mind whether it wants to be a Pearl Jam concert film or sports documentary, Let's Play Two succeeds at neither.

If the film succeeds in attracting an audience, it may very well drive up the tourism that this remote town so desperately needs. At least as shown here, it seems like a pretty cool (pun intended) place to visit.
Visually poetic but often feeling as air-deprived as its shaven-headed subject, My Life Without Air would have benefited from more narrative oxygen.

Rough-hewn stylistically and occasionally bordering on self-indulgence, 32 Pills: My Sister's Suicide nonetheless packs a powerful emotional punch with its unflinching portrait of two siblings dealing with past and present demons.
For the most part the film chronicles the complex tale cogently and effectively, using extensive archival footage as well as contemporary interviews that help put the events in context.
A depressing portrait of a political system that has gone hopelessly off the rails, PACmen is essential viewing for anyone seeking to understand some of the reasons why.
[A] generic horror movie featuring a skeletal plot, barely developed characters, recycled clichés, and subpar special effects.
Viewers may at times be hard pressed to keep track of what exactly is going on, but the essential truths about combat, including post-traumatic stress, are vividly conveyed.
A character acknowledging that the proceedings resemble an "entertaining but far-fetched TV show" isn't enough to make Baywatch anything more than the cynical cash grab that it is.
The clips from the two championship matches go on far too long, ultimately proving more numbing than exciting for any but the sport's most ardent fans.
movie_title: Spirit Game: Pride of a Nation (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Despite such rich source material, however, Letters From Baghdad proves oddly unsatisfying.
The Incomparable Rose Hartman doesn't quite make the case for lengthily profiling its irascible and not particularly interesting subject.
Documentarian Bill Morrison delivers a worthy follow-up to his classic 2002 film Decasia with another cinematic tone poem dedicated to the glories of silent cinema.
If an apocalypse ever does occur, one hopes that whatever survivors are left will have better material to draw from when they make the inevitable films about it.
Exerts fascination with its haunting imagery of what it informs us is still an active volcano that may well erupt again (the last time was in the 1700s).
Exploring the ramifications of that tragic state of affairs while introducing a concept dubbed "Moral Injury," Almost Sunrise makes for powerful viewing.
Feeling particularly relevant these days because of the ever-growing obstacles faced by less-educated people struggling for economic gains, the moving film depicts the American dream in action.
The jumble of storylines inevitably results in narrative confusion, and the relationships linking them, some of which are only revealed late in the proceedings, don't resonate strongly.
Camera Obscura squanders its intriguing premise with a ham-fisted execution.
F(l)ag Football reveals that gay athletes can be just as dull as straight ones when they become the subject of documentaries.
A stylishly executed but narratively muddled effort that confounds as much as it engrosses.
A Better Man deals with a hot-button issue in sensitive fashion.
Despite the strenuous efforts of all concerned, the love story at the film's core never seems credible.
movie_title: This Is Not What I Expected (2017)

movie_review_blurb: On its own limited terms provides the sort of violent entertainment geared to fans who enjoy watching movies like, well, Lady Bloodfight.
Based on Lee Strobel's best-selling book, this religious-themed drama earns points for proselytizing in more narratively compelling form than usual.
The film's stage origins, and a cameo appearance by Lin-Manuel Miranda, may be of interest to theater buffs, but everyone else will be left wondering what all the fuss was about.
I Hate Myself :) centers on two thoroughly repellant, self-absorbed figures with whom spending time proves a nearly intolerable trial.
With its mystical storyline weighed down with symbolic and allegorical elements, The Last of Us isn't sufficiently resonant to reward the viewer's patience.
movie_title: Akher Wahed Fina (The Last of Us) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Since the action takes place entirely on the plane, it's mainly of the claustrophobic variety, with the shootouts and fistfights often rendered in near incomprehensible fashion.
Benefiting from its charismatic and emotionally complex central figure, Jeremiah Tower: The Last Magnificent proves compelling enough to appeal beyond its target foodie demographic.

Although imparting an important message ... The Penguin Counters is too rambling and diffuse to have significant impact while lacking the accessible qualities that would make it appeal to younger audiences.
Achieves its goal of shining a spotlight on its subject while delivering a fascinating true-life tale.
Flower is redeemed only by Zoey Deutch's magnetic performance, which would be star-making if in the service of a better vehicle.
Anyone capable of explaining the near-incomprehensible storyline deserves a prize of some sort.
Movingly chronicles its subjects' emotional travails and the societal and family pressures they face.
Keating fails to effectively transmit his love of pushing the horror genre to new heights, with the result that we feel less gleefully complicit than merely voyeuristic.
A documentary so affecting and effective it will make viewers feel grateful they are healthy enough to see it in a theater.
A riveting combination of political commentary and true crime story.
The problem is that, as anyone who has spent time with junkies knows, they're not a terribly interesting lot.
An undeniably steamy effort that delivers plenty of heat in its profusion of sex scenes while falling significantly short in dramatic terms.
A coming-of-age tale is infused with complicated emotional and sociological dynamics in award-winning writer David Bezmozgis' adaptation of his book Natasha and Other Stories.
[An] intensely visceral documentary which shows just how far some fringe segments of the population are willing to go to stand up for their beliefs.
Danger Close provides a vivid portrait of combat and its emotional and physical aftermath.
Never proves compelling.
Thumper fails to overcome its numerous clichés.
The film mostly feels like a slow-paced slog featuring a hokey, melodramatic ending.

There's certainly a good film to be made about Srila Prabhupada and the spiritual movement he founded that became an international sensation starting in the mid-1960s. But John Griesser's documentary isn't it.
movie_title: Hare Krishna! The Mantra, The Movement And The Swami Who Started It All (2017)

movie_review_blurb: By the time Can't Stop Won't Stop: A Bad Boy Story reaches its conclusion, viewers will know that the rapper/businessman wears Calvin Klein boxer briefs. And that a room in his home is devoted entirely to candy.
movie_title: Can't Stop, Won't Stop: A Bad Boy Story (2017)

movie_review_blurb: An inferior effort that fails to do justice to both its central character and provocative premise.

[It] certainly doesn't neglect its religious themes. But it mainly stresses the humanity of its characters and the importance of community ties. It does this in a manner that is never heavy-handed, making the true-life tale all the more inspiring.

... the ensemble does an excellent job of adjusting their performances for the cameras, with the young male leads delivering sensitive, well-modulated turns that keep us fully involved in their characters' fates.
You can practically feel yourself getting smarter while watching Keir Burrows' brainy feature debut.
Diffuse and rambling, the documentary offers plenty of fascinating historical tidbits but lacks the breadth and depth to do justice to its complicated narrative.
The material feels very talky and stagy, which is only accentuated by the fact that the film essentially takes place in one room.

Winning doesn't break any new ground when it comes to sports documentaries, with its whole proving lesser than the sum of its parts. But sports fans will still find much to enjoy when they encounter this documentary...
Proves so exploitative that its end credits' dedication to the victims and first responders feels tawdry.
For most viewers inclined to check out a film about the subject, it will be hard not to cry.
Other than mostly eschewing the found-footage style in which one can easily see it going, Brent Cavallaro's horror film leaves no clichéd stone unturned.
Stronger on style than substance.
A character study of an endlessly flawed human being, Easy Living thankfully avoids heavy moralizing or platitudinous bromides and it even makes familiar situations ... seem fresh.
In addition to its unconvincing, cliché-ridden storyline, Alina takes itself too seriously.
Although boasting impressive visual sheen, Ryde proves by-the-numbers horror.
Despite Anna Schafer's gripping performance in the lead role, this deeply personal effort is too narratively sluggish to sustain attention.
Its hammering home of the religious angle in the final segment feels more than a little heavy-handed.
Don't Sleep practically begs audiences to defy its ill-chosen title.
It's the sort of self-regarding, preachy documentary that should be sold in health food stores, not shown in theaters.
The controversy over vaccinations will rage on and this cinematic portrait will merely be a footnote. But it proves a compelling one, however you may feel about the burning issue.

Although it never quite lives up to the satirical possibilities of its high-concept premise, Unleashed delivers some mildly enjoyable laughs thanks to its engaging female lead and the exuberantly physical performances of her co-stars.
The film should prove catnip to music lovers, especially blues fans.
The scientists' joy as they discuss the mission proves infectious.
Pilgrimage alternates long stretches of tedium with ultra-violent sequences that have the feel of medieval torture porn.

In Pursuit of Silence doesn't really tell you much that you didn't already instinctively know - silence is good, loud noise is bad - but it does provide a sporadically interesting overview that could well have you rethinking your next vacation plans.

Chronicling the years-long efforts of a mother to strengthen the legal rights of victims of domestic violence, Home Truth is a harrowing and deeply moving portrait of a woman determined not to let her children's deaths be in vain.
This is a low-budget horror film so generic you'll forget everything about it, including its title, just hours after watching it.
Something that both Nicolas Cage and Faye Dunaway will want to leave off their filmographies, and at this point that's saying something.
Mali Blues should appeal both to world music fans and anyone interested in the increasing tensions between secular and religious forces in Africa.
Although it never manages to transcend its genre conventions, Dark Harvest... effectively holds its own against the similar B-movie exercises commonly seen on late-night cable.
A perfectly serviceable Western featuring a comfortingly familiar storyline, Hickok will tide genre fans over until more substantial offerings come along.
Gives grandparents a bad name.
This vehicle is one of seven - count 'em, seven - movies that Seagal made last year, and anyone still ponying up to see them has to be considered a sucker.
Long before the movie's over you'll be as much in love with its subjects as they obviously are with each other.
Battle Scars is neither sensitive nor gripping enough to be taken seriously.
So formulaic and unoriginal that its poster should accompany the dictionary definition of derivative ...
The film, although fascinating, is also slightly boring.
movie_title: That Most Important Thing: Love (L'important c'est d'aimer) (1975)

movie_review_blurb: While Imperfections lives up to its name with its too clever by half plotline and failure to find a coherent tone, the indie film features enough enjoyable moments to overcome its flaws.

Wolf Warrior 2 is even bigger and bolder than its predecessor, which doesn't always work in its favor. But genre fans will definitely relish the near constant barrage of elaborate set pieces that are choreographed and filmed for maximum impact.

Wylie's spunky heroine proves engaging enough to compensate for the rickety storyline, with viewers likely to end up cheering her character on as she proves herself far cleverer than the men trying to take advantage of her.
A film which clearly and desperately aspires for cult status, 68 Kill will undoubtedly have its fans, but they won't be people you'll want to have over for dinner.
The film wastes several talented performers with its low-key, rambling humor and one-dimensional characters.

Resembling a Philip Roth novel that the author had the good sense to leave unpublished, Chronically Metropolitan leaves no cliché unturned in its depiction of the social and romantic travails of a group of Upper East Side New Yorkers.
Quietly shattering.
movie_title: This Time Tomorrow (Mañana a esta hora) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Despite some undeniably powerful moments, Bronx Gothic, both the show and the film, suffers from an overall pretension.
As amusing and sometimes painfully awkward as attending your own high school reunion, All American High Revisited is a vivid reminder of both how much things change and how they remain the same.
Banderas proves more than capable of playing the sort of strong, silent type who resorts to vigilante justice.

It's all as ridiculous as it sounds, with only the occasional attempts at dark humor providing saving graces. Genre fans, at least, should be satiated by the copious amount of gore and viscera on display.
Milla Jovovich delivers an over-the-top peformance in this melodramatic tale of an immigrant con artist and her juvenile delinquent son.
Motherland doesn't fully succeed on any of its levels. But Doris Yeung's subtle and intelligent debut feature contains enough interesting elements to mark the filmmaker as someone to watch.
This self-indulgent documentary about the family dynamics among the children of a Holocaust survivor could have used a more ruthless editor.
Like many parties, this film about a gay bachelor party during Provincetown's Bear Week goes on for too long.
Cogent doc makes the persuasive argument for the role that U.S. military and corporate interests have played in the influx of immigration from Latin American countries.
There's no escaping the fact that the sheer profusion of similarly-themed efforts in recent years reduces their individual impact.
movie_title: Escape Fire: The Fight to Rescue American Healthcare (2012)

movie_review_blurb: This cliche-ridden coming of age story is as painfully awkward as its troubled teen protagonist.
movie_title: Someday This Pain Will Be Useful to You (2012)

movie_review_blurb: A first-rate cast and stunning black-and-white visuals aren't enough to make this homage to classic film noir successful.
Internet chat rooms provide the dubious hook for this generic slasher movie.
Minor curio about Rick Springfield's devoted fan base has less weight than a VH1 Behind the Music special.
Filmmaker Ross McElee continues his obsessive self-reflection in this entertaining meditation on aging and memory.
Kate Clere McIntyre and Saraswati Clere's less than revelatory documentary that incessantly makes the point that yoga is really, really good for you.
This documentary about the rising state of anti-Semitism is more polemical than informative.
This found-footage horror film about the search for Sasquatch is the latest tired entry in an overworked genre.
movie_title: Big Foot: The Lost Coast Tapes (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Silent Hill is not a place you want to go, and that applies for moviegoers as well as this videogame adaptation's characters.
Bradley Rust Gray's attempt to weave horror elements into a fairly conventional narrative yields diminishing returns in this overly stylized effort.
Forget Christmas, this risible early holiday release won't make it until Thanksgiving.
Both provocative and self-indulgent.
An already silly premise is given a ham-fisted treatment in this ill-advised remake of John Milius' 1984 hit action film.
This assemblage of star-filled shorts makes for a generally rewarding grab bag.
This inspirational drama, while trafficking in cliches, manages not to deliver its message too heavily.
This religious-themed drama about a small-town mayor's personal crusade against "the war on Christmas" is about as subtle as the character's name -- Bob Revere.
A divorced couple rehash their relationship in this touching indie drama.
A basic monster movie that benefits greatly from its unique setting, Chernobyl Diaries again demonstrates Oren Peli's ability to wrest scares with minimal production values and a clever premise.
This historical drama about the little-known Cristero War in 1920s Mexico is more educational than involving.
The film's 104 minutes ambitiously packs in a huge amount of evocative imagery that well conveys the diversity of life on the planet.
Don't look for Elvis in this stark musical doc set in a maximum security prison.
The large ensemble deliver mainly endearing performances and the tech elements are solid despite the obvious budget.
Although it's doubtful that film fans walk around lamenting the dearth of Israeli characters in gangster movies, For the Love of Money nonetheless attempts to fill the gap.
Even such potentially amusing comic set-pieces as when Madea goes through airport security, with predictably chaotic results, feel awfully half-hearted.
Shamelessly schmaltzy and predictable from first moment to last, Rob Reiner's The Magic of Belle Isle nonetheless manages to conjure a certain spell.
China Heavyweight is an uneasy mixture of familiar sports doc tropes and sociological portraiture.
Haunting documentary about the descendants of top Nazi leaders struggling to endure their horrific legacy.
Hard-hitting sports doc examines the darker side of the recruitment of young baseball players in the Dominican Republic for the major leagues.
This umpteenth variation on Schnitzler's classic play La Ronde fails to arouse.
This psychologically tinged thriller about a mysterious female assassin won't erase memories of La Femma Nikita.
A talented cast is wasted in this sub-par, umpteenth variation on The Dirty Dozen.
Ultra-gory horror comedy squanders its intriguing premise of crime-stopping vigilante zombies with its uneven execution.
This Jewish-themed horror film demonstrates that the Anti-Defamation League is never around when you need them.
This Chinese period thriller set in 1930's Shanghai boasts a fiendishly clever plot and gorgeous production elements.
A well-meaning but pedestrian documentary that deals with gut-wrenching subject matter.
Endless video-game-style, violent mayhem is on display in this latest edition of the mind-numbing apocalypse series.
[A] powerful documentary about the devastating effects of head injuries in sports.
Irish villagers rally to the aid of a stranded Colombian pilot in this quirky comedy.
This deeply humanistic, profoundly touching work representing independent cinema at its finest should be seen by far wider audiences.
This alternately amusing and heartbreaking documentary coherently chronicles the endles process of rebuilding Ground Zero.
This sequel to 2009's The Collector features enough gratuitous carnage to satisfy hardcore horror fans, if few others.
Lushly photographed and featuring a stellar performance by the luminous Emily Mortimer in the title role, Hisako Matsui's film is deeply heartfelt but only intermittently compelling.
Sara Rue delivers a charming and funny turn in this otherwise hopelessly formulaic rom-com.
Despite its familiar genre trappings, this nastily efficient horror film delivers genuine chills.
This portrait of an indomitable figure overcoming his handicap proves deeply inspirational.
movie_title: You Don't Need Feet to Dance (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Despite its visual polish and fine ensemble, this British police drama is strictly by-the-numbers.
This taut and effective thriller produces maximum suspense with a minimum of means.
This heavy-handed melodrama represents one of Tyler Perry's weakest efforts ever, and that's saying something.
Although Andre Gregory's fans will find much here to savor, this rambling and unfocused portrait smacks of self-indulgence.
movie_title: André Gregory: Before and After Dinner (2013)

movie_review_blurb: This dark comedy's clever premise is too thin to sustain its feature-length running time.
Despite its admittedly intriguing parts, the film ultimately feels too diffuse and self-indulgent to represent a truly incisive portrait of its subject.
This would-be cult item runs out of steam after its establishes its wickedly satirical premise.
This turgid and pretentious thriller is all style, no substance.
Less sensationalist than its similarly themed predecessors, this informative documentary makes a strong case for the benefits of organic famring.
Spoofing movies ranging from Black Swan to Mama to Paranormal Activity, this installment of the profitable series is woefully, painfully unfunny.
This moving but sketchy documentary fails to explore its provocative issues in fully satisfying fashion.
Although it eventually descends into silliness, this creepily atmospheric effort delivers some effective scares along the way.
This darkly comic horror tale strains too hard for both laughs and shocks.
Niels Arestrup delivers an award-caliber turn as a malevolent patriarch in this gripping melodrama.
This mesmerizing revenge thriller is filled with surprising plot twists and generous doses of mordant humor.
This painfully unfunny assemblage of would-be comedy sketches manages to make Movie 43 look good in retrospect.
Despite its undeniably clever conceit and visuals, this love story set in twin worlds remains earthbound.
This loving portrait of the angst-ridden comedian should well lift his profile.
It all quickly proves wearisome, despite the occasional visual glories provided by shots of the magnificent icy vistas and frolicking polar bears.
movie_title: The Other Side of the Ice (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Superbly choreographed and filmed action sequences enliven this ultra-violent B-movie.
This unimaginative remake of Silent Night, Deadly Night continues the trend of mediocre remakes of '80s era horror films.
Religious mumbo-jumbo, turgid storytelling and lackluster animation drag down this anime fantasy.

Notwithstanding its slavish adherence to familiar genre conventions, the film nonetheless makes for reasonably fun viewing, thanks to its off-kilter humor and the chemistry exhibited by Scheweighofer and Kekilli.
This romantic drama about a couple in crisis mixes relationship and religious issues to uneven effect.
Beautifully observed characterizations and fine performances enliven this sometimes static drama about an unexpected family reunion.
Anchoring the film as much as his character does his family, Burns displays such an affable screen presence that one is able to overlook the film's hoarier aspects.
Connie Stevens' directorial debut blends family drama with psychological thriller to ultimately uneven effect.
This latest in a long line of Occupy Wall Street-minded documentaries suffers from its strident tone and scattershot approach.
A moving if sometimes overly exhaustive examination of the mystery behind the 1990 car bombing of environmental activists.
In-your-face 3D and a half-hearted attempt at psychological complexity add little to this umpteenth Texas Chainsaw Massacre movie.
This parody of Paranormal Activity and other found-footage horror films too often substitutes raunch for wit.
An awesome array of talent doesn't prevent this witlessly profane anthology of comic shorts from being an utter disaster.
Some decent scares are provided in this refreshingly low-key ghost story.
movie_title: The Haunting in Connecticut 2: Ghosts of Georgia (2013)

movie_review_blurb: This affectionate documentary doesn't do full justice to its important subject.
This restrained exercise in torture porn benefits from its clever concept and restrained execution.
This richly entertaining documentary relates the history of the ubiquitous song that has been covered by everyone from Lena Horne to Elvis.
Creepy atmospherics don't compensate for the lack of genuine scares in this unimpressive follow-up.
This forceful documentary deals with the hot button issue of climate change in powerfully compelling fashion.
This uplifting rock doc will provide inspiration to countless karoake singers.
This low-budget Alien knock-off set in a London self-storage facility inspires more claustrophobia than chills.
Meandering and affected, this tedious character study is as aimless as the lives it depicts.
First Position overcomes its predictable elements thanks to the inherent visual drama of watching children strain their bodies to the limit in obsessive pursuit of their goals.
Sensitively wrought family drama told from the children's perspective.
Both overstuffed and undernourished.
Amateurish doctors-in-training comedy/drama too blatantly reveals its television inspirations.
The Rite becomes more ludicrous as it goes along, with more than a few lines of dialogue from Michael Petroni's over-the-top screenplay eliciting unintended titters.
As modern updates of classic Jane Austen novels go, From Prada to Nada is no Clueless.
Innocent young college girl moves in with psycho roommate. You know the rest.
Faux documentary about the legendary comedian squanders the rich potential of its subject.
The search for a "female Viagra" is the subject of this entertaining, eye-opening documentary.
Rough hewn neo-realist drama from India has its sociological fascinations.
This lame WWE produced family comedy isn't likely to turn wrestling star Paul "Triple H" Levesque into a household name.
This lame sex comedy doesn't exactly add much to the debate over illegal immigrants.
Despite its lapse into melodrama, this faith-based drama is surprisingly effective.
This entertaining portrait of the legendary exploitation filmmaker is probably more fun than actually watching his films.
movie_title: Herschell Gordon Lewis: The Godfather of Gore (2010)

movie_review_blurb: This touching if insular drama about a woman grieving over the recent death of her aunt is well acted and incisively observed, although it's ultimately too low-key to have much dramatic impact.
Effective atmospherics don't rescue this formulaic slasher flick.
For all its aesthetic deficiencies and self-promotional aspects, it at least provides a valuable and important message.
This painfully unfunny comedy set in the theater world is no All About Eve.
Tyler Perry's signature character returns to kick more butt in this raucous comedy.
This fascinating sequel provides a surprisingly upbeat prognosis on the transition to electric vehicles.
[Sam Shepard] delivers a beautifully understated, world-weary turn that largely makes up for the slow-paced film's longueurs, and which in a better film could be described as iconic.
Christopher B. Landon's sordid anthology film never quite achieves the balance of melodrama and dark comedy for which it's aiming.
Disturbing, cautionary documentary that will make you rethink the products with which you surround yourself.

Running almost two hours, its increasingly convoluted narrative may be too difficult to follow for younger viewers. But its thematic ambition and dazzling visual style ultimately make it one of the more rewarding anime efforts to reach these shores.
As freewheeling and irreverent as the man himself, Saint Misbehavin' is that rare documentary whose flaws seem appropriate for its subject matter.
movie_title: Saint Misbehavin': The Wavy Gravy Movie (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Robert Rodriguez returns to the grindhouse with this entertainingly over-the-top, ultraviolent exploitationer.
The Transporter Refueled is running on cheap gas.
Want to experience the worst sort of theater without the bother or expense of heading to New York?
Essentially the first feature-length YouTube video.
State-of-the-art 3D effects add a welcome dose of visual freshness to the fourth installment of this video game-based franchise.
Familiar adoption drama is enhanced by complex characters and credible situations.
An earnest effort that too often betrays its good intentions with an overly heavy hand.
Vitally important historical documentary finally sees the light of day.
The devil made them do it, but that doesn't mean you have to see it.
It's hard not to wish that it had taken a few more chances and explored its certainly relevant themes a little more deeply.
By-the-numbers horror flick is about as welcome, and entertaining, as a real chain letter.
Simply watching the movie makes you feel practically lazy.

Destined to become a perennial for film buffs everywhere, the explicitly titled Cameraman: The Life and Work of Jack Cardiff pays well deserved tribute to the legendary cinematographer who also became a respected director in his own right.
movie_title: Cameraman: The Life And Work Of Jack Cardiff (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Thematically ambitious but poorly executed sci-fi tale.
Technically accomplished in its fake video-verite style but artistically bankrupt.
It's unfortunate that the creators killed off their villain so early in the series, since Mandylor's Hoffman is an exceedingly bland stand-in.
Familiar show-business satire is enlivened by genuinely witty, off-kilter humor.
The shaky narrative style and broad characterizations undo its effectiveness, though the climactic concert sequence... will possess an undeniable fascination for wide-ranging music connoisseurs.
This portrait of the famed indie rock composer-musician is for fans only.
movie_title: Strange Powers: Stephin Merritt And The Magnetic Fields (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Delivering the cinematic equivalent of a lump of coal in a Christmas stocking, The Nutcracker in 3D is an apparent Scrooge-like attempt by Russian filmmaker Andrei Konchalovsky to forever ruin children's associations with the classic Yuletide ballet.
It's your money that's at greater stake with this subpar horror entry in barely noticeable 3D.
Kate Hudson dies prettily in this tone-deaf dramedy about a woman finding love while suffering from colon cancer.
Harrowing depiction of the American educational system features a superb performance by Adrien Brody.
Put a stake in this film noir monster movie, it's done.
Janet Evanovich's best-selling Stephanie Plum series deserved better than this woefully executed, stillborn attempt at a franchise.
Where's Madea when you need her?
Eddie Murphy should have just said the word "No" to this tired, formulaic comedy.
A bland romantic comedy in the Richard Curtis style, The Decoy Bride is mainly notable for its proof, if any was needed after Boardwalk Empire, that Kelly Macdonald is a major talent.
[An] earnest, faith-based drama, which lacks sufficient entertainment value to make its message go down more palatably.
Impressionistic documentary about the temporary Parisian home of the Beat writers fails to justify its full-length running time.
This toothless shark thriller lacks B-movie fun.
Benasra obviously has an affinity for her subject. But her alternately lighthearted and pseudo-serious approach here ultimately proves more wearisome than illuminating.
Heavy-handed teen drama mixes moralizing and partying to uneven effect.
This ATM-set horror film fails to dispense sufficient thrills.
This cautionary documentary makes a strong case that our technological advances are in fact dooming us.
Witty one-liners compensate for cliched plotting and cheesy effects in this sci-fi action thriller.
This tawdry, faith-based kidnapping melodrama has a lot to atone for.
movie_title: Woman Thou Art Loosed: On the 7th Day (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Documentary about young children learning the horrors of the Holocaust feels like an elaborate study aid.
The film may be hopelessly old-fashioned, but it's hard to entirely resist its portrait of a city that not only never sleeps but also seems to be bursting with melody at every turn.
A young acting hopeful finds that things are tough in Tinseltown in this not exactly revelatory gay-themed drama.
