Chris Colfer's Glee appeal is AWOL in this strained dark comedy about a high school misfit.
Good performances and atmospheric direction aren't quite enough to elevate this home-invasion thriller above genre clichés.
Depictions of custody battles have become a cinematic staple, but few register with the heartfelt emotion of Any Day Now.
Like his unlucky-in-love characters, prolific filmmaker Eric Schaeffer keeps trying, to little avail.
More aggressively violent and thankfully less mythology-driven than previous installments, Underworld: Awakening is strictly for the converted.
This documentary about a private citizen's journey into space plays like the most expensive home movie ever made.
movie_title: Richard Garriott: Man on a Mission (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Relentlessly unpleasant and nihilistic in its approach and execution.
Go For It! never manages to conjure an iota of the joyful exuberance that enlivens even the most formulaic dance films.
Fascinating documentary about the reclusive author and her sole literary masterpiece.
movie_title: Hey, Boo: Harper Lee and 'To Kill a Mockingbird' (2011)

movie_review_blurb: This Dutch melodrama compels despite its formulaic elements.
TV reality show-style doc offers superficial portraits of amour.

Ultimately, the film is best appreciated as a welcome big-screen starring vehicle for Fischer, who expertly navigates the comedic and dramatic demands of a role that keeps her onscreen for virtually the entire running time.
The backstory behind the film is as compelling as the events it depicts.
This space-set, "found footage" horror flick never lifts off.
About as funny as the typical scribbling on a public bathroom stall.
movie_title: Bucky Larson: Born to Be a Star (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Uniquely personal look at one of the 20th century's most important spy figures.
movie_title: The Man Nobody Knew: In Search of My Father, CIA Spymaster William Colby (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Filmmaker Alex Gibney dissects an infamous sports incident in fascinating and wildly entertaining detail.
Featuring a tedious procession of statistics, graphs and talking heads, American Teacher undercuts the forcefulness of its arguments with its underwhelming presentation.
Whatever gothic originality the first Human Centipede possessed is altogether lacking in this sorry follow-up.
A surprisingly effective debut effort from writer-director Robert Kirbyson.

Although not exactly breaking any new ground with its by now all too familiar found-footage format, Paranormal Activity 3 hews to the formula in expertly crafted fashion, mustering up the requisite scares and then some.

There's one thing to be said about WWE Studios -- they're consistent. Every one of their movies designed to showcase their stable of popular wrestling stars has been a critical and commercial disaster.
What could have been a typically didactic message film instead resonates with thoughtful humanity.
The script lacks the depth to transcend its cutesy gimmick and -- as with the misleading horoscopes that fuel the plot -- the film never approaches a five star level.
Engaging doc mixes passionate environmental arguments with a warm biographical portrait.
movie_title: Force of Nature: The David Suzuki Movie (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Harrowing documentary details the traumas of combat journalism.
Astute show business satire packs a darkly comic punch.

The performances are effective all around with director Kendrick quite moving in the central role of Adam, the veteran officer, who suffers a horrific family tragedy that sets much of the film's plot in motion.
Despite its spiritual subject matter, this documentary doesn't dig very deep.
movie_title: One Track Heart: The Story of Krishna Das (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Better than its premise would suggest, the film works to the degree that it does thanks to the well-drawn characterizations and the frequent doses of sly, subtle humor.
This otherwise generic '80s-style actioner benefits from the presence of the ever-colorful Mickey Rourke as an exotic villian.

Rodrigo Reyes' documentary... is at times too elliptical for its own good, but it delivers a haunting portrait that stands in marked contrast to the incendiary arguments usually attendant to its subject matter.
movie_title: Purgatorio: A Journey Into the Heart of the Border (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Despite the impressively committed performances by the two leads and the screenplay's touches of sly humor, the proceedings are mostly all too redolent of the endless found-footage horror films that have followed in the wake of The Blair Witch Project
Filled with declamatory speeches, stereotypical characters and heavily telegraphed, melodramatic plot developments, the film fails to work as either thriller or politically themed drama.
Fine performances compensate for the overwrought elements of this rural-set drama.
This essentially two-character romantic comedy has its charms, mainly supplied by the engaging lead performances of Joel David Moore and Madeline Zima.

A fascinating little-known historical tale is stirringly recounted in Roberta Grossman's documentary about Jewish-American fighter pilots who volunteered to fight for Israel in its 1948 War of Independence.
There's a compelling documentary to be made about the best-selling boy band of all time, but Backstreet Boys: Show 'Em What You're Made Of isn't it.
movie_title: Backstreet Boys: Show 'Em What You're Made Of (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Love Hunter is consistently engaging, mainly thanks to its star's winning personality.
Erotic thrillers are a time-tested genre, but this effort, scripted by Wesley Strick, is neither erotic nor thrilling.

More thematically ambitious and less saccharine than the usual big screen nature docs that constitute the primary fare at museum venues, the film is educational enough to please adults while providing the "wow" factor necessary to impress youngsters.
Boy Meets Girl is a funny and touching comedy/drama boasting a superlative debut performance by Michelle Hendley.
Kiah Roache-Turner's zombie movie set in the Australian outback displays enough gonzo elements to please genre fans, with its resemblance to the Mad Max series clearly not coincidental.
The Worst Year of My Life wears its influences a little too obviously on its sleeve but it overcomes its ultra-low budget limitations with enough cleverness to make the filmmaker someone to watch.
movie_title: The Worst Year Of My Life (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Director Trevor Matthews stages the violent mayhem with admirable profiency, and the film's target audience is bound to come away reasonably satisfied, if not fully satiated.
Digging Up the Marrow is a playfully self-reflexive exercise whose endless in-jokes will best be appreciated by only the most ardent genre aficionados.
Tracers seems destined to disappear from theaters quickly without leaving much of a trace.
[Director Joe Lynch] stages the action cleanly and kinetically. And Hayek delivers a fully committed performance, handling the role's intense physical demands with commanding authority.
The film squanders whatever potential it had, not to mention the talents of such performers as Duplass and Wilde who clearly deserve better.
The end results are too diffuse to have the desired impact, with the result that Allure ultimately has the feel of an experiment that doesn't quite pay off.

Despite Chalfant's typically stellar work as a flinty, dying matriarch of a highly dysfunctional Irish-Catholic family, Michael Patrick Kelly's clumsily executed, low-budget feature is an unfortunate misfire.
It's rare in today's era of overstuffed nonfiction films that a documentary leaves you wanting more. But that's the case with Mary Dore's cheekily titled She's Beautiful When She's Angry.
Veteran actor William Sadler delivers a superb performance in this thoughtful if overly soapy drama set in the world of academia.
The two stars display a winning chemistry in this amusingly observant study of female friendship.

Despite its gimmicky provenance, Hollidaysburg proves to be a nicely low-key, unassuming coming-of-age tale about a group of former high school friends reuniting in their Pennsylvania small town during Thanksgiving college break.
The Rapture won't come soon enough for the unfortunate souls forced to suffer through Left Behind.
The film is ultimately so generic and formulaic that you'll probably forget it by the time you get home.
Essentially a chase movie infused with buddy comedy elements, the film is a fast-paced, mildly entertaining lark that's chiefly enlivened by Cusack's droll performance.
Much like the recent, widely reviled I, Frankenstein, this misconceived project mainly signals a need to go back to the drawing board.
The film unfortunately depicts black female sexuality, a topic rarely portrayed onscreen, with all the depth and subtlety of a late night Cinemax offering.
A visually stunning effort that makes up for its formulaic storyline with an enchanting atmosphere that sweeps you into its fantastical world, or in this case, three worlds.

The resulting domestic tension is rife with darkly comedic and dramatic possibilities that were better exploited on the printed page, where King was able to more fully delineate his heroine's tortured thought process.
Less scary than landing in jail while playing Monopoly.
Comedian Adam Carolla mines his own career experiences to amusing effect in his semi-autobiographical dark comedy about an embittered stand-up comic.
Bereft of interesting characters, clever dialogue and any semblance of humor or visual coherence, Exists offers nothing to justify its cinematic existence.

Thankfully devoid of the cutesy anthropomorphizing that afflicts so many Disney nature documentaries, Pelican Dreams will give you a new appreciation for these creatures sometimes referred to as "flying dinosaurs."

A good portion of the cinema verite proceedings, ranging from endless glimpses of her domestic life to footage of her performing an original song in a Greenwich Village cabaret, prove less than arresting.
[A] dysfunctional family holiday comedy that squanders the talents of its impressive cast who presumably signed on merely to work with the comedy legend.

Director-screenwriter Hopkins is unsuccessful in navigating the absurd storyline's jarring tonal shifts, with the result that this kinder, gentler variation on Ms. 45 mainly emerges as off-puttingly bizarre.
The plot, of course, is merely an excuse for an endless series of gags, and the percentage of them that score is fairly high.

The degeneration into familiar genre tropes reduces the impact of the wittily satirical set-up, with the result that Starry Eyes fails to live up to its initial promise. But the film indicates genuine talent on the part of its directors/screenwriters.
Even if it doesn't convince us they're likely to conquer death before it comes for them, the film does prompt interesting debates about just how desirable an unlimited stay on Planet Earth would be.
This simultaneously heartbreaking and joyful doc provides a fitting capstone to an extraordinary musical career.
Nothing in the proceedings is remotely convincing, let alone entertaining.
Complete with a charismatic hero and touching love story at its core, The Invisible Front vividly succeeds in bringing this little-known historical saga to light.
Henry & Me is a heartwarming tale that should prove irresistible to young baseball fans.

The world's population can safely be divided into two camps: those eager to see a movie called Zombeavers and, well, everyone else. The former may well find themselves satisfied by Jordan Rubin's feature debut.
The Hand That Feeds is an impassioned socially themed documentary that may even succeed in swaying a few hearts and minds.
Mala Mala depicts its subjects with an uncommon degree of empathy and understanding, not to mention glamor.
The clever premise eventually loses steam as the convoluted plot unfolds... But there are still plenty of laughs along the way.
Hit man thrillers are a dime a dozen, but director Dru Brown's Aussie variation on the familiar genre takes some seriously clever, nasty turns.
Safelight squanders the efforts of a talented cast who are unable to lift the material beyond its clichés.
The "Last of the Red Hot Mamas" has lapsed into showbiz obscurity, something that William Gazecki's loving documentary clearly hopes to correct.
As generic as its title, Jack Heller's monster-in-the-woods horror film aspires to be the stuff of nightmares but instead merely lulls the viewer into an untroubled sleep.
Throughout Famous Nathan there are enough scenes of customers gleefully wolfing down juicy frankfurters to convert even the most staunchly vegetarian viewer.
Alex R. Johnson's Texas-set neo-noir... begins slowly and surely before ratcheting up the tension to terrific effect.
With subject matter so esoteric that an onscreen glossary is provided, Sneakerheadz will leave you shaking your head even as the showcased colorful footwear inevitably induces sneaker envy.

While it's admirable that director Macneill and his co-scripter Clay McLeod Chapman opted to emphasize mood and psychology over the story's more exploitable elements, it nonetheless results in a listless tedium.
That she nonetheless emerges as all too relatable is a credit to Moondi's astute screenplay and the nerve-rattling performance by its lead performer, here making an auspicious acting debut.
[A] sluggish post-Civil War drama directed and co-written by Kane Senes that wears its shopworn ideas too heavily on its sleeve.

[Manis says] the number one goal for couples should be to achieve "oneness" and "intimacy." The latter word is invoked time and time again, and... most viewers should assume that their relationship is sorely lacking it.
Showcasing juicy performances by its actors who tear into their stock roles with admirable conviction, the film looks terrific.

While there's something to be admired in the film's economy and tightly controlled atmospheric tension, its effectiveness is limited by the derivative storyline, mostly unmodulated performances and the obviously miniscule budget.
This supernaturally tinged comedic thriller is far more wickedly clever than most comparable Hollywood offerings.
This zeitgeist-tapping revenge fantasy doesn't deliver enough guilty pleasures.
An overwrought family melodrama involving that hoariest of clichés, the reading of a will.
It's not so much the plot or themes of the film that's the problem as the ham-fisted execution.
The late Ernest Borgnine receives a moving send-off in his final film, The Man Who Shook the Hand of Vicente Fernandez.
movie_title: The Man Who Shook the Hand of Vicente Fernandez (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Ted's Boston-accented zingers are expertly delivered by the director/star, whose voice talent is undeniable, and Wahlberg again demonstrates that he's skilled at comedy ... Seyfried proves adept as well ...
Despite its impressive formalistic rigor, the film fails to connect on an emotional level, with even the tragic ending failing to move us as it should.
It will be interesting to see what the filmmaker achieves in the future if provided with greater financial resources.
Neither the dramatic nor action elements are remotely compelling.
Desert Dancer too often lapses into generic cinematic clichés, failing to live up to the dramatic potential of its subject matter.
Caryn Waechter's debut feature is instead a piercing portrait of adolescent rebellion and alienation.
[A] weirdly baroque modern-day Western that, while it boasts undeniably imaginative visual and plot flourishes, is far too absurd to take seriously.
An effective modern day noir.
Much like the rusty jalopy in which the characters make their journey, Finding Fanny delivers a very bumpy ride.
James tries hard, very hard, to inject the proceedings with slapstick humor, propelling his large body through endless physical contortions in a fruitless effort for laughs.
A serious misfire.

While it might have made for a mildly diverting stage thriller -- the hugely successful Deathtrap, for instance, was built on similarly absurd contrivances -- the endlessly talky 3 Holes and a Smoking Gun founders onscreen.

Concentrating on two disparate figures seeking their fortunes, Earth's Golden Playground squanders the dramatic potential of its exotic locale and subject matter with a soporific style that all too readily suggests the drudgery attendant to the process.

Teddy Chen's combination police procedural and kick-ass action film provides a sturdy vehicle for longtime Hong Kong star Donnie Yen, who at age 51 proves he's still in good enough shape to deliver all the right moves.

What might have made for a fascinating segment on a television newsmagazine program is here stretched out to a numbing 110 minutes, filled with enough facts and statistics to make one wonder whether a pop quiz will be forthcoming.
movie_title: Primum Non Nocere -- First Do No Harm (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Suffused with an air of dread thanks to director of photography Rob Hardy's atmospheric, dark-hued lensing, the film nonetheless never achieves the necessary dramatic tension.
As passionate about its subject as the actor was about driving, Winning: The Racing Life of Paul Newman provides a fascinating footnote to his distinguished cinematic career.
movie_title: Winning: The Racing Life Of Paul Newman (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Sunset Edge has a visually poetic quality that goes a long way towards compensating for its opaquely nonlinear, barely there narrative.
[Its] admirable intentions don't make up for its muddled execution.
Displaying considerable stylistic finesse if not narrative coherence.
Although suffused with welcome touches of sly humor, the proceedings never gather the necessary dramatic momentum.
Provocative and hard-hitting, Every Last Child is a chilling reminder that even diseases once thought eradicated are still capable of rearing their ugly heads as a result of ignorance and prejudice.
Even without the cloud of the recent disturbing developments, United Passions is a cringeworthy, self-aggrandizing affair that mainly benefits from its unintentional camp value.
If there was ever a man lucky enough to have found his true calling in life, it's the subject of Dave LaMattina and Chad N. Walker's affecting documentary.
movie_title: I Am Big Bird: The Caroll Spinney Story (2015)

movie_review_blurb: [Pegi Vail's] documentary about the effects of global tourism... should be mandatory viewing for anyone who's ever thumbed through a Lonely Planet guidebook with an eye toward visiting an exotic destination.
An entertaining doc vividly chronicles a troubled era.
This is a Canadian film even Rob Ford would be embarrassed to watch.
This breezily entertaining and informative documentary deserves attention.
This haunting cinematic collage puts a human face on the country's strife-wracked history.
It's a reasonably entertaining portrait of disreputable Tinseltown types that should at least provide some knowing chuckles for insiders.
Despite appealing performances and glossy production values, this faith-based drama has the feel of a lengthy church sermon.
movie_title: I'm In Love With A Church Girl (2013)

movie_review_blurb: This deeply moving documentary will melt the heart of anyone who sees it.
This intimate documentary presents a human face on the corrosive effects of war.
The generically titled Standing Up registers as a mildly inspiring if familiar tale of adolescents standing up to bullying.
This compelling, eco-themed documentary will be of vital interest to anyone who loves acoustic guitars.
This uplifting documentary delivers a compelling human interest story from a still traumatized Rwanda.
While not as comprehensive or objective as one would hope, this vivid documentary will prove fascinating to history buffs.
This sensitively observed humanistic drama features deeply moving performances by Naomi Watts and Matt Dillon.

A quietly effective thriller with a few clever narrative tricks up its sleeve, Tony Glazer's debut feature overcomes its low-budget limitations with clever variations on its familiar genre as well as a taut execution and strong performances.
Casually charming road trip doc about aspiring screenwriters desperate to meet their show biz idol.
This harrowing true-life tale provokes maximum outrage.
The prolific multi-hyphenate media mogul has pumped out an endless array of movies in recent years, but his latest effort ranks as one of his very worst.
This movingly understated drama benefits from strong performances and incisive characterizations.
Suffers from its overly insular and hagiographic perspective, but in its best moments it well illustrates the reasons for her musical influence and social importance.
movie_title: Mercedes Sosa: The Voice of Latin America (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Mainly notable for the fact that its titular character, as played by Aaron Eckhart, is really, really ripped. If People magazine had existed in the 19th century, he surely would have been feted as the sexiest undead man alive.
Van Damme makes for a highly entertaining villain in this briskly paced B-movie.
Although at times resembling a promotional video, this documentary provides a vivid illustration of Afghanistan's changing social dynamics.
This slight but entertaining documentary scores laughs along with its sociological points.
This blandly formulaic romantic comedy doesn't deliver on its titular promise.
This improbably fascinating documentary will be manna from heaven to pop culture devotees.
This subtly engrossing psychological thriller plays like an intellectual version of Fatal Attraction, minus the sex and the dead bunny. And that's meant as a compliment.
Lacking the objectivity or contextual analysis to more fully examine the important issues it raises, it's a minor chapter in an unfinished story.
Notable for its dark atmospherics and strong performance by Liam Neeson in the latest example of his unlikely late career transformation into an action hero.
Despite its claustrophobic setting and small-scale concerns, this low-key drama proves unexpectedly diverting.
This real-life show-biz tale makes for fascinating viewing.
movie_title: Évocateur: The Morton Downey Jr. Movie (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Uneven comedy/drama tackles hot button issues like gay marriage and immigration.
This horror sequel delivers the explicitly bloody mayhem genre fans crave.
This alternately harrowing and inspirational doc puts a human face on the fight for gay rights in Uganda.
A quietly elegant chamber piece that, at 77 minutes, is careful not to wear out its welcome.
Lacks the sustained emotional power of many of the similarly themed Holocaust documentaries that have preceded it.
A fine cast is wasted in this lurid, grindhouse-style effort that strains for both laughs and shocks.
Using real-life surveillance footage and interviews with several of the gang's members themselves, this eerily timely true-crime documentary fascinates.
movie_title: Smash & Grab: The Story of the Pink Panthers (2013)

movie_review_blurb: This emotional documentary succeeds in putting a human face on this growing health issue.
This feel-good sports doc brings a little-known story to compelling life.
Marin Ireland and Paul Sparks deliver terrific performances in this charmingly quirky love story.
A complex story is compellingly told in this powerful 9/11 documentary.
movie_title: Out of the Clear Blue Sky (2013)

movie_review_blurb: It's all utterly silly and derivative but also undeniably entertaining.
Hot rod fans will race to this sports bio-drama drenched in period authenticity.
This deeply moving but thankfully unsentimental doc is both inspiring and depressing.
Unfortunately, this tale of an illicit romance between an unhappily married woman and a younger man traffics in far too many genre clichés, beginning with its idyllic locale.
Although suffering from cheesy historical reenactments, this inspirational Holocaust-themed documentary recount a story that deserves to be more widely known.
This visually stunning, thematically complex documentary will stir up a wide range of reactions.
Creepy atmospherics enliven this idiosyncratic chiller.
This ambitious teen-oriented fantasy is like taking a university philosophy course in The Twilight Zone.
This haunting and dreamlike cinematic essay is filmmaking at its most personal.
Squanders the talents of its talented cast and is bound to test the patience of more discriminating audiences.
Despite the essentially formulaic nature of the proceedings, the film does boast some nasty twists that prove galvanizing.
This static, talky effort ultimately doesn't justify its feature-length running time despite some strong performances and the occasional moving moment.
Five Dances should well impress dance aficionados even if its skimpy narrative proves less than inspired.
Director Overbay, working from an effective screenplay by his wife Ginny Lee Overbay, slowly ratchets up the tension in quietly compelling fashion.
The Purge: Anarchy efficiently exploits its high-concept premise while delivering far more visceral thrills than its predecessor.
Persecuted squanders the talents of its impressive cast -- including James Remar, Bruce Davison, Fred Dalton Thompson and Dean Stockwell -- with its bizarre premise and inept execution.
Kevin Asch's sophomore feature attempts to tackle weighty themes but ultimately feels as shallow as the lives of most of its principal characters.
This formulaic sex farce is rescued by sharp comedic performances.
Let's not and say we did.
Theaters showing Septic Man should be required to issue hazmat suits at the door.
[Comes] across as the sort of standard police procedural that might serve as the pilot for a television series.

While its provocative themes certainly bear exploring in our sex-obsessed societal landscape, The Olivia Experiment is too superficial and cliche-ridden to make them resonate, and its attempts at humor fall thuddingly flat.
This uplifting documentary offers a rare ray of hope in its portrait of an urban school that's defying the odds.
This one certainly doesn't go unpunished, at least for the audience.
This is strictly for the New Age crowd only.
Creepy atmospherics aren't enough to compensate for the muddled storyline.
The feature-length film ultimately becomes repetitive, with the lack of contextual information about the subjects' lives rendering the proceedings shallow.
Although more than a little meandering and self-indulgent, the film is likeable nonetheless due to its incisive characterizations and canny capturing of true-life moments.

Livia De Paolis's too cutely titled debut feature wears its themes a little too baldly on its sleeve, but this modest effort about a non-nuclear family dealing with various interpersonal crises boasts some genuinely effective, understated moments.
Iglesias is a likeable presence, and his fluid delivery, complete with spot-on accents and sound effects, is consistently engaging.
Playing like a very special slasher film-themed episode of Glee, Stage Fright mixes horror and Broadway-style show tunes to decidedly mixed results.
While this version lacks the subtlety of the original, it delivers enough raunchy humor to be far more entertaining.
[Home, James] is modest in its aspirations and execution, but it delivers an affecting portrait of a relationship threatened to be torn apart by conflicting goals.
John Cusack delivers a deliciously deadpan performance in this uneven and self-consciously quirky dark comedy.
Costner effortlessly blends deadpan comic flair with action movie heroics in this preposterous but entertaining genre mashup.
This beautifully acted, admirably understated drama never succumbs to mawkishness.
This clinical documentary will be of interest only to serious students of acting.

[Director Andrew Douglas] is only partially successful at depicting its many twists and turns in convincing fashion. But it's compelling nonetheless, if only for the sheer bizarreness of the events depicted.
This Portland-set tale pungently captures its arty hipster milieu.
Raymond De Felitta's terrifically entertaining film benefits from a smart screenplay and superb performances.
Despite the affecting performances by the two leads, this overly muted drama fails to make much of an impact.
This is a club that you don't want to join.
Zach Donohue's debut feature ingeniously uses only computer images to tell its tale.
This entertaining and enlightening doc also serves as a highly effective cinematic personal ad.
A horror franchise isn't born.
There's life yet in the found-footage horror genre.
Close encounters of the mediocre kind.
This heartwarming doc illustrates the power of dance to bring people together.
Desert Riders nonetheless serves as a bracing cautionary tale.
Director Doug Aarniokoski and co-screenwriter David Loughery fail to infuse the overly familiar elements with the necessary dark humor.
Banks delivers an amusing slapstick turn in this otherwise strained, formulaic comedy.
The title's definitely an exaggeration; this isn't a great 'Game,' but it's a pretty good one.
A perfectly acceptable elongated episode of a television series projected onto a screen several sizes too large for it...more pretender than real contender.
This grotesquely manipulative bit of whimsy is like sucking on a sugar cube for ninety minutes when each of your teeth is suffering from an exposed nerve.
Though slightly better than most smiles-and-tears chick flicks...it will work better as a DVD double-feature with 'Beaches' six months down the road.
Homely but enjoyable...if you might not want to join this 'League' permanently, you should find it a pleasant crew to spend ninety minutes with.
The light it sheds on the subject is at best a flickering one.
Ostentatiously and unremittingly tasteless. Unfortunately, in this case at least, that does not equate with hilarious...You can't wait for the movie to end.
For the first hour or so generates some heat, but at about the halfway point it fumbles badly and never recovers. Neither wins, places nor shows.
A raucous mess, constructed and edited with such crazed intricacy and shot with such extravagant flamboyance that it's actually physically painful to look at after awhile.
Shows plenty of visual imagination but is totally devoid of charm, wit or emotional resonance.
Goes soft and mushy in personal terms even as it ratchets up the violence and decibel level.
None of it seems remotely real. Elizabethtown may be an actual place, but 'Elizabethtown' seems like nowhere on earth, because Crowe's script is so disjointed and tone-deaf.
It's rather refreshing to encounter an almost quaintly retro thriller that depends more on tension and suggestion than on gross-out effects.
Transcendentally silly fun...sure to enchant toddlers, great-grandparents and everybody in between.
movie_title: Wallace & Gromit: The Curse of the Were-Rabbit (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Beneath the flashy surface it doesn't have a shred of intelligence, and it sinks in a sea of lame writing and laughable performances.
Perhaps it's only just that a movie about a loser should be a loser itself.
The old 'Bachelor Father' formula is resurrected with a killer dose of whimsy in this pointedly quirky, almost unbearably dilatory feature.
Comes across like a Lifetime movie with attitude--and a much better cast than that network's usual list of TV has-beens.
There's no known antidote for a movie as poisonously bad as Venom.
Almost laughably mournful...would be substandard even for broadcast on a basic cable outlet.
Serves a useful public service; more important, it's an engrossing film in its own right.
There's a glibness to the treatment that smacks more of sophomoric black comedy than sharp satire, but the cinematic verve is hard to resist.
Though the 'religious' overtones are a new touch, ends up seeming like one of those amusingly cheesy semi-supernatural thrillers broadcast as 'originals' on the SciFi Network.
At once a mystery so intricate that the multiple climaxes generate snickers and a slasher picture too subdued to satisfy the thirst of that genre's audience for blood.
A thoughtful, intelligent film about brilliant but troubled people...works on both an intellectual and an emotional level.
Makes the medley of genres and moods a rich blend, at once profound and hilarious, serious and absurd--it's a masterful film that's masterful in a strange, deceptive way.
Another visually witty stop-motion animation piece that mingles the gleefully macabre and the sweetly sentimental...a winningly lively treat.
So preposterous that you not only have to put your brain on hold but remove it from your skull, toss it to the floor and stomp it into insensibility.
Not good enough.
Decleir's performance alone would be reason enough to see it, but the clever script and nifty execution are added attractions.
movie_title: De zaak Alzheimer (The Memory of a Killer) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Cinematic cotton candy, but it goes down easily, even if there's not a lot of nourishment in it.
Like a Classics Comic Book adaptation of the story--tasteful, subdued and just a bit dull.
The only thing 'HellBent' proves is that in a slasher movie, homosexual victims can be as dumb as heterosexual ones. This is progress?
The sincerity and earnestness of 'Innocent Voices' are beyond doubt. It's a pity that the film's execution doesn't always match them. Still, it's a mostly laudable effort.
The title's oddly appropriate, since in an era of animation giants, this movie is small potatoes. Or in keeping with the theme, chicken feed.
Just call it 'Aliens for Dummies'--dark, murky, loud, gory and incredibly dull.
A lovely and refined meditation on modern romance rather than the Hollywood sitcom version, and all the better for it.
May not break new ground, but thanks to some sharp writing and ingratiating performances, it farms the old fields quite productively.
This movie may make a bunch of money, but it's D.O.A.
There are a few genuinely amusing moments...but most of 'Zathura' is either shrill or flat.
The same old story about finding Mr. Right, but shows that if your take on the familiar tale is sufficiently deft, it can be as fresh and enchanting as Austen's book itself.
This silly, sleazy stiff is a train-wreck of a movie.
One can admire the struggle of the Naumanns somehow to talk to God, but it would be nice if they said something intelligible to us in the process.
Though you'll probably leave the theatre swinging to the music, this highly conventional movie really doesn't do its subject justice.
While [it] doesn't come close to matching the magic of its predecessor...it's slick and exciting enough to satisfy the fans of the series.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (2005)

movie_review_blurb: A succession of frantic, and frequently brutal, slapstick episodes...raucous but largely mirthless.
At once so bland and so frantic that it's almost unendurable...will no one save us from this plague of alternately messy and mawkish comedies about oversized families?
The fact that it provides one with an opportunity to bask in Falk's almost uninterrupted glow for ninety minutes doesn't make it a good movie.
You needn't be a fan of rock and roll to be both amused and moved by this documentary...a winningly bittersweet little film.
Smart rather than smart-alecky, it captures the gleefully cynical tone of its models while adding a strain of grim humor that never degenerates into campy spoof.
There's certainly a time and a place for Rent, but on the evidence of this film, it's not in 2005 or on the screen.
Despite the obvious opportunities to turn this subject into a strident polemic, it follows an entirely different route--one that in the end carries considerably more impact.
Despite its good intentions and some very strong acting, 'North Country' proves a frustratingly unsatisfying destination.
While beautifully crafted from a purely visual standpoint, the film remains structurally chaotic and emotionally remote.
Just a run-of-the-mill homage to motherhood lifted from the ordinary only by Moore's natural radiance, and in the end that's not quite enough.
movie_title: The Prize Winner of Defiance, Ohio (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Pure corn--and though Gatins and his cast serve it up as slickly as one could ask, it still comes across as more than a little stale.
movie_title: Dreamer: Inspired by a True Story (2005)

movie_review_blurb: As is the case with Capote's book, the film's mixture of fact and artistry carries, in a strangely subdued, allusive way, enormous power.
A woozy, pretentious would-be thriller that aims to be mind-bending but instead is patience-trying.
You'll find it hard to keep the proverbial stiff upper lip when the overheated melodrama on the screen is prompting you to laugh out loud.
If you're in the mood for a comedy in which the bitter definitely exceeds the sweet, you'll find a good deal to admire and enjoy here.
Zorro doesn't get a chance to sword-swipe his initial into opponents' clothes very often this time around, but when he does, it should be an 'M' for 'Mediocre.'
Not a dish for the faint of heart, perhaps, but for those with a taste for cruelty with a side order of irony and a dash of gore, it will be a perversely delicious treat.
Despite its title, 'Prime' doesn't earn terribly high grades.
With 'Saw II,' to misquote Sherlock Holmes, the game's a-flat...Despite the makers' almost desperate efforts to shock and surprise, proves a curiously dull blade.
A literate, sharply observed film that juggles tragic and comedic elements to achieve a wonderfully distinctive tone.
While superficially engaging, ends up in retrospect seeming a very thin, and surprisingly ramshackle, contrivance.
All affectation and no affect...by the end the smug artificiality of it all has become well-nigh intolerable.
No-budget no-brainer...but West shows signs of real talent, even if he doesn't have the resources needed to put it to best use.
A stylish exercise with some agreeably weird touches, but as a whole it substitutes atmosphere for coherence or credibility.
Like a series of acting exercises...by the close it comes to seem a bit thin, promising more than it actually delivers.
A stylish, absorbing account of an episode in American journalistic history that has as much to teach us today as it did Murrow's audience half a century ago.
Like swimming in sewage for an hour an a half--which may be the intention, but is still neither a terribly pleasurable or edifying experience.
The exotic setting and the starkness with which the young man's story is told--along with Nusuppaev's muted charisma--help it transcend the narrative commonplaces.
Despite a tendency to ramble and some uncomfortable shifts of tone, overall the picture generates a quiet humor and warmth that are quite appealing.
Not so much a terrible movie as an unnecessary one...a sense of redundancy plagues the movie.
A movie that's sweet without being sugary and quirky without being insufferable.
movie_title: Me and You and Everyone We Know (2005)

movie_review_blurb: An uneven film that's nevertheless genuinely disturbing.
A pretty good little flick--gritty, well-acted, and, up to the too-cute finale, mostly worth working to suspend disbelief over.
Doesn't even have the idiotic charm one might expect of a 'Plan 10 from Outer Space'...a home movie that ought to have stayed there.
Van Sant hasn't found a means of deepening the premise he initially establishes, and his film bores and irritates rather than entrancing us as its predecessors did.
Can't be classified as a good movie, but if you have a taste for this sort of thing and a strong stomach to go along with it, this could be the dish for you.
A good film that might have been a great one.
An unholy combination of 'Dr. Strangelove' and '2001' that manages to trash both those Kubrick masterpieces at once.
By today's whiz-bang standards, may seem a tad tame and old-fashioned, but it's a harmless trifle whose easy-going, undemanding tone should appeal to younger viewers.
A poignant, powerful valedictory from one of the true masters of cinema.
Crass and obnoxious where the show was affable and even rather sweet-natured.
Treats of serious matters, but in a delightfully quirky and curiously affecting way.
In the end one joke isn't quite enough...a little of it goes a long way.
If you love this movie, you're figuratively obeying the title's injunction.
A typical example of Bay's excess...sleek but utterly bombastic and silly.
The surface smoothness can't make up for the deeper flaws...fails signally in establishing any solid emotional connection with most of the people it portrays.
Visualized with imagination and artistry...strives for a magical quality it doesn't always achieve, but the attempt succeeds often enough to make the tour one you should take.
As familiar as it is, 'Rebound' could well have been titled 'Replay,' but although it's just a formula flick, it's not an awful one. Too bad that's not saying much.
With this picture and 'Magadascar,' the penguins are enjoying a banner cinematic summer...most viewers will find it enthralling.
Skillfully done...but the broader historical context may make one just a tad queasy reveling in its visual and emotional excesses.
movie_title: Balzac and the Little Chinese Seamstress (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Doesn't manage to get much beneath the surface of its provocative topic, but Gordon-Levitt compensates considerably by digging deep into the soul of his character.
Even the lights of Paris seem unusually dim in this limp, lackadaisical farce.
Made on so frayed a shoestring that it looks like a Dogma project minus the glitz and about as vacuous as its array of clueless twenty-something characters.
The level of coincidence driving the narrative is as high as the Big Apple's tallest skyscrapers, but the cast is stong enough to help transcend the structural weaknesses.
Exuberant, colorful, viscerally exciting but overly flashy and sadly disorganized.
Both crushingly pretentious and oddly silly--rather like the cinematic equivalent of Jack Handey's 'Deep Thoughts,' but without the saving grace of intentional humor.
The script's shifts of tone are never smoothly melded, and the lethargic pacing drags the story out mercilessly.
Could have been dumb fun...unfortunately, the filmmakers succeed in getting only the dumb part right, omitting the fun entirely.
This 'Water' may be agreeably dark, but it turns out that it's disappointingly shallow, too.
While the first ninety minutes or so are sporadically amusing, if hardly classic, the sag of the last thirty leaves one anxious for it all to end.

You can safely await its appearance on the small screen in your home.
Basically amounts to an intricate but empty cinematic shell-game...less intriguing than irritating.
An agreeable, though rather stunt-like feel-good piece that most audiences will be able to identify with.
Pushes itself as strenuously as its young protagonist, but ultimately collapses in a welter of sentiment, cuteness and whimsy.
Like reading a book from which most of the connective chapters have been removed, backwards.
Just about the quality of a busted WB Network pilot, 'Undiscovered' certainly deserves to remain that way.
While 2046 looks absolutely radiant, its deliberately choppy structure and mannered style make it very heavy going...like watching a brilliant paint job dry in a storm.
A tedious movie about very unpleasant people.
Exhibits a lot of energy and visual pizzazz, but ultimately it's all empty style without substance, and its characters are a repulsive lot.
Even in a season of bad action movies, this one marks a new low...doesn't go beyond the level of the most puerile 1940s serial.
In this second lap the brainless busyness and gaudy excess amount to utter overkill...nothing more than pointless speed and empty action.
This oddball mixture of bloodsucking horror and soft-core porn is both objectively terrible and perversely fascinating.
Not only preserves the book's flaws but has added to them...the combination of drama and soap box proves an uneasy, and ultimately unsuccessful, one.
A black comedy told in the garish colors of Almodovar...well worth a look.
movie_title: The Perfect Crime (El Crimen Perfecto)(Crimen ferpecto) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: A searing indictment of the tragedy that occurs when good men choose to do nothing, and a portrait of a man who deserves respect for having tried to confront evil head-on.
movie_title: Shake Hands with the Devil: The Journey of Romeo Dallaire (2005)

movie_review_blurb: A lack of real satirical bite is incongruously accompanied by a smug sense of self-importance in this shrill but toothless movie.
One dull and anonymous movie...less like 'Midnight Run' or '48 Hrs.' than 'Pure Luck.'
A curious melange of elements...ultimately the disparate parts war against the whole.
This anti-Close Encounters is a spectacular technical exercise, but in the final analysis it's as loud and soulless a piece of equipment as the aliens' Tripod Death Stars.

This latest exercise in claustrophobic mayhem is hole-y awful.

Succeeds as both a homage to its quirky model and as an engrossing film in its own right.
movie_title: De Battre mon Coeur s'est Arrêté (The Beat That My Heart Skipped) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: An artfully simple, quietly perceptive movie...one of the most honest, revealing portraits of familial love and friction to hit the screen in years.
A movie that exceeds your lowest expectations--it's not only coarse and raunchy but utterly unfunny.

A film that's at once beautiful, horrifying, tragic, uplifting, grimly humorous and unutterably sad, and it's among Herzog's very best.
Utter hooey...more likely to leave you shaking with laughter than with fright.
Painfully slow and earnest, more like a museum exhibit than a motion picture.
A movie that wants to be daring but winds up feeling prefabricated.
Pretty much a stunt, and not an entirely successful one...on balance the nuggets are embedded in just too much dross.
A thoroughly laughable underdog-takes-the-gold saga...supercross this pathetic slice of hokum from your viewing list.

Doomed by its script to a sort of tedious mediocrity, this pigeon's as dead as a dodo.

While the film looks authentic in every insignificant detail, it never seems remotely real from an emotional standpoint.

movie_title: Wild Safari: A South African Adventure (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Unlike the Antarctic ice shell, there's not much here beneath the surface. The only message it carries is that for certain people, music can be a potent aphrodisiac.
Isn't much more than a high-toned soap opera, but it's a relatively sophisticated and occasionally affecting one.

Remains, thirty years later, as rambling, flaccid, enigmatically brooding and ultimately tedious as it was back in 1975.

Finely controlled...a docu-drama of seriousness and integrity.

Not only consistently engrossing but genuinely engaging, if technically conventional....Bravo!

It's a joy to see Kirk Douglas on screen again. That's not quite enough to make this...recommendable, but it's a reason you might want to take a look at it despite the flaws.

Like cinematic cotton candy, the picture is pleasant enough in the viewing but ultimately pretty wispy and ephemeral.
movie_title: The Promise (Master of Crimson Armor) (Wu ji) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: As a summer time-waster that provides an empty adrenaline rush, M:I 3 will do. But it doesn't represent an advance on the first installments, and it does go on.

An interesting misfire that unfortunately flames out well before the inevitable final shoot-out.

By the final whistle you end up feeling as battered by the banalities as some of the on-screen players are by the nasty hits they endure on the field.
movie_title: Goal! The Dream Begins (Goal!: The Impossible Dream) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: A really dumb, derivative rip-off, slovenly constructed and played with the sort of ludicrous earnestness that just misses being bad enough to qualify as high camp.
A bold and imaginative piece of filmmaking that also happens to be delightfully droll...a grand, goofy entertainment in the true Sterne mold.
movie_title: Tristram Shandy: A Cock & Bull Story (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Told without sentiment or an excess of didacticism, the story of redemption among the urban underclass carries considerable power but never becomes a truly searing experience.
The sort of cloying, sentimental heart-tugger that would be more at home on network television than the big screen.
movie_title: Marilyn Hotchkiss Ballroom Dancing & Charm School (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Slight, deadpan, mild and understated, but enjoyable in a quiet, almost throwaway fashion.
Another tale of an unusual program to help disadvantaged school kids turned into a formulaic, sappily uplifting Hollywood product.
Little more than a clever puzzle: though the pieces ultimately fit together, when fully revealed the picture proves less than meets the eye.
Enjoyable but thin, an exercise in style in which the appearance almost compensates for the lack of substance--but not quite.
Pretty terrible--a movie fashioned for the arrested development set (not those addicted to the fondly-remembered TV series, but those suffering from the psychological malady).
Reminiscent of a hand-me-down Shepard play, recycling ideas that he's treated far more effectively in the past.
Isn't merely difficult to swallow, but none too tasty going down.
A prefabricated crowd-pleaser with a distinctly by-the-numbers feel, distinguished only by Ejiofor's canny transvestite turn.

Marginally preferable to its immediate predecessor (mostly because it seems slightly less crass--or am I becoming inured?), but it's nothing to write home about.
On a clear day, to misquote the old Broadway tune, you can see the cliches.

One of those movies that starts out seeming very silly and grows more and more preposterous as it lurches along....Be on guard against it.
A simple-minded cartoon that aims for low-brow laughs rather than going for the jugular.
Despite the fact that the meal served is kosher, the recipe is so hammy that the movie proves pretty indigestible.

Light, amusingly macabre, droll, looking and sounding freshly minted...a marvelous holiday treat with luscious tricks up its sleeve.
Well-meaning and decently put together, and it has occasional moments of charm...[but] more than a trifle stale.
A movie made by yahoos for yahoos...the cinematic equivalent of a body-slam in which the viewer is on the receiving end.
A pleasant little comedy with the soul of one of those old, much loved Ealing pictures of the forties and fifties but overlayed with a coating of Hollywood glitz.
Does its spoofing with a blunt instrument instead of a scalpel, and it's engineered to appeal to the lowest instincts of its targeted adolescent audiences.
Waking the Dead is D.O.A., and none of its manifest good intentions are capable of resuscitating it.

A rather stunted and sliggish exercise in style whose sporadically haunting visual quality doesn't make up for its shallowness and ponderous pace.
Nasty, sadistic, ugly and pointless.
Often wondrous to behold and enormously exciting (and, amazingly, even occasionally moving), but also way too long and at times exhaustingly elaborate.
A well-structured and literate yarn that employs the classic qualities of older films with a simplicity and sincerity that makes them fresh again.
movie_title: The Three Burials of Melquiades Estrada (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Yet another of those dysfunctional-family-at-the-holidays movies that aim to elicit smiles of recognition but are more likely to make you wince in pain.
This story of suppressed passion is, irrespective of gender considerations, a deeply moving, indeed lacerating, film.

One's left with the gnawing suspicion that while it's a decent adaptation that should satisfy fans of the books, it really belongs on the Hallmark Channel.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, The Witch and The Wardrobe (2005)

movie_review_blurb: I guess you had to be there.
movie_title: I'm the One That I Want (2000)

movie_review_blurb: Like the rusted old subs deployed in the story, the picture seems designed to stay in the safe shallows and not to plumb any real dramatic depths.
Lacks the pizzazz of energetic pulp, but doesn't replace it with any compensatory insight or power.
It might have been a blast. As it is, it's more like a damp squib.
Flashy but incredibly dull...a real catastrophe, the cinematic equivalent of a tsunami.
Admirably serious but untidy, excessively schematic and more than slightly self-important...its higher ambition is enough to make it mildly recommendable.
Exhibits little passion and even less mind.
The In Crowd isn't a movie--it's a J. Crew catalogue. Junk mail, junk movie.
Despite a ton of good intentions, the picture is numbingly obvious and crushingly sentimental.
The 2005 Joe Wright version is superb.
Though employing an utterly conventional romantic design, it tweaks the formula sufficiently...to come across as charmingly distinctive rather than tiredly imitative.
Despite the occasional miscalculation and disappointing last half-hour, an estimable piece of work.
Like its lead character, eventually becomes so aggravating that it long overstays its welcome.
This astonishingly bad tearjerker, a Fannie Hurst weepie with a gay twist, is as phony as a three-dollar bill and just about as entertaining.
A putrid mess...simultaneously vulgar and boring.
An odd mingling of the old and the no-longer-quite-so-new, a picture that shows flashes of wit but as a whole doesn't hang together.
Has such a powerful subject...that it can hardly fail to make an emotional impact.
While almost aggressively French in tone and style, nonetheless an affecting, if fragile and flawed, meditation on the realities of romance and aging.
The big Baker clan goes for a vacation at a Wisconsin lake, and we get drowned in a sea of slapstick and schmaltz...but it's actually an improvement on its predecessor.
It may be the holidays, but Carrey and his cohorts offer precious little cheer here...The first movie of this title...wasn't much fun, and this updating is even less so.
For all its craftsmanship, the film never cuts to the bone...may not leave one cold, but at most it leaves you lukewarm; and in a tale like this one, that's just not enough.
A good-looking picture that should especially satisfy upper-middlebrow adult audiences--a high-toned crowd-pleaser, if you will.
Though the movie isn't the 'Holiday' from hell, it's not one you should be anxious to go off on.
It's round two of the battle between vampires and werewolves. I won't reveal who wins, but the audience certainly loses.
The political thrust of the premise is defanged, and the movie becomes a toothless vehicle for Brooks's drowsy-eyed shtick.
movie_title: Looking for Comedy in the Muslim World (2006)

movie_review_blurb: A good, respectable piece of underwater filmmaking, but not an especially innovative or entrancing one.
A string of cliches...As the plot plays out it not only follows formula but italicizes every element of it.
A delightful surprise, visually witty and almost unfailingly charming, perhaps the best film of its kind since 'Babe.' This should become a family perennial.
Joins a line of distinguished thrillers...that are more than just thrillers, and proves their equal.
A picture that belies its ostensibly prosaic feel to give a touch of offbeat poetry to these deceptively humdrum lives.
The picture just sets up its unimaginative premise and then coasts along through a chain of forced, mostly unfunny episodes to a thoroughly predictable conclusion.
Probably isn't as enthralling as its makers hoped, but interesting enough to make for good, informative family entertainment.
There's a cinematic tradition that movies taking their titles from pop songs turn out to be bombs. 'Imagine Me & You' upholds it.
Completely artificial...a flimsy, flabby picture in which the romantic chemistry is forced, the script does nothing unexpected and the direction is slack.
An excruciating bore, a hopeless hodgepodge of the hoariest imaginable horror movie cliches...When this 'Stranger' calls, just hang up.
'Air Force One' without the presidency or the plane...the formula feels awfully tired, the plausibility quotient is ludicrously low, and Ford seems a bit long in the tooth.
Ferrell proves he can be almost as annoying when unseen and merely heard, making it impossible even to enjoy 'Curious George' as the cinematic equivalent of a fluffy pillow.
It's not bad enough to leave you feeling had, but unlikely to make you plan a return visit, either.
Instead of the perfectly calibrated Sellers-Edwards routines we get hit-and-(mostly)-miss slapstick from Martin and Levy and jokes about flatulence and Viagra.
A few sizes too small for the story it wants to tell...a picture that leaves no cliche unturned in its journey to a foreordained conclusion.
Not only incessantly talky, but talky in that arch, affected fashion that not only sets one's teeth on edge but induces deep drowsiness as well.
So bad that it persuades you that the show's record-setting Tony victories in 2001 were absolute confirmation of the demise of the Broadway musical, not its rebirth.
So pedestrian that it almost makes one regret Rob Reiner's decision not to run for governor of California.
While the movie is certainly unsettling, and even repulsive in parts, it's not actually frightening; graphic depictions of mindless cruelty are more revolting than scary.
Pure blarney, but it's well-meaning blarney, told by a master cinematic storyteller and boasting an eye-catching lead performance.
The problem isn't that it's tasteless--because it's not--but that it's flaccidly paced, overly predictable and burdened with Knoxville's stiff, charmless performance.
Pretty much a mess--a woozy, sometimes inspired but mostly infuriating piece far more interested in conveying mood than information.
While not as awful as some of Allen's flubs, this film is one of those instances in which the cinematic ball doesn't quite make it over the net.
The film's triumph is that it's ultimately much more than a stunt--despite occasional missteps, it's mostly a sweet, penetrating, funny and intensely human story.

May not manage a clean cinematic thrust, but Brosnan puts on a fine, flamboyant show to keep the crowd entertained.
A movie of fits and starts, sharpness and stumbles. And it comes up short in the end.
A high-minded, elegantly-mounted and starrily-cast but dramatically inert and emotionally desiccated snoozer.
Skillfully made...but basically this is a movie that traffics in sadism as much as its villains do, and your reaction to it will pretty much depend on how you feel about that.
A brain-dead piece of slacker swill, worse than the worst Sandler, Schneider or Spade movie ever made.
An astronomically awful movie; the only question is whether it's worse than Uwe Boll's last atrocity 'Alone in the Dark,' and you might say it wins by Ben Kingsley's nose.
A tepid, tinny modernist recasting of the epic romance...something like a WB Network twentysomething soap opera in medieval dress.
Nothing more than a zombie movie, but it's a first-class zombie movie, good, ghoulish fun, staged with skill and a nicely twisted sense of humor.
Basically preaching to the choir, of course. But that doesn't mean that the sermon isn't one that needs to be heard.
One time too many around the track...a mishmash of slapstick, action, romance, domestic comedy and feel-good feminist fantasy.
One has to suspend disbelief to an almost incredible degree to swallow any of this movie.
A cerebral comedy that's too anxious to demonstrate how clever and erudite it is to bother creating...a narrative that's more than an affected faux-philosophical puzzle.
While its apparent effort to be both a critique and a reverential homage leaves lingering doubts, what's unquestionable is the high quality of the filmmaking on display.
A precocious and imaginative work--though also a fairly impenetrable one.
A serious, often very moving portrait of the effect the Vietnam War had on the nation and particularly those who served in it.
movie_title: Going Upriver: The Long War of John Kerry (2004)

movie_review_blurb: A competently-made treatment, though it does grow a bit repetitious over the long haul and doesn't end with the sort of rousing triumph the filmmaker seems to have hoped for.
An action comedy in which the action is negligible and the comedy nonexistent.
Typical of the sort of melodrama that's the stuff of well-meaning telefilms, but...played at too high-pitched a tone.
Though it has moments of inspiration...at best the picture is only fitfully amusing, certainly not up to the standard set by the 'South Park' movie.
A chilly, silly bit of sci-fi nonsense played so turgidly that every one of its flaws is thrown into the sharpest sort of relief.
Comes across like an earnest after-school special disfigured by off-putting fantasy elements and bloated with self-indulgent touches.
An incoherent melange of horror movie gimmicks that's genuinely laughable when it strives for profundity. It induces more tedium than terror.

Smothered by the heart-on-sleeve melodramatics of the storytelling, which seems intent on leaving no cliche unused and pounding each of them home.
A cinematic foul ball that, despite all Mac's efforts, doesn't reach the comedy playoffs.
Reduces what's bracingly biting on the page to something that's pretty but rather toothless on the screen.
A piece of visual wizardry...[but] more Rocketeer than Indiana Jones, more admirable exercise than actual fun.
movie_title: Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Such a stinker that each ticket should come with a can of Glade.
Pretty much impenetrable, but what makes it especially exhausting is a mountain of technical babble and long-winded philosophical reveries that slow everything down.
An uneasy mixture of political satire and investigative thriller, with neither element coming off very well.
An innocuous, inconsequential bit of fluff...notable for both its energetic but predictable court action and an unfortunate lack of chemistry between the leads.
A reasonably coherent story of grief and remorse. Unfortunately, the grief and remorse will be felt more by the audience than the characters.

A silly shaggy-dog story that even a slick production, canny direction and a fine cast can't rescue from absurdity...put it out of your mind.
Still one scary mother.
It may want to be, as the British might say, a bloody riot, but in fact it seems to suffer from a case of comedic anemia.

Reminds you of a political campaign: it's colorful and flashy but completely vacuous, and differs very little from its competitor.

Kind of an endurance test, like sitting through a bad touring company of 'The Jerk Who Came to Dinner.'
Not only offers useful information but contains moments of gravity and pathos that genuinely touch the heart.
Even if [it] has a slightly mustry, afterschool special message to impart...the picture delivers it with sufficient charm and complexity to escape TV-movie mediocrity.
An arch, clumsy effort...not only poorly written but ineptly staged... Mercy!
As the British might say, it's bloody awful.
movie_title: Bridget Jones: The Edge of Reason (2004)

movie_review_blurb: One scavenger hunt that's definitely not worth playing...it has more climaxes than a porno movie.

An interesting misstep...the lead performances are superb, but even they can't make up for the hard-to-swallow story.

The sort of disaster only a fanatical cult-movie buff could like.

Moderately engaging but hardly a classic.

A sprightly but shallow tale of a defiantly untraditional family...but the pleasures of the picture largely make up for the affectation.

movie_title: Anacondas: The Hunt for the Blood Orchid (2004)

movie_title: What the Bleep Do We Know!? (2004)

This movie is definitely one you should scratch from your own little list.

movie_title: Outfoxed: Rupert Murdoch's War on Journalism (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Like its protagonist, it loses altitude and crashes. Unlike him, though, it doesn't manage to get up again.

movie_title: The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy (2005)

movie_review_blurb: A dumbed-down, pumped-up takeoff on 'Seven Days in May'...basically brainless pulp--and even at that, not very well-executed pulp.

movie_title: Enron: The Smartest Guys in the Room (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Although its reach exceeds its grasp, Rodney Evans' picture deserves points for its ambition and many elements of its craftsmanship.
An almost perfect film about decidedly imperfect people...manages to be both profound and delightful.
Though this is a step up from the usual teen snuff-movie fare, it still very much wanes more than it waxes.

Sporadically amusing but more often flat...its batting average is regrettably low.

movie_title: The Other Side of the Street (2004)

movie_review_blurb: While parts of 'Up and Down' are effective, as a whole it doesn't measure up to its laudable ambition...the last word of the title proves more accurate than the first.
movie_title: Up and Down (Horem Pádem) (Loop the Loop) (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Made without much finesse and tends to lumber rather than soar, but still possesses a sweetness that's rather disarming.
Visually very impressive but cliched and predictable...just another clone of 'Metropolis' that falls far short of its inspiration.
As ludicrously complex and silly as any of Brian De Palma's worst thrillers...suffers from an excess of filmmaking brawn and a lack of brains.

movie_title: The Boys and Girl from County Clare (2004)

movie_review_blurb: This is, at best, a distinctly low-grade 'Fever.' If not a foul ball, barely earns a single.
Brainless...but it's also breathless. If the content is negligible and even puerile, the packaging is choice.
On The Ring 2.
Small but charming...It's a nice story, and it's nicely told.
movie_title: The Wild Parrots of Telegraph Hill (2005)

A mostly uncomfortable experience that doesn't carry a compensating degree of insight or impact.

Too scattershot an affair, offering surprisingly little depth in its coverage of either students or teachers.

Pedestrian...a high-minded snoozer studded with stars who all seem almost perversely miscast and directed in a grimly deliberate style designed to italicize every point.
