movie_review_blurb: Has its moments, but unlike the music Green wants his students to play, it's no classic.
Half-baked--astronomically high in cinematic calories but very low in nutritional value.
Technically magnificent but dramatically inert, it's a lumberingly predictable finale to the space saga that peaked in 1980 and has been going downhill ever since.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode III - Revenge of the Sith (2005)

movie_review_blurb: The austere, cerebral 'Dominion' is a serious and ambitious alternative to Harlin's movie, but it's only marginally superior to it.
Cool, incisive, funny but also strangely melancholy...connoisseurs of cinematic elegance should find it a brilliant jewel.
Perhaps it's appropriate that a tale about the avoidance of food should be so unappetizing, but that doesn't make it any more enjoyable to watch.
Not a great film, but the joy of watching Dench and Smith perform their charming duet for nearly two hours makes it worthwhile.
Cruz...can't rescue the film as a whole from its combination of soapoperatic melodrama and pretentious musings on life and love.
A destination you should add to your summer moviegoing itinerary...makes for an enjoyable trip.
A major summer movie fumble...it's mostly the audience that gets sacked.
One hates to dismiss the efforts of those trying to support short films nowadays, but the average in this compilation just isn't high enough to warrant a visit.
An arid and ultimately pointless exercise in style.
A wrenching experience...portrayed with a degree of honesty and intensity that transcends the hackneyed material.
A small film whose structural weaknesses are largely redeemed by its big heart.
A grossly manipulative tale of an underdog who comes out on top, but one so skillfully manufactured that it effortlessly--and pleasurably--carries you along.
The movie works so long as it stays on wheels, but turns pretty flat-footed whenever it hits the ground.
Nothing to celebrate: it's a garish, cluttered piece of plasticine whimsy that's as derivative as it is leaden.
movie_title: The Adventures of Sharkboy and Lavagirl in 3-D (2005)

movie_review_blurb: A visual feast that nonetheless leaves one feeling hungry for some emotional nourishment after the succession of all-too-similar courses has passed.
movie_title: Lemony Snicket's A Series of Unfortunate Events (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Unquestionably sincere, but it doesn't do the subject justice in either the African or the western sense of the phrase.
A ramshackle movie, jerry-built from leftover materials and...so rushed to completion that it threatens to collapse from the effort to cobble everything together.
A cross between Stand And Deliver and Hoosiers,...it's no all-star, but not a bench-warmer either.
A comedy at once pungent and charming...both amusingly cheeky and disarmingly serious--and an almost unalloyed treat.
Laughably bad...a tepid, torpid comic-book movie that could accurately be described as this year's Catwoman.
Astonishingly enough, the old chestnut is still a grabber...earning its suspense the old-fashioned way, by pacing and atmosphere rather than cheap thrills.
A film that masks its urgency and intensity with a cool, matter-of-fact approach, and is all the better for it.
Happily, the answer is eventually 'Yes.' Travels such a well-worn road that you feel you've ridden it many times over.
It has enough heart and humor to land it in the winner's circle, even if not in first place.
Its lack of sense is exceeded only by the absence of chills.
movie_title: Qui a tué Bambi? (Who Killed Bambi?) (2004)

movie_review_blurb: It may be an efficient horror exercise, but not an exercise you'll much enjoy participating in.
Terrible beyond belief, like the worst 1940s serial ever made. As for Slater and Dorff...well, they've been in worse movies--wait a minute, no they haven't.
Like a wilted bridal bouquet...a movie that arrives dead on the vine and then asks you to spend eighty minutes watching it wither.
McAvoy puts across the part with considerable skill, but unfortunately the picture as a whole, though well-intentioned and likable, is also formulaic and manipulative.
An incoherent grab-bag of disconnected shock effects--stylishly mounted but ultimately empty and pointless.
Like a big box of Valentine's chocolates that turn out to be a mite stale when you bite into them.
Though only 48 minutes long and the 3-D effects are sometimes stunning, it has substantial passages that are curiously dull...can't hold a candle to Cameron's other 'Aliens.'
Samuel Bicke might not succeed in his murderous venture, but Sean Penn makes him a memorable failure...a great performance in a film that isn't up to his standard.
A pleasurable amble down a well-worn cinematic street.
Pretty much seems a movie about poor television reception--something you can probably get for free at home.
More standard programmer than action blockbuster, a remake that may not be offensive but is basically unnecessary.
This waterlogged bit of whimsy is the cinematic equivalent of a belly-flop.
movie_title: The Life Aquatic with Steve Zissou (2004)

movie_review_blurb: The final third...transforms what had been a finely-tuned but somewhat conventional sports saga into a life-and-death tragedy of raw emotional power.
Far from being a standard-issue tearjerker...the picture rises above its generic roots to emerge as a powerful human drama.
movie_title: The Sea Inside (Mar Adentro) (The Sea Within) (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Unbelievably raunchy...an avalanche of s******ing sexual humor masquerading as a family comedy.
On the boards The Phantom of the Opera was bloated kitsch; now, thanks to Schumacher, it's hysterically bloated kitsch.
Though inoffensive, it's also flat and rather tedious...the movie isn't ready for the junkyard, but it isn't very fresh, either.
A deeply affecting film as well as an impassioned one...featuring a stunning lead performance by Don Cheadle.
Less mystifying than incoherent, inviting more giggles than shudders.
Kevin Bacon's superb performance alone is reason enough to recommend 'The Woodsman.' It's too bad that the film itself isn't as courageous as he is.
What 'Mr. Holland's Opus' might have been like had it been genetically crossed with 'The 400 Blows.' A formula piece, and a highly manipulative one, but also hard to resist.
A bowl of overcooked but bland cinematic gumbo...heavy on stars who are all wrong for their parts.
movie_title: A Love Song for Bobby Long (2004)

movie_review_blurb: A revelation, combining the colorful flash of the writer-director's previous work with a richer, deeper emotional vein than ever before.
The sentimentality is made palatable by the shrewdly low-key approach...unlikely to bowl you over, but in its quiet, unassuming way it may touch your heart.
movie_title: Postmen in the Mountains (Nashan naren nagou) (2003)

movie_review_blurb: A respectable attempt to deal with the issues the text raises in a way that minimizes the potential offensiveness without unduly diluting its power.
movie_title: William Shakespeare's The Merchant of Venice (2004)

movie_review_blurb: In contrast to Tigger and Piglet, Lumpy offers fewer incentives to take a trip to the theatre to make his acquaintance.
If you're a fan of old-style Hong Kong martial arts movies, you should find Ong-Bak a blast. And even if not, you may be surprised at how much dumb fun it is.
Though anxious--one might even say desperate--to please...more contrived than charming, neither western fish nor eastern fowl.
Though for opera buffs the result may well be fun, it's also camp with a high C....Douglas Sirk and Ross Hunter, eat your hearts out.
The attempt at understanding is the goal of history, and of art too. And the success of 'Downfall' is that it manages to be both.
A charming oddity...a gently rib-tickling, genuinely warm-hearted jewel.
This 'Ring' is strictly zircon, not diamond...plods along, trying to create a brooding atmosphere of menace but instead engendering one of boredom.
Pre-teen girls may very well enjoy 'Ice Princess,' but as I don't belong to that particular demographic, it pretty much left me cold.
Offers stunning background art but characters that are drab...with apologies to Jude Law, just call this 'Private Pipsqueak and the World of Yesterday.'
Depicts both the heartbreak and resiliency of childhood...at once heart-warming and heart-rending, though in a delicate rather than overbearing way.
Says more about aging in America...than all the sweet but false fables Hollywood has manufactured about the elderly. It's worth seeking out.
Sentimental without becoming sticky, with a cheeky undertone that helps to moderate the sweetness...those who try it will probably be dazzled by the technique.
Despite the subtitle, it's an utterly mediocre comedy that shoots blanks...maybe the CSI team can investigate how a stiff like this wound up in their town.
No classic, but Mac and Kutcher prove a surprisingly winning team, and considering today's comedies, you could do a lot worse.
Little more than a failed stunt, a would-be magic trick in which the sleight of hand is all too obvious.
Proves a case of some very good actors crossing the boundary from the region of off-beat domestic drama into the dread realm of preciousness and pretension.
Ultimately sinks under the weight of an unwieldy script and uncommunicative performances.
Rather trite and passe, not to mention overwrought and narratively chaotic...this is one 'Love' that's easy to resist.
The bad-boy equivalent of One from the Heart... the splendor of the images comes to seem pretty vacuous in the absence of any content deeper than the pulpiest pulp.
Itself seems recycled...as far as these kinds of movies go, it's mediocre--sporadically amusing but never hilarious, and curiously flat despite all the frantic motion.
A dreary dirge of a movie that's less about real human beings than characters who are little more than literary contrivances, though well acted ones.
movie_title: The Ballad of Jack and Rose (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Isn't exactly a pleasant viewing experience, but it has a passion that's difficult to ignore.
By piling coincidence upon coincidence, the picture, though quite slickly made, collapses under the weight of its accumulated cliches and improbabilities.
Has a patchwork quality that can be infuriating, but it's never bland or uninteresting, and works more often than not...clearly the work of a filmmaker of promise.
Apocalyptically awful, End of Days bad, The Order bad, Lost Souls bad. Religiously it's blasphemous, but as a movie it's just plain lousy.
Unrelievedly manic, gruesomely unfunny... a disastrous mess. It's actually physically painful to watch.
There's a place for a movie like this--but it's really on the Hallmark Hall of Fame rather than in an auditorium you have to pay to get into.
It's makers would like it to become an instant classic of the genre, but at best it's an amiable but mediocre formula flick more suitable for the home screen than a theatre.
It's nice, and occasionally affecting, but also fairly pedestrian.
Rarely has a movie been such a tonal train wreck...rather like riding a cinematic roller coaster, and it may well bring on in the viewer the same sort of nausea.
movie_title: Diary of a Mad Black Woman (2005)

movie_review_blurb: In the end the title seems to refer to the filmmakers--and the audience--rather than the characters.
Not so much terrible as mediocre, a frail and obvious bit of fluff--sort of like a feature-length version of a one-season network sitcom.
Ultra-smooth ex-gangster Chili Palmer returns to the screen after a decade's absence and the audience gets whacked...an unmitigated disaster.
A reasonably digestible slice of domestic drama--one that's good-hearted, but that doesn't give you excessive heartburn.
Lukewarm kitsch...neither powerful enough to be taken seriously nor splashily crude enough to be a guilty pleasure.
Harmless, though mediocre, live-action family fare...likely to strike even the small fry as covering awfully familiar territory.
If you want to get a feel for what American soldiers really experience while serving in Iraq, this unassuming, fly-on-the-wall documentary is the place to go.
A documentary which, though hardly perfect, is a lot better than the movie it's about.
The mixture of sitcom and soap opera that worked in 'Terms of Endearment' feels stale here, especially since the final-reel revelation is more cheat than treat.
An incisively observed, richly detailed and wonderfully unpredictable portrait of a young man's journey to maturity,...a singularly affecting movie.
Not a terrible movie...but it's awfully familiar--so much so that it probably should have been called Trudy.
Underwhelming...among kidflicks of this sort it's neither great nor terrible, just mediocre.
While it showcases some fine performers, it unfortunately has a stiflingly literary tone.
Another clumsy Jaglom vanity project that's as grating as fingernails on a blackboard.
Provides aficionados of empty-headed action with a surfeit of it. [But] this long-gestating third sequel has a lot to live up to, and unfortunately it doesn't quite manage.
The best comedy of the summer, animated or not, and perceptive parents may enjoy it even more than their offspring.
If Dahl's picture won't exactly slay you, the performances make for an oddly diverting little flick.
Williams' Reverend Frank is so obnoxious that he'd empty the pews as fast as this dreadful movie will empty theatre auditoriums.
Although one-sided, it's arguably a lot less problematic than the health system it asks viewers to cast a critical eye on and consider alternatives to. And very entertaining.
One silly, overblown movie, skillful but bombastic eye-candy for the adolescent-minded, with the cinematic I.Q. of your average household appliance.
A genuinely unsettling film about a sociopathic child...an enjoyably decorous creepshow.
After the exceptional quality of the last two installments,...a letdown. This chapter of the story feels like it's just biding time.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Supposed to be a romantic comedy, but it's neither very romantic nor particularly funny.
The movie proves even more dysfunctional than the Dwights themselves...despite the title, you'd be well advised not to make this family's acquaintance.
Quote not available.
Though there's tension between the two halves of Talk to Me, both of them are quite good.
Herzog's rigorous, unvarnished approach carries considerable power, and it affords a showcase for another remarkable performance from Bale.
Has serious problems in historical terms. But in this case they're exacerbated by the simple ineptitude of the filmmaking.
Given the pitfalls the director's achievement is considerable...makes its point without falling into the Stanley Kramer trap of becoming obvious and smugly didactic about it.
A soggy mess...To think it's any good would require a supreme act of faith.
Just a middling entry in the tidal wave of computer-animated pictures that have been engulfing theatres over the last few years.
Labored, a bit of backwoods magical realism that wants to soar but never takes off.
A documentary that both informs and entertains, and that will invite animated debate--which is precisely what a good documentary should do.
Might not be the high-school story most of us want to hear, but it's a true one, and Chalk tells it with insight, humor, and an appropriate touch of sadness.
Another slab of Sadism-Is-Us cinema from writer-director Eli Roth...It's check-out time for this series.
Varied in tone and perspective, but also variable in narrative quality. But Paris je t'aime offers at least as many hits as misses.
Captures the sheer weirdness of the tale without turning it into sleazy sensationalism...turning what's really a sordid story into a perversely fascinating romance.
Rather fussily structured and ostentatiously virtuosic, and one might wish...it had told us even more. But...it's almost worthy of its subject.
Uncomfortably straddles the line between revival and send-up...[Nancy Drew] probably should have been kept in mothballs.
Rather like a sociological document narrated in a flamboyantly rhapsodic visual style...more affected than affecting.
Wants to be charmingly off-kilter but comes across as insufferably grating.
Stretches its one-joke premise and artificial look beyond the breaking point.
Compared to the best superhero movies, the best that can be said of this flyweight effort is that it's unpretentious. But then it has a great deal to be unpretentious about.
movie_title: Fantastic Four: Rise of the Silver Surfer (2007)

movie_review_blurb: As a purely sensory experience Paprika is a spicy dish, but one that doesn't deliver much nourishment for the mind.
A retro joy, a Halloween Haunted House of a movie that delivers the sort of pleasurable shivers and jolts that today's exercises in torture porn don't even attempt.
Even worse than the movie's being torture-porn junk is the fact that it's also incredibly boring...as predictable as it is ugly and tedious.
A match made not in heaven, but in the sort of studio script conference that turns every idea into mass-market mush.
movie_title: I Now Pronounce You Chuck & Larry (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A prosaic period piece, high-minded and attractively mounted but muddled and turgid.
A lively, ebullient crowd-pleaser that replaces satiric spark with sitcom slickness, but is still good, clean fun.
Thrives on rowdiness and raunchiness and celebrates the infantilism of the male side of the species as a source of boundless humor.
A misbegotten clone whose awfulness only accentuates the varied virtues of earlier versions of this pod-people tale.
Like its characters--and unlike those in most pictures set in high school--this movie is smart.
An old-fashioned boys' adventure yarn...no great shakes as a fantasy epic...but there are far worse movies out there for young boys.
Like Burtynsky's pictures, captures images that are at once awesome, humbling, and rather terrifying.
Given its sense of quiet and penchant for harmless slapstick, a breath of fresh air in today's sea of raunchy, foul-mouthed sex comedies.
A sour, stilted, graceless misfire that can't make its mind whether to be an edgy satire of class division or a feel-good feature-length sitcom.
Comes across an awful lot like a sentimental, manipulative teleflick. The good news is that it's a fairly well-executed example of the type.
Pure B-movie hokum...a cheesy, goofy combination of family melodrama and gangster cliche that strains not only credulity but patience.
It lumbers rather than soars, feeling dry and desiccated despite all the greenery and pink skin on display.
Basically a wryly observed talkathon, the picture hits a few rough patches but is mostly a charming confection.
Even if it becomes little more than a case of preaching to the choir, it's still a pretty sound sermon.
This awful slapstick martial-arts tournament send-up is all bad ideas and worse execution.
Ocean's Seven at best...a puny heist comedy that's nowhere near as clever or amusing as it thinks it is.
Tawdry and unintentionally hilarious...so ludicrous that it's hard to suppress a guffaw while you watch it.
An attempt at dark comedy that comes off more dark than comic...strained and effortful rather than blithely lighthearted.
Bright and glitzy but ultimately ephemeral and rather silly, featherweight sleight-of-hand without much of a payoff.
A werewolf movie so bad it merits a silver bullet.
A soggy, sorry mess. In a summer that's seen a lot of terrible sequels with 3 in the title, [this is] the worst of the lot.
A sci-fi fiasco that wants to be the new 2001 but instead manages to be as silly as Armageddon and as solemnly pretentious as Solaris.
A super-sized serving of warmed-over cliches...though No Reservations may well make your mouth water, it will probably be for a good movie.
An overly cutesy, ludicrously anthropomorphic critter feature, even if it is in a good cause.
Like a one-act off-Broadway play that's wandered onto the movie screen...a sporadically amusing talkathon, but a pretty shallow and forgettable one.
Doesn't offer startlingly new information, [but] its calm, methodical presentation of the evidence is a solid contribution to...the American public's understanding.
Certainly smart enough to please fans hungry--as Homer always is--for a super-sized helping of their favorite TV family.
This sleazy, silly thriller is so bad it doesn't even seem to realize it's unadulterated kitsch.
Doesn't exhibit the imagination of some of Tony Palmer's films on musicians, [but] Grabsky is certainly to be congratulated on his dedication, sensitivity and good taste.
Mingles every cliche of the genre with a hyperkinetic style more likely to induce vertigo than sympathy or understanding.
Although the picture doesn't really do much except run and jump and punch and explode, it does all those things extremely well, and is viscerally very exciting.
Inevitably exudes a kind of hand-me-down quality, the feeling of being a second-rate copy instead of a true original, at once too clever and not clever enough.
Apart from an occasional bright line and amusing throwaway bits of business, the humor here is juvenile and flat...The Ten is at best a five.
Aims to be goofily anarchic...but it's sloppily written, lazily staged and annoyingly dumb...like a home movie slapped together by a bunch of half-addled bar pals.
Dumb, garish and formulaic...as plastic as the dolls it's based on.
Memo to Cuba: if you're offered the lead in a sequel to Murphy's Pluto Nash, say no.
Winds up seeming heavy-handed, like an elephant trying to dance ballet--a movie about magic that's just not magical enough.
Just the latest misguided attempt to recycle an old horror classic, replacing suspense and a sense of mystery with splatter movie cliche and heavy-handed backstory.
The cinematic equivalent of a bludgeon that wallops you into a sort of mindless stupor with its brazenly stupid plot and chintzy visual pyrotechnics.
Another helping of the combination of romantic sweetness and slob comedy that made The 40-Year-Old Virgin such a smash...the raunchiness too often overwhelms the charm.
A neo-noir picture that won't entirely satisfy, but offers enough incidental pleasures to make it a moderately enjoyable trip to the dark side.
Itself a cinematic sleight of hand...but it pulls off the trick with surprising deftness and amusement.
An immensely entertaining throwback...a big, fast-paced World War II adventure, old-fashioned but with some welcome twists.
An unholy mixture of religious balderdash and horror-movie cliche...it would probably be wise to Passover it.
As was the case with most of the AIP exploitation programmers it fondly recalls, Grindhouse proves more entertaining to anticipate than actually to watch.
Though Loach's film loses some of its dramatic impetus in the second half, it illuminates the events that led to eight decades of tortured Irish history.
movie_title: The Wind That Shakes the Barley (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Even if you look forward to meeting the Robinsons, after ninety minutes you'll probably be happy to take your leave of them.
As much a broken-down wreck as the house at the center of the plot.
The Boston cops had it wrong: the promotional gizmos put up in public places to advertise this movie weren't bombs, it's the picture itself that's one.
movie_title: Aqua Teen Hunger Force Colon Movie Film for Theaters (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Until the final reels it's actually a fairly nifty little thriller...Unfortunately, it goes awry in the last act.
Another graphic novel-y movie that presents its maniacal machismo on a smaller scale than 300 but makes up for it by being even loonier.
A three-hour practical joke without a punchline, at once maddeningly obscure and infinitely boring.
In less accomplished hands might have been dismissed as mawkish and contrived, but...comes across as surprisingly honest and affecting.
The title is half-right: the picture moves at a glacial pace (which allows all its absurdities to stand in clear relief), but it generates no heat.
Perfectly awful...[a] luridly trashy whodunit that quickly degenerates into an appalling whydidtheydoit.
This exhibition of infantilism is all very silly, of course, but worse it's not terribly funny.
[A] loopy lark...the sheer goofiness of the premise, together with its gossipy 'insider' nature [and] the take-no-prisoners performance of John Malkovich...carry it along.
Nifty in construction and savvy in execution, this is a twisty thriller that's both cannily suspenseful and honestly moving.
Fanboys may embrace its wanton carnage, he-man heroics and bombastic dialogue, but 300 really belongs on a PlayStation rather than in a theatre.
One helluva monster movie--a giant-tadpole flick that melds chills, heart and humor into one gloriously wild, weird package...an immediate oddball classic.
So utterly synthetic that though set in New York, it might as well be happening on another planet...despite the title, Gray doesn't matter at all.
If one learns by suffering, as grandpa keeps saying here, this movie offers a good deal of instruction.
A solid, informative piece, but not a revelatory one. And if you should go see it, it's probably a good idea to pay at the boxoffice with cash rather than via a credit card.
I had a feeling this movie wasn't going to be any good, and as it turns out I was right...both confusingly opaque and frustratingly simple-minded.
A tired reworking of The Seven Year Itch in which scripter Rock supplies star Rock with unfunny lines and dumb situations that director Rock stages without any style.
movie_title: I Think I Love My Wife (2007)

movie_review_blurb: This Silence is definitely D.O.A.,...a genre movie that's well-produced, but extremely silly and not at all scary.
Sprawling but affecting family drama, marked by sensitive direction and fine performances.
Some turtles live a very long time, but on the evidence of this bewilderingly complex but curiously pedestrian movie, the teenage mutant ninja variety has passed its prime.
There's absolutely nothing new here, but though Howard can't make this swimming tale seem fresh, he does make it feel slightly less mildewy.
A feel-good celebration of political vigilantism...As a piece of empty-headed action entertainment, it misses the target by a wide margin.
A manipulative male-bonding dramedy that's hobbled by the questionable casting of Adam Sandler in a pivotal role and use of a national tragedy to give it emotional resonance.
A New Age version of E.T....more fuzzy-headed and inarticulate than the title's stuffed bunny.
There's gore galore, but not much more. And it's a bore.
An extraordinary blend of the humorous and the sad...a sweetly empathetic study of society's emotional fringe-dwellers.
Though the picture's like a souffle that occasionally goes soggy, for the most part it's a tasty treat.
This combination parody of Agatha Christie and Michael Bay turns out to be pretty funny stuff...a Police Academy with brains.
An efficient enough legal potboiler...But Hoblit set the bar high with Primal Fear, and this attempted follow-up, though mildly engaging, doesn't quite clear it.
Even for a zombie-ghoul movie, its idiocy is beyond the pale.
A berserk combination of tasteless comedy and even more tasteless melodrama.
Though it boasts a few moments of odd, laid-back humor, what distinguishes the picture is that it's not just bad, but perversely bad.
Like a rerun of a television show you didn't much care for in the first place.
The film's sensitive treatment of the domestic issues at the center of the story goes far to make up for the more problematic passages.
Shrek has always been a lumbering, heavy-footed fellow, but his first two movies were a lot more nimble than this one.
A shambling, episodic movie that, in the end, just droops along to nowhere.
In the sea of blood and gore rolling down theatre aisles nowadays, this cheeky, scary horror farce proves that the comic slasher movie isn't dead yet.
A weak satire of network television programming, telling you nothing you don't already know and doing so without providing much more than the occsasional mild chuckle.
Arch, annoyingly complicated and insufferably smug, this will appeal only to those for whom Hartley and Posey can do no wrong.
Wins you over without appearing even to try... Once...is so emotionally resonant and exuberantly enjoyable that you might just want to see it more than that.
Even if you don't particulary care for rap, The Hip Hop Project may persuade you that there's something to be said for it, after all.
Those willing to work their way through a woman's halting effort to overcome grief will find it a sensitive and engrossing film, though not always an entirely plausible one.
Though the characters in it might not actually have bugs under their skin, Friedkin's creepy film will certainly get under yours, for good or ill.
A convoluted, ponderous, joyless spectacle whose lack of charm is matched only by its incoherence.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: At Worlds End (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Straightforward but not detached, touching but not maudlin, it's an honestly moving, if modest, portrait of a marriage affected by a terrible wasting disease.
Though it's not as smooth as it might have been and by the close has gotten too clever by half, this trashy thriller delivers the goods more often than not.
Boasts a distinctive style and tone, but the style is arch and quaint, and the tone too insistently quirky.
There's the faint air of a solid cable movie about Civic Duty...but the questions it raises are provocative enough to make it worth seeing.
As a portrait of a young man's rather late coming-of-emotional-age, it's pleasant but unexceptional...firmly situated in the mediocre middle.
Doesn't make a great addition to the register of motel-based horror movies.
Though the influence of Chabrol is apparent in Dercourt's film, it's more than a mere encore; it's an inventive composition in its own right.
movie_title: The Page Turner (La Tourneuse de pages) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Another well-oiled piece of comic machinery from Francis Veber.
A near-lunatic combination of a movie that's basically wall-to-wall violence--not especially well-executed, at that--with a warning about the effects of violent entertainment.
A wonderfully quiet, serene portrait of Carthusian life edited to reflect the rhythm of the monastic regimen.
An extremely simple-minded present-day chase movie...blown to smithereens by plot holes the size of the majestic mountain canyons where some of the action is set.
An interesting Twilight Zone-ish tale...which tries to make, even if a bit muddily, some deeper points about responsibility and redemption.
Obviously meant to chill us to the bone, but it barely registers on the cinematic thermometer.
Jamie Kennedy may be becoming the new Pauly Shore...ineptitude marks every aspect of the writing and execution.
Utterly conventional...but still works as an uplifting tale of success in adverse circumstances, and as a testimony to the power of one dedicated teacher.
A rather drab dramedy that, despite the title and some very real virtues, doesn't really dig deep or true enough.
A minimalist stroll not worth taking...but if Old Joy doesn't do much, at least it doesn't do it for very long.
Both overstuffed and undernourished...in the comics the Web-Slinger has occasionally lost his grip and come crashing to earth, and that's what happens here, too.
Rather tepid going...the title obviously doesn't refer to the viewer.
A bad idea poorly executed...unfortunately, Blind Dating doesn't deserve to be seen.
Works as a dramatically compelling indictment of a particularly odious regime, but also as a commentary on the corruption of power in the broadest sense.
Like some of the players it showcases, earns a nearly perfect score...funny, poignant, surprising and satisfying from beginning to end.
movie_title: The King of Kong: A Fistful of Quarters (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Certainly attractive to look at, but what goes on in front of the manicured lawns and sumptuous seventeenth-century interiors is considerably less amusing than it might be.
Not good, mind you, but probably about as efficient an example of an unnecessary sequel as was possible under the circumstances.
[An] engrossing epic of misanthropy, capitalist monomania and religious quackery...at once savagely bleak from an emotional perspective and incredibly beautiful visually.
A remarkably fluent and genuinely uplifting picture about a paralyzed man...no solemn, calculating tearjerker but a marvelously rich and fluid evocation.
movie_title: The Diving Bell and the Butterfly (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A tidy, if slow-moving ghost story that offers some modest chills, a couple of genuine shocks and an ending that will probably come as a letdown.
Borrows so heavily from the corpus of J-horror flicks, and especially Hideo Nakata's, that it should really be titled The Ring Tone.

With its simple but elegant (if not always ideally expressive) images (almost entirely in black-and-white) and its deadpan, self-deprecating tone of spunkiness in the face of woe, Persepolis is an agreeably accessible.
The sap flows freely in this geezer tearjerker...unless you're a sucker for...sentimental twaddle...you should cross The Bucket List off yours.
The comedy about a botched robbery and hostage-taking is so bad that even The Cube's most ardent fans are going to feel they're the real victims.
For all its good intentions and solid acting, it ends up more maudlin than penetrating.
Neither clever nor engaging enough to work as a celebration of either larcenous cunning or womanly feistiness.
The only thing surprising about the picture turns out to be how unsurprising it is. Also--despite massive special effects--how boring.
Even in the brainless universe of romantic comedy...goes beyond the bounds of permissible absurdity even while it's following every step of obligatory formula.
Not a bad film, but it does seem to be rather an unecessary one...middle-grade late Allen, which means watchable but little more.
While there's no denying that this is a fine concert film that should certainly please fans, it's not a watershed picture of its kind.
Easily lives down to what genre fans have come to recognize as the Boll standard.
movie_title: In the Name of the King: A Dungeon Siege Tale (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Nessie lays an egg literally and figuratively in this inoffensive, visually attractive but highly derivative family movie about a boy and his beastie.
movie_title: The Water Horse: Legend of the Deep (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Though highly calculating and predictable, and pretty far from documentary status, it's still a remarkably entertaining example of the underdog-wins-against-the-odds genre.
[Langella's] finely shaded performance is the main reason to check out [this] gently affecting film that portrays the fragility of life, love and art with sympathy and taste.
There's an emptiness at the heart of The Golden Compass that all the visual pizzazz and star power in the world can't fill.
A strong ensemble cast spruces up a weak script in this trifle...the little picture that, ultimately, doesn't.
Both a delicious exercise in great acting and a richly refined comedy-drama--tangy and touching in equal measure.
Almost impudently wry and sassy but with an unexpected vein of seriousness and poignancy, this is a crowd-pleaser of the best sort.
Wants to be a Christmas perennial, but it wilts badly well before the final credits roll.
The screen throws the story's weaknesses into sharper relief than the printed page did, and despite the obvious dedication and craftsmanship, the film finishes as a near-miss.
Almost unrelievedly grim and increasingly tedious as it goes along, with a third act that stumbles badly and a coda that's speciously uplifting.
Arguably the most irritating novelty act in record history gets a CGI-updating...and the result is pretty annoying itself.
Errant pseudo-mystical nonsense that manages to be both ponderously pretentious and extravagantly absurd...an act of real cinematic lunacy.
Though hardly a revelatory journey, it's a stroll that offers some modest pleasures along the way.
Offers a few inspired moments in a sea of mediocre gags, fumbled opportunities and that great foul among contemporary comedies--unnecessary grossness.
movie_title: Walk Hard: The Dewey Cox Story (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The title of this stinker should really be compressed to P....You.
Monumentally silly...But viewers looking for the dumbest sort of escapism are likely to be satisfied.
Bloody good, a lusciously Grand Guignol excercise that's true to the composer's original vision but spectacularly cinematic as well.
movie_title: Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Purely as popular entertainment, the picture snaps and crackles with colorful characters and droll dialogue, and on that level alone it's enormous fun.
Too slight and formulaic to amount to much.
Police procedural meets torture porn...sleazy and absurd rather than clever and surprising.
The original Rambo movie was actually titled First Blood...This one should be called Entirely Too Much Blood.
Blithe Spirit with all the blitheness and spirit sucked out.
May not exactly be the belle of the ball, but this ugly duckling updating is certainly fetching enough to serve as enticing family entertainment.
Plays like a bad period soap opera, burying the fascinating complexity of the events of the 1530s in crude historical oversimplification and melodramatic cliche.
Only sporadically funny, ineffectual when it goes serious or sentimental, and, in the last analysis, is mostly mediocre.
A road movie that boasts pleasant company but a broken-down vehicle...in a story that seems ready-made for the Lifetime Network.
May mean well, but its soapy plot and comparatively flabby execution make for a surprisingly tepid combination.
Really nothing more than a bright, sugary confection, but one that goes down easily.
movie_title: Miss Pettigrew Lives for a Day (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Just isn't clever or surprising enough: it's complicated but conventional, strikes no sparks...[and] fails to juggle its myriad tones successfully.
This crackpot combination of Pathfinder and Apocalypto [is] a brainless exercise in prehistoric goofiness that actually affords more laughs than Ice Age.
The cumulative effect is very tasty indeed.
Blows up what's essentially a sweet little fable into something far bigger and louder, but...retains just enough of the original's charm to make good family fare.
movie_title: Dr. Seuss' Horton Hears a Who! (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Bruising but brainless teen action-melodrama...like a match that delivers a few good punches but drags on to a dull and predictable end.
Though fundamentally a nihilistic exercise, it's one with intellect and purpose behind it, and though chilly and remote, it's certainly unnerving.
Dreadful stuff, aggressively silly and repulsively nasty.
Engaging and touching--a manipulative tearjerker, but an effective one.
A pretty but platitudinous paean to American freedom and diversity in which never is heard a discouraging word.
A moving piece of work...at once sobering and infuriating.
A film of rare refinement and artistry...an impeccable adaptation.
Has a certain gritty punch...but in the end it doesn't amount to much but the usual genre static.
The level of foolishness here is simply too high, and the execution so slapdash that the result doesn't seem so much a parody of amateurishness as an example of it.
I spy with my little eye another unnecessary remake of an Asian horror movie.
The cinematography and sound work are mediocre, but still far better than the material deserves: you can still see and hear what's happening on the screen.
Nothing more than a modern film noir incongruously set in a medieval city, but...made enjoyable by its unusual locale, tart tough-guy dialogue and a strong cast.
A lumpy, leaden mixture of romantic comedy and adventure that never takes wing.
The movie makes it abundantly clear that Roscoe should have gone home again. Unfortunately, what's equally apparent is that you shouldn't go with him.
Not a film that's easy to watch, but it is one of remarkable power...a searing indictment of a society gone wrong as well as a harrowing personal story.
It's all easy to take, in a cable-TV sort of way, but neither outrageously funny nor especially revealing.
movie_title: Vince Vaughn's Wild West Comedy Show: 30 Days & 30 Nights - Hollywood to the Heartland (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Charming and touching...gentle and soft-spoken, but it speaks volumes about the possibility of reconciliation in one of the most politically volatile regions of the world.
The film's artsy surface diminishes its impact [but] tells a story that needs to be told repeatedly.
After so many failed attempts to fashion new Harry Potter-like franchises from children's books...it's nice to encounter one that actually works.
Maybe you'll enjoy this, but it's definitely no romantic comedy classic.
George Romero's zombie franchise has definitely run out of brains as well as steam.
A decided step down even from the mediocre original.
An elaborate but messy sci-fi chase...marked by flat characterization, a narrative rife with illogic, and surprisingly poor special effects.
The cascade of coincidences and logical lapses drains it of excitement and leaves it seeming overwhelmingly ridiculous.
Made palatable by its good-natured eagerness to entertain even if its simultaneous desire to teach doesn't quite come off.
The rare coming-of-age tale that offers real historical resonance rather than mere nostalgia.
A would-be psychological thriller without much psychology and even fewer thrills, Awake is more likely to put you to sleep.
A dreary, indeed irritating portrait of people who never seem authentic and certainly aren't emotionally engaging.
Sweet--indeed, cloying--coming-of-age tale...the barrage of messages it carries ultimately proves too heavy a cargo.
As a character study it carries a quiet, almost serene dramatic power as well as a strong current of dark humor.
The cinematic equivalent of a Homeric epic...an ambitious, mesmerizing evocation of the mystique of celebrity and the strange mixture of admiration and envy it generates.
movie_title: The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Quickly degenerates from a serious topical tale about twenty-first century terrorism into a jingoistic gung-ho shoot-'em-up.
The Beatles survived Peter Frampton and the Bee Gees, so they'll survive Julie Taymor, too.
A visually stunning modern-day epic in which the protagonist, unfortunately, remains a blur.
However much Douglas might have savored making it, this King deserves no royal welcome.
So clumsily made that even its hopeful message can't make it go down pleasantly.
It looks wonderful...but feels thin and weightless, as pretty a bauble as a Christmas tree ornament and ultimately just about as durable.
There's a good deal less to the movie than meets the eye--and the ear. But there's still just enough to make for a close verdict in its favor.
Clumsily made and not at all magical, with a confusing story, a bland young hero, a really boring villain and mediocre visuals...read the signs and search elsewhere.
movie_title: The Seeker: The Dark Is Rising (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A marriage definitely not made in heaven, and a picture that's a disheartening commentary on the decline in the standards of American comedy over the last quarter-century.
Offers some smiles and rueful insights about the vicissitudes of love, but its almost slavish imitation of the Woody Allen formula ultimately makes it seem stale.
Half soap opera and half sitcom, but successful as neither.
Beautiful but remote...But fascinated or bored, you won't be able to deny the level of craftsmanship it displays.
Seems more exploitation than exploration...ends up not illuminating its subject but cheapening it.

A wonderfully old-fashioned western that works in contemporary terms--a rousing demonstration that people can make the kinds of pictures they supposedly don't make anymore.

A mixture of seriousness and humor that doesn't quite gel...easier to respect for its ambition than to praise for its achievement.

movie_review_blurb: Could hardly be called even-handed, and it's certainly repetitive, but despite its failings it's still worth seeing--as so often, especially by those who probably won't.

If the overwrought dramatics are like an opera drained of its music, that's a price you may be willing to pay for the purely sensual pleasure the images afford.
Represents a serious and sensitive epic on the real nature of war--not as some strategic game but as a devastating human experience.
A film suffering from an acute case of Jumanjiitis...the one exhibit that would be most appropriate for this Museum would be a white elephant.
Important subject, good intentions, bad movie...its sheer ineptitude trumps its noble aspirations.
Though in terms of atmosphere it's a gripping exercise in modern Orwellianism, it's less well realized in human terms.
Dank, stupid and--the most unpardonable of sins--extraordinarily tedious.
Bleak, mean-spirited and wonderfully enjoyable.
Though it may come across more than a little precious and pretentious, its memory will linger in your mind long after those of other films have faded.
movie_title: Perfume: The Story of a Murderer (2006)

movie_review_blurb: An astonishingly inventive portrait of childhood fears and hopes, an eerily beautiful modern fairy tale that truly merits the overused adjective magical.
Thanks to its star it possesses both a delicate charm and a poignancy that doesn't descend into mawkishness...O'Toole lights up the screen with masterful understatement.
When life hands you a script about a guy whom life hands lemons, make a bigger lemon.
As triumphant on the screen as it was on the boards, though like the original, it's a triumph of style over substance.
A drab, unaffecting combination of unrealistic drama and muddled didacticism, impossible to connect with on either an emotional or an intellectual level.
An earnest film that shows an advance in Estevez's filmmaking technique, but one that--given its setting--seems curiously shallow, even trivial.
Almost everybody's got amnesia in Unknown, and after watching it you might pine to be similarly afflicted.
It avoids Hallmark greeting-card slickness and Cecil B. DeMille razzmatazz, but replaces them with a plodding earnestness that leaves it largely inoffensive but rather dull.
Another helping of sadism disguised as entertainment...even aficionados of such massacre-fests are likely to find this a long slog.
Subdued and deliberate, but also sensitive and quietly moving. And it gives Judd a chance to shine as a real actress again.
Has a visionary quality that makes it weirdly beautiful and endlessly fascinating...a film of astonishing vibrancy, stunning imagination and sheer bravado.
Another attempt to convey the torment of post-colonial Africa that doesn't fulfill its ambitions.
Brash, annoying juvenile slapstick comedy...Once word gets around, these Minors probably won't be as much unaccompanied as unattended.
A far from festive experience...so completely synthetic that there isn't a moment or line of dialogue that has the remotest connection to reality--or to humor, either.
Though studded with strong moments, ultimately has the feel of a harder, more unflinching version of a monitory after-school special.
Tells a familiar story, but does it well enough to merit a passing grade.
An intelligent but hardly momentous recycling of an old formula; and as such it's mostly amusing but surprisingly conventional--and ephemeral.
Though Charlotte's Web looks and sounds nice enough, it radiates familiarity and blandness...has none of the gossamer quality needed to bring the 1952 classic to life.
Essentially a repeat of the first episode of Star Wars dropped into a Lord of the Rings context...comes across as plodding and rather dull.
Homages don't get much more homagey...but if you love its models, and the sheer artificiality of the effort doesn't bother you, you should have a good time.
Ambitious, but while it serves as a showcase for some terrific performances, it achieves the wrenching drama it's aiming for only intermittently.
Quote not available.
Moderately enjoyable, but a step back rather than forward.
Rather like its subject's books--pretty to look at, sweet without being syrupy and cute without being cloying, but rather thin.
Flyweight but mostly agreeable romantic comedy...buoyed by its jovial but good-natured send-up of pop music past and present.
While a mostly sturdy adaptation of a much-loved book, it isn't quite as secure a structure as it might have been.
An old-fashioned poor little rich girl story gussied up with 1960s glitter...as vacuous as the milieu in which it's set.
Expertly crafted, if slightly pedestrian, docudrama, more quietly intriguing than compellingly dramatic [but] sparked by Cooper's bravura turn.
Crappy comic, worse movie...joins Albert Pyun's Captain America at the bottom of the Marvel barrel.
Satisfying enough to demonstrate that some stories deserve to be told more than once.
There are times when cinematic heart-tugging takes on the character of a frontal assault. Opal Dream is one of them.
Apparently calculated to lift your spirits but will probably cause your jaw to drop instead.
A big fat zero...an exhaustingly busy cinematic puzzle, this year's Butterfly Effect--but even less entertaining.
Though it's not as inspiring as its makers might have wished, it's a solid, respectful treatment of a significant episode in the anti-slavery movement.
Can be heavy-handed at times but overall makes its points with considerable power.
Abandon all hope of entertainment, ye who enter here...dreary as well as dull.
By presenting both sides, even if unequally, the film manages to do something like justice to an important if controversial figure.
A vacuous male-bonding farce...made worse by dumb slapstick interludes and the failure of the stars to generate much comic wattage.
Will make some people uncomfortable, but for many others it will be a giddily guilty pleasure.
Hard to stomach...this handsomely appointed but turgid, dramatically inert movie simply bites off more than it can successfully chew.
Carries neither satirical bite nor emotional punch, an indictment delivered in an oddly mellow tone. Don't order a helping.
Perversely fascinating as a cultural document, but as a movie it's simply dreadful.
Just dumb formula, and even the Pang brothers' technique can't raise it above the humdrum.
Astronomically awful, like the crappiest copy of a Dario Argento giallo ever made...Thr3e isn't even half the movie Se7en was.
Its obvious good intentions can't compensate for its utter familiarity...just a case of old wine in an equally old bottle.
Compared to the best movies of its kind (Shrek), Happily N'Ever After is insipid. Compared to mediocre ones (Hoodwinked!), it's not very good, either.
A quick sweep-up is in order.
Flashy but skin-deep...all the sound and fury can't disguise the fact that Alpha Dog doesn't signify much.
A step up from the run of fare ordinarily targeted at the so-called urban audience...But it doesn't step up far enough.
A mediocre, humorless, old-fashioned creature feature...hobbled by risible effects and a crude attempt at political relevance.
Bigger, louder and far bloodier than the original, but devoid of all the delicious ambiguity that made it so fascinating.
Basically just an old-fashioned western chase saga with delusions of grandeur. But it's still enjoyable as a flamboyant exercise in nostalgia.
Lachrymose and lugubrious, this drippy dramedy tries to mix laughter and tears but earns only an exasperated frown.
What Carnagehan--sorry, Carnahan--has wrought is a foul, speciously cool exercise in gross, pointless mayhem...all sass and no substance.
For a werewolf movie, this is an awfully toothless, turgid effort.
One of those throw-everything-at-the-screen-and-see-if-anything-sticks movies...In this case, nothing does...All terrible--puerile, vulgar and unfunny.
A simple but heartwarming period tale...a generous and--appropriately, given the title--sweet-natured portrait of a time long past.
It's appropriate that much of Because I Said So is set in a bakery, because even in a sea of awful chick flicks, this appalling confection takes the cake.
It's probably impossible to enforce a complete ban on the use of fat suits in Hollywood comedies, but certainly it's time for an extended moratorium on them.
So puerile and gross that though the movie wants to say something about the dumbing down of America, it winds up not so much commentary as part of the problem.
There must be an underground contest in Hollywood to see who can make the worst Christmas movie...Hang the Crepe would be more appropriate.
Makes Bill & Ted's Excellent Adventure look like a model of cerebral wit...there's a difference between genuine satire and Three Stooges-style stupidity.
movie_title: Tenacious D in The Pick of Destiny (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Quote not available.
A gently moving tear-jerker...a small film, but it has a large heart.
movie_title: Riding Alone for Thousands of Miles (2006)

movie_review_blurb: A fair-to-middling coming-of-age tale [is] played by a stellar cast in an unusual locale [but] never escapes seeming rather ordinary.
A by-the-numbers futuristic cop yarn as ordinary in its narrative as it's remarkable for its technique...as boring as most of its live-action siblings in the genre.
Really nothing more than a phantasmagorical reworking of The Secret Life of Walter Mitty using lots of tacky effects and goofy imagery.
A solid but unremarkable piece...will be more at home on the tube.
No classic but not a disaster...by comparison to the recent competition it hits the target, if not the bull's-eye.
Efficient rather than profound. But when efficiency is this much fun, it would be churlish to ask for more.
An uneven film not entirely successful in juggling its very different tones, but...Whitaker's performance is so good that it makes the picture almost insanely watchable.
Before his transformation for the love of Amy, hero Zack's motto was 'Why bother trying?' That seems to have been the filmmakers' mantra, too...a bland, formulaic rehash.
Given that this is a prequel...there's no suspense, only ninety minutes of lip-smacking sadism. This is entertainment?
movie_title: The Texas Chainsaw Massacre: The Beginning (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Would seem sincere enough, but it's just a chain of ludicrous cliches of both the sports and religious variety.
Rankly sentimental...though the prudish should definitely steer clear, what ultimately derails Shortbus is that it's actually far less daring than it pretends to be.
Capote Lite...a distant also-ran. With Miller's film still fresh in the memory, it pales into insignificance.
[A] deliciously sharp but strangely poignant comedy of political manners...at once wry and touching.
Pretty much a case of 'been there, seen that.' If this kind of by-the-numbers stuff is your cup of seawater, this is a professional example. But don't expect any surprises.
Mildly engaging...in an age of appallingly coarse comedies, its relative restraint is definitely welcome.
The scariest movie of the season by far...a fine, thought-provoking documentary.
Terribly mawkish, like a Hallmark Hall of Fame TV movie. And not even a good TV movie.
So muddled as to be virtually incoherent...but the chases and fight scenes are the raison d'etre of The Protector, and in purely athletic terms they're great.
A guys-for-girls version of Charmed. It's sad indeed when one's making movies that wouldn't even have passed muster on a network that no longer exists.
A good film with a great performance.
A stylish but oddly flat exercise in noir conventions, a homage that doesn't so much honor its models as alternately embalm and ridicule them.
Muccino's film was a deliciously surprising, high-spirited dance; Goldwyn's is a dreary dirge,...a sadly typical blend of morose relationship tale and second-rate sitcom.
Though one of the producing entities is called Original Film, nothing could be further from the truth...hopelessly formulaic and pat.
Predictable and bland...it would be hard to muster any adjective stronger than 'pleasant' to describe it.
Pretty much a mess, misconceived in the most fundamental ways and badly cast.
The cliche-ridden histrionics were already old-fashioned...fifty years ago. Now they seem positively moldy, and all the CGI dexterity in the world can't enliven them.
It would be easy to go on at length about how tasteless and repulsive the movie is, but what's really depressing about it is the repetitiveness and tedium.
Almost childishly naive but beautifully crafted and both viscerally exciting and oddly touching...a surprisingly rich and satisfying love letter by Li to the martial arts.
movie_title: Jet Li's Fearless (Huo Yuan Jia) (Legend of a Fighter) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: By any objective standard, Feast isn't a good movie, but by those of its low-rent genre it's kind of fun.
Moderately amusing, but rather wan when compared to really inspired mockumentaries.
Likely to leave you scratching your head--not merely because the plot's so hard to follow but because you'll be wondering why anybody thought it was worth making.
A hybrid of so many parts that it would be unwieldy even if it were executed very well. But as it happens, it isn't.
Bland and formulaic, a kind of British Cody Banks without that movie's gaudily over-the-top elements and largely minus its humor.
Quote not available.
A needlessly complicated, totally redundant follow-up to a mediocre original.
Like its scriptural model, an impressive structure, but one that doesn't reach the intended emotional heights.
The makers of Driving Lessons may have learned a bit too much from previous movies, but they've put the results to pretty enjoyable use.
A guy version of a chick flick, and like regular chick flicks, it's pretty sappy stuff, though with the lovely locations and sumptuous cinematography, it's very pretty.
Despite its pretensions to be unusual, oddly imitative and ordinary...less like a story you find clever and surprising than like a book you've read before.
Takes off fast and rarely pauses along the way, but doesn't manage to take you anywhere worth going.
A spiffy, satisfyingly old-fashioned thriller with supernatural overtones that hangs together and, at barely eighty minutes, doesn't overstay its welcome.
While managing to say something about the principle of free speech and the power of consumerism in America, it also manages to be as smart, sassy and enjoyable as the Chicks.
movie_title: Dixie Chicks - Shut Up and Sing (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Earnest and well-intentioned though it may be, it just never rises above ordinary television-movie quality.
Visually stunning...but it's a curious sort of family film that's part Las Vegas extravaganza and part pro-environmental tract, unlikely to enchant children.
A sadly conventional treatment of the career of a man who defied convention...Beethoven still awaits a cinematic craftsman as imaginative and driven as he was.
A solid action-adventure in the modern mold...expertly crafted in every respect. But it's also just a little anonymous amidst so many similar films.
Should have been titled Let's Go to DVD, where it will clearly move with unbecoming alacrity, and where it will be much more at home. Though, one hopes, not yours.
A shaggy dog story for adults, but one that takes itself much too seriously...so pretentiously, and turgidly, dramatized that...it borders on the risible.
movie_title: Fur: An Imaginary Portrait of Diane Arbus (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Obvious and limp, a pale reflection of the quirky verve that marked its predecessors.
An artsy-fartsy disaster...a would-be film of ideas that runs dry of them very quickly.
A gaudy but bland lump of coal in this year's cinematic holiday stocking.
movie_title: The Santa Clause 3: The Escape Clause (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Just a middle-grade action-adventure with pretensions and serious script problems.
Hold the hyperbole...isn't a work of genius, just a cable comedy sketch with some sharply funny bits but overextended, needlessly crude and ultimately...smug.
movie_title: Borat: Cultural Learnings of America for Make Benefit Glorious Nation of Kazakhstan (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Moderately moving but not truly shattering, as you might expect of a film with this theme;...its impact is more intellectual than visceral.
Low-budget, logic-free action shlock...explosion-laced, fisticuff-heavy, utterly brainless stuff.
A picture of some generalized power that's nonetheless unfocused and awfully high-pitched...too florid and messy to succeed as a whole.
movie_title: A Guide to Recognizing Your Saints (2006)

movie_review_blurb: There are enjoyable nuggets throughout Mum, but they're sporadic, and in the end the movie is no keeper.
A good idea executed with insuffient flair and clumsily put together.
movie_title: This Film Is Not Yet Rated (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Rather like its heroine--extremely pretty to look at but rather simple-minded.
A ponderous tale of envy and one-upmanship that promises much but in the end delivers surprisingly little...seriously short of cinematic magic.
Makes Dreamer, the last mediocre girl-and-her-horse movie, seem almost brilliant by comparison.
Isn't perfect, but its flaws arise from an attempt to deliver a message about the complicated nature of heroism that's worth hearing in our own time of conflict.
A reality show that transcends that now-hackneyed phrase to become an utterly unique work of 'popular history'--and of art.
Beautifully crafted, sharply funny and emotionally piercing, all at once.
One of the most grating, irritating movies you're likely to see all year...an avalanche of eccentricity without any redeeming comic or dramatic virtues.
Extremely dull in every sense. Even the most devoted fan won't find much to enjoy in this grab-bag of tired cliches and inept tricks.
A pretentious gabfest...When one of the characters opines toward the close, 'This has been a complete waste of time,' you'll be hard pressed not to nod in agreement.
Bomides of the most banal sort...If you don't already belong to the choir, the preaching isn't likely to make much of an impression.
Exceptional...the effect is shattering.
The combination of Aardman eccentricity and antic DreamWorks energy proves a far more palatable mix than one might have anticipated.
One of the best pictures of its kind ever made, at once cheeky, exhilarating, funny and genuinely moving...a triumph of the super-hero genre.
The kind of picture for which the phrase 'shows promise' was invented...As a theatrical offering, though, it's way out of its league.
Though it's clearly a hate letter to Bush, it's a cleverly composed one, and it will succeed in infuriating and satisfying audiences in approximately equal measure.
Now seems peculiarly dated....The contrivances here are obvious and heavy-handed.
Absurdly threadbare.....Supposed to be darling, of course, but it's mostly a stream of flat, pedestrian or nauseatingly cute talk.
The weird combination of slapstick and noir gruesomeness ...is a nice antidote to the bland familiarity of so much of today's Hollywood comedy.
It does the obvious well enough, but ironically--considering the subject--it lacks the touch of magic....a picture that, while well crafted, is ultimately uninspired.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone (2001)

movie_review_blurb: Pleasant, but ultimately fairly predictable, 'Dinner Rush' won't be as crowded as the restaurant it depicts as jammed even on a Tuesday night.
Runs out of invention long before it lumbers to a close...a decidedly thin, anemic farce.
Does narrative cartwheels in a futile effort to outwit us....you'll probably emerge from the theatre thinking you're the one who's been robbed.
Probably the worst Woody Allen movie that Woody never made... it's supposed to charm our socks off but merely makes us grit our teeth in impatience and annoyance.
The title reflects the condition viewers are advised to be in while the picture unspools...about as appetizing as an anchovy- flavored sno-cone.
A haunting film in every sense...a picture that engages the eye, the heart and the mind with equal success.
movie_title: The Devil's Backbone (El Espinazo del diablo) (2001)

movie_review_blurb: Miraculously simple and spare, yet quietly and astonishingly eloquent and moving...It transcends its genre, the rare tearjerker that honestly earns every drop and sniffle.
Very much the sort of thing that one finds--and enjoys--on PBS all the time.
A piece of jingoistic claptrap, but one expertly calculated to appeal to viewers' emotions, particularly at the present moment of national crisis.
As far as horse operas go, it's a broken-down old nag infested with fleas and well past the point of being saddle- worthy.
A good, solid, middle-of-the-road secret agent yarn, almost gleefully old-fashioned in narrative and tone.
[A] mixture of heavy-handed poignancy, hopefulness in the face of adversity and bitchy dialogue.
A pedestrian filmization of a three-character play that comes across like a watered-down combination of Sam Shepard and David Mamet.
An uneasy blend of the naughty and the nice in which the two ingredients fail to mesh....The result isn't bad; it's just not good enough.
A gruesome, gloppy, goofy but perversely amusing shlockfest that will probably appeal to young audiences looking for a Halloween date flick.
Entirely prefabricated...the attempt to meld 'American Beauty' with 'Terms of Endearment' proves shallow indeed.
More boring and unintentionally risible than frightening.
Abominably written, directed and acted...wretched from first stop to last.
An audacious, astonishingly confident debut feature...a haunting, deeply personal and wonderfully experimental collage of genres and themes.
The slender tale has been loaded down with so much Hollywood contrivance and phony piety that it collapses under the weight.
A pretentious snoozer...While there's a good deal in the picture to excite the eye, there's not much to stimulate the ear or...to engage the mind.
What dooms this Hamlet to mediocrity is the quality of the acting, especially in the leads, and the general slowness and turgidity of the proceedings.
Despite some flaws, for the most part it offers a genial, family- friendly ninety minutes' worth of amusement.
An utterly negligible martial-arts flick--cheap-looking, clumsily written, and not even very well staged, fight-wise.
Would barely have made a decent Movie-of-the-Week twenty years ago...even the title is generic.
A lovely, very funny and strangely moving film, one that takes its rightful place in the ever-more-amazing corpus of the brothers' work.
So pretentious, arch and spuriously clever that watching it almost makes your teeth ache.
May not offer much to think about, but it does provide a feast for the eye, even if it's a meal that's mostly bright red.
Quirky, witty, and visually exhilarating...a charming confection turned out with dazzling directorial aplomb.
The bracing nature of the humor, the energy of the direction and the authenticity of the performances go far to mitigate its weaknesses.
Bouncy and amusing...utter fluff, to be sure, but it's highly enjoyable fluff, far superior to the earlier picture.
Almost surrealistically bad...not only fails totally to delight but is even likely to creep you out.
A misbegotten venture that transforms a flawed but intriguing original into an elephantine, pretentious mess....All that's left is the murkiness and obscurity.
Watching it is rather like strolling through an overstuffed museum exhibit in the company of a dry-as-dust, long-winded guide constantly chattering into your ear.
Formulaic and manipulative, to be sure, but its sincerity and good-heartedness keep it from crashing and burning.
An absolute, unqualified delight, without a weak stretch or an unwanted second.
A cheesy sci-fi flick...not significantly better than direct-to-video fare.
A succession of set-pieces, each of them individually impressive but adding up to very little because there's nothing between them to move us.
While the contrivances tend to pile up rather uncomfortably...the picture is saved (though barely) by its remarkable leads.
Delightfully bad and, for the most part, deliciously entertaining...one of those great, extravagant pieces of cinematic lunacy that somehow get made.
Basically it's cable-ready, and it shouldn't be long in getting there.
A distinctly mixed bag, the occasional bursts of sharp writing alternating with lots of sloppiness and the obligatory moments of sentimental ooze.
A tale of unrequited love and maturation so emotionally pure that it seems effortlessly moving, a picture of rare poignancy and surprising depth.
Has considerable charm, wit and style, and does the unexpected often enough to keep you consistently amused.
It remains a wonderfully imperfect explosion of genius and immaturity, in approximately equal measure.
A mongrel of a movie--scruffy, obvious and slightly disreputable...the best one can say of it is that it could have been worse.
In spite of the fact that it's almost impossible to take your eyes from 'Fat Girl,' the film ultimately proves disturbingly obvious.
The deft blending of the serious with the silly makes for a recipe that proves wonderfully satisfying.
As a cinematic exercise it's breathtakingly brilliant; as drama, however, it's not nearly so successful.
Slow, talky, and, in its final act, more than a little maudlin... rather like a decorous soap opera, which seems a contradiction in terms.
A sadly pale, drab piece of hokum, hopelessly old-fashioned and emotionally flat.
A grand and glorious entertainment, and a welcome return to form by one of today's directorial giants.
Gruesomely unfunny, an appalling debacle that's like one long, agonizing groan...an astoundingly awful picture.
Triumphantly successful...long but never dull, filled with incident but surprisingly clear, and even at some points quite affecting.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring (2001)

movie_review_blurb: While one can easily respect the noble intentions behind it, one has to admit that purely as a work of cinema, it doesn't equal the best of recent Iranian films.
movie_title: Kandahar: Le soleil derrière la lune (2001)

movie_review_blurb: A consistently intriguing, if not completely satisfying, portrait of sexual politics inside and beyond the boardroom...worth searching out.
You have to admire its cleverness and eccentric charm.
A crock--well-intentioned and slickly made, to be sure, but a crock nonetheless...unbelievably sappy.
Innocuous and instantly forgettable...for the most part the material is flat, and it's flatly played.
It's not only intelligently conceived and smoothly crafted, but also manages be be emotionally resonant without degenerating into mawkishness.
It's no 'Shrek,' and not even a 'Monsters, Inc.,' but it's a genial kidflick that should amuse the younger set.
Its unremitting coarseness and utterly amoral attitude will be excruciating for most viewers to sit through.
Winning fluff, easy to take and easy to like--the rare example of its genre that's genuinely enjoyable.
Nothing more than a heavy-handed soap opera masquerading as serious drama; in the end it sinks under the weight of its own pretensions.
A curiously unsatisfying piece which reveals far less about its subject than you want to know...overly schematic, more hagiography than history.
This is an affecting, thought-provoking film despite the plot contrivances on which it depends...a remarkably moving experience.
The deliberately lackadaisical, almost improvisational approach occasionally achieves striking moments, but mostly seems more flat and redundant.
An almost brutally manipulative piece...can't stand up against the tidal wave of treacle that swells up and swallows everyone in the final reels.
A total muddle which will prove as frustrating to audiences as 'Vanilla Sky'...paradoxically, both formulaic and incoherent.
A grey, sullen treatment of an increasingly hackneyed subject, marked by opaque characterizations and a fractured, disjointed narrative style.
A trip that has an entirely predictable destination, and tugs far too insistently on the heartstrings in getting there.
A woebegone attempt at an ensemble farce which Paramount Pictures could label 'guaranteed laugh-free' without the slightest danger of a lawsuit.
Voluptuous and visually entrancing...but a variety of flaws-- most notably Cage's tone-deaf performance--render it earthbound when it should soar.
It's a frail, anemic trifle, a five-minute sketch inexcusably drawn out to well over an hour and a half.
movie_title: The Curse of the Jade Scorpion (2001)

movie_review_blurb: In a summer of really rotten movies it still stands out for its wretchedness...has the air of something falling several rungs below straight-to-video standards.
A flick designed so exclusively for his rabid fans that outsiders won't even understand, let alone enjoy it.
movie_title: Jay and Silent Bob Strike Back (2001)

movie_review_blurb: Will provide modest enjoyment for viewers who like a challenge and don't go expecting too much.
A spiffy but ridiculous frat-boy oater.
While...it has a certain gangly charm, it's just too frail and wispy to go the distance.
An empty-headed, chaotic, utterly tasteless atrocity...bubble- brained and obnoxious.
A cinematic foul ball....Do yourself a favor and just throw it back.
In this case, unhappily, 'O' stands not so much for 'Othello' as for 'Zero.'
This 'Rhapsody'...would have seemed a maudlin, musty composition even back in the fifties.
Well-intentioned but curiously out-of-date...far too earnest for its own good.
The first half...is surprisingly lithe and stylish...That's not enough, unfortunately, to save its increasingly poor second half, which careens into silliness.
Certainly isn't indigestible, but by comparison to its more savory source, it's considerably less than mouth-watering.
A stale pastry that's likelier to make you gag than to smack your lips in satisfaction.
A picture that has all the charm of 'Cool World' and all the laughs of 'Larger Than Life'...a pretty noxious combination.
A film of fits and starts, occasionally striking but more often curiously flat and uninvolving.
For the audience this dreary piece is truly a losing proposition.
A great, somewhat mad endeavor, well worth revisiting in the theatre.
The musty odor of a fossil hangs over the whole enterprise
A deft, old-fashioned combination of jokes and sentiment, the cinematic equivalent of one of Crystal's opening monologues at the Academy Awards.
A near-miss that the adventurous might still want to check out.
While respectable enough on its own low terms, the picture is disappointingly conventional and unimaginative.
Worth seeing simply as a flamboyant cinematic exercise that explores the possibilities of the medium in ways you won't have experienced before.
Quite affecting, powerful and (at times) funny...and it's well worth investigating.
A fascinating and rewarding journey for those willing to take a bit of a risk.
The sort of picture that murkily suggests all sorts of deep meanings because it's fundamentally incoherent.
It would probably best be reserved for a gals' matinee out... it's like 'Cinderella' in modern dress.
A sloppily constructed, frantically humorless retread.
Can be recommended only to moviegoers who like pictures so outrageously bad that you can revel in their awfulness.
Though it creates tension and manages a few effective jolts,...after it's over frustrated viewers may be inclined to call it 'The Sixth Nonsense.'
An intriguing, if flawed, picture of a woman driven to the most extreme measures to protect her wayward son.
If this picture doesn't set your toe tapping and your spirit soaring, you'd better check your pulse.
Pretty much a compendium of riffs that would have been old-hat in film school.
A series of brief snapshots of frustratingly varied quality...it doesn't get much beneath the surface.
Almost a model of what's best in American independent cinema... provocative but not exploitative, moving but not maudlin.
Even the most tolerant viewer is likely to groan more than once at the enormous mass of contrivance and manipulation stuffed into a mere ninety minutes.
A numbingly idiotic retread, a half-baked mixture of 'Duel' and 'The Hitcher' that's markedly inferior to both....Goes nowhere fast.
By the time its drawn-out finale lurches to a screeching close, 'Training Day' has come to feel more like 'The Longest Day.'
It's one of those movies that the family should take pains to avoid together.
A feel-good helping of cinematic tiramisu--it's sweet and spongy, but rather clammy and artificial.
Easily one of Schroeder's best films, cannily employing understatement to convey unforgettably the despair of modern amoral society...a remarkable and engrossing film.

movie_review_blurb: Doesn't equal the greatest cinematic military satires, but its mixture of grimness and farce carries a salutary jolt in an era of silly comedies with nothing to say.
A well-groomed example of middlebrow kitsch...what might have been an exuberant tale of the Sport of Kings is instead a hokey ode to the resiliency of the common man. Neigh...I mean nay.
The music in it is uniformly lousy, but one doesn't notice because everything surrounding it s even worse.
Engaged filmmaking that makes a political point, and the observant script and incisive direction give it considerable power.
movie_title: Mondays in the Sun (Los Lunes al sol) (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Ben and J-Lo are no Tracy and Hepburn--they're more like the Sean Penn and Madonna of Shanghai Surprise. And their movie is just as rotten as that one.
If this flavor of 'Pie' is your desert of choice, you'll find it served up as well here as you could wish, but in reality it's an awfully tasteless confection.
Easily the weakest installment in the popular kids' series...one can only hope that the subtitle is more than just a reference to the virtual reality game at the center of the very thin plot.
A film which, while intriguing, is also more than a little frustrating.
A contrived, witless piece of work...a tune titled 'I Want To Be Bad'...could be the movie's theme song.
movie_title: Sin noticias de Dios (Don't Tempt Me) (2003)

movie_review_blurb: While a harmless enough diversion, proves to be a relatively feeble--and rather precious--little comedy-drama about aging and parenthood.
Self-indulgent twaddle...pretentious but impenetrable babble.
Tells a story of sudden success and abject failure that, apart from the skateboarding setting, isn't all that unusual...but it's told well enough to be worth a look.
movie_title: Stoked: The Rise and Fall of Gator (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Offers not feast but famine...at its core Susman's film, despite its subject, is utterly conventional and as eager to please as a puppy dog.
Undemanding audiences may be willing to succumb to 'Temptations,' but the more discerning will easily be able to resist.
For a movie about a centuries-old battle between vampires and werewolves, Underworld proves to be a surprisingly toothless affair.
