A crowd-pleaser of the most old-fashioned sort, and who cares about calculation when it's served up with so abundant a desire to please and blessed with a cast like this one?
When it hits its stride, it's almost like a modern version of one of De Sica's neo-realist classics from the fifties...a superb, quietly devastating film.
Floridly awful...offers absolutely no surprises.
Nothing much...what once might have seemed witty and sophisticated now comes across as tired and recycled.
Part travelogue and part Lifetime liberated-woman-of-the-week movie...little more than a standard-issue (and standard-tissue) women's picture.
The picture seems...a rehash--a well-cooked one, perhaps, but a rehash nonetheless.
One of the oldest weepie plots in the book...doesn't quite transcend the essential staleness of its premise, but thanks to [Polley] it comes very close to doing so.
A one-joke farce so sour that it's more likely to cause an unsettled stomach than belly-laughs.
A sincere, well-meaning movie, but it's stilted and ponderous, all too representative of the worst failings of simplistic docudrama.
A surprisingly professional, smoothly realized adaptation...faithful to its source and sensitively translated into cinematic terms.
This strange mixture never gels...the idea might be clever, but the realization doesn't do it justice.
movie_title: Once Upon a Time in the Midlands (2003)

movie_review_blurb: The story makes little sense, while offering few surprises and even fewer scares...it might be a cinematic act of faith for some, but simply as a movie it's a travesty.
One of the happiest surprises of the fall season--a full-throated, energetic comedy...smart yet also slightly demented.
A dull, stolid attempt at a contemporary film noir, clumsily constructed and loaded with bad hard-boiled dialogue, slack direction and stilted acting...a no good movie.
Tries to be both genuinely scary and gruesomely funny...The mixture is sufficiently eccentric...to be worth a look--for those who can tolerate the abundant gore.
Feels like a mediocre Hong Kong movie lacking even the charm of misspelled subtitles or bad dubbing.
A sloppy, shambling farce..but Kutcher's amiability, Stamp's skill and the sporadically inventive slapstick make it more tolerable than you might expect.
So clueless about its subject that it's like being force-fed a 10-CD retrospective of Vanilla Ice's greatest hits...will send viewers fleeing up the aisles--faster than Seabiscuit.
A very good piece of rather easy didacticism, but it doesn't go much beyond that.
This isn't either 'Bollywood' or 'Hollywood' as much as 'Follywood.'
A good-natured but somewhat slack family film...rather stilted and didactic, like a Disney live-action feature from the fifties or sixties.
An anemic little paean to a type of Hollywood storytelling that would have been better left undisturbed.
Like VH-1 with a Spanish soundtrack...reasonably colorful and energetic, but ultimately it's just too empty and ephemeral to matter.
movie_title: The Other Side of the Bed (2003)

movie_review_blurb: 'Jeepers Creepers 2' isn't terrible, just mediocre...it adds nothing to the genre and, like most sequels, doesn't top the initial installment.
Though slight and rather frail, it's still modestly entertaining...and LaBeouf is well worth watching throughout.
Spade's version of 'The Wedding Singer'--a movie that might actually appeal to people who've previously found its star insufferable...a good-natured bit of family fluff.
A cheap, silly, tawdry supernatural thriller...a gloomy, goofy mess that's talky and tedious to boot.
At its best exhilarating and at its worst repetitious and curiously preachy, it's a mixed bag, but more diamond than zircon.
A lovely, loopy modern-day 'Brief Encounter' that has the wisdom not to push too hard or linger too long.
Eye-catching and moderately enjoyable...however, in spite of its many strengths the film winds up less clever than it obviously thinks it is.
Might have been intended as a homage, but winds up seeming more like a bad parody...pumps the adrenaline and feeds the eye but starves the brain.
movie_title: Once upon a Time in Mexico (2003)

movie_review_blurb: The emperor has no clothes...The good news is that the picture has an intermission, but the bad news is that it resumes after it.
At about half the length of the original 'Black Stallion,' it provides about 50% of its entertainment value, but the scenery is impressive in the big-screen format.
The final novel by the prolific Canadian author Brian Moore was, to be honest, not one of his finest, but it was better than Norman Jewison's film of it suggests.
So not scary that it's positively frightening--and not in a good sense...Just stamp it as you would a piece of unwanted mail: Return to sender.
Where's that can of Vapoorizer when you need it? Just aim it at the screen and push.
I'd rather be seeing other movies--and you'll probably feel the same way.
Austere in style but deeply humane in its outlook...a visually enthralling, spiritually uplifting film that portrays a man's journey from childish naivete to enlightenment.
If it actually lived up to its title and lasted a mere New York minute, it might be tolerable. Unfortunately, it drags on for ninety-three ordinary ones, and it's not.
Monstrously bad...Sommers not only plunders the classic films for material but trashes what he's cribbed from them.
Genuinely spiky and amusing...much sharper and funnier than most movies of its ilk.
For two hours or so, 'Troy' is a reasonably good boys' adventure story--a sort of Classics Comics version of Homer. In the final act, however, it goes haywire.
Bright, witty and very nearly without a dull patch, the rare followup that matches its predecessor.
A moderately engaging, visually lovely, if narratively commonplace tale of a precocious child and his dream of a family.
'An Officer and a Gentleman' refashioned as a sappy WB teen soap opera...a melodrama of astonishing flatness and insipidity.
Moves very slowly and tends to be repetitive, but it has a simmering intensity beneath its deceptively placid surface...quietly devastating.
movie_title: S21: The Khmer Rouge Death Machine (2004)

movie_review_blurb: If you decide to go see 'Super Size Me'--not a bad idea--you might want to skip that stop at the concession stand on the way into the auditorium.
Somber, almost clinically severe...ultimately 'Son Frere,' for all its admirable qualities, fails to move us.
A sadly ordinary bit of fluff, a romantic comedy that aims to be wacky and charming and winds up being neither.
While it's done up with gloss and good will, it falls far short of its models and winds up innocuous, but thin and decidedly creaky.
Earnest, plodding docudrama...Bobby Jones might have had a stroke of genius, but this reverential biography about him is a movie of mediocrity.
Requires an insupportable suspension of disbelief to swallow its convoluted and absurd scenario...still, it's made with a seriousness that's oddly refreshing.
Note well that Ella is enchanted, not enchanting...any charm it might have possessed is buried under reams of cuteness and silly anachronism.
A fast-moving, wonderfully rowdy, terrifically entertaining collage of stories...boasting some witty surprises on its way to a satisfying conclusion.
A big, sprawling movie with remarkably little grandeur; what's worse, it's emotionally hollow...with cardboard characterizations and wooden dialogue.
The original may not have offered a full nine yards of laughs, but the comedic value of this moronic sequel would have to be measured not even in inches, but in millimeters.
Artifice without true artistry...the writer-director means to excoriate American hubris, of course, but what he makes all too evident is his own.
Aptly titled: it's punishingly long, slow and tepid, as flat and glossy as any issue of the comic...a long-winded, curiously unexciting revenge fantasy.
A thriller, but a gorgeously lyrical one, an entrancing exercise in hyper-realism...like a cinematic dream, hazy and suggestive, atmospheric and moody, almost operatic.
movie_title: I'm Not Scared (Io non ho paura) (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Overall it may prove a letdown for those expecting the energy and deft takeoff-homage character of the previous film. Still, it has just enough going for it to get by.
An egomaniacal misfire...a foolproof defense against both CD and VHS/DVD piracy.
A curiously feeble wartime comedy...to be filed under the heading of 'Might Have Beens.'
'Some Like It Schlock' might be a better title for this cross-dressing comedy...entirely too strident in the pursuit of easy laughs and fuzzy emotions.
A really big yawn...No one whose age is into double digits will find much to enjoy in this gentle, innocuous and very dull feature.
A sprightly surprise...a girl's wish-fulfillment fantasy that's engaging rather than trying, a chick flick that even their dates can enjoy.
It doesn't delve much beneath the surface; and though that surface has been drawn with considerable effect, in the end it's not enough.
Cruelly underwritten but wildly overproduced, this latest Hollywood example of the vigilante vengeance movie is...at once sensorily fatiguing and intellectually dispiriting.
Though the picture is only sporadically powerful and shows a streak of sentimentality beneath its gritty exterior, its strengths outweigh the weaknesses.
An extravagantly florid romantic comedy in which the lead couple are so self-absorbed and obnoxious that a viewer can barely tolerate their presence.
The fact that it's an old story doesn't mean that this new telling of it doesn't, in its rather simple and unaffected way, carry considerable impact.
Degrades both those who chose to appear in it and those of us unfortunate enough to watch it.
An amalgam of very disparate elements that are never really integrated into a unified or compelling whole.
Judicious and revealing...despite some unfortunate omissions...Tune it in, and it may tell you something you didn't know--and entertain you as well.
Supremely condescending...If you need to look down on others to feel better about yourself, 'Napoleon Dynamite' is the movie for you.
Garish, frenetic, but curiously dull...suffers from a serious case of the cutes, a disease that in this case proves fatal.
One can only wish Dame Judi had been allowed to declaim at some point 'Alas, poor Riddick'...let's just hope there are no further chapters to these chronicles.
Neither scary nor funny...a cinematic clone gone terribly wrong.
Steven Spielberg and Tom Hanks serve up a heaping helping of Capracorn...and in their hands it's a reasonably palatable, though hardly gourmet, dish.
This comic riff on the Verne classic loses altitude as it proceeds, closing with a crash landing in more ways than one.
Once again, Hollywood's big-budget blockbusters are overshadowed by a small but infinitely more moving piece of expert non-fiction filmmaking.
As juvenile and lowbrow as the game itself, but it's surprisingly funny...if you give it a chance you may finding yourself laughing a lot more than you'd expect.
Like a fourth-generation duplicate of an original--curiously pale and tired although straining for vivacity and color.
movie_title: My Mother Likes Women (A mi madre le gustan las mujeres) (2002)

movie_review_blurb: A self-consciously arty piece that may be psychologically useful to its writer-director but is torture for its audience.
Can perhaps be commended for attempting to raise serious moral issues, but not for the ham-fisted way it does so.
A woefully unfunny slapstick farce in which even the makeup is bad.
Cassavetes directs this manipulative flummery with a crushingly heavy hand...Even if you yearn for an old-fashioned tearjerker, you should write off 'The Notebook.'
Frantic but flat, a picture so neutered and declawed that even toddlers will find it too bland for their taste.
In trying to add some spice to the customary formula, it winds up more tasteless than tasty...a distinctly uneasy combination of light and shade.
Infuriatingly obscure...a bit of rarefied madness that proves that Maddin's films are an acquired taste most of us are unlikely ever to acquire.
movie_title: The Saddest Music in the World (2004)

movie_review_blurb: It has a good deal of energy and a splashy visual style, but its mixture of dramatic recreation, interviews and social commentary succeeds only sporadically.
Though it sometimes seems as plodding as its burly protagonist,...an intriguing, if imperfect, piece of work.
Staged with almost newsreel precision but presented with the punch of a great political thriller..despite being half a century old, still has a powerful and pertinent message.
movie_title: The Battle of Algiers (La Battaglia di Algeri) (1967)

movie_review_blurb: Its unusual ambiance and quirky turns make it a peculiarly affecting addition to the coming-of-age genre.
Beckham never bent it like this...a delightful, if empty-headed treat.
The failure to blend very disparate elements satisfactorily marks the movie...Parts have an oddball charm, but too much of it is either flat or unappetizing.
Like a bad sitcom, it wants to make you smile while tugging at your heartstrings, but what it induces is a grimace and heartburn.
A promising premise without a successful follow-through...vacillates between preachy tract and bland comedy.
Clearly the work of a beginning filmmaker, modestly budgeted and variable in effect, but it shows promise.
Worth seeing because its odd, self-effacing subject is satisfying by reason of his very emptiness, and more than a little pathetic.
Modestly engaging, but ultimately the fragile little movie wipes out, like a surfer who's misjudged a wave.
Blizzards, tornados and floods--oh, my!...Just a brainless orgy of special effects periodically interrupted by sappy human-interest episodes.
A frail independent feature with an impressive cast but not much energy and equally little point.
Comes nowhere near scoring a satirical bull's-eye--a pity, given that its target is such an inviting one.
Hand out the barf bags...the level of tastelessness and vulgarity should cause cultural security checkpoints to go off.
A visually ravishing, narratively crisp treatment that represents a major advance on the earlier installments...not just a good Harry Potter movie; it's a good movie, period.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (2004)

movie_review_blurb: The work of a filmmaker so convinced of his own hipness and secure in his cult status that he needn't concern himself with such niceties as clever writing.
A determinedly weird, almost wordless Gallic concoction that casts a considerable spell even if it's not supposed to make much sense (and definitely succeeds in that respect).
Not only a blatant ripoff of 'National Lampoon's Vacation,' it's a lousy one besides.
The sort of Disney product that would be more at home on the tube or the video shelf than the big screen...at best an okay time-killer.
A lethargic movie that lopes and stumbles far more often than it springs to life.
A perfect bore that flunks every cinematic test.
About as engaging as watching a synchronized swimming meet minus the pool...if you pay to see this movie, you get snookered.
A major spring crowd-pleaser--'Seabiscuit' with pucks--but while the victory of Team USA in 1980 might have been miraculous, the movie reduces it to something pretty ordinary.
Earns a visit, if only by a hair...if the business isn't quite so brisk this time around, there's an amiable familiarity that warrants your continued patronage.
The pits...even by the appallingly low standards of the genre, 'Catch That Kid' is dismal.
It generates strong visceral impact while conveying the essentially inexplicable nature of such tragedies.
Has an attractive facade, but its apparent audacity turns out to be as empty-headed as its photogenic but vacuous lead characters.
The treatment is so meandering and flaccid that what might have been a spicy study of service capitalism instead proves a decidedly bland dish.
The makers sustain its fragile, delicate spirit with considerable skill...in its curiously muted, ruminative fashion it proves oddly affecting.
Decidedly a mixed bag--still, it has enough laughs and charm to be moderately engaging, a definite cut above the usual run of gross-out studio farces released nowadays.
With its unusual setting, winning characters and engaging performances, it's an affectionate coming-of-age tale whose sweetness never becomes cloying.
movie_title: Monsieur Ibrahim et les fleurs du Coran (Monsieur Ibrahim) (2003)

movie_review_blurb: A punch-drunk combination of pugilistic hokum and feminist empowerment fantasy.
Accomplished filmmaking and powerful human statement...Like mountain climbing itself, it's both thrilling and rather terrifying.
A road trip you should definitely not take...one of those movies that generates plenty of unintentional laughs as it drones on.
A minor but affecting story of men caught between their personal desires and societal expectations... distinguished by sharp writing and nicely understated acting.
Ultimately more chore than pleasant diversion. After sitting through nearly two hours of this movie, you might welcome a blackout yourself.
A loser...one date you'd be wise to turn down.
movie_title: Win a Date With Tad Hamilton! (2004)

movie_review_blurb: A wonderfully entertaining, old-fashioned melodrama of love and war.
Despite its virtues, the picture comes across rather like something that has itself been disinterred from the fairly remote past.
A student film of enormous ambition and modest attainment...precocious, perhaps, but also uncomfortably pretentious.
A solid and respectable piece about a man of enormous integrity and courage.
A masterpiece of misanthropy...an uncompromisingly bleak reverie on human misery and meanness.
Sweet, ultimately poignant portrait of a year in the life of a one-room school in Auvergne...an evocative, observant portrait.
movie_title: To Be and to Have (Etre et Avoir) (2003)

movie_review_blurb: A fine showcase for Theron's powerhouse performance, but in comparison to the great true-crime pictures of the past, it comes up short.
While it gets a good deal of the background right, the picture stumbles in the dramatic department.
Not everything Judge and Hertzfeldt have chosen is top-drawer, but their anthology contains enough gems to make it worth a look.
Fascinating, intense but disturbingly incomplete and one-sided...an accomplished, involving but highly selective account of a still-charged historical event.
A determinedly innocuous, moderately irritating, totally predictable and largely charmless bit of teen-pandering fluff.
A weird, off-the-wall bit of surrealistic nonsense that should keep the kiddies transfixed with its colorful characters and slapstick mayhem while amusing adults.
Successfuilly transforms the socio-political triaals of the region into a personal drama of great emotional resonance...comparable to the Italian neo-realist pictures.
It would need to move up several rungs on the evolutionary ladder to be classified as garbage...you come out feeling as though you've just been run over by a semi.
Mildly recommendable...The central romance is tepid, predictable stuff, but it's made more palatable by some sharply-written supporting characters who are brilliantly played.
A bit of political fluff several rungs below 'Dave' on the sharpness scale...a hundred minute dead spot punctuated by very occasional moments of feeble humor.
Sometimes doesn't match the extravagance of its subject, but the subject is nonetheless a fascinating one.
A gripping film...even more effective for being a somewhat muted, well-modulated one, characterized by resigned grief rather than anger.
Winds up seeming little more than a grisly exercise in well-calibrated acting and what one hopes are well-executed special effects.
'AKA' is DOA...boring, and boring in an irritatingly complicated way.
Drollness and dry wit characterize this charming Scandinavian comedy...a wryly affectionate story that will touch the heart of almost every viewer.
An uncommonly engaging tale of tradition, change and growth in a strangely haunting locale...its stylishness carries the film over most of the rough spots.
The fall of Communism in eastern Europe becomes the subject of a gentle satire tinged with melancholy in Wolfgang Becker's funny, touching 'Good Bye, Lenin!'
However well done, it's still nothing more than a live-action version of a mediocre old cartoon; and while affectionate and nicely tooled, it's no more than tolerable.
You might think you're trapped in a 'Bachelor Father' marathon...though it's hardly 'Gigli' redux, it's so mercilessly sweet and cloying that it might make you gagli.
'The Ladykillers in Big Momma's House'...a film that, despite some inspired moments, is alternately arch and crude.
Elegantly mounted and realized, to be sure, but basically a fairly conventional portrait of your typical noble rebel...it might have been much more.
So outlandishly bad that it actually incites a viewer's morbid curiosity: you watch it wondering how much worse it can get.
Something is rotten in the state of Denmark--and it's this movie, a flyweight romantic comedy.
Half parody and half homage, this comic throwback to Hollywood's lavish wartime romances of the forties and fifties is almost entirely enjoyable.
Maybe it does as well as anyone could with this rambunctious but extravagantly self-indulgent festival; unfortunately, that isn't much.
Tugs at the heart more than it warms it...a lovely-looking film, but hardly the emotional powerhouse some are suggesting.
The rare labor of love that should both satisfy die-hard fans and excite newcomers as well.
Nothing more than an efficiently-manufactured piece of crowd-pleasing vicarious violence, but it does what it sets out to do, even if that isn't much.
There isn't much here that you haven't encountered in lots of other horror movies, but you'll rarely have seen the familiar elements delivered so effectively.
Deadly serious, almost funereal...a pretentious, dreary film, which is also frustratingly unenlightening.
Another unpleasantly glib, shallow demonstration of Kaufman's self-satisfied cleverness, further marred by failed pretensions to profundity about romantic destiny.
movie_title: Eternal Sunshine Of The Spotless Mind (2004)

movie_review_blurb: While this Israeli domestic drama might seem on the surface like a made-for-TV movie, it's a clear step above that.
'Eurotrash' is more like it--even the opening animated credits are repulsive.
A juvenile 'I Love Lucy' episode...that's more irritating than charming.
movie_title: Confessions of a Teenage Drama Queen (2004)

movie_review_blurb: The 1987 original was no prize, but it dances circles around this cinematic misstep.
It definitely makes the viewer suffer--but it's debatable if by itself that's a truly enlightening contribution to one's understanding of Christ's message.
It's not horrible--which for these guys is a real step up, though not enough of one.
A supremely dumb who's-doing-it concoction so crowded with red herrings that it smells like a fish market...all the twists in 'Twisted' end up going nowhere.
Reeks of mediocrity...the show was hardly a classic, but even so this insipid remolding doesn't do it justice.
While the picture is well-meaning and handsomely mounted, many will find it too formulaic, earnest and leisurely to be much more than a barely passable diversion.
In the final reckoning, this modern version of a medieval morality play, with its fine surface but problematic plot, proves more impressive for its body than its soul.
Though you might admire bits and pieces of it, overall this movie is unlikely to be the object of anyone's affection.
It's a good, solid, enlightening piece of work on an interesting, engaging topic.
This uninspired, maladroit entry should insure that 'Cody' won't be bankable for long, and that his days as a cinematic 'Agent' are numbered.
Surprisingly earnest and sedate...the sort of perfunctorily informative instructional film that might be the first leg on a guided tour of a NASCAR museum.
For all its last-act problems, the picture's stylishness, genuinely unsettling atmosphere and spectacular lead performances make it an enjoyably creepy thrill-ride.
A serious disappointment...one Mamet shell-game that's not worth laying down a bet on.
A serial-killer-tracked-by-female-detective movie so preposterously contrived that by rights it should star Ashley Judd...more likely to evoke snickers than gasps.
An almost perfect embodiment of the spirit of its subject: it's slick, self-serving and amusing but ultimately rather shallow, more apologia than analysis.
movie_title: The Kid Stays in the Picture (2002)

movie_review_blurb: A clumsy, charmless pastiche of nineteenth-century escapist tales told with twenty-first century technology and attitude--arch, muddled and bereft of characters one can care about in the slightest.
A giddily goofy bit of old-fashioned nonsense, a swashbuckler with supernatural overtones and a jolly sense of fun that keeps it surprisingly light on its feet.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl (2003)

movie_review_blurb: A very slow, uneventful ride around a pretty tattered old carousel.
movie_title: Love in the Time of Money (2002)

movie_review_blurb: A harmless, though instantly forgettable and utterly brainless, diversion...a popcorn movie that isn't terribly good, but is better than it might have been.
Like its predecessor, it's no classic, but it provides a reasonably attractive holiday contraption, one that families looking for a clean, kid-friendly outing should investigate.
A small miracle of a film, a pitch-perfect homage to American films of the fifties that becomes genuinely moving in its own right...elegant and astonishingly eloquent.
Bad girl, worse movie...In the De Palma oeuvre, ranks toward the very bottom, somewhere between 'Body Double' and 'Raising Cain' on the one hand and 'Mission to Mars' on the other.
Basically recycles all the old, tired cliches that abound in every story about the rise to stardom of poor but talented youngsters who overcome terrible obstacles in their drive to succeed.
A soggy, shapeless mess...just a dumb excuse for a waterlogged equivalent of a haunted-house movie.
More dutiful than enchanting...terribly episodic and lacking the spark of imagination that might have made it an exhilarating treat.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Could as easily have been called 'Under Siege 3: In Alcatraz'...a cinematic corpse that never springs to life.
Exhibits the shallow sensationalism characteristic of soap opera...more salacious telenovela than serious drama.
Ourside the theatre Roger might be intolerable company, but inside it he's well worth spending some time with.
Doesn't fully recapture the magic of the Connery films, but avoids the torpor which has afflicted most of the later ones...there's a pulse in the old boy yet.
Both ploddingly earnest and curiously phony...the surface gloss can't disguise the emptiness of what lies within.
A mixed bag: there are a few cheerful presents in it, but more lumps of coal; and some of it is ho-ho-horrible.
In comparison to his earlier films it seems a disappointingly thin slice of lower-class London life; despite the title...amounts to surprisingly little.
A simpler, leaner treatment would have been preferable; after all, being about nothing is sometimes funnier than being about something.
Like being trapped at a perpetual frat party...How can something so gross be so boring?
Graceless and inelegant...the sad truth about 'Charlie' is that while it isn't a complete travesty, it would have been better left unmade.
Distinctly sub-par...more likely to drown a viewer in boredom than to send any shivers down his spine.
Has a shambling charm...a cheerfully inconsequential diversion.
Hardly an objective documentary, but it's great cinematic polemic...love Moore or loathe him, you've got to admire...the intensity with which he's willing to express his convictions.
Apparently designed as a reverie about memory and regret, but the only thing you'll regret is remembering the experience of sitting through it.
movie_title: In Praise Of Love (Éloge de l'amour) (2002)

movie_review_blurb: A recipe for cinematic disaster...part Quentin Tarantino, part Guy Ritchie, and part 1960s spy spoof, it's all bad.
Something has been lost in the translation...another routine Hollywood frightfest in which the slack execution italicizes the absurdity of the premise.
Sharp, shrewd and observant...a small gem of a movie.
The lack of naturalness makes everything seem self-consciously poetic and forced...It's a pity that [Nelson's] achievement doesn't match his ambition.
A creepy, intermittently powerful study of a self-destructive man...about as unsettling to watch as an exploratory medical procedure or an autopsy.
'Abandon all hope, ye who enter here'...you should definitely let Dante's gloomy words be your guide.
The mixture of high artistry, visual poetry and depth of meaning makes for an endlessly fascinating and compelling film.
It takes you somewhere you're not likely to have seen before, but beneath the exotic surface (and exotic dancing) it's surprisingly old-fashioned.
All too familiar...basically the sort of cautionary tale that was old when 'Angels With Dirty Faces' appeared in 1938.
Cruel and inhuman cinematic punishment... simultaneously degrades its characters, its stars and its audience.
An old-fashioned, Hollywoodish biopic, oddly unimaginative in everything but its visuals.
Quite simply, a joy to watch and--especially--to listen to.
movie_title: Standing in the Shadows of Motown (2002)

movie_review_blurb: There's a certain raggedness and preachiness to the picture, but ultimately its simplicity and basic integrity shine through and compensate for the flaws.
A fast-paced, glitzy but extremely silly piece.
For most of the distance the picture provides a satisfyingly unsettling ride into the dark places of our national psyche.
Meeting, even exceeding expectations, it's the best sequel since The Empire Strikes Back ... a majestic achievement, an epic of astonishing grandeur and surprising emotional depth.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers (2002)

movie_review_blurb: A very stylish but ultimately extremely silly tale...a slick piece of nonsense but nothing more.
A powerful, compelling and intelligent if imperfect work...a film of enormous ambition which realizes its aims more often than not.
Like a medium-grade network sitcom--mostly inoffensive, fitfully amusing, but ultimately so weightless that a decent draft in the auditorium might blow it off the screen.
A crowd-pleasing tearjerker...a film whose earnestness and dignity almost (though not quite) overcome the narrative's sentimentality and lack of surprise.
Lee's best film in years...raises essentially pulpish material to the level of moody cinematic poetry.
A glib but bouncy bit of sixties-style slickness in which the hero might wind up caught but the audience gets pure escapism.
It's a great deal of sizzle and very little steak. But what spectacular sizzle it is!...In this incarnation its fizz is infectious.
A grave disappointment...oppressively intricate and melancholy without offering much compensatory insight.
A portrait of alienation so perfect, it will certainly succeed in alienating most viewers.
An empty exercise, a florid but ultimately vapid crime melodrama with lots of surface flash but little emotional resonance.
Refined and reserved but still haunting...one of the finer non-documentary films yet made about the deepest stain on twentieth-century history.
Works better in the conception than it does in the execution...winds up seeming just a little too clever.
May be Dickens Lite, but taken on its own slick, genteel terms it's a surprisingly winning confection...a film of wit and style.
Benigni's folly...In every sense of the word, the picture is just frightful; it will either terrify children or bore them to tears, and adults will be rightly appalled by it.
A formula family tearjerker told with a heavy Irish brogue...accentuating, rather than muting, the plot's saccharine thrust.
Rather slight, with a sweet-and-sour mood that doesn't quite gel...a comparatively lightweight piece that dissipates as soon as the final credits roll.
A tired, derivative picture that suggests it's time to put at least this crew of Trekkers into well-deserved retirement.
Showcases what's easily one of the year's best performances, and it's thoroughly delightful besides...one of the jewels of recent American film.
A winningly fresh take on a tale that has never gone out of style...Disney has done Stevenson proud.
A complex, ambitious film...one can't help but admire the film's reach, even when the goal exceeds Egoyan's grasp.
A chilly, remote, emotionally distant piece...so dull that its tagline should be: 'In space, no one can hear you snore.'
An astonishingly tasteless combination of gross sentimentality and simple grossness.
The plot is so infantile and the characters so uniformly obnoxious that it's impossible to care about what's going to happen next.
When you find yourself rooting for the monsters in a horror movie, you know the picture is in trouble.
A muckraking job, the cinematic equivalent of a legal indictment, and a fairly effective one at that.
A fascinating piece...assured and frequently witty.
A thin, smug conceit, and one that gets more tired and exasperating as it goes along...clever, but in a juvenile, self-indulgent fashion.
A flaccid sci-fi opus slavishly modeled on 'Fahrenheit 451'...flat and antiseptic.
A tired, unnecessary retread...a stale copy of a picture that wasn't all that great to begin with.
Just a piece of flashy trash, disheartening in terms of both its empty cinematic pizzazz and its calculated amorality.
As flimsy and predictable as they come, but still a reasonably tolerable bit of formulaic fluff.
When it tries to be funny it's usually appalling, but when it attempts to be sweet it's truly nauseating.
A refreshingly honest and ultimately touching tale of the sort of people usually ignored in contemporary American film. Search it out.
A thoroughly formulaic movie...the only truly new element here is the musicmaking background, and it's a fairly easy transplant.
Piercingly affecting...while clearly a manipulative film, emerges as powerful rather than cloying.
A Dickensian story recast for the age of Oprah...well-meaning but episodic and ultimately pat.
Synthetic and rather bland--more like 'Brown NutraSweet.'
Something like a pint-sized, pitiable British version of 'Beaches'...an arch and obvious bit of soap opera twaddle.
While unsettling, it's also chilly and unmoving. One has to admire its craftsmanship, but in the end it proves oddly unsatisfying--not unlike Williams' performance in it.
Demonstrates that a one-joke movie can work just fine if the joke's a good one and is well delivered...a delicious takeoff on the culture of celebrity.
Sugary sweet, heavily didactic and relentlessly uplifting, it should probably come with a warning that diabetics could be endangered by watching it.
The only thing indisputable here is that lots of talent has been frittered away on a really silly and formulaic story.
From the viewer's perspective 'Suffering Sara' or 'Surviving Sara' might be more apt...a serving of 'Sara' that you'd do well to decline.
So muddled, repetitive and ragged that it says far less about the horrifying historical reality than about the filmmaker's characteristic style.
Boasts enough funny dialogue and sharp characterizations to be mildly amusing.
Might have been played as a glum cautionary tale, but in Toback's hands it becomes a lark--flashy, florid and blissfully over-the-top.
Transcends the technical limitations and emerges as an oddly funny and ultimately quite affecting film...a heartfelt fable.
Exuberant but chaotic...likely to speak to the already converted. Others will probably find the journey a rather bewildering salute.
Glizty but formulaic and silly...Cagney's 'top of the world' has been replaced by the bottom of the barrel.
A big, plush, overripe tale of misguided passion, a richly illustrated but grossly simplified and romanticized history lesson that plays like a period soap opera.
A vile, incoherent mess...a scummy ripoff of David Cronenberg's brilliant 'Videodrome.'
A shrewd blend of crisp humor and restrained heart-tugging, likely to prove very appealing to American audiences.
Like Disney's Pluto, this one is a dog. Cave canem.
A lovely film...elegant, witty and beneath a prim exterior unabashedly romantic...hugely enjoyable in its own right though not really faithful to its source's complexity.
Despite the deep-ocean setting, it has all the profundity of a kiddie wading-pool...The banality of the script is matched only by the ineptitude of the acting and direction.
True to its animatronic roots:...as stiff, ponderous and charmless as a mechanical apparatus...'The Country Bears' should never have been brought out of hibernation.
Any gold in this edition of the franchise is mostly of the fools' variety...a hit-and-miss affair that misses more often than not.
The real question this movie poses is not 'Who?' but 'Why?'
Its rawness and vitality give it considerable punch.
An alternately raucous and sappy ethnic sitcom...you'd be wise to send your regrets.
A visually flashy but narratively opaque and emotionally vapid exercise in style and mystification.
Uncommonly stylish but equally silly...the picture fails to generate much suspense, nor does it ask searching enough questions to justify its pretensions.
Chaotic, self-indulgent and remarkably ugly to look at, it's...like a series of pretentiously awful student films strung together into one feature-length horror.
Surrealistically horrid...it's all about makeup and completely lacking in wit, style or even simple dumb fun.
Smug, artificial, ill-constructed and fatally overlong...it never finds a consistent tone and lacks bite, degenerating into a pious, preachy soap opera.
A subtly creepy, gently disturbing portrait of a genuinely disturbed man...The point of the exercise might not be apparent, but its artistry certainly is.
A flashy but curiously heartless exhibition of technical wizardry...wildly colorful, crammed with special effects and incessantly busy, but largely devoid of charm.
movie_title: Spy Kids 2: The Island of Lost Dreams (2002)

movie_review_blurb: It's a boom-box of a movie that might have been titled 'The Loud and the Ludicrous'...the pandering to a moviegoing audience dominated by young males is all too calculated.
A shrewd, observant ensemble comedy-drama...A little film that cannily melds edgy satire with a degree of warmth and even a touch of profundity.
Sometimes this 'Blood' seems as tired as its protagonist...Still, the pulse never disappears entirely, and the picture crosses the finish line winded but still game.
If you're willing to surrender to its languid, indirect style and its offbeat comic sense, you may find it a rich and rewarding little film.
Earnest but earthbound...a slow, soggy, soporific, visually dank crime melodrama/character study that would be more at home on the small screen but for its stellar cast.
A waterlogged version of 'Fatal Attraction' for the teeny-bopper set...a sad, soggy potboiler that wastes the talents of its attractive young leads.
More vaudeville show than well-constructed narrative, but on those terms it's inoffensive and actually rather sweet.
It gets onto the screen just about as much of the novella as one could reasonably expect, and is engrossing and moving in its own right.
A pleasant ramble through the sort of idoosyncratic terrain that Errol Morris has often dealt with...it does possess a loose, lackadaisical charm.
Never transcends its basically soapoperatic premise in the way that 'In the Bedroom' actually did...will be remembered more for its potential than for what it actually delivers.
An action comedy whose action elements are flat and whose comic ones are lame...ordinary and rather dull.
Offers very little genuine romance and even fewer laughs...a sad sitcom of a movie, largely devoid of charm.
A dismally unfunny clunker...Do yourself a favor and just kiss it off.
A film at once depressing and uplifting--depressing in terms of the sad, often horrifying subjects of Nachtwey's photographs but uplifting in terms of his commitment and integrity.
Impresses as a skillfully assembled, highly polished and professional adaptation...just about as chilling and unsettling as 'Manhunter' was.
Where's a Vegamatic when you really need one?
Astonishingly skillful and moving...it could become a historically significant work as well as a masterfully made one.
Half of it is composed of snappy patter and pseudo-sophisticated cultural observations, while the remainder...would be more at home on a daytime television serial.
A synthesis of cliches and absurdities that seems positively decadent in its cinematic flash and emptiness.
Russell...treats the story with such solemnity and reverence that the picture seems an embalming rather than a realization...earnest but earthbound.
Will make your eyes ache while offering little compensatory insight or emotional contact...a cold, crass exhibitionist exercise without heart or soul.
Just another combination of bad animation and mindless violence...lacking the slightest bit of wit or charm.
One of the year's most beguiling films...it has the fizz of fine champagne and delivers a wonderful kick.
A pint-sized 'Goodfellas' designed to appeal to the younger set, it's not a very good movie in any objective sense, but it does mostly hold one's interest.
A thoroughly awful movie--dumb, narratively chaotic, visually sloppy...a weird amalgam of 'The Thing' and a geriatric 'Scream.'
Nasty, repellent and dull...a sleazy, sensationalistic but curiously boring kidnap tale that wastes the talents of its starry cast.
Instead of 'The Royal Tenenbaums,' a viewer might be inclined to term the result 'The Royal Pains'...you can admire its attempts at wit without finding the actual outcome terribly funny.
Quote not available.
Contains many haunting moments and some striking shards of dialogue, but overall it's an uneven, often pretentious effort.
Combines some wonderfully imaginative visuals with a plot that, to put it charitably, will seem loony to most American viewers.
Gorgeous to look at but insufferably tedious and turgid...a curiously constricted epic.
Intimate in its narrative structure but almost operatically extravagant in its cinematic gestures, it's a genuine find...enormous fun to watch.
Not as painful as you might expect, but it is flat, shapeless and largely devoid of laughs...even Greenless it still wouldn't be much more than relentlessly mediocre.
The humor is forced and heavy-handed, and occasionally simply unpleasant.
The level of comic invention is surprisingly low, and the resultant amusement spotty at best.
A totally synthetic, artificial movie...like a two-hour sitcom in desperate need of a laughtrack.
A sly dissection of the inanities of the contemporary music business and a rather sad story of the difficulties of artistic collaboration.
movie_title: I Am Trying to Break Your Heart (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Considering the harsh locations and demanding stunts, this must have been a difficult shoot, but the movie proves rough going for the audience as well.
A shambles of a movie--visually unattractive, unbearably loud and utterly silly...its hilarity is completely unintentional.
A romantic film designed to make viewers queasy rather than comfortably content...far from a great movie, but Spader's is a great performance.
Remains a solid, if somewhat heavy-handed, account of the near-disaster...done up by Howard with a steady, if not very imaginative, hand.
Hardly a masterpiece, but it introduces viewers to a good charitable enterprise and some interesting real people.
A mesmerizing, hallucinatory fable of loss...vibrant with cinematic craft and visual magic.
If you've cared for Almodovar's previous work, you should like it; if not, it may strike you as equally contrived and vaguely unpleasant.
A journey that's too random and inconclusive to be compelling, but which Hoffman's brilliance almost makes worth taking.
Loaded with wow-inducing effects, but on the narrative level it shoots blanks.
Enjoyable enough as a lark and lovely to look at, but totally synthetic and artificial.
One of the rare female coming-of-age stories in which the overall sense of authenticity more than compensates for the narrative lapses.
Really just a bleaker variant of 'The Breakfast Club.'
A cinematic puzzle that's more schematic than natural, and one with a distinctly sour aftertaste, but despite the artificiality it still works.
An elegant, amusing odd-couple divertissement...made not only tolerable but pleasurable by Leconte's austerely patrician style, Rochefort's roguish charm and Hallyday's deadpan authority.
movie_title: The Man on the Train (L'homme du train) (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Efficient, if cloying, crowd-pleaser...it does manage to hit its target, even if it's aiming very low.
A great literary mystery...even though its subject is an author who, from the purely practical point of view, was a 'failure,' it proves an uplifting, even joyful, experience.
Take evasive action--serpentine, serpentine!
Mighty bad, like a lowbrow version of 'It's a Wonderful Life' rewritten by the Farrelly Brothers for a middle-aged Jerry Lewis.
An intriguing combination of lower-class neo-realism and lush romantic fable...a mostly vital, vivid experience.
A pretty good car commercial, but not much of a movie.
Children and adults alike should be enchanted...as quietly charming, cheekily amusing a family feature as you're likely to encounter this summer.
Slight and overly eager to impress with its flourishes, but sufficiently brisk and colorful to prove satisfying nonetheless.
If you think of it as the cinematic equivalent of a dental appointment that's less painful than you'd anticipated, you'll have a fairly accurate notion of its quality.
A fascinating case study...the leisurely, almost rambling approach that James has adopted eventually pays dividends.
Narratively slight but wonderfully vivid and genuinely moving.
Little more than an adolescent wish-fulfillment fantasy so familiar that it's like pre-chewed bubble gum.
A wealth of beautiful, breathtaking close-up shots of flocks on the wing...and yet...rather repetitive and strangely detached.
Torquemada had nothing on this Spanish torture chamber of a movie...supposed to be a romantic comedy, but proves to be neither.
Surprisingly winning...In terms of both content and style, 'Holes' is far from being as empty as its title suggests--and as pictures targeted at youngsters usually are.
What starts out as a stylish bit of hokum has degenerated into a bloated, banal farrago of cliches by the end.
No more than a benign time-waster, not consistently funny enough to recommend, but the fact that it isn't the horror its trailers suggested is itself a relief.
An unforced, affectionately mocking picture which might not generate a constant gale of laughter, but does invite a steady stream of smiles and chuckles.
Viscerally exciting but emotionally cool...It fills the eye even as it fails to touch the heart.
Doesn't avoid being a bit too solemn and self-important, but its intelligent craftsmanship and good intentions go far to make up for it.
A simple tale of an unlikely friendship, but thanks to the gorgeous locales and exceptional lead performances, it has considerable charm.
A stifling, tedious experience...Follow the lead of its title and cross this misfire off your list.
Doesn't live up to the best examples of the con-game genre, but thanks to the efforts of the colorful cast, the sleight-of-hand is sufficiently dexterous to make it a pleasant, if empty, diversion.
Absurdly intricate and intricately absurd...like a slickly-produced puzzle whose pieces fit together just fine, but when completed depicts a scene not worth looking at.
An urban cousin of 'On Golden Pond' that sinks under the weight of all the banal domestic tragicomedy it's forced to bear.
Very much like its predecessor: slickly made but overstuffed with characters and excessively busy.
Despite Bardem's charisma and an intriguing scenario based on historical events, it's flabby and more than faintly self-indulgent.
Turgid and self-indulgent...haphazardly constructed and featuring dialogue that sounds poorly improvised--as well as a central character who's less a human being than a collection of cliches.
Less a gripping drama than a stimulating bit of polemic.
A serious and well-intentioned film, but a stylistically ponderous, dramatically muddled one.
'Deliverance' us! In this case the wrong turn is into the theater parking lot.
A profoundly disturbing film, but a brilliant one...It portrays the disintegration of an American family in a fashion that would have done Eugene O'Neill proud.
Lee has at once been faithful to the pop source material and invested it with surprising dramatic resonance...looks very much like a comic, but feels deeper and richer.
There's very little sense to what's going on here, but the makers serve up the cliches with considerable dash.
Wants very much to mimic the screwball comedies of the forties with a gay twist, but the script and direction are simply too clumsy to carry it off.
Colorful but decidedly brain-dead...just a mediocre piece of fluff, and the fact that it could have been worse isn't much consolation.
Despite moments when the exotic spell it creates is intoxicating, the film as a whole is ungainly and, in the end, not very enlightening.
An admirably controlled exercise...in its chily, discreet way it manages to touch an emotional nerve--due in no small measure to Hoffman's extraordinary performance.
Makes it clear that the Pangs have an eye, so to speak, for unnerving visuals. It's a pity that they're not quite so adept in script construction and plotting.
Relentlessly grim and gruesome, it does what it sets out to do; the problem is that apparently what it wants isn't so much to give us a pleasant scare as to disgust us.
Proves that a female buddy-action movie can be every bit as brainless and aggravating as those starring guys...feels as though it had been written by the trio's resident scatterbrain Natalie.
The hero's boat makes it back to port after a multitude of near-disasters, but the movie sinks...though visually pretty, it's bland, and though filled with action, it's curiously enervated.
movie_title: Sinbad: Legend of the Seven Seas (2003)

movie_review_blurb: A Capitol crime...a garish, dull-witted sitcom as empty-headed as its heroine.
A superfluous sequel...while the movie is as smooth and efficient as one of the cyborgs that populate the series, it's also just as soulless.
A moodily effective thriller that in the end also works as a clever commentary on the creative process.
Technically 'Secret Lives' is quite ordinary, but the people to whom it introduces us are far from that...this unassuming little film is very powerful indeed.
movie_title: Secret Lives: Hidden Children and Their Rescuers During WWII (2001)

movie_review_blurb: While the leads imagine themselves in love, you have to imagine you're being entertained by them.
Total garbage...visually vile, to be sure...but what's worse is that it's a crushing bore.
Though 'City of Ghosts' can't match its models, it takes us close enough to Greeneland to be a worthy homage and an impressive, though flawed, debut...well worth a look.
A slight, wispy confection that never manages to take wing.
An absorbing film that will send you home with a real affection for these kids...emerges as a champion in its own right.
A remarkable film, a visionary poem to the Russian past that washes over the viewer like an ancient, half-remembered dream.
A brilliant comic cry of pain, a surrealistically piercing protest at what its maker sees as brutal oppression and chooses to attack with satire rather than rocks or bombs.
'2 Fast' '2 Furious' = "4 Pity's Sake, Spare Us No. 3,' Isn't much beyond the level of a repeat episode of 'Fastlane.'
Has its heart in the right place, and in Castle-Hughes it boasts a young protagonist of charm and energy; it's just a pity the rest of the film isn't quite worthy of her.
Strikes a melodramatic, soap operatic tone...doesn't penetrate deep enough to touch a raw emotional nerve.
movie_title: Under the Skin of the City (Zir-e Poust-e Shahr) (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Corny, but it's mostly flavorful corn, and one feels it really comes from the heart.
Grows more and more ludicrous, like some compendium episode of 'Dallas' or 'Dynasty,' but with snow.
A deadpan delight...a graceful, quietly humorous tribute to the sort of fringe-dwellers rarely seen in mainstream movies, let alone treated with such affection and respect.
Has its moments...but it never manages to be as clever--or as amusing--as Roberts apparently thinks it is.
A rather aimless, soggy affair, without much energy or charm.
For the most part this is--if you'll pardon the expression--a sadly flat-footed cop caper.
Just goes from worst to worster...a true endurance test for any viewer with an IQ above those of its two lead characters.
movie_title: Dumb and Dumberer: When Harry Met Lloyd (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Too disjointed, derivative and stylistically clumsy to be much more than an irritant.
A lacerating portrait of an abused, impoverished youth drawn to a life of crime and violence...startlingly fresh and deeply moving.
A colorful, vibrant introduction to a universal human impulse, lushly photographed and beautifully recorded.
Elegantly crafted but emotionally cold, a puzzle whose intricate construction one can admire but is difficult to connect with on any deeper level.
A voyage of discovery that's generally absorbing and sometimes breathtaking, though some of the directorial choices are unnecessarily glitzy.
Isn't bad enough to get really furious about, but in view of the talent it wastes, mild irritation is certainly in order.
The inventiveness of the death scenes isn't quite enough to compensate for the dullness of the rest, but it comes close.
Suffers from a nearly fatal case of sequelitis...stumbles more often than it flies.
Practically laughless...most viewers will plead for deliverance not just from Eva, but from the whole movie.
Cinematic costume jewelry...a more appropriate title would be 'How to Lose an Audience in 10 Minutes.'
movie_title: How to Lose a Guy in 10 Days (2003)

movie_review_blurb: There's an excellent 90-minute film here; unfortunately, it runs for 170.
Despite its visual virtuosity, 'Naqoyqatsi' is banal in its message and the choice of material to convey it.
Basically a slow, lazy soap opera that just happens to be set in the world of California bike gangs...the intimate scenes plod mercilessly, shapeless and distended.
More squeaky echo than rambunctious roar...resolutely lacks enchantment.
At once overly old-fashioned in its sudsy plotting and heavy-handed in its effort to modernize it with encomia to diversity and tolerance.
Little more than a pale contemporary version of 'L.A. Confidential'...strident and pat.
A dismally unfunny, crass and rambling farce that flunks out on every conceivable level.
An honorable try, but also a trying picture...While the battle recreations are expertly done, everything else in the movie has a stilted, historical-pageant feel.
On the scales of cinematic justice, the picture's good intentions are outweighed by its heavy-handed preachiness and its lurid approach.
A picture of fits and starts, sometimes touching and occasionally insightful, but overall quite artificial and affected.
Ironically, the problem with 'Daredevil' is that it takes absolutely no risks...even when you're watching it for the first time, it feels like a movie you've already seen.
Good-natured, whimsical and actually pretty funny...offers little that's new, but at least it adds some welcome ethnic zest to its familiar formula.
A gaudy, contrived bit of cinematic legerdemain thick with style and atmosphere but distinctly short on logic and sense.
Tone-deaf and structurally flaccid, 'May' is little more than a Troma movie with unrealized pretensions...In short, 'May' not.
Neither revelatory nor truly edgy--merely crassly flamboyant and comedically labored.
Families who have warmed to it around their television sets or enjoyed the stage adaptation will jump at the chance to see it on the big screen again.
By maintaining a modest stance and a gentle, affectionate tone it emerges as winning rather than wearying.
An implausible, manipulative but moderately enjoyable crowd-pleaser.
Comes across like an audio book to which photos have been rather unnecessarily added.
A sensitive, cultivated treatment of Greene's work as well as a remarkably faithful one.
Sharp psychological thriller...about mothers and children.
movie_title: Alias Betty (Betty Fisher and Other Stories)(Betty Fisher et autres histoires) (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Just terrible...a witless, moronic bore.
A chilly, brooding but quietly resonant psychological study of domestic tension and unhappiness.
movie_title: Comment j'ai tué mon père (My Father and I) (2001)

movie_review_blurb: A weird combination of Jerry Bruckheimer action flick and cartoonish kiddie movie...far too flimsy and formulaic a farce to linger in anybody's memory very long.
A pretty lame, crude affair...but the agreeable cast make it more palatable than it would otherwise have been.
A slapsticky buddy action-comedy so bad that it's hard to decide who's dumber: the two guards at the center of things or the filmmakers who've put them there.
A sincere but dramatically conflicted gay coming-of-age tale.
Vastly enjoyable--a stylish, affectionate, old-fashioned swashbuckler...staged with such elan that the result is completely winning.
The truly frightening darkness...is when the house lights dim and this wretched excuse for a thriller starts up...a chaotic jumble of horror movie tropes.
A minor masterpiece of moviemaking tragicomedy that will fascinate buffs.
May work better as a cinematic puzzle than as a pure thriller, but it still makes for an enjoyable ride.
movie_title: He Loves Me, He Loves Me Not (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Though it offers little new information, the very intimacy of the project gives it surprising power.
Certainly cinematic junk food, but it's slickly fashioned and packaged.
You'd have to go back to 'Gilligan's Island' to find an equally bad comedic shipwreck...leaves no leering or vulgar gag unused and no stereotype unexplored in its search for cheap laughs.
Pretty much DOA...a thoroughly artificial contraption in which the seams show and the revelations lack the sense of inevitability that would have made them satisfying.
When these four fellows deliver their best material, the picture delivers, too.
movie_title: Blue Collar Comedy Tour: The Movie (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Just call it 'Cormageddon.' Come to think of it, given its hokey, jokey quality 'Corn-mageddon' might be more apt.
Despite that big grin Rock is famous for flashing, 'Head of State' is utterly toothless.
The strength of the film comes not from any cinematic razzle-dazzle but from its recovery of an historical episode that, in the simple telling, proves simultaneously harrowing and uplifting.
Wasn't particularly good last year, when it was called 'The Princess Diaries,' and it's even worse the second time around.
Vin Diesel tries to stretch in 'A Man Apart,' and it's not a pretty sight.
More loud than funny...Maybe a few years down the line Griffin can give it another shot.
A thin conceit...slick, hyperkinetic but utterly superficial. You just might want to hang up.
An easygoing charmer...The point isn't the plot, but the people and the style. And in this respect 'The Good Thief' succeeds nicely.
The big-screen treatment allows the creators' vision to bloom in a way it could never quite do on the tube, but in essence the movie is an expanded episode of the show.
movie_title: Cowboy Bebop: The Movie (Kaubôi Bibappu: Tengoku no Tobira) (2003)

movie_review_blurb: A graceful, moving tribute to the courage of New York's finest and a nicely understated expression of the grief shared by the nation at their sacrifice.
Drugs may be bad, but this movie is worse. Do yourself a favor and just say no.
A deliciously decadent, delightfully twisted and masterfully macabre tale.
Loses altitude faster than AMR stock.
If 'Tomorrow' has the feel of an afterschool special, it's a surprisingly good one.
An unholy mess that's nonetheless full of holes...a senseless hodgepodge of genre cliches.
A picture of lovely simplicity and directness that reveals something of the complexity of the human heart with marvelous understatement.
Filled with crude stereotypes...the odd couple pairing fizzles instead of sending off sparks.
The overwhelming reaction must be one of distaste at seeing so real a human tragedy turned into so false a combination of gung-ho theatrics, pious pontificating and mawkish melodrama.
An incredibly irritating comedy about thoroughly vacuous people...manages to embody the worst excesses of nouvelle vague without any of its sense of fun or energy.
movie_title: God Is Great and I'm Not (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Although the result sometimes feels rushed, overstuffed and technically a bit too flashy, the emotional resonance of the subject wins out over the stylistic hyperbole.
movie_title: Amandla! A Revolution in Four-Part Harmony (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Both heartbreaking and heartwarming...just a simple fable done in an artless sytle, but it's tremendously moving.
Irredeemable...just a pointlessly nasty violence-and-vengeance tale told backwards for 'effect.'
While structurally dense and very deliberately paced, it's also surprisingly delicate, almost gossamer...the work of a great filmmaker at the top of his form.
The episodes seem strained, the characters sketchy and underdeveloped, and the connections among them contrived.
A long dirge of a movie, beautifully photographed...but plodding and affected.
A laboriously manufactured sitcom that strings together a small army of cliches and stereotypes in its determination to become a guaranteed crowd-pleaser.
Just too familiar and unimaginative to be anything more than a forgettable time-waster for undemanding family audiences.
A baroque black comedy...if you're in the right mood, the combination of over-the-top camp and sinister style will be rather a hoot.
Little more than a vapid exercise in mood and mayhem.
May not be the deepest film around, but the sharp writing, an able cast and sensitive direction make it an engaging one.
Those willing to venture off the beaten cinematic path may find this visually dazzling, intellectually stimulating film a rare and wondrous discovery.
A soft, cuddly, thoroughly inoffensive ode to friendship designed for the six-and-under set.
So long as the freshmen are at center stage, this is cheekily engaging in an old-fashioned way. But when the upperclassmen and adults take over, it pretty much flunks out.
An artificial contrivance that doesn't tell you much that you didn't already know, but does so loudly and garishly.
For those able to tune in to its peculiar wavelength this deceptively simple film will prove another strangely profound [Van Sant] experience.
A truly excruciating journey...a feel-good movie that's bound to make you feel absolutely awful.
movie_title: Hector And The Search For Happiness (2014)

movie_review_blurb: There are moments when the movie hits the target. Unfortunately, they're not enough to raise what might have been a sharp, perceptive take on the rah-rah side of modern Christianity above the level of mediocrity.
An attempt at a modern noir that works its way to a pretty exciting, if absurd, climax but mostly bides time until then.

An entertaining movie with an intriguingly intricate plot, but it's really nothing more than a slick, well-manufactured potboiler that ends up more as an expression of the culture it depicts rather than serious commentary, or satire, on it.
By aiming to be a crowd-pleaser, it fails to do justice to a harrowing part of recent history.
A mediocre horror flick that can't hold a candle to the one that inspired it...a sort of catch-all of horror movie cliches.
Though it's more than a mite chilly emotionally, it compensates with some understated British wit and a typically good moral.
Bland, though well-meaning, animated fable.
A solid fact-based period piece...anchored by a vivid performance by Jeremy Renner...a welcome throwback to the days of activist Hollywood David-vs.-Goliath films.
Banality posing as profundity...a ponderously didactic ensemble piece...so determined to deliver a message...that it doesn't bother to create credible characters, situations or dialogue.
Though one can name lots of worse family movies, if not horrible, terrible and very bad this one is--considering its pedigree and the quality of the cast--disappointingly mediocre.
movie_title: Alexander and the Terrible, Horrible, No Good, Very Bad Day (2014)

movie_review_blurb: An incredibly sloppy found-footage flick that's awful enough to give Halloween a bad name.
An ungainly combination of comic-book history lesson with the tropes of both horror movies and superhero sagas.
Bill Murray's irascibility, even at the most mawkish moments, is enough to save the picture from drowning in a sea of sentimentality.
Slick but superficial and overloaded with cliches...entertaining enough, but in a shallow, manipulative fashion.
Seems to beg for a 'used' label, not primarily because it's based on an old TV show, but because it stubbornly embraces the tired tropes of every dumb action movie Hollywood's ever made.
Despite its leisurely pace, the film proves a gripping journey both across Australia and into the heart of its heroine.
A glum, torpid tale of grief and loneliness that's intended to be profound but instead is simply dull.
movie_title: The Disappearance of Eleanor Rigby: Them (2014)

movie_review_blurb: An extremely silly attempt at a young adult thriller that winds up more laughable than scary.
A film of intricate emotions and small gestures that, taken together, express wonderment at the profundity of human relationships while resolutely eschewing melodramatic excess.
The basic premise is actually fairly interesting. Unfortunately, it's been poorly worked out and clumsily executed.
May be remembered primarily as the last film featuring the late James Gandolfini, but it possesses many virtues beyond his stellar performance.
A pleasant, innocuous family movie that's rather short on energy but compensates with loads of earnestness.
Ed Harris brings such world-weary gravitas to his role as a grieving widower...that he comes close to making up for the picture's sometimes clunky narrative.
Essentially a character study that lacks much character itself...elegant but ultimately slight.
This exuberantly vulgar coming-of-age story is more exhausting than exhilarating.
Nasty, ugly, extremely dumb home-invasion stinker...meretricious junk.
May be trash, but it's grade-A trash, an absurdly enjoyable piece of pulp hokum that's a throwback to some of the best B-movies of the seventies and eighties.
A moodily effective piece of pulp that moves slowly but delivers some genuinely creepy moments.
Though hardly a champion-quality entrant in this crowded YA field, it crosses the finish line winded but game.
Earns points for sheer audacity, but audacity isn't enough.
Thanks to the efforts of a superlative cast, the slight piece comes across as a charming mixture of comedy and drama.
Treading familiar territory with a heavy foot, the picture and its characters grow increasingly irritating as the family squabbles drone on.
movie_title: This Is Where I Leave You (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Rife with the most crushingly obvious Sparksisms, from stereotypical characters to inane plotting and pseudo-profound observations about life and love.

Its traditional storytelling represents an agreeable throwback to a time when tales of combat managed to be viscerally exciting while also saying something about camaraderie and the effect of the battlefield experience.

A visual feast that will appeal primarily to those familiar with Mexican culture and folklore...a weird assemblage of elements that never cohere into a convincing whole, but are entrancing from moment to moment.
An entertaining if rather rambling documentary [about] a crafty artist indeed.
It's not hard to understand why Wahlberg and friends were drawn to remake 'The Gambler,' but they botched the job badly.

It's heartening that at a time when movie musicals are still an endangered species, such loving care has gone into bringing one of Sondheim's most ingenious, affecting works to the screen without unduly compromising what makes it so special.
Despite the instances when it strays from, or grossly simplifies, the record...succeeds in presenting an affecting portrait of Alan Turing.
Represents a solid return to form for Burton, even if it never attains the dizzying heights of 'Ed Wood.'
A respectful, and more than respectable, attempt to celebrate Kyle's service while also taking account of the effect it had on him and his family.
So turgid and enervated that it's more likely to generate snores than shudders.
movie_title: The Woman in Black 2 Angel of Death (2015)

movie_review_blurb: A cerebral sci-fi time-travel puzzler that proves consistently engrossing and, for all its contrivance and complication, satisfying.
As history 'Selma' may cause some controversy, but as fact-based drama it's exceptionally fine.
A loopy fever-dream of a movie that recasts the conventions of noir in a blissed-out psychedelic haze.
One of the finest films about an artist ever made, fashioned by a filmmaker who's a notable artist himself.
Just another extended chase movie, one far longer--and sillier--than a Road Runner cartoon.
Droll and delightful...the best family movie of its kind since 'Babe.'
Old-hat, an unimaginative take on a cutting-edge subject that comes off both ludicrous and boring.
This 'Wedding' is by no means a classy affair, but in the post-'Hangover' era it's not the worst comedy to come along.
It demands patience and attentiveness, but...reveals a great deal about the reality of the human condition through its probing characterization and pungent dialogue.
Slow-moving, episodic and frankly over-refined.
It's not a classic you'll rave about for days, and at 138 minutes it does go on too long, but for fans of Asian period action, it will certainly serve.
Sober, often moving documentary [that] performs a service by reminding us of...the Deepwater Horizon oil disaster of 2010 and its continuing impact.
Basically a genial, good-natured boys' adventure, and if it stumbles somewhat in the second hour, when it becomes more derivative and action-oriented, it remains likable to the end.
A film that deals with serious matters but does so in a way that makes it an irresistible crowd-pleaser.
A savage satire of Hollywood celebrity gone to seed...delivered with an irresistible degree of cinematic panache.
Its strength lies in the teaming of Teller and Simmons, who play their scenes together like an inspired jazz duet.
Efficient and stylish, rattling off genre conventions with aplomb.
Sufficiently provocative to raise important issues and cheeky enough to remain entertaining while doing so.
A threadbare attempt at a frightfest--dumb, turgid and ultimately tedious.
A compact but structurally diffuse psychological thriller [that] honors Simenon, but in ways that might frustrate a segment of its audience.
On the one hand, it's well-meaning and high-minded; on the other, it's obvious and predictable.
A near-miss, a supernatural romance-cum-whodunit that strains under the weight of its warring elements.
Will enthrall everyone with its evocative images but probably task the patience of anybody not already acquainted with, and fascinated by, the story.
movie_title: The Tale of the Princess Kaguya (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Little more than a pallid gender-reversal version of 'Fatal Attraction' with an unseemly religious twist...at best cable-TV fodder.
Wants to be cutting-edge, but in the end its creative blade proves rather dull. Still, it's hard to take your eyes off Gyllenhaal.
The cool deliberation...takes a degree of patience to appreciate, and some may find its abrupt tonal shifts bewildering. But it's a remarkable portrait of a family on the verge.
A lethargic, very silly would-be thriller...featur[ing] scenes of abuse that are extremely nasty and protracted.
You can certainly respond to its craft, but its attempts at emotional depth and cosmological profundity fall short.

Though the production retains a bit of indie grunge, in terms of content the picture isn't all that far removed from typical studio romcoms--and to be frank doesn't rank higher than the middle of the pack.

Like the films made by Sidney Lumet in the same gritty urban locale, it quickly heats up to a simmer and generates considerable tension in exploring the darker byways of the drive for success in America.
A minor discovery, but a diverting one...a low-key, unassuming but pleasant family road dramedy.
Tagging along with these exaggerated versions of the two stars is just about as enjoyable the second time around.
Little more than another recycling of 'The Hangover'...loud, abrasive, frenetic and singularly unfunny.
Isn't the equal of Michod's previous film, but it shows that he's hardly a one-hit wonder, but rather a filmmaker of vision as well as finely tuned technique.
The success of 'Korengal' lies in its ability to convey the complicated mixture of emotions connected to the combat experience.
As conventional as its bigger California cousins in so many ways that except for its raggedy look it's virtually indistinguishable from them.
Uneven but compelling...coming-of-age, troubled-teen [drama].
An elephantine stinker that's the very definition of sound and fury that signifies nothing.
Neither very entertaining nor especially enlightening...an old-fashioned rags-to-riches-to-rags show-biz melodrama punctuated by a few laughs and some musical interludes.
The treatment...is rather scattershot, but even if some of the targets get only glancing blows and others are ignored almost entirely, 'Ivory Tower' provides lots of food for thought.
Too scattershot and episodic to work as a whole, but overall it's a better vehicle for McCarthy than those she's shouldered before.
It may not be the brightest movie around, but it's almost insanely watchable...deliciously different from run-of-the-mill doomsday pictures.
One of those imperfect films that's nevertheless more intriguing than conventionally stronger but less challenging ones.
Another nice musical spin by Carney on the conventions of quasi-romantic dramedy.
Charmless and visually oppressive, it only serves to highlight the superiority of the movies it's so crudely copying.
Marked by a solemnity that frequently lapses into either silliness or tedium, this thriller ultimately fails to deliver the goods.
The spirit of genial youthful rebelliousness has seldom been expressed with such effortless glee.
At the very least it's a lot more fun than, say, 'The Love Guru.'
movie_title: Supermensch: The Legend of Shep Gordon (2014)

movie_review_blurb: While 'Dragon 2' is a rather different critter from 'Dragon 1'--bigger, more sprawling and preachier--it has no less heart and humor, and is a rousing adventure besides.
Too cerebral for the SyFy Channel but too silly for any other venue...[a] stylish thriller that offers sporadic chills amidst some very pretentious patches on its way to a pedestrian finish.
Pierce Brosnan and Emma Thompson...make a charming couple. But their best efforts can't save Joel Hopkins' weak script,...which he also directed, clumsily.
Sporadically amusing and touching, but also precious, and it never comes together as an authentic emotional experience.
An admirably restrained, respectful portrait of the kinds of Americans contemporary films generally avoid showing at all--or if they do, treat with heavy-handed mawkishness.
There's an abundance of visual magic, but not much of any other sort in Disney's revisionist take on the 'Sleeping Beauty' villainess.
There's not much that's good in it, plenty that's bad, and an awful lot that's just plain ugly.
movie_title: A Million Ways to Die in the West (2014)

movie_review_blurb: An artistic triumph whose stunning simplicity conveys an entire world of moral complexity and human pain.
Makes the transition to the big screen in a form that anybody can enjoy, whether you're already a fan of the TV sketches or not.
[A] loosely structured, sporadically engaging film, which serves primarily as a star vehicle for French screen icon Catherine Deneuve.
The modern equivalent of the B movies that studios used to make, and it reminds you of how good many of them were.
A very melodramatic picture...yet it's remarkably evocative and compelling, almost compulsively watchable.
If you're willing to succumb to its admittedly glacial pacing, you may well find yourself drawn into an unfamiliar world that, in [Reichardt's] hands, is worth visiting.
Moderately engaging, but not up to the level of truly outstanding summer action fare. You could say that it's on the very edge of being a winner.
movie_title: Live Die Repeat: Edge of Tomorrow (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Unquestionably a sappy, manipulative movie, but on those admittedly low terms it succeeds....for most viewers Green's calculated assault on the tear ducts will work.
Though it's neither as beguiling as it would like nor as intellectually sophisticated as it hopes, its virtues outweigh its flaws, earning it a passing grade.
The rare follow-up that improves on its predecessor...consistently amusing and sometimes hilarious.
An admiring, and admirable, portrait of Ebert as a writer and as a person...not merely touching but honest.
A canny continuation of the saga that delivers mood and action in approximately equal measure to compensate for a threadbare plot.
movie_title: Dawn Of The Planet Of The Apes (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Never becomes anything more than an anemic sit-com leavened with heavy doses of mawkishness. 'Wish I Was Here' will make you wish you weren't.

A farce that tries so hard to be naughty without becoming tasteless and raunchy without becoming gross that it winds up exhausting its stars as well as the audience, while never achieving the hilarity it's straining for.
The formulaic premise and self-indulgent writing defeat the best efforts of a likable cast.
Loud, frenetic and exhausting, it's really too violent for younger children and too dumb for adults who aren't driven by sheer nostalgia.
The formula has grown very stale, particularly in this surprisingly tepid telling. It's not even worthy of re-gifting; just return for a refund.

The alleged action comedy is so bad that the perpetrators should probably be arrested, convicted and incarcerated anywhere but a movie studio. But maybe appearing in it is punishment enough. Certainly watching it is.
Comes across as a sad throwback in which the attempt to add some fresh blood is no more effective than a dose of Geritol.
A genial but meandering tale...that sneaks up on you if you'll give it a chance, the charm gradually vwinning you over.
A teen soap opera...[that] has all the authenticity of a project written for the CW network by Nicholas Sparks.
