It's fairly certain that while watching it you'll wish you were somewhere else.
It uses what initially seems a slight, even ludicrous conceit to treat of deeper relationship issues in an intelligent, sophisticated way.
Apart from one element it's a thoroughly likable, though hardly overwhelming, travelogue.
Workmanlike rather than inspired...well-intentioned but heavy-handed.
This second trip to the same noirish well has come up dry.
movie_title: Frank Miller's Sin City: A Dame to Kill For (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Whle it an be faulted for its shortcomings as a film and even as an argument, it's welcome for providing a glimpse of what amounts to an alternative treatment for the ever-growing number of Americans suffering from dementia.
A pastiche of old-fashioned espionage cliches, clumsily stitched together and even more ineptly executed.
A cinematic mess...[a] dreary, incoherent, visually ugly jumble of cliches and inanities.

'Suds in the Cyclone' might be a better title for this old-fashioned disaster movie...a 'Twister' on steroids that employs massive amounts of CGI imagery while ladling on soap opera cliches to add a 'human' element.
A quirky, weirdly funny tale with an underlying layer of deep melancholy, about the fragility not only of art but of the human psyche.
Trenchant, absorbing and quite distinctive...an intriguing blend of high drama and dark humor.
Essentially a quirky version of 'Love Story' told with all the visual gimcrackery the director can muster--which is an awful lot.
An instant classic twelve years in the making, striking in its tender tone and stunning in its cumulative emotional impact.
A 'Twilight Zone' dinner party whose guests frankly wear out their welcome.
A playful-yet-serious rumination on sexual gamesmanship presented through a form of theatrical artifice that Polanski embraces while giving it cinematic polish.
A surprisingly humdrum affair, notable only for the mixed messages it manages to deliver along its corpse-strewn route.
Provides an incredibly intense, and genuinely moving, glimpse into the operation of one of the nation's premier emergency medical facilities.
The film ultimately fails to work except as an aesthetic exercise.
There's no doubt it wants to be clever and deep. Unhappily, it's actually rather goofy.
If Hoffman's splendid, subtle performance might not be the apex of his wide-ranging career, this intelligent, engrossing film proves a fitting finale to it.
Loony and laughable...There's something outlandish about Besson trying to infuse ideas into his usual jumble of over-the-top action and comic-book violence.
It's like watching Oscar the Grouch turn into Mister Rodgers in ninety minutes.
A cheerfully unpretentious, mostly enjoyable throwback to the boys' adventure movies of yesteryear...dumb, old-fashioned fun of the sort one gets too rarely in popcorn movies today.
A cinematic meal that goes down fairly easily, but isn't tasty enough to be memorable.
A stiffly-choreographed period piece [in which] the sleight of hand proves all too slight.
The very empty-headedness...will probably insure its enormous success, since many in the audience will be able to identify with it.
Though it spotlights a great performance, this isn't a great musical biography, largely due to the splintered nature of the storytelling.
An ambitious but uneven attempt to translate McCarthy's book to the screen.

Not only the best film in the 'X-Men' series, but one that rivals the best super-hero movies of the past. Inventive and slick in the best sense, it continues the franchise's rejuvenation and whets the appetite for more.

Paradoxically, even when pulling its emotional punches 'Still Alice' can't entirely escape the limitations of the disease-of-the-week genre, but largely as a result of Moore's extraordinary skill it largely transcends them.
Many fine ingredients--not least the performances of Aniston and Barraza--have gone into making this 'Cake,' but it leaves one wishing that the end result had been more uncompromising.
Tells a lurid, fact-based story in a curiously understated, reticent way...intriguing but emotionally rather dessicated.
movie_title: In the Name of My Daughter (2015)

movie_review_blurb: A purely visual exercise...unless you're willing to be satisfied with a handsome exterior, you won't find Bonello's film very involving.
Just loud, boorish frat-boy wish-fulfilmment stuff, festooned with wink-wink celebrity cameos.
A shambles...a movie you might appreciate for its unwillingness to turn your stomach, but that won't raise many pleasurable goosebumps either.
An exceptional musical biography featuring not one but two exemplary lead performances.
A top-notch vehicle for McCarthy, but though she's clearly the linchpin, it's not a one-woman show--and is all the better for it.
A solid, respectable police procedural [about] the same criminal enterprise as 'The French Connection,' but it's not in the same league as Friedkin's film.

Tries hard, incredibly hard...but it fails, not because it's lacking in craftsmanship, but because it's devoid of the inspiration that might have made it distinctive rather than a by-the-numbers retread.
Pixar's streak continues...Imaginative and colorful, it's a literal head-trip about the process of growing up.
A brisk, funny tale in neo-Hughes mode...energetic and quick.
Skillfully walks a fine line between the precious and the maudlin, its initially excessive quirkiness morphing into something cheekily amusing and at times quite affecting.
movie_title: Me and Earl and the Dying Girl (2015)

movie_review_blurb: A largely incomprehensible story told in a painfully lugubrious, structurally fractured fashion...it's likely to leave you cold--as well as bewildered.
The droll way in which it simultaneously subverts and embraces the conventions of the romcom template makes it a genuine find.
While nice--arguably too nice, in fact--it feels like fifty minutes of material drawn out to nearly ninety.
movie_title: I Am Big Bird: The Caroll Spinney Story (2015)

movie_review_blurb: While one can certainly admire the way in which Holmes and the Safdies immerse us in the hellish world of these characters, the result is really nothing more than a wallow in nihilism.
Infuriatingly messy and opaque...so misshapen and tonally awkward that whatever [Crowe] intended has to be imagined rather than experienced.
Routine post-9/11 espionage thriller than leans far too heavily on ticks taken from far better Hitchcock films.
An unabashed throwback to the simple-minded disaster movies of decades ago...[and] a ho-hum affair.
Not only a music documentary that's worthy of its subject, but an exceptional work of pure filmmaking.
Isn't unpleasant, but it does end up feeling synthetic--the work of a filmmaker who's simply trying too hard.
Amiable but little more than that...about on the level of a Hallmark Hall of Fame special.
As efficient an exercise in pure action and visceral excitement as today's jaded audiences could ask for, though little more than that.
Feels tired and off-key, a bungled attempt to recapture the modest charms of its overrated predecessor.
Droll and whimsical, for the most part it's good fun, a modern take on the old Ealing template.
movie_title: The 100-Year-Old Man Who Climbed Out the Window and Disappeared (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The documentary leaves little doubt that Maysles was captivated by Iris Apfel, and it's probable that you will be too.
Though serious-minded, it's a turgid, pretentious attempt at an adult western.
As its title indicates, this is a straight-up inspirational tale, but its sincerity and above-average execution set it apart from many other similar movies.
You have to respect a film that takes the risk of alienating viewers [but] the result, while fascinating, is as deeply flawed as its protagonist.
Deficient in magic and decidedly short on enchantment, as well as tiresomely preachy.
A formulaic but engaging dramedy...older audiences in particular will find it a pleasant way to spend their time.
movie_title: I'll See You in My Dreams (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Whether the hallucinatory beauty of the visuals is enough to compensate for its narrative pretentions is...doubtful.
One has to give it credit for taking on a serious subject, even if it fumbles the attempt.
Doesn't improve on Hooper's film, or equal it, but at least it doesn't bastardize it. But...why settle for a respectable retread when you can still savor its superior model?
Gives Del Toro the chance to shine, but it just uses his portrait of a modern-day monster as a backdrop to a pulp B-movie plot that Hutcherson isn't equipped to carry.
For all its supposed edginess,...it winds up being little more than mildly naughty, drawing titters rather than gasps.
Run-of-the-mill 'Jaws'-on-land potboiler.
A lush, curiously decorous adaptation of the memoir by Vera Brittain...its very conventionality and tactfulness undermine its power.
A slow, opaque Australian psychologicsal drama.
For Dante's reputation, it would be best that the movie should itself be buried without an identifying headstone.
An attractive cast can't rescue this well-meaning but slow, sappy romantic triangle.
Represents something of a comeback for Apatow, as well as a promising big-time debut for Schumer.

Before long we're in 'Death Wish' territory, with the plot turns growing more and more implausible as the picture lumbers toward what might pass for a happy ending [but] distinguished by a ferociously committed performance by Viola Davis.
Essentially just a down-and-dirty variation on that classic pugilistic tearjerker 'The Champ'...despite its hardboiled exterior, the movie still wallows in sentiment and cliche.
Yet another misfire from Adam Sandler's Happy Madison Productions...juvenile in every conceivable respect, less coarse than Sandler's recent vehicles but unhappily not much more engaging.
Paper-thin...a meandering coming-of-age tale that comes across as a nostalgia trip for John Hughes devotees.
Isn't one of Loach's more notable films, but even a lesser effort from him is worth seeing.
Breezy though inconsequential, and...intellectually shallow despite rather show-offish attempts to appear philosophically sophisticated in dealing with ethical issues.
Goes on too long, with at least one too many prolonged chases and fights, but is still expertly mounted, enjoyably old-fashioned, action-packed cloak-and-dagger hokum.
Really nothing more than an extended promotional reel for the Danish company...but despite being a mite padded, it's a mostly sprightly tour through the byways of Legoland.

The last sound you hear before the closing credits of 'Vacation' is that of a toilet flushing. That's a fitting end to this unremittingly crude, frequently repulsive sequel to a fondly-remembered cable perennial.
Deserves credit for raising important issues at all, but the trite romcom packaging compromises the good intentions.
An uneven, though compelling and unsettling film...When it's over you may think you've been put through the wringer.
Vigilantism on both sides of the Mexican-U.S. line is the subject of Mathhew Heineman's powerful but curiously diffuse documentary.
A weird combination of saccharine drama with "Footloose," deadly earnest but utterly incredible, the good intentions overwhelmed by silly theatrics.

Gentle and autumnal, 'Mr. Holmes' will undoubtedly strike younger viewers as overly decorous, but it's a perfect antidote to the loud, vulgar bastardizations of the character starring Robert Downey, Jr.
As a record of the event it's amiable enough, but also a bit ragged and more than a little self-satisfied.
A good inside joke...Its ace in the hole is Luchini.

This second helping of MacFarlane's smugly lowbrow hijinks [is] well-nigh unbearable....a juvenile stream of drug gags, penis-centric jokes, pop culture riffs and other raunchy stuff ladled out with a sluggish, leaden hand.
A very peculiar sort of patriotic family film, it mixes a boy-and-his-dog tale with action-movie violence...one strange beast for the coming Fourth of July.

Little more than a slapdash woman's wish-fulfillment fantasy--in which male entertainers bare their all for their pleasure--that embodies a man's wish-fulfillment one, in which their jiggling and shaking sets women a-flutter.
Another movie so crammed with visual razzle-dazzle in the service of empty, repetitive action that long before it ends, you feel exhausted by the excess.
[Ruffalo's] gleefully over-the-top performance...anchors a picture on a potentially difficult subject that instead is content to be a manipulative crowd-pleaser, but a moderately engaging one.
An engrossing portrait of a decidedly peculiar family, but one in which significant pieces of the puzzle are lacking--or summarily ignored.
A glossy, manipulative but affecting portrait of a brilliant man struck, but not struck down, by a terrible malady.
An old-school boys' adventure story [that's] absurdly outlandish but ridiculously enjoyable.
The slender character study...has moments of genuine poetry and tenderness [that are] ultimately undermined by a script...that makes its points in labored fashion.
A technically proficient portrait that aims to be appreciative of the singer's talent and sympathetic to her problems while not papering over the destructive elements of her personality.
Young kids may enjoy the hulabaloo of what amounts to a manic but rarely inspired prequel--cinematic hamburger rather than filet minion.
Could have been a thoughtful, provocative, cerebral thriller...but instead it chooses to become an action movie so dumb that it might be titled 'Sense/less.'
Excruciatingly awful horror movie...in which the lack of technique is exceeded only by the lack of imagination.
A darkly humorous rumination about the primacy of fate or free will presented in the form of a twisty thriller with a smidgen of the supernatural,...it's well worth investigating.
The movie's almost self-deprecatory sense of tongue-in-cheek humility is matched by the fact that all the pleasures it affords are very small indeed.
An uneven, hit-and-miss affair, but it represents a comeback for Pacino and, to some extent, for Levinson.
A movie that wants to push the envelope but in the end is so clumsy and cautious about it that the result hardly amounts to a nudge.
Content with hitting the high points of the plot as a solid Masterpiece Theatre presentation might do, [but] Vinterberg at least treats Hardy's work with respect, if not a lot of imagination.
It's difficult to imagine a movie more vulgar and crass than this, or one more likely to evoke groans of disgust than gales of laughter.
Covers familiar territory in a decent but not terribly compelling fashion...a gentle, understated but only fitfully affecting tale of a teen's psychological turmoil.
Transferred to film its artificiality becomes oppressive...the realistic backgrounds accentuate the synthetic nature of the piece rather than mitigating it.
A piercingly relevant study of life under the rule of Islamic jihadists.
Love it or hate it,...clearly the work of a filmmaker with a unique--as well as provocative--vision and a distinctive, compelling style.
A series of contrived twists...that fails to recapture the magic of the best Hollywood caper movies of the past.
A tepid, undernourished clone of the John Hughes high school template, with attractive leads stuck in a script that feels like a tattered hand-me-down.
A send-up of the vampire mythos that's affectionate and genial.
movie_title: What We Do In The Shadows (2015)

movie_review_blurb: A far cheaper cousin to 'Flatliners' that, thanks to the better-than-average cast, is reasonably engaging for the first hour or so before deteriorating badly in a mayhem-filled finale.
More of the same, but not as good...despite the attractive facade, the movie is a pretty ramshackle affair.
movie_title: The Second Best Exotic Marigold Hotel (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Should have generated plenty of suspense and excitement, but instead it simply moseys along and eventually runs completely out of gas.
Change the second letter of the title and you'll have a pretty good description of 'Chappie.'

One doesn't have to have seen the previous films in the trilogy for 'Gett' to provide a searing view of the Israeli system of divorce, or to make one feel deeply for a modern woman trapped in its religious intricacies.
movie_title: GETT: The Trial of Viviane Amsalem (2015)

movie_review_blurb: A visually attractive but curiously flat retelling of the old chestnut.
Humdrum supernatural melodrama...atmospheric but not at all frightening.
It might cross the finish line a bit winded, but overall proves more sure-footed than most of its inspirational sports-movie cousins.
An animated film about a magical world that casts an enchanted spell of its own.
An inoffensive but bland and unimaginative romcom.
A bottom-of-the-barrel endangered woman thriller that even executives over at Lifetime might have dismissed as too hackneyed to be aired.
A thoroughgoing disaster...which aims to be a larkish homage to caper movies of the sixties but falls dismally short of the target.
Yet another fine exercise in the Dardennes' impassioned neo-Neorealism.
An old-fashioned sort of submarine suspenser [that's] a mostly enjoyable throwback to macho melodramas of an earlier age.
Visually hysterical, narratively nonsensical time-travel cheapie.
A heartfelt but contrived and simplistic take on the subject [of race relations].
Not so much a whodunit as a whocareswhodunit...clear out a space on the 'Le Bad Cinema' shelf for this turkey.
A portrait of familial crisis so pointed and wrenching that though nearly two-and-a-half hours long, it rarely fails to engross--and to an extent--exhaust.
A breezy, colorful, giddily zany return trip to Bikini Bottom.
movie_title: The SpongeBob Movie: Sponge Out of Water (2015)

movie_review_blurb: A pretty but empty sci-fi bauble that quickly sinks in its derivative foolishness.
This 'Son' is stillborn.
A dark, bitter commentary on how absolute power corrupts absolutely and smashes those who resist it.
Florid, hysterical (though far from historical) pseudo-biographical movie about the famous violinist [Paganini].
A near-miss...it runs down in the second half and its dark turn proves overly jarring.
Advertises itself as edgy and titillating, but proves fatally tepid and boring.
A terrific action movie that also says something painfully true about the deceit and double-dealing that poisoned peoples' lives during the years of conflict in Northern Ireland.
Incredibly engaging and equally informative music documentary.
Though the inventiveness tends to run down as the film runs on...Szidron's sextet remains intriguing to the end.
Agreeably unsettling if not the terrifying experience some have claimed.
While very nicely fashioned, winds up as an oddly prosaic cautionary tale dressed up in quasi-literary duds [with] the air of an upscale afterschool special.
A fact-based but slow-paced legal thriller notable more for its cast than its narrative momentum.
A coolly cerebral sci-fi tale that really isn't all that inventive but nonetheless casts quie a spell.
The lead monkeys are such an engaging trio, and the filmmakers are so successful in capturing them in vibrant images,that family audiences will probably be charmed, if not enthralled.
Won't efface memories of the best caper pictures. Golfers, however, may well find it a pleasant diversion. At least it shouldn't tee them off.
Stultifyingly stupid...It's dificult to care about the demise of characters in a horror movie when they're all already brain-dead.
A hopeless muddle of clumsy police procedural, fraught domestic fireworks and heavy-handed totalitarian tropes, presented in the grimmest possible fashion and drawn out to insufferable length.
A probing, illuminating rumination on art versus life, present versus past, and youth versus maturity, all craftily combined to invite reflection as well as admiration.
A sentimental period tale...schmaltzy but generally agreeable in a determinedly old-fashioned way.
Terribly earnest and earnestly terrible...bungles its good intentions in a welter of mixed signals and mangled messages.
[A] blandly manipulative romantic fantasy [that] represents the sort of melodramatic pseudo-profundity that poses as meaningful in hokey novels.
More of the same, just not as good--lots of sound and fury (along with some Fury) signifying very little.
An extended sitcom with surprisingly little comic bite...just floats along on a current of bland affability.
A film that can be frustrating in its steadfast refusal to be clear about who's who, but by the end has become an effective neo-noirish parable about how slippery and shifting the truth is.
A tough, sober portrait of a culture seeped in deadly traditions that perpetuate themselves, and in which any attempt to escape the cycle merely prolongs it.
The treacle flows for well over two hours, an interminable serving of the author's trademark schmaltz.
Crass, frantic farce--a distaff riff on the formula of 'Midnight Run' that will make you wince more often than Charles Grodin did in that 1988 movie.
The crime melodrama, whch its makers have dubbed a 'black comedy thriller,' has a few oddball moments but is never funny, and it certainly isn't thrilling.
Less 'Fargo Lite' than 'Fargo Flat'...a thoroughly pedestrian stroll through Coen brothers territory.
A virtual compendium of action cliches that's efficiently made but in the end totally superfluous.
More Sergio Leone than John Ford, it's a visually expansive compendium of revenge-movie cliches suffused with Scandinavian angst--not a spaghetti western, but sort of a cheesy Danish one.
An improvement on its predecessor...a workmanlike job, if an uninspired one.
Obviously aiming for camp cult status, but unlike the beavers the makers don't have the chops to pull it off.
Nothing but a standard-issue series of action tropes that grow more and more ludicrous as each tries to top the last.
At once a celebration and a quasi-historical analysis, it may try to stuff too much into a ninety-minute span, but...it's pretty darned tasty.

Descends so far into racial stereotyping, offhanded homophobia, class division, sexual coarseness and scatological gags that whatever chemistry the stars might have brought to the table is pretty much dissipated.
While Fogelman's script is extremely calculated and heavy-handed, the cast's nimble execution turns it into an agreeeable way to pass the time.
A major misfire...inert, stodgy and unconvincing, utterly failing to capture the chemistry that Cooper and Lawrence achieved in their work with David O. Russell.
Colorful, energetic but highly derivative...less an imaginative addition to the crowded kidflicks field than a tidily manufactured collection of familiar, rather tired elements.
Earnest and well-intentioned but preachy in the way of an afterschool special and stylistically problematic.
The behind-the-camera contributions--along with Mirren's presence--mark this as a prestige production, but the unsubtle, prosaic treatment--along with the bland Reynolds--vitiates the effort.
A huge, galumphing bore...the maelstrom of mayhem very quickly becomes an orgy of stupidity, and a remarkably tedious one at that.
This is an interesting story, but it's treated here in a fashion that's at once timorous and overstated.
Oversimpliies matters somewhat, but...the subject is an extremely timely one, and it presents an extremely important side of it quite persuasively.
Isn't as sharp or consistent as 'Greenberg,' Baumbach's previous collaboration with Ben Stiller, but while uneven, its high points outnumber the low ones.

A typical Jeunet film, which means that it's amazingly accomplished from a technical point of view but synthetic and emotionally remote...a truly personal effort that has to be taken on its own terms or not at all.
movie_title: The Young And Prodigious T.S. Spivet (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The mixture of romantic comedy, frantic farce, family sitcom, sentimentality and coarseness doesn't really blend that well. But compared to his last few films, 'Blended' is a relief--a new Sandler vehicle that at least doesn't make you want to retch.
Informative and exciting...an educational film that's uplifting in the best sense.
Despite a glitzy surface it ultimately seems as devoid of substance as its airheaded young characters.
A manipulative assemblage of tear-jerking cliches...But it has Stamp and Redgrave, who play Marion and Arthur with such conviction that one almost buys into it.

A summer action movie without a brain in its head, but if you approach it by putting yours on hold, you'll find it skillfully enough made to hold your attention as you consume that tub of popcorn and--given its length--a refill as well.
A cluttered, misshapen piece of work, cobbled together in a way that suggests desperation--or, when it comes to the extensive footage given to the Minions, crude calculation.
'The Wild Wild West' of 2013, a visually extravagant but tonally chaotic behemoth that never finds the right balance between slam-bang action, goofy comedy abd solemn historical critique.
While one can sympathize with the subjects Bouchareb is exploring here, his picture strives for a great deal more than it actually delivers.
A surprisingly clear-headed and faithful adaptation [with] a good deal of charm, effervescence and rollicking humor.
Alternately charming, penetrating and rote comedy-drama...an agreeable, insightful if uneven film.
A buddy-cop action comedy every bit as crass and dumb as the ones male teams have been making for years.
A second helping of infantile lowjinks...a lazy, plotless excuse for a comedy.
A 'Power Rangers' on steroids with an inane plot, cliche-ridden dialogue, cardboard characters and stilted acting.
Running on fumes long before the final lap.
A viscerally wrenching experience, filled with foreboding from the first frame but stylistically naturalistic.
Creepily effective...the cinematic equivalent of a well-constructed spooky carnival attraction.
Strange and moody.... Cinema buffs will find it an intriguing curio, though.
Despite a huge budget, a lean, mean zombie machine that builds enormous tension by speeding through a succession of nail-biting set pieces.
Likable but fundamentally ordinary 3D-animated children's fare...just a pleasant but minor diversion, not up to the standards one used to expect from Pixar.
An absorbing exercise not only in documentary excavation but in narrative construction.
One might compare 'What Maisie Knew' to 'Kramer vs. Kramer.' This is the better film, more subtle and less manipulative.
Every bit as bad as you'd fear of a movie from the writer of 'The Book of Eli' and the director of 'The Last Airbender.' Where are the guys from Mystery Science Theater when you need them?
A fast-moving puzzler that, on a minute to minute basis, is moderately engaging but by the close has become a rather heavy-handed bit of hokum.
Works...as a saga of self-destructive behavior by capable people whose judgment was perverted by smugness about their own principles.
movie_title: We Steal Secrets: The Story Of Wikileaks (2013)

movie_review_blurb: [A] lurid but undeniably powerful story, and the lead performances are compelling.
A quirky, genial crowd-pleaser that probably cost less than the catering bill for one of the franchise mega-productions but delivers a lot more fun than most of them.
An uneven film...an odd blend of sophistication on one level and maladroit technique on the other.

The conclusion of a trilogy that...has subtly depicted the birth, growth and maturation of a man-woman relationship with its inevitable vacillations between affection, sacrifice, self-concern and acrimony.
A sly, stylish blend of melodrama and suspense that's also a cunning commentary on the seductiveness and danger inherent in storytelling itself.
Just a routine home invasion tale with heavy-handed pretensions to social commentary.
A lazy comedy, innocuous and inoffensive but formulaic and tired, as well as fatally overlong.
Less sharp-edged satire than frat-boy goofiness.
This rather dour but aggressively whiz-bang take on Superman's first appearance on earth is intriguing up to a point, but...it won't blow you away.
Neither as writer nor as director is Fletcher able to sustain his conceit.
Even this lesser LaBute offers a nice twist to his characteristically stinging dissection of man's inhumanity to man--and especially woman.
Makes every effort to be wickedly wacky and light-footedly seductive and fails at virtually every turn.
While the comedy...occasionally works--especially when Malkovich is around--the action elements are mostly a drag.
Relentlessly artificial and broad...absolutely nothing in 'Girl Most Likely' feels remotely human.
Yet another comic-book adaptation that should have stayed on the page...aims to be loopy and cool but only succeeds at being dumb and boring.
This might not be a spectacular movie, but compared to the stuff Hollywood usually churns out about teenagers, it's a breath of fresh air.
While there's a certain tautness to the result, the many longueurs along the way almost make one yearn for an infusion of good old Hollywood pizzazz.
A tepid would-be corporate thriller with a young lead not ready for prime time, and even old hands like Ford and Oldman can't save it.
Overstuffed, overlong...and brainless beyond belief...[with a] numbingly convoluted and derivative plot, woodem acting and cheesy effects.
movie_title: The Mortal Instruments: City of Bones (2013)

movie_review_blurb: A thoroughly repulsive picture that's even worse when it tries to add some dark humor to the grisly mix of carnage and gore.
A good deal smarter than most big-budget romantic comedies, but its shrillness makes it less pleasurable than it should be.
Isn't as wacky as 'Shaun of the Dead' or 'Hot Fuzz,' but it's amusing enough to please their many fans and plenty of others besides.
For those who value the life of the mind and the responsibility of the public intellectual, it's an engrossing--indeed important--film.
With ostentatiously artsy visuals...and far more concern for mood than narrative coherence, it's a film that tries to mimic the style of Terrence Malick and succeeds only too well.

A legal thriller curiously devoid of thrills--the sort of stolid, unexceptional film that might serve as a perfectly adequate offering on PBS Masterpiece Mystery but is woefully out of place on the big screen.
So completely idiotic you might swear it was made by Luc Besson and starred Jason Statham or Liam Neeson.
Part concert movie, part bio-sketch and all commercial [but] expertly directed, handsomely shot, spiffily edited and--perhaps most important of all--well recorded.
A broad, witless romantic comedy...a would-be homage that lacks both common sense and an appropriate sensibility.
A serious, gravely artistic, stylistically operatic film that's visually intoxicating but also a crashing bore.
A strong, moving portrait of a man shunned by the only society he knows for reasons he can't understand, marked by a stunning lead performance from [Mads] Mikkelsen.
Strangely affecting...a small-scaled film that offers an alternately funny and sad rumination on the fragility of human affairs.
While this is hardly Bier at her best, the agreeable leads, lovely locale and tweaking of romantic comedy conventions make the film more engaging than one might expect.
A pedestrian work that exhibits none of the imagination and daring its subject was famous for.
Its predecessor was almost shamefully giddy fun. By contrast Wadlow's picture is simply shameful...nasty, brutish, but certainly not short.
A genre exercise that shows some promise, but descends from pleasant obfuscation into patent absurdity.
The angst doesn't deepen the action, nor does the action energize the melodrama.
Etches a moving portrait of the enduring love of a couple whose life together only appears to be ordinary.
Inoffensive but insufferably bland...while it will do as a cinematic babysitter, it's not much more than that.
A buddy-cop action flick with a ludicrously convoluted plot but plenty of energy and good star chemistry.
A standard-issue creepshow, undermined by script holes and a meager budget that brings distinctly subpar effects.
A sitcom elongated to excruciating feature length...a misfire on almost all counts.
A repetitive but still compelling piece of activist filmmaking.
As a boys' adventure tale, it's not awful, but not particularly wonderful either.
'National Lampoon's Vacation' retooled for the 'Hangover' generation...aims for the funnybone but more often hits the crotch.
Completely lacking in imagination and panache, it makes for a boring flight during which passengers young and old will inevitably get restless.
Expertly made but intellectually shallow, especially when it devolves into standard-issue he-man heroics in the last act.

Both a sharp-edged character study of a woman on the verge of a psychological breakdown and a cannily-constructed ensemble piece reflecting the differences of class and culture that permeate American life.
A shocking exhibition of what Hannah Arendt called the banality of evil--or, in this case, the absurdity of evil.
The spin it gives to the story makes for an intriguingly stylish, if incomplete, biography/cautionary tale.
An earnest, well-intentioned film...obviously a labor of love for all concerned, [but] manipulative, melodramatic and rather simplistic.
A mostly competent but utterly mediocre exercise in outer-space mayhem.
A thoroughly brainless movie...action without wit or even coherence.
It's the absolute pits.
Earns points for dealing with a serious social issue...but by trying to pass muster as a conventional action movie while delivering its message, it comes up a mite short.
Since all the second-hand ingredients are delivered without much style or flair, the movie makes for a pretty insipid dish.
A surprisingly deft, enjoyable variation on the old tale... [with] a vibe reminiscent of Rob Reiner's 'Princess Bride.'
Fine but conventional documentary on the problem of hunger in contemporary America.
Remarkable for its unusual perspective...but never manages to connect emotionally as deeply as it might have.
Or 'The Hangover: The College Edition'--and totally abysmal...the pits in every respect.

There's a bit of a cable-movie feel to 'Bless Me, Ultima,' but in the end its sincerity and willingness to address big issues...make it an admirable attempt to bring an important piece of Chicano literature to the screen.
Dramatically waterlogged and, despite the efforts of a strong cast, more than a little silly.
Despite the title, Sam Raimi's new Oz movie isn't great; it isn't even good.

Extraordinary...not only an engrossing first-hand account of Israel's Palestinian policies over time, but one that may have lessons to teach both Israeli leaders and other nations confronting those they identify as terrorists.
A decent history lesson--even if one told with a major dose of dramatic license--that's dragged down by a sappy, clumsily played romantic subplot.
An alphabetically-organized horror anthology that's often unsettling but only sporadically rises above mediocrity and sometimes descends into absolute awfulness.
A noirish, rather ugly crime melodrama with pretensions that never get past pulp cliche.
Larrain fashions an unlikely crowd-pleaser from a historical episode that has its share of tragedy as well as triumph.
This feeble sequel makes even its lackluster predecessor look good--or at least less terrible than it was.

Quite simply one of the great documentary projects in the history of cinema, an engrossing sociological experiment on film; and though this mostly mellow installment isn't as revelatory as some earlier ones, it's still a remarkable document.

Nobody goes to a movie in this franchise expecting an exercise in intelligence, but even the most die-hard fans will have a difficult time swallowing [this] entry...which falls into the depths of dumbness at the very start and goes downhill from there.
movie_title: A Good Day To Die Hard (2013)

movie_review_blurb: The combination of turgid treacle and bonehead mystery culminates in a concluding twist of such complete goofiness that you almost have to admire the utterly shameless tugging at the heartstrings--almost, but not quite.
If you've seen the 'Paradise Lost' trilogy on the case, 'West of Memphis' will be a must. If not, it's even more so.
An old-fashioned, painfully earnest film that conjures up a Capra-like populist fable of the little people taking on the powerful, only to switch suddenly into cynical mode in the last act.
Pretty thin stuff...a geriatric version of the old "let's put on a show!" plot...but it's been cannily cast for maximum effect, and Hoffman gives the actors plenty of room to do their thing.
Isn't as bad as you'd expect...but it's further evidence that the kindest cut would be to leave these old movies alone.
A dumbed-down version of 'The Untouchables' done in floridly violent comic-book style.
A thrill-free, strangely sluggish political potboiler.
To mangle the old cliche, politics' loss is not cinema's gain.
Though it's visually elegant...and boasts some genuinely creepy moments, it's narratively thin and repetitive, and relies too much on 'gotcha' moments that quickly grow tiresome.
A goofy grab bag of computer-manipulated stunts, endless fights, creature effects and supposedly cheeky but definitely lame dialogue, limply directed.
Surprisingly light and whimsical...a blissful contrast to the deadly earnestness of the inter-species romance of 'Twilight' and its ilk.
A middling action movie, neither great nor terrible...efficient but completely unexceptional.
More curdled nostalgia than cinematic excitement.
A clever thriller with so many twists that you'll probably stop counting.
Dismal...Lots of things get stolen in 'Identity Thief,' but the biggest heist is of the hundred minutes you'll lose forever watching it.
If Tim Burton had made 'Twilight' on an off day, the result would have been something like this.
It may be more 'The Merely Okay Burt Wonderstone,' but as Frank Loesser observed, mediocrity is not a mortal sin.
An emptily flamboyant explosion of style over substance.
An extremely unsavory thriller that's like a grosser, grislier (and dumber) episode of 'CSI' or 'Criminal Minds.'
Much less clever than one might hope, a film based on a couple of slender premises that earn an occasional chuckle but little more.
Claustrophobic and repetitive...a numbingly tedious would-be thriller.
Wants to be a goofy blend of farce and violence but comes off as a nasty, brutal, cringe-inducing misfire.
An extended sitcom with a particularly raunchy streak that grows more and more artificial and hard to stomach as it proceeds.
Dark, gloomy, chaotic and basically misanthrophic...Iron Man in Dark Knight territory.
A sort of grown-up version of a boys' adventure tale...most travelers will be happy to disembark when the credits roll.
An earnest, serious film, but ultimately one that fails to satisfactorily dramatize the subject--or to transcend a bare, frustrating didacticism.
This isn't a great 'Gatsby,' but it's quite a good one...Despite the spectacle-for-spectacle's sake filmmaking philosophy and lack of interpretive depth the picture works on its own terms.
An extraordinary combination of documentary and dramatization...a Holocaust film that's also a modern detective story.
An old-fashioned, fifties-style melodrama, it offers a host of plots and sub-plots, twists and turns that frankly never congeal--except to make a rather murky mess.
Given the quality of the cast,...this highly uneven, ill-constructed comedy is a disappointment.
A sprawling, lumbering epic that manages to preserve a substantial amount of the book's content but achieves little of its magic.
Nearly as exciting and engaging as its predecessor, and just as supremely well crafted.
An engaging if incomplete portrait of an unconventional politician.
Ridiculously reverential...a love letter to the famously upscale New York department store, lacking any critical sense.
A brooding, neo-noir portrait of a psychopath who balances an apparently normal family life with a career as a cold-blooded hit-man.
Despite (or because of) Huard's mugging, 'Starbuck' is more likely to cause queasiness than smiles of contentment.
A visual marvel that's unfortunately pretty derivative in terms of plotting.
An artificial exercise about people who are synthetic in more ways than one.
Great-looking but not very filling...this stately, solemn film is yet another sci-fi epic that's technically accomplished but narratively derivative.
Dumb, slick, shallow and cartoonish, a piece of jingoistic claptrap that merely panders to patriotic emotion.
The animation is excellent [but] 'The Croods' features characters who have remarkably little personality and dialogue that has very little wit.
There are moments of striking visual beauty and dramatic intensity...but...as a whole is a disappointment.
Just a bombastically brainless summer behemoth that's arrived a few months early.
Meyer has concocted an extremely silly story made worse by Andrew Niccol's ponderous, self-important adaptation.
Garish, goofy, leering and nasty, it's meant to be hypnotic, but winds up nearly unwatchable.
The reach of 'The Place Beyond the Pines' exceeds its grasp, and the result is intermittently powerful but ultimately disappointing.
Just another gorefest, not appreciably different from the scads of other similar dreck that floods into theatres every month nowadays.
Doesn't always mix its anti-prejudice message and its feel-good nostalgia with complete smoothness. But despite some ragged edges it provides a reasonably good time.
A diverting excursion for lovers of Kubrick's films...even if, at over a hundred minutes, it does go on a bit long.
By the close you're likely to be exhausted by the effort to keep things straight and angry that you bothered to try.
Lacks the visceral energy that would raise it from the level of a curiously humdrum political thriller.
Has its heart in the right place but plays the inspirational card too often, and too ham-fistedly.
Ironically, by linking things up so snugly it damages its ability to connect with us.
Banal ideas presented as deep thoughts and bandied about in a self-consciously poetic style.
A coming-of-age tale that's also a suspense thriller...this beautifully realized picture is easily one of the year's best thus far.
Engaging but uneven documentary...burdened by material that seems extraneous, not least much of the footage of Depp.
In lesser hands...could easily have become a tearjerker, but it neatly sidesteps the trap to remain truthful and affecting.
Though you can't logically buy into the movie in the slightest, at least you can enjoy it for the lurid trash that it is.
Will probably be embraced by committed Christians for its obvious sincerity and fidelity to the gospels...despite its many cinematic flaws.
History takes a beating in '300: Rise of an Empire,' and viewers get a pretty good pummeling, too....another wacky, CGI-dominated, ultra-macho bloodbath.
Has its less inspired stretches, but for the most part it's charming and funny, a nostalgia trip that should also appeal to newcomers.
A delight to the eye, intricatey designed and flawlessly crafted...[with] a streak of tenderness and melancholy to go along with Anderson's characteristic whimsy and wit.
A movie about fast cars that makes 'The Fast and the Furious'...look literate and clever...hilariously melodramatic muscle-car camp, unbearably loud and extremely stupid.
Might not offer new insights into a terrible conflict, but it depicts its human cost on the ground with often starling power.
A committed cast and crew do their best to keep this airplane thriller aloft, but ultimately a ludicrous premise and multiple plot inanities lead to a crash-landing, literally and figuratively.

A workmanlike but hardly scintillating mystery that spends more time and energy reintroducing characters from the show and trying to capture its original flavor than constructing a compelling narrative.
If vulgar language doesn't offend you overmuch, you'll find 'Bad Words' an engagingly off-color way to spend an hour and a half.
An oddly drab and unexciting portrait of a conspicuously nonsensical dystopian society... The combination of an inane premise and uninspired execution dooms the movie.
A genial but barely average installment in the long line of Muppet movies.
An extraordinarily atmospheric, unsettling film that raises mysteries that, in the end, remain insoluble.
What sets 'Big Men' apart and makes it engrossing is the extraordinary degree of access Boynton had to the major parties and the deftness with which she uses it.
Grows tedious...by the close the breathing has become, shall we say, more than a little labored.
A slick, taut, reality-based little cyber-thriller that may be a mite dated in technological terms but still fascinates because of its sheer luridness.
Isn't terrible, but it tries much too hard to be hip and sassy while telling a story that, to be honest, is far less fresh than it wants to be.
While one might certainly debate how persuasive the non-fictional implications of the story are, it's difficult not to be moved by the fictional narrative that leads to them.
An irresistibly engaging documentary that might be described as a lab experiment in art history presented with Las Vegas-style showmanship.
It not only resurrects figures from Dickens' own life, but gives them some of the richness, humanity and frailty that mark those he created on the page.
A cheesy riff on the 'Rosemary's Baby' and 'Omen' template, deserving of nothing more than rotation on the SyFy and Chiller networks.
Like an Afterschool Special intended for the Eternal Word Network.
Pretty much a mess...truly a terrible movie.
A plodding, mushy melodrama in Nicholas Sparks mode [that] might have been a labor of love for Reitman, but for the audience is just laborious.
Awful rather than awkward is the operative adjective here...you wince as the game cast strives to make the picture tolerable, and fails miserably.
A fascinating story tepidly told...a prosaic, pedestrian take on a subject that should have elicited real passion from its makers.
Even those who have never touched the little plastic blocks should find it unexpectedly enjoyable.
Toothless genre mash-up, which should finally put a stake into the heart of these teen vampire movies.

A competent action movie, but one that could have been, like the 1987 film, something more than that...the set-pieces are impressively choreographed [but] they can't but have a been-there, seen-that feel.
A dud of epic proportions, a fantasy that's less magical than risible.
Mawkish folderol...so glossy and bland that you'd swear it had migrated from the CW onto the big screen, and feel yourself inclined to doze off as it unspools.
A respectable, though hardly entrancing, adaptation of Zola's once-notorious novel, though there's a whiff of minor Masterpiece Theatre about it.
At one point in '3 Days to Kill' Kevin Costner says, 'I've done some terrible things.' The movie proves it.
While...a pleasure only in the guiltiest of senses, if you're willing to leave your brain in the lobby it can be giddily amusing as an exercise in wretched excess.
A grotesquely nasty piece of work...a rancid, nihilistic wallow in cynicism and gore.

Won't please literalists...and it's frequently a bit absurd. But visually 'Noah' evinces a sort of loony grandeur, and emotionally it possesses much stronger resonance than one might expect, not least because of Russell Crowe's zealous performance.
A rousing adventure that will make devoted Captain America fans swoon while also pleasing those who met him only in the first film, but also touches on some hot-button contemporary issues.
Another portrait in Morris' extraordinary gallery of self-deluding subjects, one more famous than the others.
Isn't just like watching paint dry; it's like watching paint dry, scraping it off, repainting, watching it dry again, scraping it off, repainting, watching it dry, and so on interminably.
Doesn't really deserve the titular adjective, but while it doesn't match the second movie in Raimi's threesome, it's slightly better than Webb's first.
Both informative and entertaining [though] less a straightforward cinematic argument than a dreamlike, multilevel evocation.
Aims to be mysterious but merely comes off as monotonous...the sort of film that should have the word 'cult' stamped onto the canisters containing the reels.
With its potentially unsavory premise and mixture of comic and dramatic overtones...a cinematic high-wire act that constantly threatens to slip into tastelessness but manages to keep its footing.
Despite Hardy's impressive solo tour de force, 'Locke' is ultimately a talky trip to a pretty sappy destination.
An engrossing, beautifully appointed, if somewhat prosaic and historically loose, docu-drama.
Frat-boy humor in every sense...a coarse and sloppy gross-out comedy made all the worse by the occasional moments that suggest it could have been something more.
A tight, taut, suspenseful little thriller...offering an effective series of tension-building sequences punctuated by outbursts of violent action.
Basically mediocre...what is does is prove there's no place like Victor Fleming's Oz.
Coming from such a talented filmmaker, the film is disappointingly prosaic, unable to shake a Lifetime movie-of-the-week quality.
An innocuous crowd-pleaser...[a] wholesome, pleasant but incredibly formulaic and predictable inspirational fact-based sports tale.
Weirdly earnest, it has the pea-sized brain of a dinosaur but compensates with an impressive display of sound and fury that practically raises the roof off an IMAX auditorium.
A recipe that most audiences will be unable to resist, though by any standard the nutritional value is negligible. And at least cinematic comfort food like this won't put on pounds.
A rather pallid, pedestrian telling of a tale that screams out for more imaginative treatment.
An abysmal horror movie that apparently wants to evoke the spirit of paranormal thrillers of the sixties (like 'The Haunting') but quickly degenerates into a chaotic mishmash of modern genre tropes.
Quite simply, a superb soap opera, but no more than that.
Intriguing, though cinematically prosaic and factually loose.
A filmmaker's labor of love about a woman whose oddly secretive artistic career seems to have been a labor of love as well.
An often intense and poignant comedy-drama [that] actually leaves you wanting more because it's created characters so rich.
Earnest but cliche-ridden...you're left with the feeling you've seen it all many times before, and needn't have seen it again.
A powerful piece of Southern gothic that gives Nicolas Cage his best role in years.
Simply tries too hard; overly busy and uncomfortably noisy, it tries one's patience, though the animation is colorful and kids might enjoy it.
A loser...loaded with cliches and inanities, it huffs and puffs but ends up more winded than pumped-up.
Feels weighted down by its ambitions [but] it's pretty hypnotic. And it boasts some fantastic action, though the violence is ludicrously over-the-top.
A taste of what might have been--and even if you doubt that the completed film would have been as remarkable as Jodorowsky and his admirers are inclined to claim, it's a tantalizing taste.
[A] slow-burning supernatural thriller [that's] uneven but genuinely eerie and unsettling, clever in its use of 'gotcha' moments and sparing in its employment of blood.
Often a striking visual experience [but] little more than a modern Luddite fable so puerile in conception that it rivals 'V for Vendetta' in lack of intellectual depth.
Though it's nothing more than a lark, it's one more engaging than most.
Too mild for its own good, a formulaic 'worm turns' story that doesn't take full advantage of its dance milieu.
The story is compelling but the telling less than ideal...ponderous rather than powerful.

As cinematic sermons go...slicker than most...But it's still a sermon [that] breaks the 'faith-based' mold in terms of production quality but in the end succumbs to the usual pattern of playing to the faithful.
Hardly a great children's movie, but the young actors are a pleasant enough bunch that at least you don't feel like squashing it.
Numbingly stupid and uncommonly nasty, this is the sort of chick flick that gives chick flicks a really bad name.
The narrative comes across as even sillier than it did in 2004, and the action less exhilarating, [while] the aggravating visual style makes it a trial to watch.
The alcohol flows freely...but happily not all the high spirits are of the liquid variety.
A pleasingly old-fashioned piece [that] manages to deliver a couple of hours of cheekily retro, amusingly implausible spycraft.
Surly Squirrel...garners fewer laughs over the course of 86 minutes than Scrat, the rodent from 'Ice Age,' gets in three or four.
A piece of lurid pulp...[whose] similarity to '21' is so striking that it should really be titled 'Rerunner Rerunner.'
Every bit as bad as most Hollywood romantic comedies.
Both uplifting and realistic, charming and incisive.
Comes across like a dumbed-down Cliffs Notes version of the classic directed at the 'Twilight' crowd.
If it's not the director's best work, in comparison to that of others it's still a potent piece of fact-based drama.
Doesn't rise much beyond the level of a sitcom that might find a home on premium cable rather than Fox.
Compulsively watchable [although] the film comes across as a little tacky, and some will even see it, fairly or not, as exploitative.
A horror film that takes considerable risks and generally makes them work.
Apart from the curious political subtext, it's mostly a standard-issue innocent-man-breaking-out-of-jail movie, enlivened primarily by Schwarzenegger's sense of abandon.
While it will never achieve the classic status of De Palma's take on King's first novel, it offers a serious, respectable alternative.
An important work, but one that's more potent on an intellectual level than an emotional one.
Terrible--nasty, ultra-violent and borderline incoherent.
Utterly mediocre. It probably won't be long before it goes the way of the dodo.
Thoroughly predictable, no more than mildly amusing, and utterly maudlin when it veers into sentimental mode.
As fascinating as its protagonist, but just about as flawed.
An astonishing technical tour de force and an exciting thrill ride, but as a human drama it barely registers, and it carries none of the metaphysical weight of a film like '2001.'
Basically constitutes a liberal jeremiad, but it's one presented with civility, good humor and a human face as well as impassioned conviction.
Trippy in one sense but trite in another...contains some genuinely gonzo eye-candy, but the weirdly imaginative images are wedded to a tired script.
movie_title: Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs 2 (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Does not make for an evening's pleasure.
It resembles a decent academic lecture on the subject...interesting, if hardly scintillating.
movie_title: Money for Nothing: Inside the Federal Reserve (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Whether you find the result tedious or enlightening will be a factor of your openness to the director's languidly atmospheric approach.
Strongly cast, but Besson proves incapable of melding the nastiness and laughs into a cohesive whole--the result is tonally schizophrenic and abrasive.
Nothing in the picture delivers the jolts that the first 'Insidious,' or Wan's more recent 'The Conjuring,' did.
An intermittently powerful piece, driven by Farahani's nuanced performance, though eventually its verbosity takes a toll.
A terrific thriller, shattering domestic drama and probing character study in a single package.
Heartfelt and well-intentioned, but it comes across like an adult version of an afterschool special.
A slow-moving, unsurprising piece of noirish backwoods pulp.
A solid PBS-level treatment of the triumphs and setbacks in the career of a man who challenged American prejudices at a time when they were still very deep and very dangerous.
Buries a few nuggets in a mountain of repetition and overstatement.
Delivers the adrenaline rush the title promises, but thankfully it does more than that, providing an engrossing--and ultimately stirring--human story as well.
Apart from Gandolfini, this is just bland, middlebrow fare that's not intrinsically superior to standard-issue Hollywood romantic comedies.
Undoubtedly raunchy, but it's also pretty funny [and] far more mature and insightful than the frat-boy gross-out farces that come down the pike every week or so.
It would have been better for all concerned if [it] had been consigned to that limbo where lost luggage winds up, never to be heard from again.
When this schmaltzy, brutally manipulative dramedy finally grinds to a halt, it's you who'll probably be saying 'It's about time.'
A survival story that eschews melodramatic exaggeration in favor of a straightforward approach that extends to Redford's understated yet authoritative performance.
Handsomely mounted but silly and tedious...a striking-looking film that never achieves the epic quality the makers are evidently straining for.
A brainless, chaotic piece of comic-book hokum so loud and action-packed that by the end you might feel you've been clobbered over the head by the hero's big old hammer.
Cartoonish, shambling, disjointed [and] as resolutely dumb as its characters.
Russell's loopy, messy reworking of the 1970s Abscam scandal is...done to a twisted turn.... You'll be happy to have been so thoroughly had.
Though it embraces a host of cliches and tugs all too insistently at the heartstrings...viewers should respond with affection to this slickly manipulative crowd-pleaser.
A brilliant portrait of the artist as a failed man.
An ambitious effort to meld learning and entertainment that ultimately works as neither.
A self-help message swaddled in some surrealistically quirky trappings...none of it is terribly funny.
movie_title: The Secret Life Of Walter Mitty (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Though it goes on too long and comes across the finish line a little winded, [it's] a mostly exciting ride on the Wall Street wild side--so long as you don't expect a moral at the end beyond 'don't get caught.'
Doesn't wind up face down on the mat, but this recycling of 'Grumpy Old Men' with boxing gloves certainly loses on points.
A respectable effort, but far from an inspired one.
In their quest to give the classic story international appeal, the makers have turned '47 Ronin' into an extravagant live-action comic book with a distinctly juvenile sensibility.
Subnormal horror fare...the combination of an unimaginative plot with what's by now a pedestrian technique makes for a pretty barren ninety minutes.
Yet another adaptation of a well-regarded stage piece that hasn't translated particularly well to the screen.
Surprisingly touching and tender...commentary on the modern realities of personal connection.
Captures the intensity of the 2005 mission...[but] fails to go beyond first-rate reenactment ...to a deeper assessment of how and why it happened in the broader context of the war.
Played with an earnestness that's positively deadly, this unholy mash-up of '300' and 'Gladiator'...seems to drag on for an eternity.
Even those who find it overstuffed, opaque and derivative will be bowled over by its sheer pictorial extravagance and visual sheen.
An action comedy in which the action is rote and the laughs pretty scsrce.
Providing a riot of action but little more than that, [it's] big and visually opulent but oddly lumbering and dull.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug (2013)

movie_review_blurb: A film...at war with itself...the trappings of serious commentary on contemporary socio-economic issues simply do not sit happily on a narrative arc reminiscent of seventies exploitation fare.
Despite its aristocratic pedigree...rather tacky.

Can be criticized for shoehorning its story into a familiar framework to make it more comfortable for mainstream audiences. But the astonishing performances by McConaughey and Leto nonetheless give it a powerful charge.
A visually spiffy but narratively flabby ensemble piece that veers uneasily from raucous farce to mawkish melodrama.
Its fidelity to the source and its stylish, though somewhat sedate approach make it a good, if not great, modern alternative to Lean's still-superb filmization.
Readers of the book should be more than satisfied, and non-devotees will find this a smoother, more affecting ride than its predecessor as well.
A retread...This is the first Gibney film that feels superfluous.
Improve[s] on the original. That doesn't mean that the picture is any less manipulative or simple-minded than its source, only that it's easier to take.
Undoubtedly high-minded and well-intentioned, but it's also overplotted and sentimentalized.
Maintains a wonderful balance between sentiment and satire...almost magical in its mixture of humor and poignancy.
The patient viewer will come away from it understanding the breadth and importance of what such an academic enterprise does.
A distinctly old-fashioned, by-the-numbers actioner that breaks no new ground and treads familiar territory without much dash.
Maintains a dignified sense of decorum while pushing all the buttons that make for a successful crowd-pleaser.
Even though its heart is in the right place and it boasts a strong cast, it's a case of preaching--and singing--to the choir.
Among Disney's recent non-Pixar animated efforts, it falls between 'Tangled' and 'Wreck-It Ralph' on the one hand and 'Planes' on the other...middle-grade at best.
A respectable piece of filmmaking from a purely technical perspective [but an] unnecessary, inferior remake...Lee's 'Oldboy' is harder to swallow than the octopus in Park's original.
All the cinematic extravagance is merely a cloak for what's essentially an overripe tearjerker.
Might as well have been titled 'Granddaddy Day Care'...a bland, predictable vehicle for what might have been the inspired pairing of Billy Crystal and Bette Midler.
A wordless delight...unfailingly charming and comically inventive.

A moodily grim, choppily edited potboiler with a howlingly ludicrous ending...The sheer luridness of 'Dark Places' may hold your attention, but by the close the goofy plot twists and laughable motivations will probably induce a few snickers.

Beautifully crafted and, like its subject, high-minded; it is not, however, exciting, as one might expect a tale of exploration of a dangerous environment to be...at times one wishes Gray had taken a few risks--after all, Fawcett certainly did.
Coming to terms with imminent death is not an easy subject for a film, but Cesc Gay treats it with commendable delicacy, a welcome absence of sentimentality, and not a little humor.
An old-fashioned Gothic mood piece whose craftsmanship holds one's attention, but proves disappointing in the end.
Takes up a subject the invites sharp satire and suspenseful paranoia, but turns it into something bland and forgettable.
Overstuffed...an elephantine sequel to a movie that was lighter on its feet; it tries so hard that the strain shows all too clearly.
An interesting but frustrating mess.

Essentially a Lifetime woman-in-peril movie with more gloss and explicit sex and all the clichés one expects of the genre, it's so ludicrous that audiences will likely be chortling derisively before the first half-hour is over.
A strange film, alternately credible and ludicrous, compelling and dull, darkly funny and gloomily depressing, though bolstered by a star turn that's basically a stunt but is still an enjoyable one.
movie_title: Norman (Norman: The Moderate Rise and Tragic Fall of a New York Fixer) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A minimalist military survival story that comes across largely as a technical exercise, though admittedly an efficiently manufactured one, with an ending that will probably confound audience expectations.
A boxing movie that happily avoids the clichés of most boxing movies...a nifty footnote to Stallone's famous film.
'Trainwreck' was the title of Amy Schumer's first starring vehicle; it's an accurate description of her second.
A coolly effective entry in the series, delivering some real jolts along the way.

A formulaic blend of slapstick and sentiment that youngsters up to age ten or so will probably enjoy, though it's not much superior to the sort of teleflicks they can regularly see on kids' cable channels.
movie_title: Diary Of A Wimpy Kid: The Long Haul (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Though a bit too cleverly contrived in the end, its voice is sufficiently distinctive to set it apart.
A dispiritingly lowbrow would-be epic-a modern-day bastardization rather than an imaginative rethinking, totally lacking in grandeur.
movie_title: King Arthur: Legend Of The Sword (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Tries to integrate its formulaic melodramatics into the historical context, but does so in such a pedestrian fashion that they instead diminish the enormities of the barbarity against which they're set.
Wheatley's empty exercise in spoofy carnage can't sustain itself over feature length.
Deftly balances humor and drama to fashion a picture of life under wartime stress that's both richly funny and occasionally quite moving.
While the new version is engaging enough, it's inferior to the original, and so basically unnecessary...apart from the cash flow, what's the point?
A film that challenges you to figure things out rather than have them spoon-fed to you..[a]nd it gives Broadbent...the relatively rare opportunity to shine in a lead role worthy of his gifts.
A stale reminder of what once seemed new and fresh...done up with frenetic dash that reeks more of desperation than inspiration.
The technical polish and Hollywood star power aren't enough to save the movie from a been-there, seen-that feel.
Whatever magic might have existed on the printed page evaporates in a meandering, tone-deaf tale that trades in blunt eccentricity until it succumbs to sloppy sentiment.

Though its parts don't entirely cohere, this is a fascinating, if sometimes frustrating, piece of work-a slow-moving, macabre psychological thriller that, while implausible, casts an intoxicating spell.

Opts for the lowest-hanging fruit rather than reach for the deeper issues it incidentally raises... you can perhaps intuit a smarter movie in 'The Boss Baby' than it appears to be on its polished, frantic surface, but it may not be worth the effort.
It's an inspiring tale [but] frankly, the Zabinskis, and those they helped, deserve a better cinematic memorial than this.
A bloated, bombastic and ultimately vacuous orgy of mayhem that-if you'll permit a play on its heroine's title-proves a Major disappointment.
Unlike the little girl at its center, it turns out to be a quite ordinary exercise in heartwarming schmaltz.

It's sporadically amusing to watch Caine, Freeman and Arkin do their thing, however little is asked of them. But that's not enough; one keeps imagining what they could have made of stronger, more challenging material.
Just another comic-book-level explosion of muscle-car mayhem, macho posturing, ludicrous stunts and juvenile banter. But it's been efficiently manufactured, even if it has an assembly-line feel.
A film whose ostensibly placid surface opens to reveal powerful undercurrents of pain, hopefulness and moral uncertainty.
Handsome to look at and sporadically engaging, but overall it comes across as repetitive and only superficially enlightening.

An honorable attempt to portray the family dynamic of two men who had a powerful impact on the development of golf as a sport of the common man...but ultimately the staid reverence with which it treats their story undermines its dramatic impact.
Simmers intently beneath a veneer of cool propriety, just as its subject herself did...a richly textured expression of its maker's distinctive voice, in the processing capturing Dickinson's as well.
Shallow and sappy... Ultimately 'Everything, Everything' amounts to very little.
Yet another misfire based on a crummy old TV series...a would-be summer blockbuster that might not be as excruciatingly bad as you might fear but certainly isn't a cinematic day at the beach.
The most see-worthy entry in the 'Pirates' franchise since the first installment, but still a comparatively leaky vessel, with Depp's Sparrow in particular a shadow of his former self.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Arguably spins out of control in the last act, but overall it makes for a wild ride that provides the sort of juice you'd expect from a top-of-the-line muscle car.
Both beautiful and unsettling...dependent more on atmosphere and suggestion rather than overt titillation.
Historically convincing in the visual details but completely bogus in terms of narrative, in particular the pallid central romance.
Running on fumes, dependent on the good will viewers might bring from their recollection of its predecessors.
A complete loser, so excruciatingly bad that it makes you cringe while watching it.

Human and humane, it is sweet without being saccharine, funny without becoming raucous, and touching without degenerating into mawkishness-the rare rom-com that appeals to your intelligence rather than insulting it.

A mixed bag: it's nice to have Spider-Man rebooted with an actor so right for the part as Holland, but the effort to integrate him into the wider Marvel Universe raises doubts the movie doesn't resolve.
A touching character study... a charming portrait of a woman who found a life of simple contentment with a most unlikely partner.
While the film is undoubtedly simplistic and fictional, it speaks to high aspirations while acknowledging the messiness of politics-and because of its superlative cast, it's also great fun.
Maintains the high quality of the first two episodes, bringing the story to a solid, if preordained, conclusion in a narratively imaginative fashion.
movie_title: War for the Planet of the Apes (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Though it's actually well-made from a purely technical standpoint, the grim efficiency of the execution can't overcome the essential silliness of the premise.
Sappy melodrama, the sort of thing that gives so-called 'women's pictures' a bad name.
Eurotrash on steroids as only Luc Besson can confect it...a goofy special-effects acid trip in the form of a berserk science-fiction cartoon.
movie_title: Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A disappointment, a visual marvel but one lacking in emotional resonance, the sort of film one respects for its craftsmanship-but feels distanced from.
A bold, unsettling transposition of Leskov's grim take on a Shakespearean motif-a promising debut for its director and a stunning breakthrough for its star.
A heightened portrait of the modern American male in mid-life crisis...that fascinates even when it doesn't fully convince.
Manipulative [but] manages to generate a good deal of suspense, and empathy, from a tale based on actual historical events.
Megatrash as only Bay can make it, this represents some of the most inane drivel ever to (dis)grace the screen-and an obscene waste of money to boot.
Though it's likely to divide viewers pro and con, the fact that it attempts to do something different, defying easy categorization in the process, itself makes it worth seeing despite its flaws.
The French cuisine the camera ogles in 'Paris Can Wait' looks succulent, but the movie itself is a bland dish.
A psychological thriller that's expertly put together but, in the end, doesn't bring enough twists to its rather predictable plot trajectory.
For roughly half of its nearly two-and-a-half-hour running time, 'Wonder Woman' is a better-than-average superhero movie; a pity it falls off so precipitously in the last act.
A provocative portrait of the great man less based on history than imagination and abounding in cinematic cliché, but showcasing a virtuoso performance by Cox.
Two people you'll wish you hadn't met... just an oddly bland would-be romance followed by a long spasm of ultra-violence.
While the movie will undoubtedly please the under-eight set...older kids and their parents might find their tolerance tested and long for a return of 'Big Hero 6' instead.
movie_title: Captain Underpants: The First Epic Movie (Captain Underpants) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A big, blustery, jokey special-effects-laden extravaganza that delivers few thrills and even fewer chills....this 'Mummy' should never have been unwrapped.
An elegant 'Masterpiece Theatre'-style adaptation of the venerable tale, as smoothly seductive as its enigmatic heroine.
Not much more than a Hallmark Hall of Fame-style exercise in audience manipulation, but it's a better-than-average example of the type.
Hampered by start-and-stop execution that depends overmuch on implausible hair-breadth escapes and gets bogged down in sappy back story.
A small-scaled picture that builds a striking degree of tension through very economical means, a cousin of Eli Roth's 'Cabin Fever' that depends on atmosphere rather than gore for its effect.
An amiable but instantly forgettable addition to the series, yet another sign that the Pixar brand is no longer the guarantee of high quality it once was.
Provocative but also genuinely entertaining... very much a fable for our time.
In an era that has descended to 'Sharknado' [this is] a fairly toothless entry in the 'Jaws'-inspired genre.
A patchy assemblage of familiar 'girls gone wild' shtick, weighed down by a dark twist that ultimately proves inconsequential and glib observations about female friendship.
Might be little more than a familiar tale of a man looking back regretfully at past mistakes and trying to redeem himself in his twilight hours, but [Elliott] makes it watchable-if only just.
By trying to be both grossly outlandish and sweetly endearing, the movie is alternately crass and mawkish.
A grim portrayal of unremitting brutality against women exacerbated by perverted religious belief, whose extraordinary stylishness doesn't entirely compensate for its underlying unpleasantness.
A sappy geriatric comedy that starts amusingly brittle but quickly goes soft, it's a showcase for MacLaine, but not a happy one.
One has to appreciate the effort to tweak the formula, even if the result isn't terribly successful.
A slick but superficial tale of crooked politicians and scheming lobbyists in Washington...[with] a pulp sensibility that marks it as a B-movie with aspirations.
A steamy neo-noir that builds considerable suspense while throwing a succession of narrative curves.
Trying to be wild and crazy, it's mild and lazy instead.

Efficiently made...but it comes across as an assembly-line product, an elaborate but fairly conventional action-adventure movie too dependent for its effect on references to earlier entries in the series.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A totally shameless, crudely manipulative tearjerker, but despite incredibly strenuous effort, it doesn't even succeed on that low level.
Attempting to be both a truthful psychological study and a tense family-oriented thriller, it succeeds as neither.
The swooning, cotton-candy, luxuriantly pastel vibe...has a rather effortful feel, but for those old enough to remember the halcyon days of film musicals, it will be a treat.

May not hit the highest note among recent animated movies, but it's an...amiable, fast-moving jukebox musical with a playlist adults will enjoy and enough cheerily colorful critter shenanigans to keep the kids happy.
A curiously tepid excursion into space, with little humanity and none of the sense of wonder it obviously aspires to.
The symbol of freedom it repeatedly references is a soaring eagle, but the movie itself is a dead duck.
A feeble string of raucous slapstick sequences, embarrassing scatological gags and cheap sexual jokes [that's] likely to leave you depressed rather than cheered.
'Fences' is historically significant, but more importantly it remains dramatically powerful, and this fastidious yet vibrant film ensures that nothing has been lost in its translation to the screen.
Tells a genuinely compelling story, but does so in a fashion that too often feels artificial, even borderline sitcomish [though] it's hard to resist the charm of the three lead actresses.
Whether...this amounts to much more than a bit of tabloidism with pretensions...is open to question.
In the hands of Lonergan and his exceptional cast, the deceptively simple story becomes a shattering tale of shared grief that carries a powerful weight of emotional truth.
The worst...The only question is whether it's more rancid or putrid. Decisions, decisions.
Youngsters, especially girls, will be captivated by Aisholpan's collaborative triumph with her pet, though others may feel that the film represents the Disneyfication of her story.
A searing coming-of-age tale, one that goes well beyond any genre boundaries to resonate in a universal way.

May feel overly subdued in telling such a major civil rights story in such a low-key fashion, but Nichols' gently intense approach is true to the character of the couple that made history without meaning to.
More brain-teaser than action film, this is an elegantly-wrought piece of thinking-person's science fiction...that plays with convention in unexpected and enthralling ways.
It's too bad that so attractive a cast was burdened with trying to inject some fun into such piffle...a far from festive cinematic experience.
An epic-length study of senior determination anchored in Sonia Braga's ferocious lead performance.

There have been many silly horror movies and psychological thrillers lately, but it's difficult to think of one quite as dumb as 'Shut In'...[it] won't scare you, except with its awfulness, but if you need a good laugh it might do the trick.
A less than magical introduction to the new series...a slightly misshapen piece in which the secondary characters are more immediately appealing than the central ones.
movie_title: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A lurid film noir, but one done so stylishly that it transcends the genre.
Fails to achieve the balance of sharp satire and dramatic heft that Lee was aiming for.
Surprisingly sharp and insightful and often very funny, but with a strong strain of serious drama in the mix.
Younger's treatment of this inspirational tale is what might be termed a dogged but ultimately rather flatfooted entry in the boxing genre.
An intoxicating blend of sex, mystery, and violence about an indelible character you'll find it difficult to forget-but would probably prefer never to meet in real life.
Tweaks the Disney animated template but sticks to its essentials, and does so nicely-it might not be revolutionary, but it's exuberantly familiar.

A mostly enjoyable lark-a character study of a real character, whom Beatty plays to the hilt, with a dash of secondary romance...it has an old-fashioned, shuffling charm that wins you over in the end.
A cornball, cliché-ridden World War II romance that...succumbs to cinematic elephantitis of a nearly risible sort.
Designed to be a crowd-pleaser, but after a turbulent, heart-wrenching first act, the second-meant to be touchingly uplifting-instead comes across as rather shallow and pedestrian by comparison.
