A curiously passionless passion project, a film that treats of great themes without attaining greatness itself. One can admire its ambition and craft, but... it fails to engender the devastating emotional impact it's clearly aiming for.
Visually imaginative but lacking in narrative magic...a beautifully wrought but curiously sterile affair that probably won't appeal overmuch to either children or their parents.

Because of the subject matter...it can't help but have strong emotional impact, even if ultimately it doesn't measure up to Paul Greengrass's 'United 93' (still the touchstone of this genre)-or the previous Berg-Wahlberg films.
Slick but overcooked...a horror thriller that shows some promise but has been tricked up to its own detriment.
Fast, funny, and visually spectacular, it's every bit as good as the original 'Lego Movie.'
A typical contemporary R-rated comedy, confusing coarseness for humor and nastiness for smarts.
Zhang Yimou is one of China's (indeed, the world's) most esteemed directors, but with 'The Great Wall' he proves that he can make a big-budget fiasco as junky as any Michael Bay behemoth.
As lacerating a portrait of marriage and family in Iranian society as the one Farhadi presented in 'A Separation,' though of a very different sort.
A tale so absurd, presented with such ludicrous solemnity, that it becomes an unintentional spoof.

Strives for a 'Doctor Zhivago' vibe but falls miles short...the earnest but unimaginative approach results in an old-fashioned romantic melodrama that fails to do justice to the historical horrors that serve as its backdrop.
Hits the bull's-eye dead on... Funny, creepy and thought-provoking at the same time, it's a picture that transcends mere genre pigeonholing to become an outstanding blend of different elements.

It's terminally bland, the script lacking any sense of surprise or suggestion of edginess; adults will find it utterly predictable, but even tykes are likely to react to the 'follow your dream' message with a ho-hum attitude.
If proof were needed that not even a starry cast can save a trashy script, 'Collide' certainly provides it.
Meretricious hooey...that turns the premise of an endlessly-repeating day into an inane, fatally humorless afterschool special.
Gives Hugh Jackman's Wolfie a smoothly-executed but hard-R sendoff that arguably represents the high point of the actor's nearly two-decade run in the role.
No better than moderately amusing, like a decent but forgettable network sitcom.

Another gritty Indonesian martial-arts extravaganza that offers little food for thought but a steady stream of over-the-top action....there are undeniably plenty of visceral thrills here for fans of the genre.
Dutifully assembled but ultimately fails to capture the spark needed to turn it into something special.

Passionate yet incisive, moving yet clear-sighted, Peck's impressionistic documentary offers a salutary reminder of how Baldwin so compellingly forced--and indeed still forces--his countrymen to confront racism in their society.
A deeply flawed film, as both romantic epic and historical commentary.
Flamboyantly trashy fare...resembl[ing] nothing as much as a mediocre puff piece in a slick woman's magazine.
A grab-bag of inane horror tropes [marked by] a lethargic, sleep-inducing pace accentuated by painfully murky visuals.

A grab-bag of hand-me-down horror movie clichés confusedly stitched together without much visual flair...its promotional tagline ...'Don't think it, don't say it' should really be expanded with 'don't see it.'
Essentially an autobiographical coming-of-age movie, one that includes a good many affecting moments but, in the last analysis, doesn't manage to bring them together into a satisfying whole.
Affleck's attempt at an epic gangster saga is a visually handsome portrait of flawed nobility that proves far more flawed than its protagonist.
Neither hatchet job nor panegyric, Hancock's clever film allows viewers to make up their own minds about Ray Kroc, whom Keaton brings vividly to life in a positively protean performance.
Louder, dumber and even more cartoonish than the original-which is saying a lot-and you come out of it feeling as though you'd been trapped inside an explosion for a couple of hours.
Perhaps it doesn't equal Almodovar's best films, but compared to trifle like his last, 'I'm So Excited,' it represents a definite return to form.
A gritty but rather pretentious tale of father-son conflict in a backwoods British family.
Shyamalan has made a horror movie that's cleverer than most, though not nearly as mind-blowing as his fervent admirers will claim.
The mixture of slapstick, melodrama, and cloying sentiment is tonally jarring, making for a movie that will convince cat people how right they are.
Overlong and-apart from a few truly bizarre moments-pretty obvious, it neither delivers consistent laughs nor carries any deep emotional impact.
Buoyed by McConaughey's unabashedly way-out performance, the result is sporadically amusing but inconsistent and, in the end, unsatisfying.

Even those who have resisted Jarmusch's idiosyncratic style in the past may find themselves drawn to this charmingly offbeat ode to the lift that a touch of poetry can bring to an ostensibly mundane existence.
An engrossing blend of poet and filmmaker, of history and art, done up in florid period style.
A movie that wants to be edgy but winds up as sappy and toothless as one could imagine.
A bland romance-on-the-run movie that might not actually be based on a YA novel, but sure feels as though it were.
A thoroughly brainless orgy of fights, shoot-outs, foot pursuits and car chases that should dazzle fans of such fare while leaving anyone who'd like a bit of steak to go with the sizzle cold.

Gibson uses tried-and-true tropes so effectively that you don't mind how hokey they actually are, and he stages the battle sequences...with such assurance that those craving violent action will be sated.
A powerful, remarkable profile of courage under fire.
A slender indie sitcom, peopled by characters who are simply annoying rather than quirkily charming.
While it doesn't match the brilliance of 'Ed Wood,' it's a mightily enjoyable, and equally affectionate, tribute to a misguided moviemaker.

Has a derivative feel, overly reminiscent not only of fifties Broadway drama but of some of Allen's previous pictures...while it probably won't bore you, it's likely to leave you with a feeling of déjà vu.
Little more than a glorified afterschool special, and the fact that it's strongly cast only adds to bewilderment about how it went so wrong.
Efficiently manufactured and enjoyable enough but overloaded with action and effects, and sorely lacking the magic that marked the first movies in the franchise.
Isn't unpleasant, but it is episodic and protracted, burying the book's simple message in an avalanche of unrelated clutter.
At once sympathetic in its portrayal of a boy tortured by circumstance and eerie in its presentiments about what he would become, it's emotionally unsettling but strangely moving.

From an historical point of view, there are aspects of Wright's film one might debate, but, capped by Oldman's strong performance, it's one of the better recent films about the great British statesman.
An unwieldy mash-up of a 1940s-style cliffhanger serial and 'The Breakfast Club' [that] boasts, however, a game cast that gives the material more than it's worth.
In 'Downsizing' Payne is, ironically, working on a larger scale than in the past, but his sharply honed focus on human foibles and failings remains intact.
Takes a rather sordid episode and turns it into a film of goofy humor leavened with some serious drama and a touch of heart.

This is, in the end, a simple and beautiful love story-a 'Brief Encounter' that happens to be gay, told with humanity and heart-wrenching truth. It is also, of course, one of the year's very best films.

Coming in just under the wire for consideration as the worst movie of the year, this big-budget Netflix original [is] a mess of apocalyptic proportions, a black hole of a movie that sucks all life from the screen.
One admires Scott's ability to reedit the film in response to circumstances more than the actual result of his having done so, which amounts to a rather thrill-free thriller.
movie_title: All the Money in the World (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Glitzy and energetically put together [but] ultimately the film represents intricacy without much depth and style without much substance.

Opulent but flat-footed, and loaded down with a series of top-forty style songs that sound like rejects from 'Frozen,' the movie insistently exhorts us to celebrate diversity while itself remaining obstinately commonplace.
A wondrous adult fairy-tale played out with impeccable cinematic control...a magical and moving experience.
An innocuous if rather bland family movie that should appeal especially to teenage girls [but] it would be more at home on the Hallmark Channel than at a multiplex.
This little would-be heist comedy proves an engaging trifle-nothing more than an extended sitcom, but a pretty good one.

[Has] a comic spin even in the action scenes... in a genre that often seems more intent on pummeling you into submission than giving you a good time, its light, breezy approach is a breath of fresh air.
A fairly standard-issue political docu-drama that's likely to hold your interest without being especially enlightening or vivid.
An engrossing, beautifully made documentary about a truly remarkable woman, and a fitting tribute to her contribution to the work of wildlife preservation.
Well-meaning but pedestrian.... Too often...things ring dramatically false, and what is meant to be deeply moving is bathetic instead.
Branagh's remake of the Christie classic is enjoyable enough, but it's not a patch on Lumet's 1974 'cavalcade of stars' version.
A sly parable of white privilege brought low.
Ho-ho-hum...offers little holiday cheer.
Though it takes a few melodramatic shortcuts, the film is a generally shrewd, thoughtful portrait of life in a cloistered Catholic community at a moment of radical change in the Church.

Surprisingly enjoyable... visually too dark, and it's hobbled by a villain who's a crashing bore, but it adds a welcome dose of humor to what had been pervasive grimness, and some promising new characters as well.
Cunning and surprisingly moving...may be burdened with an unwieldy title, but it advertises one of the year's most compelling films.
Tugs at the heartstrings so insistently that you might well leave it feeling assaulted rather than uplifted.
A coming-of-age film that stands head and shoulders above most in that popular genre... smart, incisive and emotionally satisfying,
It's undeniably enjoyable to watch Washington sink his teeth into such a florid role [but] as a whole the picture feels manufactured rather than authentic and the plot goes haywire in the final act.
There's a lot about 'Coco' that feels familiar...but the visual splendor certainly makes it an enjoyable confection, with the Latino ambiance an added bonus.
An exercise in calculated sentimentality...like a box of colorful candy, much too sugary and not at all nutritious.
While a minor contribution to the Western genre, it offers a clever twist on its tropes.
At once a gripping fact-based period newspaper drama and a timely tale of female empowerment in a male-dominated world.
May satisfy the most undemanding fans of the franchise by fleshing out Elise Rainier's backstory, but on its own it's just a mediocre haunted house movie...more tedious than frightening.
Contains some brutal action scenes, but its focus is on character, and while its message is not a subtle one, Cooper's slow, somber delivery of it proves quite effective.
A sadly muted thrill-free thriller, starring a disappointingly manic-deprived Cage.
In the end this is a wasted 'Night'...more likely to elicit a grimace than a grin.
Though none of the sting penetrates very deep, it has a degree of punch, especially when the barbed lines are delivered by a cast that savors their every syllable.
Consistently tantalizing but also deliberately obscure...You might come out of 'Annihilation' wondering about what you just saw, but the sense of wonderment will stay with you.
May not deserve the adjective of the title, but Vega certainly does; her performance makes an imperfect film worth seeing.
Despite an occasional moving moment,...this cinematic dirge fails to achieve the degree of profundity it's obviously aiming for.
Another of Zvyagintsev's lacerating portraits of a country-and a world-in decline.
Panders to the audience's fears and fantasies as much as the first movie did, but does so with a cynical grin on its face.
Suffers from an air of affectation and artificiality made worse by the convoluted structure imposed on the narrative.
Consistently intriguing and at times even compelling, though it does seem a bit out-of-date, as well as arguably overlong.
Barely coherent, overburdened with unimpressive special effects and hobbled by unremittingly bad acting, it will confound and bore children and adults in equal measure.

An entirely artificial construct designed to please through a satisfying puzzle-like maze of words and incident... its synthetic character and mannered style are more likely to frustrate than captivate.
Thanks to the efforts of a talented cast and spirited direction, this nasty mixture of cynical farce and violent action offers a few pleasures along the way-though not quite enough.
An exercise in pure sadism that feels all the more sordid because it's quite efficiently made.
Married life has its ups and downs, and so does this movie. Unfortunately, more of the latter than the former.
Will obviously appeal especially to soccer-obsessed Europeans, but its consistent strain of genially eccentric British humor should endear it to audiences everywhere.
The adjective is part of the title, but it also serves as a pretty fair description.
The good definitely outweighs the problematic here, making for a superhero movie that's definitely one of the better examples of the genre though hardly as groundbreaking as some would claim.
Wants to be a thriller as well as a piece of soft-core erotica, but totally fails as either.

If you want to enjoy Liam Neeson's latest high-speed thriller at all, you'll have to do more than merely suspend disbelief. You'll have to grab it, smash it into little pieces and toss them into a black hole.
The first movie based on Michael Bond's Paddington Bear books was an absolute delight, and defying the usual laws of sequelitis, the second is equally charming.
A strangely cerebral, lovingly fashioned but slightly trashy study of emotional gamesmanship that invites respect for its chilly craftsmanship more than its dramatic resonance.
A sappy, mawkish romantic drama....The publicity likens this movie to those made from Nicholas Sparks' books. Unhappily, the comparison is all too apt.
An interesting but less than spontaneous record of effort and achievement that has been almost completely undone by the unexpected result of the 2016 presidential election.

In its desire to laud the heroism of this small band of Americans in Afghanistan, ignores the overall reality of that conflict, which...seems to have become yet another sad episode in the history of a land often called the graveyard of empires.

Drags on repetitiously, its simple narrative unable to sustain the unconscionable length. Despite lots of bombastic action scenes, individual face-offs and self-sacrificial turns,... it lumbers rather than sprints to the finish line.
Haneke again looks uncompromisingly on the dark reality of how human beings live, and how their inhumane tendencies will be passed on to their children in ways that might shock even them.
Sluggish and strangely unaffecting...an essentially mediocre tearjerker that is nonetheless notable for showcasing yet another striking turn by a superb actress.
movie_title: Film Stars Don't Die in Liverpool (2017)

movie_review_blurb: In its ponderousness and clumsily didactic dialogue, it resembles the flat-footed Biblical epics that Hollywood churned out in the fifties and sixties, and though handsomely made, contains an extraordinary amount of violence for the family trade.
movie_title: Bilal: A New Breed of Hero (2018)

movie_review_blurb: Depending more on words than mayhem, it's a thriller that's somber, slow-moving and quietly heartbreaking.
While the Oscar-nominated film is certainly wordy, sometimes makes its points too bluntly and softens toward the close, it proves a powerful intimate drama with broader overtones.
As far as horror movies go nowadays, it's relatively restrained and stylish, but also pretty silly...merges tedium and absurdity in approximately equal measure.
Owing as much to Bugs Bunny (and the slapstick of John Hughes's 'Home Alone' movies) as to Beatrix Potter, it nonetheless retains enough twee British humor to prove moderately fetching.
The story of Stone, Skarlatos and Sadler is, as Hollande said, an inspiring one that deserved to be told. It's a story, though, that deserved to be told better than Eastwood manages to do.

A beautifully crafted example of [Ozon's] ability to evoke the slippery, ever-changing dimensions of human experience...has style aplenty, as well as a dreamily enigmatic vibe and a sly mixture of playful sexuality and mordant humor.
While 'Atomic Blonde' might not be bad enough to be renamed 'Atomic Bomb,' after the preposterous postscript has rolled you might agree that despite all the surface flash, it's a dud.
A failed experiment, a dull tale of a marriage driven on the rocks by a medical miracle that is not enlivened by some visual tricks.
Cinematic artistry of a high order...This deliciously artificial, intricate tale of lives intersecting in surprising ways will leave most viewers moved and delighted.
Ryan Reynolds and Samuel L. Jackson are potentially a good team for a cartoonish action comedy, but the writing and execution here let them-and us-down.
Whatever ambitions Johnston might have had for the picture, they aren't realized on the screen.
Inoffensive but bland, a composite that carefully incorporates elements from other movies into what seems a prefabricated construct rather than something imaginative and innovative.
Another intense, convulsive Safdie exercise in urban nihilism, buoyed by a take-no-prisoners turn by an almost unrecognizable Robert Pattinson.
While far more formulaic than it pretends to be, 'Patti Cake$' has enough going for it-including Macdonald-to be worth a look, as long as rap doesn't completely turn you off.
Hardly a rousing crowd-pleaser, but it is a quietly affecting rumination on memory and loss that will touch those willing to watch and listen attentively.
Quite simply, one of the most sheerly enjoyable movies of the year....we're lucky to have [Soderbergh] back.
As silly as 'Red Dawn'-either version-working only on the low level of a shoot-'em-up video game.
A wispy, feeble sitcom-quality ensemble piece... what the ellipsis appears to indicate are the humor and heart Bell's omitted this time around.
Tells a sadly familiar story, but it does so well.
Despite good intentions, this is a disappointing treatment of a subject that deserves better.
Poignant, but shot through with welcome touches of humor, it opens a door to an unfamiliar culture, and does so with honesty and heart.

In this chaotically assembled incarnation Moggach's tale of romantic intrigue set against the notorious seventeenth-century financial bubble generates little dramatic heat, let alone a cinematic fever.
This sequel fails to score the hoped-for goal...when Doug Glatt hangs up his skates again as it ends, one can only hope that this time it's for good.
Has the feeling of a long, turgid prologue to a movie we never get to see.
A visually luscious travelogue and a savory introduction to upscale Spanish cuisine, as well as another delicious joint comedic routine by two masters.
Flush with pent-up anger and pain, but also a major helping of sad resignation, it's both a searing experience and a thought-provoking one.
Superior to its predecessor, though still mediocre by the standards of the best family-friendly fare, boasting lots of mindless hubbub but a distinct lack of wit or memorable lines.
movie_title: The Nut Job 2: Nutty by Nature (2017)

movie_review_blurb: While hardly subtle, honors a man deserving of wider recognition.
Warmed-over 'Glengarry Glen Ross' mixed with afternoon soap opera...watching the mawkish movie might make you gag on its mixture of bluster and treacle.
It has flaws, but they are faults that can be forgiven in view of the film's sheer cinematic power, as well as its historical significance and topical relevance.
Imbues the horror genre with a rare degree of poetic elegance while ruminating on the nature of time, memory and grief...Lowery's mournful, strangely moving film is likely to haunt you.
Berry, Berry bad... the pulpy, preposterous 'Kidnap' is a B-movie that's not elevated from its humble status by the presence of a star whose name still carries a whiff of prestige.
There have been worse adaptations of books by King, but this long-awaited one is almost guaranteed to disappoint his many fans while failing to bowl over anybody else.

Though a relatively slight tale of a woman who breaks free of a stifling life as a result of an unexpected encounter with her past, 'The Midwife' offers the opportunity to watch two fine actresses joust, and for some that may be enough.

An impassioned follow-up [whose] impact isn't likely to match that of its predecessor, not only because a great many documentaries on the subject have appeared in the intervening years but because it inclines toward hagiography.
movie_title: An Inconvenient Sequel: Truth To Power (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The script's incoherence makes the movie feel like a random assemblage of cunningly crafted horror tropes rather than an intelligible narrative.
While one might wish it possessed more of the grit of 'Short Term 12,' the film mostly works as a more traditional kind of family melodrama-Cretton by way of Douglas Sirk.
The prettiness of the locations, and of the characters set in them, can't conceal the essential phoniness that permeates the film.
movie_title: The Only Living Boy in New York (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Despite its propensity to aim for the jugular rather than the brain...'Pilgrimage' proves an intriguing attempt at capturing the often contradictory spiritual and material realities of Europe's so-called age of faith.
A taut, brooding procedural with a compelling central character and a startlingly real setting.
An uplifting documentary that's also realistic about the obstacles its subjects face.
An excessively precious, quirky little indie comedy with a remarkably sentimental streak.
Piled high with inanities and cliches...This is a romantic comedy that comes up short in both departments.
A solid, well-made picture, one of the better King adaptations if not of the very top rank among them, even if its over-reliance on CGI effects grows tiresome by the close.

A nearly incomprehensible farrago of the tropes of young adult literature and pseudo-religious myth, hobbled by a trio of uncharismatic leads and exploding at the end with some hilarious not-so-special effects.
One of those documentaries that at first seems like just an enjoyable lark about some eccentric people but winds up raising deeper issues about human needs and the creative process.
'Lucky' is a small film, but it has a big heart, as well as a performance that in many respects acts as a summing-up of Stanton's long, remarkable career.
A portrait of the jurist as a young man [that] resembles a good made-for-cable movie, and in Boseman and Gad it boasts a strong team.

Fitfully amusing, overly shrill and preciously titled comedy-drama. Though it definitely overstays its welcome, however, [it] does have one redeeming feature: a delicious performance by Dustin Hoffman.
Turns an edgy, quite radical tale...into a rather blandly conventional crowd-pleaser, but in its glossy, unthreatening way it's still reasonably engaging.
In many respects a fairly conventional paternal revenge movie, gussied up with some oddly anachronistic political machinations, but it's well-made and offers its stars some chances to shine.

The ponderous title, unfortunately, is appropriate to a film that is not only lethargic and unexciting but will be a muddle to anyone who doesn't bring a pretty good knowledge of the Watergate affair to the theatre with him.
movie_title: Mark Felt: The Man Who Brought Down the White House (2017)

movie_review_blurb: [A] mad, marvelous enterprise...The sheer beauty of the individual frames goes far to compensate for the narrative bumps.
Neither scary nor funny enough to survive even to Halloween.
A sappy tearjerker, so shameless in its employment of manipulative clichés that at times it seems almost a parody of the genre.
A decent, well-crafted film, but ultimately more workmanlike than inspired, though one has to commend its commitment to authenticity while regretting its periodic lapses into domestic melodrama.

Atmospheric but chaotic, a ponderous, hazy parade of red herrings and misdirection that winds up with a totally implausible, psychologically simplistic denouement that wouldn't be out of place in a TV crime procedural.
Sincere but flatfooted...survival story. The truth was no doubt uplifting; the cinematic fictionalization turns it into rather a bore.
A preposterous blend of cautionary tale..., cheesy over-the-top disaster epic and goofy political skulduggery that is almost bad enough to become a camp classic.
Sometimes too beautiful for its subject...but Ai Weiwei's artistry doesn't obscure the size or urgency of the problem on which he focuses...the great human tragedy of our time.
A misfire in virtually every respect...Tonally the picture is a mess rather than a satisfying blend of disparate moods.

Some curmudgeonly critics-like this one-will have a hard time enduring the saccharine taste of 'My Little Pony,' but the series' legions of fans-and those legendary 'bronies'-will probably be enchanted by it.
An engrossing modern variant of the doom-laden tragedies of Aeschylus and Euripides, exerting a hypnotic effect even as it makes you intensely uncomfortable.
movie_title: The Killing of a Sacred Deer (2017)

movie_review_blurb: An improvement on the original-a thoughtful, visually striking, emotionally satisfying continuation of Scott's celebrated but rather muddled film.
Remarkably satisfying, a piece of period entertainment that is old-fashioned in the best sense-elegant, refined, and beautifully executed.
Gruesomely enjoyable period pulp... a flamboyant piece of Grand Guignol.
A young Catholic priest questions his vocation in Paul Shoulberg's earnest but overly schematic and ultimately ineffectual comedy-drama [that] never really rings true.
Despite the updating, the movie is essentially a boilerplate action flick following a template that hasn't changed much for decades, and while efficiently made, it holds no surprises.

Manages a few effective moments but winds up as less a genuinely creepy haunted house thriller than a silly, self-indulgent allegory about the torments that bedevil the artist as he strives to give birth to a masterpiece.
The luscious widescreen images don't make up for the cartoonish hollowness of this cluttered, overstuffed exercise in hyperkinetic spycraft.
Can't help but follow a fairly familiar template, but...Gyllenhaal's commitment, astute direction by David Gordon Green, and some outstanding supporting performances elevate it beyond the ordinary.
A genial but undercooked Lego product, one that tries hard to apply the recipe of the brand from previous films-smart dialogue and witty visuals-to an inferior story, and only sporadically succeeds.
A sharp but sensitive satirical study of male mid-life crisis.
The obvious response to a movie this bad is to press 'Delete' and hope you don't get an error message.
Literal rather than literary, a dutiful recitation of the facts of Salinger's life that fails to convey much of a sense of the author's inner self.
Harris seems to be striving for a 'Smiles of a Summer Night' vibe as the characters interconnect, flirt and (all too frequently) break into song, but it proves very short on the smiles part.

Though this over-the-top Cruise-Liman combination is sporadically amusing, its raucousness often comes across as desperately frantic rather than satirically telling....For what it is, though, it earns a marginal pass.
A solid lob, but not the grand slam one might have hoped for.
Proof positive that skill in designing dresses does not ensure an ability to fashion a good film...so opaque, repetitive and dull that few viewers will have the patience to endure the entire thing.
The message of this remake of the 1990 thriller is that one must own up to his mistakes. If so, the makers and cast of the new 'Flatliners' need to apologize immediately.
The authentic locations war against a hokey storyline. Though the stars are attractive, 'The Mountain Between Us' represents too high an accumulation of implausibility to swallow.
An engrossing tale of long-buried secrets that finally bring retribution...cheekily suspenseful and unsettling right down to a satisfyingly twisted ending.
You might label 'Trolls' as 'F.T.O.'-meaning 'for tots only,' like the Smurfs, though the studio is obviously hoping it can appeal beyond that demo.
A rich, intoxicating epic of chicanery and deceit-a puzzle that entangles the viewer just as it does its characters.
Like so much of the writer's work, a rather sophomoric attempt at profundity dressed up in existential angst.
Just more of the same, which means it's not very much...what was mediocre in the first go-around is no better in the second.
Unbearable...so ill-conceived that it will insult the intelligence of a kindergartener.

Brash, loud, corny and-especially toward the close-cheesy in its use of special effects, [it] represents a sincere effort to be true to the facts that unfortunately falls prey to the director's innate action-movie propensities.
movie_title: 13 Hours: The Secret Soldiers Of Benghazi (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Plays like a Disney Channel version of 'Invasion of the Body Snatchers' or 'The Invaders,' the sixties Quinn Martin ABC potboiler inspired by it.
[A] harrowing portrait of life and death at Auschwitz-Birkenau that also becomes a tale of redemption for one of its Jewish prisoners.
Based on a promising premise but quickly devolves into a grab bag of routine "gotcha" moments embedded in a plot that slides into incoherence and torpor.

Every once in awhile a movie comes around that's so repulsive that you leave it certain that the theatre is in need of fumigation, and get home feeling a desire for a quick shower...Such a picture is the abysmal 'Dirty Grandpa.'

An oddball mélange of action, slapstick, sentimentality and ghoulishness, all wrapped up into one big, galumphing package... more a curiosity than a delight, but the adventurous might want to give the sweet-and-sour dish a try.
A discourse on existential angst in the modern world, the ensemble piece comes across as sadly familiar, and as emotionally desiccated as its pallid characters.

Set in 1952, and apart from the CGI it might have been made then, given the surfeit of clichés reflective of pictures from the Eisenhower era... like its nondescript title, it's underwhelming despite the size of those billowing CGI waves.
A visually stunning but story-wise pretty threadbare entry in the popular series.
[An] intensely observant portrait of a marriage in crisis after nearly half a century...the sensitivity of Rampling and Courtenay fills even the pauses with unspoken meaning.

Impresses more as a fitfully engaging exercise than a fully realized vision... But to render unto 'Caesar' its due, the movie does deliver sporadic amusement and a few absolutely spectacular sequences.

For the first hour or so,... a fairly effective slow-burning chiller, old-fashioned and silly but nicely crafted...In the final third, however, it collapses into preposterous cliché, and even technically grows ragged and scraggly down the home stretch.

A film that's far easier to admire than to love. Indeed, one takes leave of it commiserating more with the actors and crew who obviously endured much making it than with the characters whose story they're telling.
A tribute to both Hitchcock and Truffaut...an engaging treatment of how Truffaut's project came about and the impact his book has had on filmmakers ever since.

Completely loses the cheerfully loony tone of the original, replacing it with dutiful action-movie dourness. And while the big set-pieces are expertly staged and shot, even they don't generate the sense of gleeful abandon they're obviously meant to.
While Helgeland's film as a whole is little more than a workmanlike job, many on both side of the Atlantic will respond to Hardy's energetic double turn as proof of his versatility.
A piece of chintzy hagiography that ends up diminishing rather than celebrating its subject. Perhaps Mother Teresa was a saint, but in Riead's hands she's become a plaster one.
This more-naughty-than-nice bit of skewered holiday horror offers at most a sporadically amusing, but utterly ephemeral, dose of Christmas cheer.
Distinctly uninspired...handsomely mounted and shot but ponderously earnest, dramatically inert and remarkably dull.
movie_title: In the Heart of the Sea (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Exhilarating, if highly derivative...an enjoyable throwback that is largely content to replicate its models rather than taking the narrative in any significantly new direction.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Not without its impressive moments, but like so many of the earlier screen adaptations, this 'Macbeth' falls short.

The girls-just-want-to-have-fun philosophy behind this gross-out misfire proves no more appealing than the numerous examples of crass frat-boy rowdiness that have filled the screen over the past decade.

Despite the gorgeous images and the presence of Michael Caine and Harvey Keitel, doing what amounts to an engaging thespian soft-shoe routine, this reverie on coming to terms with growing old comes across as both pretentious and prosaic.
So cautious in dealing with the subject matter, so anxious to avoid the slightest hint of sensationalism, that it ends up exceedingly attractive to look at but curiously bland dramatically.
Smart and manic, it might leave you more with a bit of a queasiness and exhaustion rather than the outrage it's aiming for, but at least it doesn't stiff you.
Exquisite...a small film, but it's like a flawless gem with endless facets to explore and appreciate.
A fact-based tale of a woman who realized the American Dream that fails to engender in viewers the emotion promised by the title.
Thoroughly pedestrian in both conception and execution when it's not downright offensive.
Not odious but no classic either...basically a western potboiler with a mystery-novel pulse, amusing in parts but overlong..., though it does provide the expected bloodbath at the close.

Based on an important...story, but could have used a better game plan to tell it...an earnest, well-meaning combination of character study, medical procedural and corporate thriller that rarely rises above the standard of conventional TV docudrama.

There's not a single moment of emotional honesty in this latest helping of meretricious melodrama Nicholas Sparks, but that probably won't stop his fans from sighing and weeping over its ham-fisted mixture of giggly romance and cheap sentiment.
Another clever construct by Alan Bennett, which gives Maggie Smith a grand opportunity to shine.
Flat-footed: as difficult as it is to imagine that a mash-up this absurd could be dull, the movie manages to be a snooze.
An exercise in following established formula while pretending to subvert it by slyly pointing out its absurdities and adding all sorts of nasty pop culture references and profane asides to the mix.
Often beautiful to look at but is yet another piece of pretentious vacuity from a one of today's most overpraised directors...brings more exhaustion than enlightenment.
A taut, claustrophobic exercise in tension with a distinctly 'Twilight Zone' vibe...that will keep you guessing.
This cinematic journey into an Amazonian heart of darkness is a haunting and unforgettable experience.
movie_title: Embrace Of The Serpent (El Abrazo De La Serpiente) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Or more accurately, 'Deficient'... a thoroughly conventional, curiously tedious halfway wind-up.
A nifty little thriller...a tense, tough, biting commentary on the way wars are fought today.
While 'The Bronze' tries hard, it's no prize-winner.
The most surprising thing about 'The Program'...is how narratively pedestrian it is...feels like territory that's already been well-trod (or ridden).
Alternately sweet and kind of creepy...an invitation you might want to skip.

A loud, cluttered, joyless muddle that might be described as Snyderissimo-which might please DC and diehard fans but will probably put off those accustomed to the breezier tone of the Marvel universe.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: One wedding too many...while Vardalos can go home again, she shouldn't have bothered, and certainly viewers would be well advised to skip this return trip.
Despite its sometimes glacial pace, a tense, chilling ride that that also manages to be challenging and thought-provoking.
In spite of the picture's sincerity and surface sheen-and Hiddleston's committed performance-Abraham's 'Light' simply doesn't shed sufficient illumination on its subject.
A biting yet strangely affectionate period piece about delusion and love.
A scattershot farce that resembles a short-form sketch stretched to inordinate length, especially in a last-act confrontation that's both ill-conceived and abysmally executed.
A tiresome orgy of blood and bombast...an excruciating, exhausting ninety minutes of virtually non-stop slaughter, sex and sadism.
Rampant stupidity and cheap jolts are the key ingredients of this old-fashioned fright flick, which is distinguished solely by its Indian setting.
movie_title: The Other Side of the Door (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Isn't by any stretch of the imagination a good movie. But...it offers a goofy but sporadically amusing take on the familiar tale.
While impressive for a low-budget horror comedy, goes off on too many tangents, ending up as an intriguing premise imperfectly realized.
A clever piece of family entertainment that wittily uses whodunit convention to deliver messages about tolerance, self-confidence and friendship in eye-catching fashion.
[A] lumbering, laugh-free sequel [that] fizzles like a defective firecracker.
While undoubtedly very opinionated...quite an enjoyable trek through some hospitable, and perhaps instructive, foreign climes.
It embraces so many sitcom clichés-mixed with periodic girls-gone-wild shtick-that any deeper message it might want to convey is lost in the shuffle.

Even those who find fault with its core message will have to admit that 'Boy and the World' is a visually dazzling experience, although it might appeal more to adult connoisseurs of animation technique than to kids.
movie_title: Boy and the World (O Menino e o Mundo) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Earnest and semi-hagiographical..., it's hard to dislike but at the same time easy to criticize for treating its subject in such glossy, sanitized terms.
A study in paranoia that creates a deepening mood of unease and dread...[and] despite a few stumbles (most notably a miscalculated final scene) is genuinely creepy.
A sort of cinematic antique, a fifties western that's been spruced up but doesn't even try to hide its dusty origins. But it has small pleasures, especially in the casting.
Comes from an unfamiliar place but touches on universal themes...a fascinating and moving film, and an auspicious debut for its director.
While hardly a masterpiece, the oblique approach to the Gospel story makes it a more engaging retelling than straight-on sermons to the choir.
Whatever misgivings one might harbor about 'Touched With Fire,' the film...provides a thoughtful take on a provocative subject.
A harmless piece of uplifting family entertainment...inoffensive but trivial.
An exercise in dreary cynicism... It's hard to imagine a picture that's more of a wallow in corruption and nastiness than this.
An extraordinarily silly, flamboyantly empty hodgepodge of splashy effects and childish narrative... It's actually dumber than 'Immortals.'
Though it doesn't entirely escape the aura of being a much more serious variant of a formula...the lead performances in particular give it a degree of emotional depth.
The picture is content with mild, obvious plot points, and in the end even descends into clichéd action-movie mode and uplifting emotional catharsis.
Bombastic, jingoistic claptrap...every bit as dumb as its predecessor.

Deliriously gleeful...a sort of cinematic kegger, loose, informal and not a little ragged, that reminds you in a penetrating but not hectoring way of what it was like to be young and full of possibility.
It's perfectly agreeable and, of course, technically masterful, but in narrative terms it's pretty conventional, paling beside Pixar's more imaginative efforts.
A mishmash that almost never earns a laugh or even a smile, but isn't particularly touching or insightful either.
Even while recognizing the calculation behind Weitz's method, you can't help but enjoy the vivacity with which Tomlin brings the manipulative material to life.
An entertaining film that's both a revealing profile of the man and a thought-provoking reflection on his broader cultural significance.
Isn't the movie that's going to refurbish Shyamalan's star--it's a muddled attempt to meld comedy and horror that doesn't succeed particularly well as either.
An ironically pedestrian movie that doesn't go anywhere adventurous, but the two lead passengers--and Clarkson in particular--make it a more agreeable journey than it otherwise would have been.
A warm and funny tale of clashes both personal and social, and an engaging showcase for a wonderfully rich performance by Regina Case.
movie_title: The Second Mother (Que Horas Ela Volta?) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: May strike a welcome chord with the evangelical groups at whom it's obviously aimed. But for others the ploddingly preachy picture will seem more like a stint in purgatory, if not someplace even more uncomfortable.
Precisely the sort of movie for which the term Eurotrash was invented--loud, slick, vacuous and stupid.
Won't win any awards for originality, but it carries the familiar adventure along efficiently, generating sufficient excitement to keep one from dreading the next chapter.
From the technical perspective 'Everest' is a most impressive achievement....Unhappily, from the emotional perspective it's pretty much a slog.
In cinematic terms, Zwick's film may not possess the unhinged brilliance of its subject, but Fischer's story--and Maguire's committed portrayal of him--carry the day.
An enthralling treatment of the war on the drug trade...a brilliant, unsettling piece of filmmaking.
Engaging but overlong, and more than a mite unsettling.
A semi-engaging coming-of-age story with a smidgen of action-movie violence added to the mix.
Comes across as a heartfelt piece of work, but also one that's stilted, cliché-ridden and grossly manipulative.
Depp's performance...makes this journey into the world of a vicious crime lord endlessly engrossing and at times positively startling.
Innocuous but insubstantial...The stars make agreeable walking companions, but they don't take you anywhere particularly memorable.
The looseness turns into haphazardness, and while the picture digs around a lot, it never really catches fire.
Practitioners of climbing--and enthusiasts who prefer to experience such extreme activity from the comfort of their armchairs--will find this film a treat.
A tedious bargain-basement Marvel movie...that spends literally two-thirds if its running-time in endless exposition setting up a final battle that's curiously brief, sloppy and dull.
Though for most it will succeed more as an exceptional acting showcase than as a revealing portrait of the artist as a young man, it's nonetheless a worthy effort on that basis alone.
The oddly bifurcated movie offers sporadic pleasures, but as a whole it just doesn't gel.
A simple but powerful parable of rebirth involving love, loss, betrayal, guilt and greed in a post-war Germany where the enormities of the Holocaust are still immediate and unresolved.
A misfire on virtually every level...more like 'The Wild Wild West' than 'Mission: Impossible.'
One can argue that this story might have been told with greater punch, more detail and less reliance on the tropes of the genre, but it's still pretty solid and vivid as it is.

Despite the...longueurs 'The Tribe' is certainly a dark and powerful portrait of the grim goings-on at a school where violence plays a far greater role than education, told in a fashion that can't help but fascinate.

If you like puzzles--and don't mind if, when completed, they don't reveal much of interest--you might enjoy this labyrinthine little brain-teaser. If not, you probably won't think it's worth a plugged nickel.
Though [it] wants desperately to be an outrageous mix of action and comedy, in the end the recipe produces a curiously unpalatable dish.
A cautionary tale, but an edgy, compelling one that's often hard to watch and even harder to forget.
movie_title: The Diary Of A Teenage Girl (2015)

movie_review_blurb: While high-minded and well-intentioned...a bit of a bore, despite some striking images.
Yet another chintzy exploitation potboiler from Jason Blum's horror shingle...poorly conceived and ineptly executed.
Despite being jazzed up with woozy camerawork, kinetic editing and splashy graphics, 'We Are Your Friends' is old-fashioned hooey.
A crudely efficient action potboiler marred by a distinctly unenlightened attitude.
A sharp, sophisticated modern screwball comedy [with] an underlying strain of poignancy.
A depressingly flat attempt to wring a few more dollars out of the premise that drove its mediocre 2012 predecessor.
Pleasant but bland, Nancy Meyer's latest exercise in anodyne filmmaking is as sweet as cotton candy and just about as nourishing.
This is a great story, but Zemeckis' film proves an overly cute retelling of it, and except for the walk itself it's more a cinematic misstep than a triumph.
Upbeat and dramatically subdued,...it's characteristically handsome but uncharacteristically warm-hearted for a Scott film.
The ambiguity of 'Truth' leaves it neither celebratory nor condemnatory, an interesting but slightly flat recounting of a major misstep in modern journalism.
A soggy, ultimately unpalatable experience...overly familiar and curiously bland.
An episodic chain of high-octane set-pieces that gets increasingly winded as it drags on.
Brings Schulz's classic creation up-to-date in technical terms while remaining faithful to the spirit and tone of the beloved strip.
There are flashes of interest in each of the films here, but overall 'Mexico Barbaro' doesn't manage to rise much above mediocrity.
The effect is of a weepy women's movie from the 1940s presented against a too-thinly-drawn period background of political agitation and official repression.
One of the best real-life tales of investigative journalism since 'All the President's Men.'
A peculiar combination of dutiful recreation and souped-up Hollywood disaster movie.
Filled with characters who are more irritating than likable and dialogue that sounds as though it had been lifted from a bad network dramedy.
Supremely corny,...opting for the most hackneyed clichés of the genre.
The conclusion will be satisfying for those who have been following the series devoutly, though quite honestly one that comes as a bit of a letdown after all the hullabaloo that's led up to it.
Dour, drab and lacking the powerful subtext of its Argentine model, it comes across as little more than a police procedural of the sort you can find any night on the tube.
Has the feel of a decent cable movie: though it's watchable, you leave it certain that the man, and the situation he was forced into, are deserving of much better treatment.
A pretentious but vapid tale of marital distress that comes off as a pure vanity effort modeled, absurdly enough, on Antonioni's famous films of nihilistic alienation.
It's hardly subtle or incisive, but works as an old-fashioned tearjerker bolstered by a strong lead turn from Saoirse Ronan.
Intended to be a sharp satire, but for the most part it's an oddly muted one that occasionally switches to rambunctious slapstick and more often veers into soapy drama.
Proves that there's life in the old Italian Stallion yet...if you doubted that the 'Rocky' franchise could use still another episode, 'Creed' should make you a believer.
Even the most dedicated fan will find this a soporific conclusion to a series that has been careening downhill since the first installment and now reaches a dead end in more ways than one.

While overlong and awfully leisurely (as well as remarkably gory)...quite enjoyable, rather like a version of 'The Hills Have Eyes' transplanted to the old West and enriched by a strong cast and a good deal of flavorful, if often digressive, dialogue.
A brew that aims for a campy, midnight-movie vibe it never quite achieves.
An insufferably sluggish, irredeemably silly supernatural would-be thriller that isn't remotely scary but is continuously boring.
Falls flat on its face...raucous, bloated with special effects and thoroughly lacking in charm, 'Pan' is the rare family movie that should appeal to no group along the age spectrum.

A glorified TV movie-of-the-week that doesn't do full justice to either the real-life story on which it's based or to its committed cast...but still manages to carry an emotional impact despite its predictability.
Dramatically it's a deck as stacked as the one that unscrupulous bankers and realtors dealt to the borrowers who lost everything.
A disappointment, clumsily constructed and more hagiographical than truly enlightening.
Hardly breaks new ground, but it's a watchable entry in the tortured young genius genre.

As if their Adam Sandler flop 'Pixels' wasn't juvenile enough, Sony Entertainment offers what's essentially a kiddie version of it in 'Goosebumps,' a similarly misguided mixture of animation and live action...more trick than treat.

Though fastidiously made, in terms of both its evocative period setting and its skillful emotional manipulation, in the end the picture comes across as little more than a solid piece of middlebrow uplift, respectable but not outstanding.
Undeniably hard to watch, but also a dramatically wrenching depiction of contemporary realities one might prefer to ignore-but shouldn't.
A haunted mansion that from moment to moment is pretty to look at but turns out to be utterly empty inside.

Sorkin, Boyle and Fassbender have painted an impressionistic portrait rather than a naturalistic one, using their imagination and gift for highly-charged theatricality in a creative fashion Jobs himself might well have appreciated.
Although you might figure out the big final twist in 'Goodnight Mommy' early on-which isn't all that difficult to do-it will probably still fascinate you, as well as creep you out.
A strong, remarkably acted tale of the bond between mother and child tested by the most extreme circumstances.
Despite the presence of a cathedral among the settings and a couple of priests in the cast, this hapless disaster doesn't have a prayer of getting past a first installment.
The film, which mixes fact with fiction, is an honorable if sometimes melodramatically facile attempt to portray a watershed moment in modern German history.
Not strange enough; it has plenty of CGI magic effects, but lacks the cinematic magic that would set it apart from the other franchises in Marvel's increasingly crowded stable.
It's a bumpy, uneven ride, but there are nuggets to be enjoyed along the way.
One of those sad cases where, in spite of two game and attractive leads, almost everything goes wrong.

A picture that will be prized by connoisseurs of animation but other viewers might find too esoteric and faintly lethargic-a film that, oddly for one aimed at a family audience, adults might appreciate more than their children.

A bit of a mongrel, inviting us to revel in some outrageous bad-boy shenanigans before sagely concluding how wrong they were, but Hill brings enough sinister energy to the proceedings to keep it interesting.

[A] bargain-basement treatment...the more intimate scenes are marked by risible dialogue, mediocre acting, inept staging and herky-jerky hand-held camerawork and the big action sequences ruined by frenetic editing and a reliance on slipshod CGI effects.
Gentle, generous and heartwarming but also clear-eyed and sharply observant.
It might ramble, but you're always willing to follow Herzog's zigzag course, even if it reaches no definitive destination.
movie_title: Lo and Behold, Reveries of the Connected World (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Tanne's imagining of the first couple's first date should prove both sweet and surprisingly revealing.

If the look of the movie should please fans, the plot is an absolute muddle-an unholy brew of flotsam and jetsam that ranges from Wagnerian motifs and garbled Latin names...to bits of 'Star Wars' and 'The Lord of the Rings.'
Has a certain visceral power, but it often seems a bit punch-drunk, stumbling from subject to subject without much overall shape...A pity, because it could have been a contender.
This adaptation of M.L. Stedman's best-selling tearjerker is tasteful, elegant and decorous-but also stiff, overinflated and ponderous.
It sets up an interesting though hardly revolutionary premise but then takes it in an entirely predictable direction, ending with rote action sequences and revelations that don't surprise.
Slight but engaging fish-out-of-water coming-of-age tale.

The tonal shifts between oddball quirkiness and potboiler cliché are never satisfactorily patched over, and when the ending rolls around, you might think you've been watching a spoof version of 'If I Stay.'
A convoluted comic brain-teaser that aims to delight but doesn't possess the wit needed to pull the trick off. Sporadically amusing but too often pedestrian.
Works best, if at all, as an exercise in nostalgia for those who look back fondly on the kind of mindless B-movie action schlock that Cannon specialized in during the seventies and eighties.
[Though] Alvarez proves an adept stager and arranger of calculated shock effects...the script isn't concerned with even an iota of logic, but merely with generating one more empty jolt.
It boasts some strong performances, but the actors are stranded no less by the flimsy script than by the inhospitable setting.
A movie that's clearly not for everyone, but those at whom it's targeted-whether allowed to enter according to the R rating or not-will find it a hoot.
Beautifully crafted and impeccably cast...at once a funny and touching tale of a woman who wouldn't let mere lack of talent destroy her desire to share her love of music with others.
While the film's allusive structure demands a viewer's concentration, it rewards the effort with a timely message about overcoming the fear of the other and a quietly moving conclusion.
Warmhearted without being mawkish... The uplifting effect of 'Life, Animated' is pretty much irresistible.
Evolve[s] from a silly, ineptly made teen thriller into a crushingly heavy-handed cautionary tale about the morality of online voyeurism.
It panders to overstressed, underappreciated mothers-and there are plenty of them-by offering them a phony fable of empowerment, one that's no more than a raucous, sitcom-level farce.
This latest episode doesn't break much new ground in continuing Bourne's story, but it's a solid, reasonably exciting entry in the familiar saga.
Interesting as it is, but it would have been much better had it really grappled with the complexities of the issue it raises rather than presenting it in a cut-and-dried way.
Doremus treats the threadbare story with a turgid solemnity that does neither the script's pedestrian ideas nor its attractive stars any favors.

James Schamus' elegant, thoughtful adaptation of Philip Roth's novella is easily one of 2016's best films... incredibly faithful to both the spirit and the letter of Roth's work [and] showing a full appreciation of both its language and its style.
There have been worse big-budget bombs than 'Suicide Squad.' But not many of them, and not by much.
The credits tell us that it took five screenwriters to pen the script, which means that they outnumber the laughs it generates.
A relatively modest [film], but one that offers some real insight into the world of performers struggling for a degree of recognition most are unlikely to achieve.

Isn't as sharp and biting as it might have been, but at least it touches, however imperfectly, on some very real and pressing contemporary issues about gender and a financial system that remains prone to manipulation despite the supposed lessons of 2008.
It's not merely a throwback... but one that recaptures the endearing qualities with which the best of its models won over audiences.

More dogged than inspiring... It's a pity that the mission to kill Heydrich-rightfully remembered as an act of supreme heroism by Czechs-has resulted in a surprisingly turgid film that doesn't spring to life until it's almost put you to sleep.
A manhunt movie that blends action, comedy, drama and even a smidgen of social commentary into an almost perfect package, offering excitement, laughs and a dollop of poignancy to go along with them.

It could be argued that the very plainness of the picture, anchored by a predictably solid but unflashy performance by Tom Hanks, is the appropriate way of celebrating a man who saw himself not as a hero but simply a fellow doing his job as best he can.

'The Mild Life' would be a better, and certainly more accurate, title for this juvenile retelling of the Robinson Crusoe story, which despite including numerous action sequences, comes across as pedestrian and rather tepid.

Features an array of characters that are immediately recognizable-unfortunately not from real life but from innumerable movies and TV series of the same sad sort. Despite the title it's certainly nothing to shout about.
For all the obvious craftsmanship and powerful acting in "Mon Roi," you might find the two hours you spend with such insufferable characters as Georgio and Tony a chore to endure.
Though the earnest dramatization of the case doesn't fully satisfy, the importance of the issues the film raises makes it worth seeing and reflecting on.

Though it's nothing more than a brainless action thriller that grows increasingly preposterous as it proceeds to a ludicrous conclusion...if the movie doesn't entirely add up, it can provide some dumb fun along the way.
A pretentious bore...a rambling, repetitive road movie that purports to say something deep about the nation's youth and its class system.
An oddball redemption story in which the religious overtones jostle uncomfortably with a would-be boys' adventure tale turned kiddie noir.
A moderately engaging but extremely manipulative crowd-pleaser that starts off quirky but grows increasingly cloying.
movie_title: A Man Called Ove (En man som heter Ove) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: While 'Desierto' brings no nuance or subtext to the table, it certainly works as a viscerally exciting cat-and-mouse chase story.
Even bored adolescent boys are unlikely to muster any enthusiasm for this chintzy reboot of the hybrid hero.
It has such a familiar ring that you might feel you're watching another prosaic episode of the long-running 'NCIS' franchise.
While fastidiously made, McGregor's film is dramatically inert-a pretty but shallow rendering of Roth's novel.
The unsavory plot permutations of the final reel undercut the promise of the earlier ones....Though a cut above the usual horror fare, this is a step down from Flanagan's previous film, 'Oculus.'
At once homage and send-up...a genially goofy oater that's not quite clever enough to be more than an amusing trifle.

Another heaping helping of hopeless hokum from the team of Brown, Howard and Hanks-a scavenger hunt of historical nonsense and thriller clichés...But you can't complain, since it does advertise itself as hellish punishment.
An interesting addition to a distinctive career, but not Reichardt at her best.
Maitland's skillful assemblage of material gives his recounting of the terrible event remarkable immediacy while also endowing it with nightmarishly universal meaning.
Provides a fine, if hectic snapshot of the golden years of the band-the triumphs onstage and the brotherly bickering backstage.

A few undemanding pre-teens might get a charge out of this curiously flat adolescent revenge comedy, but most kids in that age group won't, and in any event you'd better hope they don't get any ideas from it.
movie_title: Middle School: The Worst Years of My Life (2016)

movie_review_blurb: An enjoyable if unexceptional episode in the ongoing series, more place-holder than game-changer, not the culmination of a trilogy but a solid springboard for further adventures.
Slick but emotionally superficial....'The Girl on the Train' might be a great read, but despite Blunt's virtuoso turn it's only a so-so movie.

By no means a balanced presentation of l'affaire LeRoy, much less an indictment of Laura Albert. But it nonetheless assembles a large amount of fascinating material...even if it sidesteps the issue of ultimate narrative reliability.
It takes guts to put the word "disappointment" in a movie title, but in the case of D.J. Caruso's would-be supernatural thriller, it just represents truth-in-advertising.
In its quiet, subdued way 'Mia Madre' touches an emotional chord, enhanced by Buy's subtle, multifaceted performance.
[A] maudlin wallow in geriatric grief.
Conventional, respectable and slightly dull.... Who'd have thought that Stone's telling of Snowden's remarkable story would be so unremarkable?
A slickly refurbished relic, a flat bit of frothy formula that only nostalgia buffs could warm to.
Absolutely awful... one of the ugliest movies you'll ever see.
This new edition of the much-told story is...a perfectly watchable couple of hours [but] it certainly doesn't match the standard Sturges and his charismatic cast...set nearly sixty years ago.
Disney's latest real-life tale of overcoming adversity is a slight but pleasant exercise in uplift that's utterly familiar except for its African setting.
Ultimately...it's the story of the real brothers, well played by Schnetzer and Jonas, rather than the pseudo ones of the frat that gives the picture its power.
An undoubted oddity that some will find penetrating and others irritating.
Nicoll's film isn't the last word in polish, but...it does the job of shining a light on the culture of the AAU as one cog in a basketball machine that's increasingly focused at all levels on money.
As peculiar as Peregrine and her charges, but...the peculiarity, if it falls short of enchanting, will be agreeable, especially to the director's fans.
movie_title: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Not long on subtlety, in either narrative or visual terms, but it certainly works as a remarkably realistic, viscerally exciting recreation of a tragedy whose impact is still being felt.
Something of a mess that moves jarringly from one genre to another, but though it never really comes together, it's also weirdly entertaining.
Painfully unfunny, 'Masterminds' feels like a movie its own moronic characters might have made.
While 'The Birth of a Nation' is not without flaws, it is overall a strong, committed piece of work. Also a provocative one.
A stylish exercise in horror tropes... may be little more than an imitation, but at least the models are first-rate.
No, it isn't... Some will find the result an exhilarating reunion with fondly remembered friends, but most are likely to cringe rather than laugh.

A busy but strangely flat animation extravaganza that feels tired despite its frenetic effort to entertain...crammed with characters that grow increasingly irritating as it ambles on, [it's] a pretty tedious slog.
Slick but superficial, Jodie Foster's comedy-drama about stock market manipulation feels slightly behind-the-curve, but it's buoyed by a couple of genuine star turns.
A stinker...the sort of schlocky mess that gives horror movies a bad name.
Runs for less than ninety minutes, but you still might have trouble staying awake through it.
More likely to make you want to avoid Puerto Vallarta than to visit there. Better yet, just avoid 'Sundown.'

Isn't the exercise in gross-out excess the first movie was, but its pairing of a tamer version of the old recipe with some laudable but imperfectly delivered PC messages makes for an alternately vulgar and tepid brew.
An affectionate parody of the sort of mismatched-buddy action comedies that proliferated in the seventies and eighties, better than most of them were.

Hobbled by the necessity...to simplify the subject's rather esoteric accomplishments [but] it works as a simple human story of the bond that builds between two drastically different men who are in a position to appreciate each other's brilliance.
Distinctly earthbound...neither bad enough to make you furious nor good enough to be memorable.
A crowd-pleasing tale of winning against all odds that's practically impossible not to like.
A finale to the second trilogy that doesn't quite match its immediate predecessors, but is still a solid entry in the superhero sweepstakes.
A dreary recitation of clichéd contemporary nostrums, albeit one decked out in all the flashily empty finery that state-of-the-art CGI can deliver.
A darkly absurdist comedy with a surprising strain of tenderness beneath its edgy surface.
Tries to get across the ambiance of a community under the sway of a weirdly magnetic figure, but inevitably it comes up short; nonetheless the taste that it provides is chilling.
Glossy but curiously uninvolving...viewers are being advised to bring boxes of tissues with them to the theatre, but that's advice you need take to heart only if you have a cold.
Winningly, and wittily, brought to the screen by writer-director Whit Stillman and a superbly chosen cast...rarely has the fit between author and adapter felt so marvelously right.
Goes a mite soft at the close, but along the way it's a mostly bracing tale of how the eccentricities of parents can affect their children.
A one-sided polemic....If the history of this debate is any indication,...it will merely confirm Wakefield's followers in their views while vexing their detractors (if you'll excuse the pun).
Your ability to enjoy 'The Phantom of the Theatre' will depend on your willingness to abandon any expectation of narrative coherence and simply revel in the cinematic splendor of it all.
A pretty conventional if consistently engaging boy's adventure story [that's] a breathtaking visual feast.
[An] astronomically silly script, which one can even imagine Luc Besson turning down as ludicrous...It's so bad, it's 'Criminal.'
A case of ambition exceeding actual accomplishment-Cheadle tries for a high note in 'Miles Ahead' that he never manages to reach.

A film that, despite Plummer's powerful turn, proves too pulpy for its underlying theme about unpunished war criminals-as well as one that serves as a sad reminder of the heights that its director once reached.
It doesn't so much remake formula as tweak it, but despite a few serious logical lapses down the stretch, Zarcoff's slow-burning debut generates some genuine chills.

Except for the CGI variety, there's no magic whatever to be found in this grim fractured fairy tale that cribs pretty shamelessly from previous smashes-'Frozen' in particular-without making good use of the pilfering.
Slight, but it moves briskly and gives Spacey and Shannon the chance to toy playfully with one of the nuttier episodes of American history.
[A] coolly artificial, oddly dispassionate effort, which impresses with its surface elegance but ultimately seems as arid as the desert locale.
If the narrative hits familiar notes, Carney has a knack for presenting it in a way that makes it feel fresh.

Compared to Saulnier's superior 'Blue Ruin,' this is a bit of a disappointment... another violent thriller, but compared to the former film it's curiously simple in terms of narrative, and the director's solemn approach works less effectively as a result.
Beautiful images are at war with clichéd writing and weak acting in...this sincere but sad misfire.

Far too derivative and frenetic to be a particularly good family movie, but kids under the age of ten or so should enjoy its nonstop pacing and silly gags-and as video game adaptations go, it's less offensive than most.
More like 'Trash Day'... One shudders at the thought of how terrible further installments might be.
Despite its technical polish, it comes across more as just another assembly-line commercial product than the special event that fans are no doubt hoping for.
Turns what could have been a sharply comic portrait of an inveterate buttinsky into a fatuously bland feature-length sitcom.
Its combination of intellect and heart is actually quite distinctive-not to mention funny and charming.
A genial take-off rather than a sharp satire...agreeable but overlong, and lacks edginess, coming across as more affectionate than cutting.
This second installment in Bay's latest franchise is mindless junk, but it's pretty much on par with its very successful predecessor, and so should satisfy fans of that movie-whoever they were.
movie_title: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Out of the Shadows (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The setting is unusual but the narrative far less so...overly familiar and more than a little pat.
A neo-Dadaist confection that muses on the meaning of life through absurdism and a deliberate effort to shock, raised beyond a juvenile premise by the commitment of two remarkable young actors.

Viscerally effective but intellectually indefensible... By adding jejune socio-economic commentary to the mix, [it] pretends to be making a point about inequality in America while still just appealing to the audience's vicarious bloodlust.
A charming, if episodic, portrait of an adolescent friendship that finds expression in a quirky road trip....if it feels like a nostalgia trip, it's one that's well worth taking.
May basically just be 'Toy Story' with animals, but at least the makers have chosen a good model and employed it engagingly.

Ultra-raunchy comedy, a movie of sub-Apatow quality that mines the wacky wedding territory..., only to come up empty....There may be worse comedies than 'Mike and Dave' this year, but one fervently hopes not.
movie_title: Mike and Dave Need Wedding Dates (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Despite the occasionally intrusive bouts of visual artiness...an engaging portrait of a likable and influential player in television history.
movie_title: Norman Lear: Just Another Version of You (2016)

movie_review_blurb: It takes a well-worn premise and turns it into a quirkily funny delight.
A cannily structured piece of pulpy pop entertainment marked by a starry lead performance and some histrionic supporting turns. It doesn't have much depth, but the surface keeps you engaged.

It all comes off feeling tired and familiar. What was surprising and fresh in 1984 has become ho-hum and musty in the intervening thirty-two years, and the gender change isn't handled cleverly enough to revive it.
A manipulative feel-good dramedy about an unconventional family that coasts along likably on quirky writing and strong acting, even by the younger members of the cast.
A flawed telling of a fascinating story, but the central subject is sufficiently compelling to overcome the miscalculations.
Lugubrious and talky, JT Mollner's debut feature is also unrelievedly nasty and absurdly pretentious.
Despite the best efforts of a game cast, the movie definitely comes across as a bush-league effort.
Admittedly selective [but] the parts of Zappa's life that it includes provide fascinating insight into a complex man and a complicated artist.
movie_title: Eat That Question: Frank Zappa in His Own Words (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Looks absolutely fantastic...shot in lush, luminous tones by cinematographer Vittorio Storaro. Otherwise, however, it's middle-grade Allen at best.
Viewers in tune with [Solondz's] sensibility...will enjoy the abundant gallows humor the film affords.
Though it might lead to an increase in viewers' electricity bills and expenditures on candles and flashlight batteries, the scary fun will be worth it.
Works on a fairly basic espionage level, though like most of the author's post-Cold War work it lacks the complexity and nuance that marked his earlier novels.
While handsome in every respect (including its leading man), utterly fails in its attempt to turn Burroughs' jungle lord into a modern-day action hero...a ponderous, self-important bore.
Feels like pretty much the same trick repeated with even less finesse the second time around, to diminishing returns.

An unholy mash-up of 'The Lord of the Rings' and 'Star Wars,' and Jones' attempt to add some humanity to the splashy but empty exercise comes across as a fool's errand: presenting nonsense like this with such seriousness only makes it more ridiculous.
Like watching a train wreck in slow motion, though...the film actually moves quite briskly.

May be a fairly standard exorcism tale, but like its predecessor it's crafted with such style, and directed with such command of the genre's conventions, that it stands head and shoulders above the competition.
A teeny-bopper version of 'Double Indemnity' or 'Body Heat' [that] has the feel of a LifeTime movie with a bit more skin than the norm.
It's ironic that a movie about a character with short-term memory loss turns out to be one of Pixar's more forgettable efforts...[still it] will afford modest pleasure to children and adults alike.

By no means a great buddy action-comedy-it's far too silly and derivative for that. But in a dumb, likable way it offers some smiles and even a few genuine laughs...providing one of the best vehicles yet for both of its stars.

By keeping the story of one person's struggle against corporate indifference on an intimate scale it manages, despite its implausibility, to be both effective in terms of its message and dramatically affecting.
movie_title: A Monster With A Thousand Heads (Un Monstruo de Mil Cabezas) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: While it's nice to encounter a sports movie that diverges from formula... this one is so dilatory, and its revelations so obvious, that it might leave you longing for some old-fashioned genre clichés.
Extraordinarily stylish and equally vacuous-as well as seriously grotesque...alternately boring and repulsive.
A heavily didactic tone and the weight of good intentions bleed much of the dramatic life out of Gary Ross' well-meaning but increasingly turgid docu-drama.
When 'Jaws' came out in 1975, one of the advertising taglines was 'Don't go in the water.' For 'The Shallows' one can suggest an alternative: 'Don't go into the theatre.'

The original... was incredibly dumb,... replete with juvenile humor and gee-whiz heroics that reminded you of a 1940s serial, but this one doubles down on the stupidity level....The only saving grace is that [it] doesn't take itself seriously.
An engaging portrait of the transcendent power of music as well as a moving testimony to the effect of political turmoil on individual artists.
movie_title: The Music of Strangers: Yo-Yo Ma and the Silk Road Ensemble (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A coiled-spring thriller that expertly ratchets up the tension before exploding in a breathtaking finale. It lacks any heart or humanity, but whether that matters will depend on your point of view.
Likable, though not magical, and a decent alternative to more antic, frenzied children's fare...but apart from a few sequences the picture doesn't take flight.
Like Joel Schumacher's...'The Phantom of the Opera,'...Tom Hooper's opulent but bloated version of another insipid pop opera proves a lump of coal in moviegoers' Christmas stockings.

Though it makes a few missteps in the final reel...overall a sensitive, small-scaled study of two people from very different backgrounds who find love despite all the obstacles society puts in their path.
A masterful piece of action filmmaking that succeeds in generating enormous tension by dramatizing a recent historical event in spite of the fact that everyone knows how it will end.
Starts with a clever premise and raises the prospect of really biting satire, only to trail off into weakly sweet comedy that falls far short of its potential.
An unexpected pleasure...goofily enjoyable.
Nothing more than a Troma schlockfest with a bigger budget, but it boasts an amusing script, a quick tempo and...a cast that milks the madness for all it's worth.
Colorful and witty...the mixture of action and humor proves as irresistible as ever.
Colorful and witty...the mixture of action and humor proves as irresistible as ever.
Though deliberately paced and somewhat repetitive, it's...powerful and enlightening.
movie_title: Anonyma - Eine Frau in Berlin (A Woman in Berlin) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: What [Moore] offers isn't an argument as much as a polemic. But as in the past, he proves a skilled polemicist,...[and] looked at dispassionately, it's fun.
The Dardennes have once again captured the harsh reality of the modern underclass while also injecting a note of moral hopefulness into what might have been a bleak and heartless tale.
Piercingly funny, wrenchingly sad and always brilliant...a small but genuine masterwork from a team that's already given us plenty of them.
As cool and elegant as its heroine. Unfortunately it's also equally impassive, opaque and--at least in this incarnation--dull.
You can always while away the hour and a half playing 'Count the Cliches.' One wishes Bleu all the best, but on the evidence of this picture his career might be a lot shorter than his hair.
Isn't much more than an extended exercise in horror tropes, but it's a clever one, expertly designed and executed, depending more on pulse-pounding suggestion rather than explicit violence.
A loud, crude, dreary misfire that feels like it was cobbled together from material cut from other lousy comedies.
One appreciates the mixture of fidelity and imagination that Jonze has lavished on Sendak's little book, but in the end the magic spark that marks a classic eludes him.
For the most part it's a tearjerker that works...testimony to the good judgment--and good taste--of everyone involved.
A turgid tale of adultery among the rich and boring.
So bad it ought to be based on a video game.
Particularly silly...the sort of emptily bombastic popcorn movie that might make you wish you had a surrogate to go and sit through it in your place.
Plenty of glitz but precious little substance...an oddly toothless portrait of a bruising business.
A peculiar but oddly effective portrait...of a loser not so much trapped as unwilling to try to escape.
