A sweet, sentimental, occasionally naughty, attractively mounted piece of old-fashioned hokum that will appeal to audiences, mostly female, of a certain age.
An Antarctic-set murder mystery that might have played well on the printed page but emerges as a slushy mess on the screen.
A hopelessly cliche-ridden tale that wouldn't be out of place on a family-oriented cable channel but is several sizes too small for the big screen.
This isn't so much sitcom fare as dinner-theatre material, directed without an ounce of style or panache and played more broadly than an old vaudeville routine.
You have to admit that it's faithful to its source. The original was lousy, and so is this retread.
Intricacy of construction takes precedence over depth of meaning or characterization, and the work entailed in figuring things out isn't rewarded by any emotional insight.
A movie of chuckles rather than belly-laughs...but they really add up. In its unforced, loopy way, this is one of the funniest pictures of the year.
A mellow, pictorially attractive period piece in which the characters seem actually to breathe rather than merely pose, as so often happens in such films.
Doesn't soar like Up, but it stays afloat long enough to remain a pleasant family treat.
movie_title: Cloudy With a Chance of Meatballs (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Yeah, love happens. So does something else. Sappy, overemphatic and cloying...[a] mountain of narrative cliches.
You have to give Cody and her cohorts credit for trying to pump some new blood into a stale genre, and there are moments of inspired cleverness...but they're not frequent or sustained enough.
An earnest comedy-drama, which covers familiar territory but in an unpretentious, and so reasonably pleasant fashion.
Riddled with cliches from beginning to end...[a] misguided exhumation of what was once a pretty lively piece.
One of the silliest action yarns in years...There's room for good pulp trash on screen, but lousy pulp, which is what this picture is, deserves a quick trip to the dumpster.
This love letter to the Big Apple has more than its share of worms.
A botched remake...A real thriller has you on the edge of your seat; watching this one, you're more liable to sit back and snooze.
Merely lets the facts of forty years ago speak for themselves, and one can't deny that its dramatization of them has enormous energy and urgency.
movie_title: Der Baader Meinhof Komplex (The Baader Meinhof Complex) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The amount of inanity exceeds the quantity of the special effects...and the movie is filled to the brim with them.
Excruciating...its awfulness is so profound that it actually takes on a perverse fascination.
Trash--grubby and nonsensical, with lame dialogue, wretched overacting and clumsily staged action sequences.
movie_title: The Boondock Saints II: All Saints Day (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A toon that puts nearly every non-Pixar one of recent years to shame. In this case, the titular adjective is well chosen.
One of the most powerful and moving films about the human cost of the Afghan-Iraq war and about those of war in general to appear in years.
If you're looking for an uplifting sports story, this one, familiar as it is, manages a winning score.
A movie so flat and derivative that it seems to have been cobbled together from other, better pictures.
Outrageously enjoyable...turns the genre conventions on their head to often uproarious effect.
movie_title: Bad Lieutenant: Port of Call New Orleans (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A lugubrious Harlequin romance with fangs and paws instead of bosoms and bodices.
A grim, tedious slog that goes nowhere emotionally [and] never manages to be either viscerally affecting or intellectually insightful.
A magnificent achievement...both fascinating and fun--so good, in fact, that after watching this cut you just might to search out the director's original 280-minute version.
[A] sorry mess, a mangy, flea-bitten comedy of Daddy Day Care caliber.
No prize, [but] at least it barrels ahead without trying to humanize its comic-book characters or deliver a ludicrous V for Vendetta-style political message.
An agreeable divertissement, easy to take--and equally easy to forget.
Smart, sexy, funny and poignant...flies high on the old-fashioned virtues of intelligence, wit and cleverness--with a dollop of seriousness added to the mix.
A grim, uncompromising--and revelatory--film. It's an incredibly difficult picture to watch. But its toughness brings equally incredible rewards.
movie_title: Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire (2009)

movie_review_blurb: While visually arresting, 9 is narratively a pretty familiar piece, and at once too mature for children and too childish for adults.
Lacks the edge it might have had, [but] as a genial, old-fashioned comedy about the spirit of the sixties, it's enjoyable enough.
While visually arresting and peculiar enough to hold your interest, in the end it proves to be pretty empty inside.
A bland tourist souvenir, the equivalent of an authorized biography rather than an independent one.
A surprisingly fascinating subject that...yields lots of laughs.
Stylistically unpretentious but highly informative and enjoyable documentary [on] one of radio's great stars and a television pioneer.
Even if you're not a soccer fan you should respond to...another expert mining of historical record by Peter Morgan [that's] not so much a sports movie as a character study.
Comes off more like a museum exhibit than a vital drama...Amelia never takes flight, but it certainly crashes.
Decked out in snazzy computer-generated animation, but comes across as more rote than exhilarating.
Not really a sequel but more a misguided prequelish follow-up...obviously enjoyed a much larger budget than its titular predecessor, but it's nowhere near as much fun.
The tawdry use of important real-life social issues in the service of what amounts to nothing more than another exercise in malignant sadism makes this picture even worse than earlier episodes.
All winded wind-up and no dazzling follow-through. Hogwart's wizards have absolutely nothing to fear from this bunch of sad second-raters.
movie_title: Cirque du Freak: The Vampire's Assistant (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The rare picture nowadays that takes satiric aim at the pomposity of the world of high art and hits the target, even if the blows are more often than not only glancing ones.

Takes what's essentially a soap-operatic plot and spins it into something very like cinematic gold...instructive about how a very familiar story can be given new vibrancy by filmmakers and actors working at peak form.
A suspenseful, often riverting drama of World War II resistance that combines old-fashioned virtues of craft and style with a more modern sense of nuance and complexity.
movie_title: Flammen & Citronen (Flame & Citron) (The Flame and the Lemon) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Clear evidence of the limitations of the performance-capture method of animation and of the excesses it invites...there's more of artifice than art in it.

If you're gullible enough to accept the backstory given here, you're probably the sort of person who'll take Criswell's assurances that Plan 9 from Outer Space is based on sworn testimony at face value.
Offers just a few moderately amusing moments, and by and large proves curiously flat, despite all the talent on the screen.
movie_title: The Men Who Stare at Goats (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A powerful fact-based parable illustrating exactly how irrational and cruel racial bigotry is.
As obvious and contrived as the original...[with] Robert De Niro in one of the 'regular guy' roles he occasionally takes on--only to prove that he isn't suited to them.
A virulently ugly, unpleasant movie to look at as well as an incredibly stupid one, an insult to the eye as well as the brain.
May be about a minor artist, but it's a major success.
Occasionally goes saccharine, [but] mostly succeeds in telling an unusual story in an engaging way.
A stylish stiff, hobbled by surprisingly uncharismatic lead performances from its stars.
Will probably keep the franchise humming along profitably, despite its persistent mediocrity.
movie_title: Ice Age: Dawn of the Dinosaurs (Ice Age 3) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Less impressive as a whole than in its parts, it's still a provocative, well-crafted picture...one of the best films yet made about the Iraq War.
A confection that has gone sour before you've finished consuming it.
movie_title: La Fille de Monaco (The Girl from Monaco) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: An indie romantic comedy even worse than most of the bigger-budgeted but almost invariably rotten Hollywood examples of the genre.
Like a Lifetime disease-of-the-week movie on steroids...tugs at your heartstrings so relentlessly that by the time it's over you might require a defibrillator.
Unsettling and at the same time genuinely moving, it's a superb psychological thriller...remarkable for its meticulous creation of mood.
The well-preserved (or well-restored) footage, and the simple joy of the artists, easily put any misgivings in the shade.
Of direct-to-DVD quality, so you might as well wait until this one makes it to disc--and then skip it.
Nowhere near as vulgar as most contemporary teen comedies...On the other hand, it's a crushing bore. At least Nia Vardalos' terrible I Hate Valentine's Day had the right verb in its title.
A condescending picture that always takes aim at easy targets, fires away with a blunderbuss, and then pretends to be courageous for what it's done.
Has moments of insight and cleverness, but it's pretty threadbare in every sense.
Such an assured, professional piece of work--and a pre-sold one at that--that it will largely disarm criticism, despite its flaws.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The point that it's making about the treatment of women under traditional Islam and the inhumane modes of punishment still prevalent in many countries...is sufficiently important that, with all its flaws, it deserves to be seen.
A numbingly wrong-headed period piece that misfires on virtually all cylinders...Hampton and Frears prove heavy-handed, and their clumsiness is magnified by the missteps of the cast.

Even longer and noisier than its predecessor--as well as dumber and more incoherent...like a big, unsightly, clattery toy powered by a battery that just wont quit, even though you devoutly wish it would.
Isn't the sort of picture that grabs you from the start, but the tale of two loners who find one another gradually grows on you.
Clearly an activist piece of filmmaking, but cleverly put together and highly enjoyable...It does, however, raise some troubling journalistic questions.
Coarse but only intermittently amusing example of boys' night out...Among guy flicks this one comes in around the middle, neither unmentionably terrible nor particularly memorable.
We're in Howard the Duck and Pluto Nash territory here...so awful that watching all forty-three episodes of the original without a break would be less painful.

The limberness of the leads and the affable nature of Mendes' treatment soften the material's harshness and make it go down easily. You should tag along with Burt and Verona on their journey of discovery.
Lovely scenery...stuck in a sub-sitcom script. Some of these group tours are really the pits.
You're unlikely to look at the stuff on the shelves of your supermarket in quite the same way ever again...probably won't be seen by many consumers, but it deserves to be.
An innocuous father-daughter movie--sweet and inoffensive--and...a distinct improvement on Murphy's recent efforts. But...it's just okay, not the enchanting treat it's meant to be.
A reasonably interesting but curiously routine heist movie that will be appreciated more by new riders than those familiar with the superior 1974 incarnation.
An intellectual sci-fi tale that unabashedly takes its inspiration from 2001: A Space Odyssey. Unfortunately, it resembles the Kubrick masterpiece less than an episode of The Outer Limits.
A gentle, deadpan comedy-drama...you shouldn't miss the opportunity to make the acquaintance of this wryly observant little film.
A dry, dull retelling of a typical gay coming-of-age tale that's invigorated by neither the period backdrop nor the fact that the characters were real people.
Has a distinct point of view on the Israeli-Palestinian impasse, but expresses it with considerable finesse as well as emotional power.
Sluggish when it should be scintillating and sappy where it should be sardonic, this romantic comedy winds up more softball than screwball.
Though this is lesser Allen, it contains enough laugh-out-loud moments in Woody's old vein to make it an enjoyable trifle.
Not much more than another raunchy, adolescent boys-out-on-the-town farrago, even if the boys are dressed in animal skins and the town is Sodom.
An experiment you have to admire for the risks it takes even while being disappointed that it doesn't quite come off.
Plays like a busted Fox sitcom pilot, though heavier on the raunchiness and dragged out to a literally painful hour and a half.
The problem with Orphan isn't merely that the film is idiotic--it's that it's also sleazy, formulaic and repellant.
The first 3-D movie from Jerry Bruckheimer, the last producer you'd think of whose pictures needed to be more in-your-face.
Crass, stupid and ineptly made, this car-lot farce is so awful that it ought to qualify for the "Cash for Clunkers" program on grounds of polluting the atmosphere.
movie_title: The Goods: Live Hard, Sell Hard (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Trite but self-important tale of a professional boy-toy in contemporary L.A.,...nothing more than a wallow in old-fashioned melodrama.
So long as you don't mind twisted history and elaborate riffs on genre convention, you should find that there's much to savor here, not least Waltz's magnetic villainy.
Both overstuffed and, despite the profligacy, curiously tedious. It must be admitted, though, that the 'wishing rock' seems to work. I wished devoutly for Shorts to end, and eventually it did.
movie_title: Shorts: The Adventures of the Wishing Rock (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A feature-length sitcom,...the kind of slight, vacuous comedy that evaporates long before it completes its tedious circuit to a foreordained happy ending.
For fans of such activities, footage of their idols in action may be enough, but even they might find the movie overall surprisingly ordinary.
Though it suffers some stumbles along the way and definitely chickens out in the end, for much of the running-time it's a deliciously deadpan satire on the cults that grow up around dead celebrities.
Leaves your hope for something not just unusual but tasty unquenched.
The scruffiness is hardly accidental, but it gives the picture a gentle warmth and easy charm that make it as pleasant, if as passing, as a warm summer breeze.
While [it] has a certain quirky charm--mostly due to its star--the overall effect is rather pallid.
Warner Bros. is demanding a surcharge of viewers for the privilege of seeing the movie in 3D. Actually the company should be paying them for sitting through it at all.
Putrid...fails to be remotely frightening and just settles for being utterly repulsive instead.
Isn't startlingly new, but it's a nice twist on a familiar formula, and should satisfy anyone who wants to see the postman, as it were, ring yet again.
An anemic, meandering ensemble comedy that just sputters along lamely before ending, apparently of sheer exhaustion.
Isn't likely to snag Guggenheim another Oscar, but it's interesting enough, even for non-fanatics.
Given its bizarre imagery and offbeat attitude, it's like The Little Mermaid on acid. [But] it's visually beguiling, and that more than makes up for the strangeness.
One might be tempted to call it perfectly dreadful if it didn't seem inappropriate to utter the word 'perfect' anywhere within miles of it.
The coolest, most intelligent action movie of the year. It's visually striking and provides an adrenaline rush, but it also has a brain.
Isn't going to win any awards, but it's a distinct step up from most striving-against-the-odds high school movies.

A touching tearjerker that's also a celebration of traditional values against the dehumanizing tendencies of modern urban life...with even the most obvious moments saved by an underlying sweetness and poignancy.
A pleasant--or I should say pleasantly unpleasant--surprise...a[n]...effective character study dressed up as a grisly horror movie.
Almost everyone's miserable in Shrink--but nobody more so than a person unlucky enough to be watching it.
Waspish political satire is rare enough today that even a middling specimen is welcome.
Sounds like the stuff of a Hallmark Hall of Fame telefilm, but happily Mayer's sensitivity and the skill of Dancy and Byrne raise it to another level.
Overlong and undeniably self-indulgent, with some brilliant high spots punctuating more mediocre material and a close that's a letdown. But it has enough perception and laughs to merit a visit.
If the torture-porn genre isn't dead yet, this idiotic exercise in pointless sadism should kill it off for good.
Isn't all that bad...but it lacks magic, and except as a harmless diversion for the youngsters on a rainy afternoon, you can safely hold off until it shows up on DVD.
An unabashedly activist, one-sided piece of cinema, but a very effective one that probably won't find wide distribution, though it should.

If you're old enough to remember the goofy double bills that American International used to churn out in the fifties, you'll have some idea of the quality of this movie. Whether you'll consider that an attractive proposition is another matter.
Old-fashioned melodramatic claptrap, served up in ridiculously overblown style...another deeply embarrassing misfire from a man once considered a major American filmmaker.
Part documentary, part fictional romcom, and all twee.
For all the talent invested in Julie & Julia, it's ultimately a bland cinematic dish that needed more comedic spice.
Will genre fans take this totally artificial, over-the-top serial-killer movie as a straight thriller, or understand it as the parody one hopes it's intended to be?
Practically a compendium of everything that's wrong with Hollywood action flicks nowadays--a non-stop orgy of cheesy, chaotic CGI effects unencumbered by any human dimension.
movie_title: G.I. Joe: The Rise of Cobra (2009)

movie_review_blurb: This sappy romantic fantasy proves that a movie doesn't have to be a CGI extravaganza based on a video game, comic book or toy line to be inordinately dumb.
While everyone won't agree with the approach...it does result in the sort of mildly amusing, feel-good period piece with an easy-to-swallow message that appeals to today's older audiences.
Those...who've seen the Danish original can't help but feel that some of the power and depth have been lost in translation.
A pleasant but undistinguished addition to the Disney animated canon,...an agreeable throwback to a type of animation one doesn't see much of anymore.
Like the better pieces of the art it showcases, an oddity worth experiencing.
Though really nothing more than a high-toned soap opera,...the extraordinary performances elevate the material far above its treacle-drenched roots.
Basically a one-joke comedy, and the joke is too moldy to support feature length--and told in an unremittingly coarse, crude fashion.
A weird fusion of romantic excess, overwrought violence and crudely-staged action, all played to the rafters, filmed in garish colors and accompanied by a bombastic background score.
Abysmal...a chick-flick 'Ishtar.'
This is utter hokum, and it's not played with enough brazen absurdity to make it much fun.
movie_title: Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Might serve a useful therapeutic function for its writer-director, but for the rest of us the exercise in self-examination will have a much less beneficial effect, unless you suffer from insomnia.
However well-intentioned, this is one of the talented but variable Loach's weaker efforts.
Far from innovative and even farther from subtle, but it's one of the more genuinely enjoyable products to come out of the Apatow factory.
Part monster movie and part domestic drama. While the mixture doesn't entirely gel,...it's a cinematic hybrid sufficiently intriguing to merit a visit.
Basically a character study, and Douglas brings the character vividly to life.
In terms of his longevity in the newspapers, 'Marmaduke' is a very old dog. And the movie has no new tricks up its paws.
A dreadful rip-off of 'True Lies'...a disaster so complete that...it will easily earn a high place among the year's worst pictures.
Less biography than hagiography, and more suitable to cable TV than theatres.
Too little--and, as is becoming increasingly clear as the franchise winds down, too late.
This fourth installment demonstrates that the big green ogre has definitely passed his prime...Maybe cinematic ogres age in dog years.
Even if you consider NASCAR itself a bore, you'll find this snapshot of what's often called its version of Little League compulsively watchable.
A slightly soggy popcorn adventure. Far from being a Robin for the ages, it's a retelling you'll hardly care about while you're watching it and barely remember after the lights come up.
A fascinating portrait of a vanishing way of life.
A flat, lifeless remake that's totally unnecessary, except of course to the studio executives who want to extract still more profit from the property.

Thanks to [Caine], a film that might have been a cheap revenge melodrama instead becomes a rather moving tale of an elderly man's valedictory crusade against the callous brutality of the modern world.
Heavy with messages, but it's good-hearted and sincere and creates a strong sense of place.
While it might have worked at the three-minute length of a Loony Tunes short, when dragged out to ninety the movie will test the patience even of the kids.
Hardly a treasure, but it offers some modest rewards.
Nothing but a stripped-down modern Frankenstein story that's more icky than truly frightening.
A flimsy character study...as ephemeral and forgettable as a sheet of paper carried off by a gust of wind.
To a certain extent it's fun to watch Cox and Dano do their duet, but there's no depth to the lyrics.
A canny, well-wrought film that uses Argentina's checkered past to fashion a juicily rapt mixture of personal obsession, simmering romance and political skullduggery.
movie_title: The Secret in Their Eyes (El Secreto de Sus Ojos) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Talky, curiously depressing for most of its running-time, weighed down by too many heroes and an army of uninteresting villains, and messily prosaic in the big action moments, 'Iron Man 2' suggests that this franchise is already running on fumes.
A mostly winning homage...Isn't just a film noir; it's so complicated an example of the genre that you might call it a film noir squared.

If you look forward to a parent taking a stack of photos of his child out of his wallet and shuffling through them for your viewing pleasure, you'll love the movie. If you try to scurry away instead--probably not.
All [the movie] proves is that if you're going to make a road movie rom-com, you should invite Vanessa Redgrave to tag along on the journey...Her grace and charm overshadow all else in it.
This isn't an awful romantic comedy, just a frail and feeble attempt at one, marred by a predictable trajectory, clunky dialogue and a crushingly dull desire to be nice at all costs.
While this 'Kid' should be engaging enough for those coming to the tale for the first time, it certainly won't efface memories of the original.
An extraordinary picture...a chilling portrait, but one with human warmth pulsating beneath the surface.
A perfectly average summer action movie--you needn't pity the fool who goes to see it, but he's not in for anything special.
If this 'piece of work' is more workmanlike than revelatory, it's an engaging portrait of a feisty lady.
movie_title: Joan Rivers: A Piece Of Work (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A reasonably engaging 'toon that both kids and grownups should enjoy.
If you come out of 'Predators' thinking you've seen it before, it's because you have.
The filmmakers have called up--and pumped up--an absolute orgy of special effects, but all they've conjured is a horrid mess of a movie.
A rather juvenile brain-teaser lacking an effective emotional core but bursting with cool visuals. Unlike the most powerful dreams it doesn't stick with you.
Stunning...a harrowing, deeply troubling and thought-provoking film, but not a tub-thumping, didactic one.
If in the end it doesn't fully capture the malignant brilliance of its source...there's enough Thompson in it to make that sick puppy Lou Ford a guy worth spending a couple of hours with.
Inoffensively amusing, and occasionally touching, but also a little bland.
A mediocre third-generation copy of an idea that wasn't very new to begin with, and the addition of a supposedly rational explanation to the mix proves more hindrance than help.
Frankly more puff piece than solid journalism, a picture that squanders its potential by preferring softballs to hard pitches.
Quickly sacrifices the slightest shred of plausibility in favor of mindless action, and becomes ever more preposterous as it rushes headlong to an apocalyptic finale.
Amiable but innocuous family movie, which would be more at home on a cable channel than theatre screens but should nevertheless amuse young girls and their mothers.
Despite the open-air connotation of the title, there's a curiously constricted, even suffocating quality to 'Agora' that leaves it...a chore to sit through.
A rather tepid special-effects spy movie for kids, in the same vein as 'G-Force,' if you'll forgive the expression.
movie_title: Cats & Dogs: The Revenge of Kitty Galore (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Successfully exchanges the satiric bite of the original for a healthy, satisfying dose of Hollywood slapstick and sentiment.
Maudlin, manipulative tearjerker...St. Jude, as the script helpfully explains, is the patron of hopeless cases, but even his presence can't save this picture.
One hopes that the final installment will be better.
movie_title: The Girl Who Played with Fire (Flickan som lekte med elden) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Revealing and exciting, even for those oldsters who know perfectly well how it will turn out.
movie_title: Most Dangerous Man in America: Daniel Ellsberg and the Pentagon Papers (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The anti-Hollywood Hollywood romantic comedy, naturalistic and acerbic rather than slick and saccharine.
The good news is that this third installment...is the best yet. The bad is that's not saying much.
If you found a picture like Bill Forsythe's 'Local Hero' to your liking, this bit of Irish blarney should work for you as well.
A good movie about a very bad one.
An interesting failure.
A worthy finale to one of the screen's best trilogies.
Calls to mind two of the worst westerns of the past thirty years...The problem isn't that the movie is moody and morose; it's that it's flat and tedious.
A morose but instructive story about the destructive influence of money--and fanaticism--on American government.
movie_title: Casino Jack And The United States Of Money (2010)

movie_review_blurb: To misquote Cole Porter, 'Knight and Day' isn't the one...a cross between 'Charade' and 'Mission Impossible' that mimics the over-the-top action of the latter but, sadly, has little of the former's charm.
Infantile, a puerile, pitifully sloppy comedy about a bunch of guys suffering from arrested development made by guys who apparently actually do.

An irritatingly cute and complicated farce that resembles nothing more than a string of three-minute live-action cartoons strung together into a whole far less funny and charming than it thinks it is.
One of the most visually stunning films of the year [but] from an emotional perspective the narrative falls flat.
Generates neither emotional heat nor intellectual light.
Despite a reliance on docu-drama contrivances, a reasonably intelligent, impressively mounted account of a little-known act of twentieth-century heroism.
Rather pallid...[a] stolid, talky adaptation of Peter Cameron's novel.
movie_title: The City of Your Final Destination (2010)

movie_review_blurb: For the most part, an enjoyably wild ride that may do for what you might call the 'noodle western' what Leone's classics did for the pasta variety.
movie_title: The Good, the Bad, the Weird (Joheun-nom, Nabbeun-nom, Isanghan-nom) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Loopy, chaotic and often very funny, though even at a mere 75 minutes it feels a mite overlong.
movie_title: A Town Called Panic (Panique au village) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The uninitiated will find the picture an odd, strangely chilly and frequently confounding experience. They won't care that this first 'Airbender' will likely be the last too.
The heist goes awry, but not as badly as the movie.
Basically a low-rent cousin of 'The A-Team'--'The C- Team,' in other words.
A flat retread of a comedy that was already moribund.
As matinee fodder for desperate families, it could be worse. But not much.
A wacky piece of pseudo-religious twaddle dressed up as a solemn, silly post-apocalyptic action flick.
A gently affecting study of the relationships among a group of friends and family...made up of small but telling details.
Plays as though the Lifetime Network were being pumped into the theatre. Unfortunately, there's no remote to change the channel with.
One can only hope it doesn't serve as a precedent for, let's say, John Cena following up 'The Marine' with a fantasy in which he plays the Easter Bunny.
Quote not available.
A movie about too many vampires that only proves there are too many movies about vampires.
The goofiest plundering of the Bible since Christopher Walkin's 'Prophecy' pictures...a combination of horror movie cliche and pseudo-religious mumbo-jumbo that proves a pretty fetid brew.
A dark, brooding 'Death Wish'-style melodrama that aims for the complexity of a good political thriller but doesn't quite achieve it.
Even in the avalanche of terrible Hollywood romantic comedies, this one is particularly inane.
Challenging as well as informative...a strong addition to an already impressive body of work.
movie_title: La Danse -- Le Ballet de l'Opera de Paris (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A buddy-spy thriller that exudes Euro-trashiness from first frame to last.
More gloppy romantic sap from the Nicholas Sparks tree...it proves that Sparks is the modern Fanny Hurst.
Tells a fascinating story in an unwieldy way...a pity the structural flaws undermine its impact.
As far as proselytizing Christian films go, this one is better than most, even if it's rather like an after-school special drawn out to inordinate length.
The scenery is beautiful and the stars are ingratiating, but while more palatable than many rom-coms, the movie is basically the same old blarney in a pretty package.
Despite Cera's consderable charm, the alternately scruffy and diffident tone that Arteta and Nash bring to the material leave it feeling both forced and limp.
Another of those failed Gilliam fantasies in which anything goes but nothing matters.
Formulaically uplifting. More hagiography than biography, it winds up an inspirational tale told in an uninspired way.
Surprisingly moving...the style constantly threatens to overwhelm the substance, but winds up contributing to it instead.
An utterly familiar but mostly satisfying character study of a man rescued from the brink of self-destruction, attuned to the rhythm of an eye-catching star performance.
Might have been called Witless Protection, if that title hadn't already been taken (damn you, Larry the Cable Guy!).
movie_title: Did You Hear About the Morgans? (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The technical wizardry is at the service of a recycled plot and a script rife with cardboard characters...and dialogue that sounds as though it had been lifted from the pages of a third-rate comic book.
It works as an old-fashioned wallow in nineteenth-century British royal romance and parliamentary infighting.
Isn't much worse than the original, but unfortunately it's no better.
movie_title: Alvin and the Chipmunks: The Squeakquel (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Part homage, part recreation, part innovation--but, happily, mostly engaging...[there's] a good deal to enjoy here.
A homage to past masters like Hitchcock and Sirk, done up in irresistible Almodovar style...as a directorial love-letter to films and filmmaking, it's an absolute winner.
Precisely the sort of mindlessly revved-up, high-octane thing one expects from Guy Ritchie...a desecration rather than an updating.

Not much more than an American version of a bad French bedroom farce...it's a depressing commentary on the state of American comedy that one as crass and clumsy as this will probably be called sophisticated.
A fussy, artificial piece of work drained of emotion and humanity by extravagant effects and directorial flamboyance.
Very hard to watch, and in the end it's doubtful it's worth the effort. But it has moments you won't forget, however much you may want to.
Evocative and suspenseful, it's both a masterful recreation of a past age and a remarkable rumination on the constants of human frailty and societal brutality.
Notable primarily as a platform for a thespian tour de force by Plummer and Mirren, and they're not to be missed.
So long as it sticks to the stunts, it's fun. Unfortunately, when it delivers its masses-against-the-man message, it stumbles. And that's far too often.
It wants to be a real chiller, but comes out curiously lukewarm.
It's like a bunch of episodes from that lousy old ABC anthology series, 'Love, American Style,' squished together.
While it certainly isn't terrible, it plays like a low-rent variation of the Harry Potter formula--innocuous but instantly forgettable.
movie_title: Percy Jackson & the Olympians: The Lightning Thief (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A real dog...another in the apparently endless stream of rotten road-movie rom-coms being cranked out by Hollywood.
Turns genre conventions on their head in creating a thoroughly engrossing mixture of murder mystery, psychological thriller and very black comedy.
A visually spectacular boy-and-his-dragon tale that's a thoroughly winning combination of action, humor and uplifting messages, all delivered with a happily light touch.
As an admitted old fogy, I hated this movie, an ultra-raunchy, raucous gross-out comedy...but if you're among those who enjoy...slob farces, [this] is for you.
A serious misstep...treating what is actually a lurid story as though it were a piece of high art.
If you laid all the cliches in 'The Last Song' end to end, they'd probably circle the globe several times over.
More properly, 'Crash of the Bores'...dark, grim and (apart from some juvenile macho banter) overly serious, a plodding, chaotic affair more likely to induce headache than a feeling of exhilaration.
Edgy, intelligent and unusual. And also uneven. [It] has so many good things going for it, though, that while you can't overlook the flaws, you might be willing to forgive them.
A heady brew, but a largely satisfying one.
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Different friom run-of-the-mill romantic comedies--which is all to the good, but not terribly funny--which isn't.
Though elegantly made, 'After.Life' is basically one long tease that in the end doesn't deliver much beyond further obfuscation.
Crazily inspired....If you can stomach the violence--cartoonish but still abrasive--you'll find it giddy fun and almost shamefully enjoyable.

One leaves this long but fascinating series appalled at the level of depravity one tiny corner of the globe can hold, but strangely exhilarated--as well as moved--by the craft and cunning with which it's been portrayed.
There's the makings of a nasty satire of modern American materialism [here] but in the end...the movie goes soft, squishy and even--heaven help us--preachy.
A moodily evocative, quietly unnerving little tale of the pain of loss and the struggle to come to terms with grief.
Charming and funny...obviously a labor of love that turns out to be worth every ounce of affection the cast and crew lavished on it.
A rather specialized picture, very unlike the usual children's fare... But as an example of sophisticated animation, this should certainly be appreciated by adult connoisseurs.
One of the silliest futuristic thrillers ever; what sets it apart, though, is that it's also one of the most thoroughly--indeed virulently--unpleasant.
Quietly, unobtrusively revealing, and pretty funny too--a shrewdly observed comic portrait of a thoroughgoing egomaniac.
A torpid retelling of the classic lycanthropy story, both bloated and constricted, mostly glum but punctuated with nasty, intrusive humor, and more interested in decor and makep than genuine style.
Trying desperately to be hip and cool, 'Saint John of Las Vegas' is fey and flimsy instead.
Reminds one of how bad American independent films...can be.
Offers very little emotional punch to go along with the visual pizzazz, seeming more a genre exercise than a deeply felt drama. It dazzles the eye but leaves the heart cold.
Not just slow but spellbinding...demands a good deal from viewers in the way of attention and concentration, but the returns are substantial.
Seems pale, weightless and--compared to the best paranoid thrillers--surprisingly ephemeral.
Wants simultaneously to be a send-up of the genre and to generate the excitement a serious example of it would. It fails on both counts.
May not break new ground, but...it treads familiar territory with considerable dexterity.
Or 'Favorite Cop Cliches'...feels like three standard-issue episodes of any police TV drama squeezed together.
Visually splendiferous but wrongheaded, the movie is far more Burton than Carroll--and not very good Burton at that--and far less than enchanting.
A crude culture clash sitcom in which both groups lose--along with those of us who belong to neither.
A tearjerker piled on a tearjerker...a gloomily mawkish, manipulative soap opera that uses the sad historical context in a way many will consider offensive.
While compared to Greengrass' finest movies it's a minor effort, it offers enough excitement to pass muster--especially since its basic argument, provable or not, carries a real punch.
Forgettable sub-Apatow fare that even the personable leads can't save from utter mediocrity.
An intriguing but flawed attempt to dramatize the rise and fall of a group that's more than an historical footnote but less than a household name.
No better than a run-of-the-mill made-for-cable movie on any network that caters to pre-teens...[but] boys of a certain age--six to ten, perhaps--may enjoy [it].
Those who make an effort to respond to its challenges will find it an absorbing and haunting experience.
Affectionate but revealing...a deeply human piece that's hilarious one moment and touching the next.
An animated movie that's far more human than most live-action ones, and easily maintains the exalted standards we've come to expect from Pixar. It's guaranteed to raise your spirits.
While it may not represent the best vintage, it goes down easily enough.
Emotionally searing....Thanks largely to Garfield's heartfelt performance, Boy A becomes a powerful, poignant story of the difficulty of forgiveness.
Very uneven super-low-budget exercise...the sort of thing that's usually referred to as 'showing promise.'
At once haunting and surprisingly engaging, a unique vision of a unique place and of the people crazy or dedicated enough (or both) to devote themselves to it.
movie_title: Encounters at the End of the World (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A dispassionate autopsy of a passionate triangle, brilliantly devised if not always perfectly executed.
movie_title: Une Vieille Maîtresse (The Last Mistress) (An Old Mistress) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Tropic Thunder makes a lot of noise, but fails to produce the promised gales of laughter.
More tourist than first class...but the chemistry between Rogen and Franco insures that, as drug trips go, this one isn't bad.
Has a Mediterranean glow that gives the tale of passion and creativity a fundamentally warm quality that will surprise many viewers.
A very minor, instantly forgettable footnote to one of the most popular cinematic series of all time.
A shaggy God story, theological Capracorn that will be indigestible except to the already converted...Henry Poole Is Here is a movie that isn't all there.
Kiefer Sutherland plays a variant of his Jack Bauer character--except that this time, it's the audience he tortures, and he fails to defuse the bomb--the movie, that is.
An uneasy mixture of raucous Will Ferrell farce and kid-friendly Disney Channel teen teleflick that never gels.
The kind of thing that probably read a lot funnier than it plays.
Loud, vulgar and stupid, but what's most amazing is that despite all the bedlam, it will probably either bore you to tears or send you into gales of unintended laughter.
It makes you want to reach for a can of Raid.
[Has] a realistic grounding that sticks with you even when some of the plot mechanics swing into melodramatic terrain...[and] Melissa Leo gives a terrific performance.
A mature, small-scaled drama that's both insightful and affecting.
Even Frank himself would blanch at this serving of stale, sodden Capracorn.
A very mixed bag -- visually interesting throughout, but only sporadically funny, and too often seeming like little more than technical exercises.
This cheeky combination of updating and spoof makes for an agreeable amusement-park ride of a movie...all the more striking by being presented in very effective 3-D.
movie_title: Journey to the Center of the Earth (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Only intermittently captures the sense of goofy, off-the-wall fun that marked the first film.
This gimmicky, one-note comedy takes a well-deserved place in the pantheon of Murphy mega-bombs.
Saturday morning-grade fare that young children may enjoy but anybody older than eight will find bland and utterly forgettable.
A superior sequel, remarkable for its blend of serious themes and crowd-pleasing action, with a performance by Heath Ledger that's a memorable coda to a career cut far too short.
Yuck!...the very model of the modern musical comedy--there's absolutely nothing original in it...[and] it looks awful.
A very handsome period picture....But it's an almost perversely wrongheaded adaptation of the book.
Builds a remarkable degree of suspense...and along the way it manages a good deal of humor and charm as well.
One more step in the infantilization of American comedy....Its vulgarity is exceeded only by its stupidity, and it glorifies both.
Even those who retain great affection for Mulder and Scully are likely to find this reunion disappointingly routine and overly glum and grim.
movie_title: The X-Files: I Want to Believe (The X Files 2) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: May be no more revealing than similar television treatments of kids--and has been molded so smoothly as to sometimes seem staged--[but] it's an engaging portrait.
Actually too clever by half, but also so skillfully played that it carries you breathlessly along for the duration.
movie_title: Ne le Dis à Personne (Tell No One) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: One of those pure films that's devoid of excess and overstatement...simple but searing.
A loud, silly bit of non-stop action that again comes off like a poor cousin of the 'Indiana Jones' flicks.
movie_title: The Mummy: Tomb of the Dragon Emperor (2008)

movie_review_blurb: [An] on-and-off comedy...as airheaded as its ditzy heroine. But it has a goofily good-natured quality.
A solid informational piece on a fiscal reality than can really be called a national emergency.
Less radical than it appears, dressing up a fairly old-fashioned scenario in contemporary trappings. But simply as a political thriller, it delivers the goods pretty efficiently.
So bad it will make you nostalgic for The Pacifier.
This isn't Prada, but a cheap, crummy knock-off.
movie_title: How to Lose Friends & Alienate People (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Nick and Norah's playlist may be infinite, but the enjoyment they provide is definitely limited.
Takes the old western conventions and juggles them in very odd but mostly satisfying ways.
Stylistically fussy and dramatically confused...a what-if story that's become a pointless so-what movie.
Earnest but artless...not only exhibits no signs of genius but barely registers on the competence gauge.
Compared to the best doggie flicks, it may be the runt of the litter, but like most mutts it grows on you.
A Maher riff that's amusing enough, but hardly profound--one that's unlikely to alter your views on religion, whatever choir you're in.
While not one of the director's best works, it's a classy, sophisticated entertainment with a typically rich subtext.
movie_title: La Fille Coupée en Deux (The Girl Cut in Two) (A Girl Cut in Two) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The performers are amiable, but the material is only mildly amusing.
movie_title: Allah Made Me Funny: Live in Concert (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Curiously lightweight...escapes neither the slick histrionics of a typical studio blockbuster nor the clumsiness that afflicts movies with political messages.
An uplifting--and poignant--tale...but it's told...in very broad strokes that make their point as obviously as any TV movie would.
For youngsters used to more exciting fare even on the small screen, City of Ember is likely to be more like City of Slumber.
Grows increasingly repetitious and tedious as the same cinematic tricks are played over and over...the effect is suffocating rather than enjoyably spooky.
A cluttered cinematic hullabaloo that seems more interested in music acts, dance routines and long-winded, impromptu speeches than in fashioning an effective dramatic arc.
A fable of black and female liberation in the sixties south so drenched in sugar that watching it may make your teeth hurt.
[Has] sporadic moments of brilliance, but...winds up being more well-meaning muddle than miracle.
In its fairly straightforward but energetic way it captures a good deal of what made Thompson a unique figure...revealing, honest and--most of all--genuinely engaging.
movie_title: Gonzo: The Life and Work of Hunter S. Thompson (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A very juvenile copy of its Hitchcock-Kubrick models, efficiently made in the overwrought mold of contemporary action-adventure movies but a painfully loud--and silly--knockoff of the originals.
So laid-back and plain that the film leaves almost no impression at all.
The sort of crass, witless, Porky's-style exercise that makes even the worst product of the Judd Apatow factory look like a comic masterpiece.
Doesn't deserve a place among the classic train thrillers, but it offers enough cinematic amenities to be worth booking passage. And you won't need a sleeping compartment.
Intricate emotionally as well as in narrative terms, poignant but not mawkish, and told in an austerely compelling style, this is a wise and absorbing drama.
movie_title: Auf der Anderen Seite (The Edge of Heaven) (On the Other Side) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: All it proves is that on their home turf the Pangs can make an international hit-man tale every bit as trashy and dull as the ones made in Hollywood or Europe.
Compared to the deliciously catty 1939 film, this one seems not so much updated as, if not neutered, definitely declawed.
Isn't much more than an extravagantly complicated joke, [but] it's a pretty funny one, with plenty of those mordantly humorous jolts the [Coens] are so good at.
A total wipeout.

Lurid, stupid cop melodrama...crammed with sequences so overwrought and dialogue so monumentally pseudo-tough as to be absolutely laughable. The celebrated stars...produce nothing but crude self-parody.
A brilliant, witty and profound tragicomedy that reflects on recent Czech history with a highly imaginative, darkly humorous and strongly sensual tone.
movie_title: I Served the King of England (2008)

movie_review_blurb: If you're willing to take a chance on a daring film that's likely to make you laugh one moment and cringe the next, you may find it as haunting as it is uncomfortable to watch.
Just a handsomely appointed but lugubrious period soap opera centered on one of the distant ancestors of the so-called 'People's Princess.'
Flawed but intriguing thriller...while the movie is basically a potboiler, the brew that it keeps simmering is more potent than most.
A comedy that's genuinely funny without being gross, and genuinely warm without becoming maudlin, a winning combination of sour and sweet that's both tasty and satisfying
It's hard to take this wild mixture of sledgehammer symbolism, period Southern Gothic, race-conscious uplift and cautionary coming-of-age parable seriously, despite Fanning's remarkable poise.
Strains to be wickedly funny and provocative, but comes across feeling curiously pedestrian and tepid.
Redolent of the schmaltziest weepies of a half-century or more ago...strong evidence for the proposition that Nicholas Sparks must have been Fannie Hurst in an earlier life.
Neither satire nor drama but a sort of stream-of-consciousness rumination on Bush past and present, Stone's film is little better than a stunt, and a fairly toothless one at that.
A super-dud.
Would be more at home on ESPN than the big screen. But B-Ball fans should enjoy it in either venue.
Has some good ingredients, but they're mostly in the side dishes rather than the main course, and they're not tasty enough to make the whole thing worth ordering.
A reasonably entertaining throwback for the younger set, which nostalgic adults can also enjoy if they don't go expecting too much.
Charming, exuberant and poignant documentary...you'll probabvly come out of it with a spring in your step.
It doesn't develop the premise so much as endlessly repeat it...just hopelessly bad.
Wherever in the world Osama bin Laden might be, there's very little of him--or much that's serious or insightful--in this movie.
movie_title: Where in the World Is Osama Bin Laden? (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Perelman's ambition...is admirable; he's obviously trying to tell this story in a distinctive and challenging way....Unfortunately, he doesn't quite pull off the trick.
Heartwarming...This is a Year worth spending with Mauro and his friends.
movie_title: The Year My Parents Went on Vacation (O Ano em Que Meus Pais Saíram de Férias) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: An inordinately sleazy medical thriller operating on the erroneous belief that the combination of hot sex and cold corpses constitutes a real turn-on.
As a thriller Deception isn't deceptive or thrilling enough; it's like a puzzle one can put together too easily and, when finished, doesn't reveal much of value.
Non-potheads, even those who liked the White Castle original...may have trouble with this dumb, rather nauseating follow-up.
movie_title: Harold & Kumar Escape from Guantanamo Bay (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A lovely, quietly touching film that approaches a provocative and topical subject with dramatic sensitivity and graceful understatement.
There's no depth or resonance to what happens in the picture; it's all surface effect. But that doesn't mean it isn't reasonably enjoyable.
In his TV incarnation Patrick Dempsey may be called McDreamy, but his new romantic comedy is more like a nightmare.
Though he's been given A-list treatment...Iron Man can't escape being a little--dare I say it?--tinny....It doesn't crash, but it doesn't soar, either.
Quite possibly the dumbest movie ever made by an Oscar winner--and that includes all the dreadful pictures with Rod Steiger, F. Murray Abraham and even Cuba Gooding, Jr.
An absolutely awful remake of an eighties teen slasher flick that wasn't any good to begin with...resolutely dumb, dull and predictable.
Quote not available.
Isn't a work of genius, but it's clever enough to make you forgive its missteps.
It gets points for avoiding the graphic gore so common in horror movies nowadays, but Shutter won't make you shudder, let alone scream.
It survives its melodramatic excesses because of the inherent fascination of its subject and an outstanding lead performance.
Stylistically strange, sluggish and ultimately unsatisfying domestic drama.
Depends on the charm of its leading man. But that proves a commodity which, in Pegg's case, proves to be not only in short supply but positively out of stock.
A glib, flashy reworking of a story that, shorn of the cheap formulaic frills that have been added to it in the name of merchandising, might have been fascinating.
Adds to the ranks of films on the Iraq war that very few people will volunteer to see, not merely because the topic is difficult but because...it's so terribly uneven.
A joke that's underdeveloped and overextended...not one of the worst examples of this tired genre, but far from the best.
Looks like a million dollars, but in reality is just chump change.
In this old-time football saga Coach Clooney gets sacked...succeeds neither as a paean to the rambunctious game of the old days nor as homage to the great screwball comedies.
A children's movie obviously straining to be magical that falls far short of the goal.
At once silly, gross and boring...aims to be something more than a generic vacationing-twentysomethings-in-peril movie, [but] its pretensions make it even more ludicrous.
Worth seeing despite its flaws and the deep depression it's likely to leave you with.
May not live up to its title, but when Caine's onscreen it definitely sparkles.
Among dirty-cop actioners...hardly royalty; despite the title, it's more like a pretender to the throne. But like Reeves's Ludlow, it gets the job done.
Befitting its title, rather a mess...You can describe it as an unfunny dark comedy or a bathetic family drama, but in reality it's both.
A cornball martial arts movie in Mametspeak...like a Chuck Norris picture played with the solemnity of a Shakespearean tragedy.
Genuinely clever and amusing...may itself be hard to find, but it's worth a search.
The brutal sensory overload is coupled with a plot that starves the brain, a recycling of the silliness of the TV show unleavened by any saving hint of postmodern irony.
A movie that just seems to be going through the motions, a thoroughly uninspired rehash of a formula done far better elsewhere.
If you're willing to accept its utterly over-the-top attitude you'll find it almost absurdly enjoyable.
So laid-back that it barely registers, despite starring two guys who haven't exactly been shrinking violets in previous outings.
This Hulk isn't incredible; it's just mediocre...a very conventional comic-book movie, a considerable step down from Lee's more imaginative treatment.
A comeback for the director, but not quite enough of one...an almost equal combination of genuine creepiness and absolute foolishness.
Amounts to a glorified Hallmark Hall of Fame special, except with British accents.
movie_title: When Did You Last See Your Father? (2008)

movie_review_blurb: At a time when kidflicks have turned raucous and crude, its inoffensive sweetness makes it a positively endearing throwback.
Uses the old show merely as a springboard for a fairly conventional comedy-action movie that's louder, more frenetic and, ultimately, dumber.
It took Mike Myers five years to come up with this?
The visual mastery that not only excused but actually elevated the illogic of the first two installments of the trilogy is absent here.
movie_title: Mother of Tears: The Third Mother (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A thought-provoking documentary that's both informative and strangely poignant--as well as beautifully shot and edited.
Possesses a 'wow' factor that will make it one of the summer's biggest hits...an unabashed testosterone-adrenaline cocktail spiced up with a dollop of torture-porn bloodlust.
Quote not available.
Little more than an old story dressed up in contemporary trappings, but in this case they elevate the formula.
For many...the picture will fail to strike the desired tragicomic nerve.
Pleasant enough--and certainly pretty enough--to serve: a lesser Pixar effort, but one that most viewers, young and old, will enjoy if not be transported by.
A remote and chilly exercise, more museum piece than movie.
movie_title: The Duchess of Langeais (Ne Touchez Pas La Hache)(Don't Touch the Axe) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The decor and costumes are authentic, but there's barely a moment in the picture that feels genuine in human terms.
Subverts expectations by being not only complex but surprisingly engaging even as it raises serious questions.
High-minded and good-looking, but plodding and emotionally rather shallow.
Quirky but curiously irritating British period comedy...tries hard to be different, only to prove that different doesn't necessarily mean better, or even good.
Nasty, brutish but--pace Thomas Hobbes--insufficiently short gorefest...nothing more than an exercise in sadism.
The overemphatic music keeps telling us to be awestruck, but the movie itself stubbornly lacks grandeur.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: Prince Caspian (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Well-mannered, high-minded and, despite its potentially inflammatory dramatic arc, curiously tepid.
Despite all the spit and polish, there's a slightly stale, musty feel to the movie, as though Spielberg were painting by numbers.
movie_title: Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Doesn't avoid all the pitfalls, [but] it plays things out quirkily enough to surprise and engage us.
movie_title: As It Is in Heaven (Så som i himmelen) (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Coolly intense...If the film is only partially successful...the goal remains important, and Morris' commitment to it is laudable.
A grisly, morally disreputable cat-and-mouse exercise that has no point beyond viscerally implicating viewers in the same sadistic game played by the villains.
A fairy-tale that's fractured in ways that seem perversely calculated to alienate us even as it tries to draw us in...a cinematic pratfall.
Devotees of the HBO series will probably flock to the movie...but anybody who's not already a fan is going to have difficulty understanding what all the fuss is about.
A nasty little thriller, but an effective--and sometimes gruesomely funny--one.
Tae kwan don't...as stupid and irritating as its protagonist.
Though Carroll's presentation is unquestionably oversimplified...his points are well-taken and worthy of serious regard.
Another in the string of exercises in coarse infantilism that represent the studios' idea of farce nowadays.
movie_title: You Don't Mess With the Zohan (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Another misfit-makes-good movie with nifty visuals but a sodden script.
The picture's bravura style makes for an intriguingly exotic adventure only occasionally hobbled by the finicky mode of storytelling.
Isn't really a good movie, but compared to the usual line of junk in this genre, it's comparatively tolerable--except for that awful trailer scene, that is.
A picture skewering the inanities of the filmmaking system needs more sharpness and bite than this one provides.
Given the effect Max Payne has, by the close you may feel that they've misspelled the hero's last name.
A festival film par excellence--one that withers when removed from that special Sundance atmosphere.
Though it has more tricks up its sleeve than you can count, in the end all the sleight of hand amounts to disappointingly little.
It spends a full 104 minutes on an idea so artificial that it could have been handled in a sitcom in 22--and a mediocre sitcom at that.
Like the title character's own act, it's old-fashioned, a bit cheesy and not a little cornball. But the mere fact that it gives [Malkovich] the opportunity to go for broke makes it fun.
So silly that it not only strains credulity--it shatters it and then stomps it into infinitesimal pieces.
The picture's combination of stylistic splash and pretentious turgidity makes for a long slog. It may be accurate, but by the time it drags to an end, you won't really care.
A total bomb, worse than the worst movie ever adapted from a Saturday Night Live sketch.
I[t']s about people trying to make their way across the border into the United States. But if you think you've seen it before, you're mistaken.
So old-fashioned in its effects that it seems positively quaint; it resembles nothing so much as one of those 'scary' primetime telefilms that ABC specialized in during the 1970s.
Even the non-stop action of this movie isn't enough to conceal how completely nonsensical it is.
Slick but idiotic action flick...doesn't have any real power, and no intelligence whatever, under its glossy hood.
Yet another quirky coming-of-age tale, it's amiable enough but rather lackadaisical, and generates neither the laughs nor the insight needed to set it apart from the pack.
Quiet, deliberate and naturalistic...refreshingly truthful, especially for a picture about sports
Isn't just...a curiosity; it's as genuine a reflection of the ethos of today's Russia as Lumet's picture was of the spirit of 1950s America.
The standards for this genre are much higher than they used to be, and unhappily this movie, though amiable enough, just doesn't scale the heights.
Like so many of Disney's revampings (see Flubber), it's merely another disappointing attempt to revive the old chestnuts by larding them up with special effects.
For what it is...The Last House on the Left is effective. The problem lies in what it is--a pure exercise in sadism unencumbered by any larger concerns.
movie_title: The Last House on the Left (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The lack of subtlety...makes Crossing Over little more than an overwrought harangue.
An unholy mixture of Heroes and Jumper...'What if nothing we did made any sense?' says the inept hero, apparently reciting the credo of the moviemakers.
Not content with having trashed the memory of Peter Sellers and Blake Edwards once...Steve Martin takes up the task again, with results that are equally bad.
Small but affecting drama...a deceptively simple but emotionally rich tale [with] a remarkable lead performance.
Bloody awful...isn't really either a remake or a re-imagining; it's just another crappy sequel in a long line of them.
The extraordinary images compensat[e] for its lack of structure, less than stellar narration and musical missteps.
Though in the end this garish, frantic, relentlessly cartoonish rom-com pretends to be a warning against mindless materialism, it spends most of its time celebrating it.
It's a mildly intriguing political puzzler, but never manages to engage the heart as well as the head or make your pulse race as it should.
Quote not available.
As far as this sort of raunchy campus comedy goes, Fired Up! isn't as bad as you might expect... But of course that doesn't mean it's good.
A legal joust that ends in the sort of satisfyingly ambiguous fashion that should spur post-screening conversation.
Devotees of the video game [would] do better to stay at home and twiddle their thumbs in front of a monitor.
movie_title: Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Presumably it was the fact that the DVD release schedule for the week was already filled that explains the escape of this picture to theatres--it really belongs on a video store shelf or a late-night slot on a non-premium cable network.
A $100 million cult movie that some fans may adore--if they can stomach the changes; but despite the visual virtuosity, it will bore many if not most of the uninitiated.
The intentions...are good, and the picture boasts a fine lead performance, but ultimately...it's just a fancy disease-of-the-week movie that comes off confused and overly cute.
Though admirably modest and understated...it has a lot to be modest about.
The protagonist might be so laid-back that he practically disappears, but the picture itself tries much too hard--and stumbles.
Excellent ensemble dramedy, which avoids mawkishness while keeping its characters complex and treating even the least likable of them with a welcome degree of empathy.
Like a souffle overstuffed with ingredients. But it looks great on the plate, and enough of it is succulent to make up for the overcooked portions.
It doesn't want to be camp, but it inevitably becomes so, because the very effort to replicate its models is so knowing that it comes across as insufferably arch.
As a vehicle for Caine to do the crotchety old man routine...doesn't offer many new wrinkles to the mix.
One of those dark, clammy, dispiriting comic book movies like Daredevil, Elektra and Catwoman, loud and frenetic but lacking either dramatic depth or a sense of fun.
It may seem perversely appropriate that a picture that's mostly about waiting should make you wait for something to happen, but what may be artistically defensible isn't necessarily pleasurable.
A fast-paced, witty prequel, a top-flight modern adventure...that's not only an affectionate tribute to the original but a successful rebooting of the whole franchise.
Winds up seeming less pleasurably anarchic than simply messy and crude.
As far as preposterous pulp is concerned, Angels & Demons is livelier than The Da Vinci Code. But it's still just preposterous pulp.
There's no depth to Rudo y Cursi, but Bernal and Luna make the surface formula more fun than you might expect.
Thanks to the stars' adept way with Belber's script, this little movie manages to win you over.
Lovely to look at, perhaps, but in the end there's not much to it behind the surface glamour.
Does pretty much what you'd expect but little more, and its sullen efficiency doesn't make up for its lack of imagination.
May not plumb the emotional depths, but in its cool, detached way it's a sharply observed commentary on the parched, incomplete relationships that result from a merely capitalist mentality.
A big, bloated bore, so overstuffed with effects and racket that it's simply exhausting...the kind of empty extravaganza that gives family films a bad name.
movie_title: Night at the Museum 2: Battle of the Smithsonian (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Notable mostly for its ultra-cutesy style, which smothers the convoluted tale in visual and verbal affectation so heavy that you almost choke on it.
Bittersweet, quietly poignant and emotionally resonant but without tears, it's a film about art that becomes a work of art itself.
Doesn't boast a plot to match its hilariously over-the-top title, but it offers enough scares and chuckles to make for an enjoyably ghoulish cinematic roller-coaster ride.
A pretty pallid, pedestrian affair, a very mild outer-space adventure with an ecological message that, in the age of Pixar, is unlikely to keep kids, or their parents, rooted to their seats.
A tediously uninvolving ensemble mating-go-round that shuffles together a group of boring Baltimore characters in what's supposed to be--but isn't--an effervescent romantic roundelay.
movie_title: He's Just Not That Into You (2009)

movie_review_blurb: This crude reworking of Dickens was probably a bad idea to begin with, but it's so haplessly done that it didn't have a ghost of a chance.
Tawdry potboiler...a very bad rip-off of Fatal Attraction.
More than just a not-so-instant replay...even for viewers who regularly skip the Super Bowl it will be something to cheer.
This adaptation is drab and lifeless enough to make one suspect it was never much of a play in the first place.
It's Paul Blart with a nasty streak, a perverse kind of farce that most people will be more likely to recoil from than to laugh at.
There's a luminous purity to this film...quietly eloquent, both in subject and cinematic expression.
movie_title: Maria Larssons eviga ögonblick (Everlasting Moments) (Maria Larsson's Everlasting Moment) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: No better than cable-quality, and devoted fans really deserve something beyond assembly-line stuff when their TV idols are brought to the big screen.
Eleven-year old boys may very well enjoy Dragonball: Evolution, but anyone outside that target demographic might well be advised to skip it.
A movie that's no classic but is still engrossing and enjoyable.
Offers a message we've heard before, but it's one that bears repeating, and it's reasonably well delivered.
Painfully earnest and unrelievedly stilted and cliched, the movie is less a drama than a well-meaning but rather ridiculous diatribe.
As a piece of cinema, Every Little Step is hardly any great shakes, but as a historical document it's fascinating and compelling.
Highly derivative but still moderately enjoyable comedy...mostly because of Efron, who's easily the best reason to see the picture.
May not score a knockout, but it sure wins on points.
In spite of the title, The Informers doesn't get below the surface of the era of Reaganesque excess to tell us anything new. But it's way cool to look at.
Mawkish, manipulative, bombastic tearjerker [that] seems more about making a statement than translating the story into affecting drama.
May be more argument than even-handed report, but it's likely to alter people's opinions about its subject while reinforcing their amazement at his career in the ring.
May not do anything radically new, but it offers enough twists on familiar territory to be worth a visit.
Deliciously macabre...an animated film with a true touch of dark poetry.
Better than [Besson's] usual product, but still pretty thin, formulaic gruel.
A prosaic thriller that needed a touch of visual poetry to make the grade...Kim's original is far scarier; come to think of it, so is Lewis Allen's The Uninvited from 1944.
Has a rather anonymous feel...but it's certainly a well-oiled action machine, delivering the high-adrenaline goods even though the cheeky style that made the series distinctive is gone.
A moodily effective thriller that shows that there's life in the undead yet.
No classic but not a dog in spite of being about one.
So bad that you might expect it's intended as a campy send-up of its source...the worst-case scenario is that it's a truly faithful reflection of the quality of the novel.
An exhilarating experience that transcends the cuteness and contrivance of its basic premise through the sheer bravura of its filmmaking.
One Christmas movie too many...three parts crude farce, with plenty of comic violence and sexual innuendo, followed by a final reel awash in sappy, supposedly uplifting sentiment.
Eurotrash...a splashy but tedious retread that suggests the franchise has totally run out of gas.
Easily ranks as one of the best biographical movies in years...topped by a grand performance by Sean Penn.

Not just long and extravagant but woozy and ultimately rather silly...Luhrmann might have been aiming, Selznick-like, for a new Gone With the Wind, but his picture ends up feeling more like a second Duel in the Sun.
Junk, pure and simple...Stevenson [is] a beefy, taciturn fellow with all the charisma of Steven Seagal and an emotional range that goes from A to somewhere just shy of A-.
Gets more and more convoluted and preposterous as it goes along, and far less fun...a movie that, despite the title, will win no prizes.
There's enough material here for a television mini-series, and cramming it into less than two hours can't help but make it seem like a Cliffs Notes version.
An enjoyable riff that engagingly mixes recreation and imagination and is elevated above stunt status by two superb performances.
Ironically, by bringing us closer to the action--or more properly, the argument--the film diminishes the play's impact, as well as accentuating the overly histrionic elements of the performances.
Less unusual than simply nutty...while it's kind of intriguing, it comes nowhere near to being satisfying.
Calling Extreme Makeover: HE. Your intervention is sorely needed at this disastrous would-be horror movie...from the same folks who gave you the awful Thr3e.
Though the picture follows a well-worn path, it does so with a winning degree of warmth and humor.
Crude and unfunny...less fitting tribute than major disappointment.
A bit more imagination and sharper execution could have made this a winner. Instead it's a near-miss...a movie that plods along rather than taking off.
