Quote not available.
A wonderfully life-affirming tale of a woman who always looks on the bright side of things...[which avoids] either comic caricature or teary treacle.
Covers territory that would be familiar even if We Own the Night hadn't taken us there just a year ago, to equally boring effect.
A moody, melancholy period drama that's beautifully crafted but very subdued and obvious in its effects.
For there to be balance in the universe, good movies must alternate with bad ones. This is obviously one of the latter.
Pretentiously convoluted...in the case of Synecdoche, New York--to garble Plato's version of Socrates--the examined life is not worth watching.
Whatever the flaws, it's lively and colorful enough to satisfy the target audience as a fitting close to the ultra-popular series.
There's really nothing new here, and what's old is not good.
Feels self-consciously naughty rather than truly edgy, an adolescent exercise that's not only behind the curve...but never make[s] the tastelessness more than mildly amusing.
movie_title: Zack and Miri Make a Porno (2008)

movie_review_blurb: There's lots of sizzle...but in the end very little to chew on.
Even for the holiday, this stinker is a maladroit trick rather than any kind of Halloween treat.
When a picture asks you to puzzle through a chain of ambiguous clues to a surprise solution, you have a right to expect something better than watered-down Shyamalan.

Superior to a lot of the bigger-budgeted, starrier-cast romantic comedies that come out of Hollywood...but too lightweight and rough around the edges to amount to anything more than a harmless time-waster.
movie_title: The Other End of the Line (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Looks marvelous--the animation really is superb--but it's not even up to the standard of the initial installment in any other significant respect.
One of those films one has to admire for what it's attempting, even if it doesn't quite succeed in achieving it.
movie_title: The Boy in the Striped Pajamas (The Boy in the Striped Pyjamas) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A very mild haunted house opus whose low-budget special effects prove more risible than scary.
'Klaatu barada crappo'...turns an intelligent and thoughtful film into what might be called a boys' adventure yarn if that weren't an insult to both boys and yarn.
movie_title: The Day the Earth Stood Still (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Paints a frequently affecting snapshot of a rudderless young woman in difficult straits, [though] its homespun approach never achieves a transcendent effect.
Avoiding the conventions of gangster movies, it presents a slice of the ghastly reality of life in the crime-infested areas of Naples that has remarkably authenticity and immediacy.
A powerful tale, but one that's done in so old-fashioned, heavy-handed a fashion that it already seems dated.
Grapples with important themes and is expertly made, but is simply too odd and off-putting to be anything more than an almost grotesque curiosity.
A long, obvious slog into marital melodrama.
Shouldn't have been brought to term.
You leave this chick flick disaster feeling like an escapee from a POW camp.
A sanitized treatment that embraces every cliche of musical biography without shedding much real light on its subject.
There's Hollywood and Bollywood, but Chandni Chowk to China respresents something new--Follywood.
Cute and rambunctious and not a little old-fashioned--it's like an old Disney live-action comedy from the 1960s, but with better effects.
Just drab and disposable rather than offensive, a throwback that's more of a throwaway.
Just one long pratfall...an avalanche of really dumb action comedy that aims to be a variant on the Inspector Clouseau formula but fails miserably.
Surely they mean Outlandish...ready-made for a late-night slot on the Sci-Fi channel.
A visually overstuffed but emotionally undernourished piece of whimsy...yet another big, overblown fantasy movie that never takes flight.
Every bit as inane and tedious as its predecessors.
movie_title: Underworld: The Rise of the Lycans (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Frozen Capracorn [that] will leave you cold...Minnesotans might legitimately want to sue for defamation.
Avoiding histrionics and overstatement, Un Secret reveals a story about a family's past suffering that may not be unique, but in this telling is quietly powerful.
Amiable but slight.
It's like watching paint dry--which isn't very exciting, however pretty the colors.
A bleak, bitter, brilliant portrayal of the failure of the fifties version of the American dream it so beautifully captures in period terms.
A sad spectacle...nothing more than a series of labored sketches in which Carrey flails about trying to recapture the zaniness of his early years.
A nice-looking, respectable but oddly unsatisfying family fable.
Thanks to both Aronofsky and Rourke it proves an honest and moving portrait of a man in the twilight of a career that's both made and destroyed him.
An incredibly sappy and manipulative dirge disguised as a deep rumination on sacrifice and redemption.
With Clint in the driver's seat, what might have been an old clunker comes very close to being a classic.
Intelligent and impeccably crafted but...also rather remote and chilly, the kind of film in which craft trumps heart...ultimately fails to do emotional justice to the subject it tackles.
Its piecemeal character, lack of shading and lugubrious pace leave it not just incomplete but, despite the length, surprisingly shallow.
Fitzgerald Gumpified...a gorgeously-made would-be tearjerker that leaves the ducts dry because of its extreme artificiality, in both plot and execution.
movie_title: The Curious Case of Benjamin Button (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The ultimate geek movie...Frank Miller's take on Will Eisner's semi-spectral crime-fighter comes DOA and never springs back to life.
A thoroughly respectable historical re-enactment, though lacking the epic scope and dramatic urgency that would make it a truly memorable one.
A slight and implausible romance that nonetheless has moments of charm, thanks to its stars. Unfortunately, that's not quite enough.
As family fare goes...distinctly middle-grade. It won't put you to sleep, but it's not likely to enchant you either.
Extraordinarily vivid and truthful...[an] incredibly honest and revealing film about public education in the age of multiculturalism and globalization.
A hypnotic dance with death that delivers an emotional wallop and a potent anti-war message.
An obnoxiously cute and mawkish man-and-his-mutt story...[with] one of the longest animal death watches in cinematic history.
Has the precision and reticence of a good novella or short story...[and] an outstanding lead performance from Kristin Scott Thomas.
Quote not available.
There's less than meets the eye to Joachim Trier's Reprise, but the loose, limber visual style gives the picture a certain panache.
A journey that prizes intellectual search over simplistic solutions, and if you come to it with a similar attitude you should enjoy ambling along.
Another raunch-fest from the Apatow sausage factory...a movie made by yahoos for yahoos.
A tepid, silly thriller that would barely pass muster as basic cable fare...'Gone' should never have arrived.
Jovial, colorful and engaging family entertainment.
Obviously aimed at the 'Superbad' crowd, but it's really just super bad in every sense.
A story of reluctant heroism that's remarkable for its nuance, complexity and power.
A near-miss that doesn't quite work either intellectually or emotionally.
Cliche-ridden...as a film rather than an encomium, it leaves much to be desired.
An independent ensemble drama that's as conventional as any studio product...promises to be different but is, sadly, extremely familiar.
For all the visual pizzazz and gee-whiz athleticism, it's a bloated bore.
Anyone interested in an early visit to Purgatory is directed to this excruciatingly unfunny, frequently repulsive movie.
movie_title: Tim and Eric's Billion Dollar Movie (2012)

movie_review_blurb: A bland but likable romantic comedy that gets by mostly on the charm of its leads...but Scott's performance reminds us of how much sharper the film could have been.
While not descending to the level of Murphy's worst work--'Pluto Nash' still stands unchallenged--it's a bland, negligible example of the 'becoming a better person through magic' scenario.
Feels like a ten-minute sketch drawn out to an hour and a half...not clever enough to sustain its premise over the long haul.
Dusts off the tired cliches of the past and tries to give them new life, with only partial success.
Ultimately the single-shot gimmick and spuriously significant concluding twist can't disguise that it's a pretty tired piece of work.
A grim, ugly movie that takes its ridiculous premise much too seriously and doesn't showcase effects good enough to make up for all its shortcomings.
Inspirational sports stories are hardly cinema rarities, but this documentary...is a good example of the genre, made better by the fact that it's true rather than ramped-up fiction.
Visually sumptuous, gentle--and some would say lackadaisical--film that's quietly likable but so understated that it borders on the boring.
Despite some cliches, it's a mostly gripping survival story, expertly shot and anchored by Neeson's powerful performance.
Things get so bad at points during 'Man on a Ledge' that you might be inclined to join the more nasty elements among the sidewalk onlookers and shout 'Jump already!'
A muddled, tonally clumsy adaptation of the first of Janet Evanovich's Stephanie Plum books.
Fiennes' film represents an honorable, and mostly successful, attempt to translate Shakespeare to the screen.
A quietly lacerating portrait of familial discord that morphs into a wider portrait of society and law...While the setting might be foreign, its concerns are universal.
A bargain-basement 'X-Men' with a heavy dose of teen angst told in the all-too-familiar 'found footage' style. [The] final reel...comes across like bad outtakes from 'Superman II.'
A satisfyingly old-fashioned haunted-house thriller, less about shocks and violence than atmosphere and dread.
Manipulative in the extreme but surprisingly enjoyable nonetheless...It's a minor miracle that 'Big Miracle' is as pleasant as it is.
A gloomy, turgid bore...Radcliffe should have brought along Harry's wand and wished [it] away--or at least off his resume.
Wenders and the Tanztheater company have combined to offer a masterful tribute to Bausch's unique vision, one that's enhanced by 3D.
Perhaps adequate as a surrogate babysitter for parents of pre-teen boys who need a ninety-minute rest from the kids' constant badgering, but is otherwise less engaging than its predecessor.
Wants to be smart, edgy and exciting. Instead it's dumb, ugly and, despite all the mayhem, curiously dull.
Though it's based...on a true story, 'The Vow' comes across as a totally synthetic tearjerker in the Nicholas Sparks mode.
A romcom about stalking is a hard sell under any circumstances, needing a lot more wit than the juvenile jokes of this script.
An amusingly twisty trifle bolstered by a first-rate cast.
A 'Twilight Zone'-ish tale about fate told in the twee New Agey style of the modified mumblecore movement...mildly amusing, but...doesn't really earn its would-be revelatory punch-line.
A perfectly agreeable exercise in musical nostalgia...undermined by clumsiness of execution.
For its first half this movie does a reasonably clever job of reinvention, though the crudeness level is excessive; but the second half jumps the rails.
'Death Wish' goes the corporate route in this silly action-thriller that's nonetheless leagues beyond Nicolas Cage's usual fare.
An emotionally powerful snapshot of the problem that should serve as a valuable catalyst to public discussion.

While one can applaud the desire to offer something less heavy-handed and preachy than the overtly Christian movies that have found their way to theatres in recent years, 'Blue' is too mild and muddled to carry off what it aims for.
Arch and precious but also pleasantly quirky and oddly charming.
Another heaping helping of middlebrow mush from Nicholas Sparks, the modern-day version of Fannie Hurst.
Better than a lot of Hollywood's rom-coms, but the overstuffed plot and uncertain direction defeat the best efforts of its ingratiating cast.
Droll, delightful...[and] jovial enough to redeem the whole pirate genre, which one might have thought had been tarnished irredeemably by the last two dreadful 'Caribbean' movies.
Linklater brings a shambling, easygoing charm to this unlikely comedy based on a real-life Texas murder case...and Jack Black, of all people, drolly essays the title character.
A dumb and cheesy period potboiler...Quoth this critic: It's a bore.
Crude, disjointed, overextended and only sporadically funny.
Quote not available.
A quietly affecting character study...remarkable for its subtlety, charm, poignancy, and generosity of spirit.
A stately, high-minded historical docudrama that's long--very long--on hagiography but extremely short on energy.
There's obviously a market for mindless action movies, but even by Statham standards--which are exceedingly low--'Safe' is an underachiever.
An overextended treatment of a pretty threadbare premise, told with a sense of self-importance the story doesn't warrant.
A movie that can communicate the excitement a lover of the comic book will experience watching it even to those who have never read a single issue.
Not particularly good...but some may find it acceptable as an impoverished Los Angeles-set analogue to 'Sex and the City.'
By thrusting the story about women who pass themselves off as men in nineteenth-century England into close-up, this film version accentuates its implausibility to fatal effect.
The picture captures the crude, raucous locker-rrom spirit of 'Slap Shot' with surprising jollity, and it's peopled with amusing characters, all played with relish.
Seems recycled to begin with but grows increasingly tired and repetitive as the narrative drones on.
Does the obvious well enough, but except for Lawrence's stirring turn never goes beyond that...[has] dedication and taste, if not much imagination.
An action extravaganza in a high-rise that makes 'Die Hard' look like a walk in the park.
The impact of the gorgeous images can't compensate for the fact that in dramatic terms 'Sea' comes across as stilted and affected.
To many viewers the picture might seem as forbidding as a dense scholarly tome. But give it a chance, and you might find it as pleasurable as a good novella.
This is no doubt a message movie, but it delivers its message in an unforced, quirky way that leaves you feeling as though you've been pleasurably cajoled rather than harangued.
Uneven but intermittently powerful...might itself have benefited from a bit of detachment and restraint.
Clunky, muddled mishmash of Greek mythology, which is most notable for loudness, splashy but unimpressive effects and the sight of some decent actors slumming it up.
A rather muddled modernized fantasy that never manages to find a coherent style
Treats a molehill of an idea as though it were a mountain of fright.
Tries too hard and ends up substituting pretension for punch.
A lazy piece of work...that expends little energy giving the characters any heart, content instead to offer a succession of cheesy sex gags.
Jean-Pierre and Luc Dardenne offer another in their remarkable succession of contemporary neo-realist dramas in this quietly devastating but gently hopeful [film].

As a tribute to the art of preparing traditional Japanese cuisine it could hardly be bettered. But it's arguably even more fascinating as a portrait of one man's single-minded devotion to his craft and its effect on the next generation.
A misguided homage that mistakes clutter for comedy.
As a take-off on genre convention it's amusing, even if as a horror movie it proves rather mild.
A grossly manipulative sports movie that tries to plant Capracorn in a 'Field of Dreams.'
A feel-good bit of fluff for the senior set....A pity it never takes any chances or goes beyond the obvious.
No better or worse than the previous entries in the franchise, which have been uniformly awful. It does, however, possess the virtue of brevity.
For what it aims to be, 'Haywire' is certainly a success. A pity it doesn't aim to be much more than a brisk, mindless action flick with a butt-kicking heroine.
