An enjoyable enough romp, if no template-breaker like 'Rango.'
This 'Rum' lacks the punch it should have had...runs out of steam as it proceeds, fading like a drunk on his last legs.
A riff on the 'Logan's Run' formula that rushes around in circles before collapsing in an exhausted heap...starts intriguingly, but it gets silly fast, and grows tiresome before long.

A subtle, sporadically powerful portrait of a young woman in turmoil. But unfortunately its fractured, elliptical form--while defensible from a stylistic perspective--ultimately undermines its effectiveness as drama.
A film that still packs an emotional wallop, and is a significant historical document as well.

Like a 1950s horror movie done up in the style of Douglas Sirk...isn't uninteresting as an exercise in Almodovarian style and themes, but its farfetched narrative makes it a minor contribution to his canon.
Yet another reality-based tale of a lone crusader who takes on past injustice, but a fairly good example of this overused genre.
While [it] never reaches comedic heights, the cast offers enough incidental pleasures along the way to make it an amiable, if inconsequential, ride.
Goes through all the expected motions, but without much energy, and the tastelessness comes across as mere calculation.
A dreary, pointless, stylistically blowsy film...rendered all but unintelligible by Montiel's messy technique and chaotic narrative choices.
[A] keenly observed, deeply felt portrait of a roller-coaster romance.
A lovely, quietly affecting film that's as much a feast for the ear as for the eye, while not ignoring the brain.
Consistently interesting as intellectual fodder but so intent on not becoming sensationalistic that it's rarely emotionally compelling.
A genre potboiler so absurd in its premises and convolutions that it winds up being unintentionally funny.
A film that might have an afterschool special feel, but compensates for it somewhat with mood and intensity.
As pure drama, without reference to the wider moral issues it skirts, it's compelling structured and played by an expert ensemble working at the top of their game.
Pushes up against the law of diminishing returns. The 'Paranormal Activity' series is basically a one-trick pony that's played its sleight-of-hand once too often.
A pretty long slog...while it clearly comes from the heart, it doesn't touch it very deeply.

An old-fashioned potboiler made up of cinematic spare parts [that] work[s] in a crass, manipulative way. But...anybody without a bleeding heart will probably be giggling rather than cheering by the final fade-out.
Doesn't capture the whole of Greeneland, but at least portrays one aspect of it reasonably well.
If, by the time characters resort to nail guns and gasoline cans to confront the villains, you're not laughing uncontrollably...you might be charged with having no sense of humor.
While likable enough, the movie proves a curiously pallid, choppy mixture of farce and sentiment that doesn't take full advantage of what the stars have to offer.
A third-rate knockoff, lacking either the Cold War paranoia of the first film or the grim post-Vietnam and Watergate mentality of Carpenter's visually blistering remake.
A formally conventional but provocative, and perhaps even important, piece of non-fiction pleading, worthy of being on a double bill with another bit of Texana, Errol Morris' 'The Thin Blue Line.'
One needn't be a student of the history or literature of the period to appreciate this excellent portrait of a fascinating and important figure.
movie_title: Sholem Aleichem: Laughing in the Darkness (2011)

movie_review_blurb: While you might appreciate its goal, the writing and execution aren't strong enough to reach it.
A visual feast that nonetheless seems emotionally parched...despite the gorgeous toppings ladled onto it, 'Toast' remains too dry and brittle a meal to be fully satisfying.

An almost risibly old-fashioned crowd-pleaser...weirdly constrained by Brewer's determination to ape the original so earnestly...so clean-cut and wholesome that the MTV imprimatur attached to it seems like a joke.
A sleepy retread of a tired formula that even Atkinson's skill at slapstick tomfoolery can't salvage.
Just uses a spooky atmosphere and fractured style to disguise the fact that it's actually covering quite familiar territory.
An engrossing, quietly unnerving film that's one of the year's best...with an astonishing performance by Michael Shannon.
A splashy but silly and bombastic (as well as curiously dull) farrago more reminiscent of 'Pirates of the Caribbean' than Dumas.
One Adam Sandler is bad enough, but 'Jack and Jill' proves how much worse it can be when there are two...goes from conventionally terrible to surrealistically awful.

A wanton melange of skewed Greek history and fractured mythology...the action movie equivalent of one of those spectacular Broadway musicals where you come out humming the sets because the music is so banal.
The source material is hopeless, that's all there is to it; and the instruments at the director's disposal--from the cast down through the crew--are thoroughly mediocre.
In its mixture of wit, warmth, poignancy and perceptiveness, it's a worthy addition to Payne's remarkable string of winners.
Despite the degree of control Ramsay exercises, what's likely to stick with you...is the portrait Miller draws of unfathomable malice and Swinton of tortured incomprehension.
movie_title: We Need to Talk About Kevin (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Enjoyable enough on the surface, but it's essentially meretricious--so much, in fact, that you'll be a bit ashamed at having had a fairly good time watching it.
Justifies its existence by improving on Niels Arden Oplev's serviceable but unspectacular Swedish predecessor, though it can't overcome the flaws of the original book.
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2011)

movie_review_blurb: It's a visual marvel and, like the Energizer Bunny, never stops going, but in the end proves more exhausting than exhilarating.
Nothing more than an old-fashioned, family-friendly tearjerker that's good-natured but not very successful at strumming the heartstrings, which is what it obviously wants to do.
Essentially a stunt, but an expertly executed one that's immensely enjoyable, especially for movie buffs...a nimble, exuberant lark.
Aching to be magical, the picture instead comes off as a 'Wonderful World of Disney' retread on steroids...what might have been heart-on-sleeve becomes bleeding heart instead.

A small-scaled, thoroughly predictable 'War of the Worlds' clone devoid of interest except for its Moscow setting, a few neat visual touches and brevity...this year's lump of cinematic Christmas coal.
A dour, depressing character study that doesn't so much develop and expand as simply repeat the same points over and over again, to diminishing effect.
Confuses profundity with bathos, narrative elegance with literary archness and emotional power with sentimental handwringing.
Overcomes its flaws to emerge as a sporadically revealing portrait of a young girl's struggle to find herself in a cruelly hostile environment--a promising debut for Rees and a triumph for Oduye.
A tired riff on an old formula that loses steam even before its atrocious ending.
One of the drearier, more unpleasant pictures to appear in quite some time...you'll feel as trapped watching it as the characters are in the story.
When it finally culminates after two hours with a prefabricated stem-winding finale, you may feel like shouting 'Hallelujah!'--but not for the reasons Graff intended.
A dull, inert action movie...a shipment it's easy to label return to sender.
A big-boned, bombastic summer-style action movie served up as a Christmas treat for fans suffering winter withdrawal pangs for such fare.
The Tuskegee Airmen are true national heroes, and it's unfortunate that 'Red Tails' should prove such a hokey collection of war movie cliches.
The inexplicably popular live action/animated series featuring a bevy of screechy-voiced singing rodents reaches its third--and one fervently hopes, final--installment.

Mirrors its title in being--like all of Cronenberg's work--superbly methodical, but also captures the dangerous undercurrents implicit in the understanding of man that Freud and Jung were instrumental in creating.
What we have here is a case of very flat 'Feet.'
Bright, witty and delightfully off-kilter, it's a very Aardman Christmas story that even a Scrooge should enjoy.
Especially for film buffs, it's an entertaining filling-out of an intriguing footnote of cinema history.
Scorsese's mastery of the medium is evident in every frame of his beguiling adaptation of Brian Selznick's children's book, which is also the director's love letter to the art of cinema itself.
A jovial tribute to the spirit of the old television series that's witty without being cynical and warm without going gooey.
All the lovely packaging can't disguise the fact that the movie has far more pretension than profundity.
So long as one doesn't take it as a history lesson,...a moderately enjoyable period piece...an exercise in quasi-biography that's engaging in an old-fashioned way.
If a bracing brew of criminal connivance and exquisite bloodletting is to your liking, Takeshi certainly provides it.
The combination of cheap humor and sappy sentiment is all too pat, and...the characters are so cardboard that to call them stock sitcom types would be an insult to situation comedy.
Though formally conventional, it carries a powerful message about the reality of life in the inner city and the struggles of thise who live there to break the cycle of violence.
A depressing cascade of gross-out humor, slapstick violence, hipster fast-talk and drug gags, to which are added a predictable streak of sentiment and a dollop of cheap enlightenment.
A viscerally compelling portrait of addiction, but in the end it seems more an intellectual and artistic exercise than a fully-rounded drama.

Shows little sign of the deep emotional undercurrents one might expect in a son's treatment of his father, but it does present a clear, incisive yet tantalizingly incomplete portrait of a fascinating and complicated man.
movie_title: The Man Nobody Knew: In Search of My Father, CIA Spymaster William Colby (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A superb adaptation of a brilliant book, made with...fidelity, care and intelligence.
A bracing comedy-drama that's a sharp gender-bending dissection of the Peter Pan syndrome.
An improvement on its 2009 predecessor...Hardly your father's Sherlock Holmes, but...an acceptable action movie in the modern mode.
movie_title: Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Though a bit choppy, it emerges as a thoughtful, compelling piece about guilt, redemption--and the difficulty of coming to terms with the moral complexity in human affairs.

The story of two marathon runners... who play musical chairs with military uniforms in stumbling their way from China to Omaha Beach over the course of WWII... might well have been titled 'Chariots of Cliches.'
In the end the delicate oddity that enlivens the earlier portion of the picture evaporates in an orgy of big-budget mayhem.
Despite its ebullience, technical polish and desire to please, the picture comes across as overly derivative and hits a surprising number of sour notes.
Broad and simplistic...the sort of earnest but pandering pabulum that might do more harm than good.
A fine cast is wasted in this feeble dramedy about neighborly infidelity in suburbia.
At once an unsettling documentary and an enlightening one.
A droll, delightfully macabre little gem...a boy-and-his-dead-dog fable that's an irresistible mixture of sentiment and spookiness.
An empty, exhausting exercise, a pumped-up adrenaline rush that despite all the running around, goes nowhere.
Its impact is sporadic and spotty...at times it's mesmerizing, at others simply tedious.
An exceptional inspirational sports movie, precisely because the stakes were so high.
No better than most of the genre stuff that studios regularly shovel into theatres nowadays, and in some ways worse.
Doesn't amount to much, but like tasty junk food it goes down easily, even if the nutrition is nil.
A garish, overwrought, sweaty, muddled mess. But at least it's not boring.
Earnestness combines with pedestrian technique in Martin Papazian's well-meaning but clumsy film.
[Vreeland's] influence on twentieth-century culture was large, and it's celebrated here with affection, dedication and skill--but very little critical detachment.
movie_title: Diana Vreeland: The Eye Has To Travel (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Visually drab despite the locales and emotionally parched despite the source, this isn't so much the heights as the cinematic depths.
An exciting, fact-based action thriller that adds some real human dimension and satirical jabs to the mix.
Faintly absurd, but done up with such confidence that you're willing to go along for the ride.
Ought to have been an agreeable place to spend an hour-and-a-half. Instead after ninety minutes you'll find yourself wishing you'd checked out early.
If [it] doesn't explore any new territory, it covers familiar ground engagingly, and sometimes touchingly.
movie_title: The Perks of Being a Wallflower (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Positively reeks of mediocrity.... Go read a good book instead.
Mostly delicious...a whimsical but bittersweet love letter to the lost Iran of Satrapi's youth.
The worst of the worst, but serious connoisseurs of le bad cinema shouldn't pass it up.
A perfunctory chase movie that drops in its tracks long before it reaches what's supposed to pass for a rousing climax.
A pretty flimsy piece, but a likable cast and a laid-back attitude make it moderately agreeable.
Will probably appeal mostly to fans of strange animation like the Quay brothers' efforts, not to regular family audiences.
A remarkable film...spare and acutely observed.
Basically a high-toned soap opera, the lick but shallow movie is entertaining enough on a lowbrow level.
Unconscionably boring. The real act of theft here is of the ninety minutes the picture steals from your life.
Obviously a masterly piece of filmmaking....Even a flawed Anderson film is more interesting than most directors' unequivocal triumphs.
'Adam-12' on steroids....Much of Ayer's picture has the feel of reality, but the last twenty minutes move into empty spectacle and heart-on-sleeve mawkishness.
Anybody who's debating whether to attend his high-school union will certainly be dissuaded from doing so by watching a few minutes of this dismal dramedy.
One expects a sports movie to have plenty of cliches, but 'Trouble With the Curve' is so loaded with them...that by the end it collapses under the weight.
Ultimately it's just an old-fashioned shocker--'Psycho' crossed with 'Jane Eyre,' and reworked for the teeny-bopper crowd. But it lives up to neither of its exalted models.
movie_title: House at the End of the Street (2012)

movie_review_blurb: While Dredd fares better here than in Stallone's Hollywoodized version, the picture fails to convince that this Robocop retread deserves screen treatment at all.
An ugly, imbecilic buddy-cop action picture that makes little sense and offers few thrills.
A gay relationship story told with subtlety and a sense of insight that comes from personal experience.
Splashy but ultimately an empty bauble...By the halfway point you'll likely be more exhausted than exhilarated.
Except for diehard fans it will prove a pretty tepid Halloween trick.
While one respects the film for trying to juggle disparate tones, it never manages to find the proper balance.
A love letter to the great director that turns his effort to make 'Psycho' into...a David-and-Goliath story in which David is a creative giant himself.
Can be heavy-handed at times, but it's still moodily effective.
There's nary a hint of sparkle or fizz in [this] sour comedy of manners.
The unhappy truth [is] that this return visit to Middle Earth is a bloated letdown.
What might have been a typical exercise in socially conscious messaging [becomes] a...touching human drama.
Has the look and feel of an extended sitcom, and a mediocre one at that.
Only fitfully amusing and overall rather irritatingly self-absorbed...doesn't represent much of an advance in Apatow's fundamentally adolescent attitudes.
It's eye-catching without ultimately amounting to much more than a pleasant but innocuous diversion.
Very dumb and surprisingly lethargic...a clumsy collection of genre cliches.
There are powerful moments here, but their impact is undermined by a lack of subtlety in the storytelling.
movie_title: De rouille et d'os (Rust and Bone) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Both insightful and poignant, but not mawkish...an intriguing character study set against the backdrop of a dark time in history.
A film so honest in dealing with end-of-life issues that its purity is a positive rebuke to all the maudlin movies on the subject.
An inspiring tale of familial strength under pressure and perseverance against all odds...It's practically impossible to resist the pull of this film.
A blend of gritty realism sand magical fantasy that's undoubtedly calculated but still deeply satisfying.
Hardly an instant classic, being too busy and derivative by half. But portions of it possess a lovely, ethereal charm, and visually it's very impressive.
A stylish but silly horror picture that...doesn't appreciably alter the formula that William Peter Blatty and William Friedkin established nearly four decades ago.
Ends up feeling like something to be admired more for its ambition than its accomplishment.
Visually stunning but emotionally vapid...a one-trick pony that reduces the tragic dimension of its source to an ornate soap operatic bauble.
Watching it feels like eating a whole bowl of fortune cookies. all bearing the same message. You wind up feeling overstuffed and undernourished.
Obviously striving for a John Hughes vibe, but its obtuse makers have confused grossness with geniality, and weirdness for wit.
Typically kind-hearted but mawkish tale...formulaically inspiring fare.
A thought-provoking, compelling documentary that encourages you to look at our national drug policy in a broader context.
A sharply written, skillfully executed adult crowd-pleaser [that]avoids mawkishness and actually manages to inspire and amuse.
A small scaled modern retelling of 'Days of Wine and Roses' [that] has a sense of authenticity and carries considerable dramatic power.
A mostly gripping character study of a man who's half hero and half villain [that] gives you the opportunity to enjoy watching Washington again at the top of his game.

A witty, imaginative romp that should please some viewers with its nostalgic references to the pastimes they affectionately remember and everybody else with its explosion of sheer exuberance and warmth.
One of the best Bond pictures ever...a satisfying blend of the old and the new.
Despite its flaws, the fine ensemble work and wealth of exquisitely played moments...make for a cinematic concert with more ups than downs.
There's a real touch of magic in both Sorrentino's film and the stately, poised performance by Penn that anchors it.
An exercise in overindulgence.
Succeeds beyond what one had any right to hope in avoiding simple hagiography, capturing Lincoln's human frailty as well as his wily political side.
Easily the best of the franchise's five episodes but still none too good.
movie_title: The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn Part 2 (2012)

movie_review_blurb: A period costume romance...joined to an intelligent history lesson.
Straight-up action fare that never asks any questions beyond where the next round of ammunition is coming from, based on a premise even sillier today than it was a quarter-century ago.
Despite the gaps in logic the movie...is cannily put together and easily holds your attention.
Though the nimble cast works hard to make it as agreeable as it can be...the movie never transcends the basic formula.
Beautifully mounted, but generally so deliberate and moody that the excitement one expects rarely surfaces...except for Pearce, it doesn't deliver the kick one might like.
An over-the-big-top picture that will probably please toddlers and franchise fans but suggests that the series has pretty much run its course.
Its very simplicity of utterance gives it a purity that makes other films that try to express similar sentiments feel forced and obvious.
Good-natured, eager to please and harmless, but also contrived, trite and bland.
It's certainly possible to enjoy the movie's canny crowd-pleasing (or pandering) calculation; but even before it's over, you'll know you've been had.
A splashy but slapdash nostalgia trip that, while offering a few good moments, is mostly underthought and overdone.
If safety isn't guaranteed by the film's title, a viewer's satisfaction with this genial, warm-hearted movie pretty much can be.
A coolly elegant, tauntly intense contribution to the 'Alien' universe...beautifully crafted and visually striking.

Unremmittingly raunchy, crude, groan-inducing so-called comedy...which tries to wring laughs from child abuse at the start and from incest at the close...The only thing that could conceivably have made [it] worse is if Sandler had played both roles.
As artificial as a Hollywood rom.com... With a different cast, a bigger budget, and some punched-up dialogue, it might have been made by Judd Apatow.

The technical wizardry on display goes far to save a story that has its heart in the right place but...[is] essentially a boys' adventure story with a female hero, and mother-daughter bomding replacing the more usual father-son one.
Starts out edgy and dark but turns progressively softer, ending up as a sappy reaffirmation that love conquers all...deteriorates into schmaltz by the close.
movie_title: Seeking a Friend for the End of the World (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Expect no intelligence or subtlety here, but if you're willing to put up with the sheer ridiculousness of it all, you might enjoy wallowing in Bekmambetov's shameless exhibition of narrative lunacy and technical fireworks.
The dramatic cop-out, like the incomplete finish of a strip-tease, is a little disappointing...But the movie has its compensations.
Just a series of four disappointingly slight one-joke featurettes.
An arresting film but ultimately an unsatisfying one, creating an effectively menacing mood but not delivering much dramatic punch, especially in a disappointing final twist.
Witless, technically slipshod, and neither remotely scary nor titillating, it pretty much fails on all levels.
The intentions are admirable but the result disappointing.
Might look better through a haze of the right kind of smoke. But unassisted it's just too sloppy and puerile to be more than sporadically funny.
A shaggy-dog tale that, despite a talented cast, is a cinematic mutt.
Earnest but forced, [it] has its heart in the right place, but is conspicuously short on brain power.
While effectively moody...proves overlong for optimal shock value, with entirely too many dull stretches along the way.
Pretty funny, but nowhere near as outrageous as it purports to be.
Don't expect much...You might think it was Garry Marshall's latest holiday-themed multi-subplot stinker.
movie_title: What to Expect When You're Expecting (2012)

movie_review_blurb: An unholy mash-up of 'Pearl Harbor' and 'Transformers'...if Berg doesn't match [Bay] in bombast and stupidity, it's not for lack of trying.
While Binoche is almost always worth watching, this is one of the exceptions to that rule.
In terms of laughs 'Mansome' is thinner than the hair on a bald man's scalp.
While 'Crooked Arrows' certainly isn't a good film by any objective standard, it has a good heart, and proves far more tolerable than many blockbuster sports movies.
Doesn't amount to much with Josh Brolin, but it would be a lot less fun without him.

Grindhouse garbage that feeds off an authentic human tragedy...both tasteless and incredibly dull...the only 'gotcha' that works is the one that might lure unsuspecting viewers into wasting ten bucks to see it.
A gossamer fable of adolescent romance, played out with the cheekily whimsical, visually delicious style for which Anderson is famous.
While it has some amusing moments, the picture never really takes off.
There's a hagiographic tone to the film, which...strains for epic sweep but gives itself over to historical oversimplification and pious melodramatics.
Gloomy and lugubrious...another expensive dud.
Has a few genuinely funny moments, but on the whole it's repetitive and stale.
The rare picture that handles soap-operatic material in a subtle and perceptive way.
Comes across as forced and manipulative.
While the Big Moments might disappoint, the more intimate ones...are surprisingly strong, thanks to Garfield's deft performance. He makes the movie worth watching.
Sappy and corny...a sluggish fairy-tale, more silly than magical.
movie_title: The Odd Life of Timothy Green (2012)

movie_review_blurb: The title could be taken as indicative of the film's chances of scoring outside of Solonfz's small cadre of followers, but 'Dark Horse' indicates that a grain of empathy has made its way into his usual desert of despair.
A movie that isn't terrible, but--apart from the goat fixation and Duchovny's zonked-out turn--doesn't offer much that hasn't been done elsewhere, and often better.
It's easier to respect this attempt to toy with the cliches of romantic comedy than it is to enjoy the result.
As beautifully crafted as any Pixar or Aardman picture and as funny and emotionally satisfying as the best of them...another Laika triumph.
May be somewhat slight in purely narrative terms, but it has a generous and humane spirit and draws real emotional impact from a most unlikely friendship.
A fascinating glimpse into the mind of a cunning con-man...and it's just as cunning as he was in constructing the story to hold our interest.
Basically a musical sudser that would have seemed hokey even in the 1940s. But the music is often exhilarating.
While it offers more goosebumps than gasps, it's a pleasurable reminder of the sort of discreet supernatural thriller that was once a staple but is now, unhappily, a rarity.
Doesn't crash and burn, but it doesn't exactly sail across the finish line a winner, either.
An uneasy combination of good and bad, which earns a mild recommendation on the strength of the two lead performances and its success in capturing the desperate milieu of Caracas' teeming underclass.
An innocuous boys' wish-fulfillment fantasy...that would be more at home on a family-friendly cable channel....But boys of a certain age--and their sports-minded dads--probably won't mind.
Not so much a movie as an exercise in cinematic adrenaline, but so long as it sticks to the pavement and avoids trying to humanize its clockwork characters, [it's] dumb fun.
The French, they are a funny race, oui? Well, on the evidence of Julie Delpy's sequel to her 2007 film '2 Days in Paris,' the answer is definitely non.
A ghastly 'Paranormal Activity'-inspired ghost story with Lovecraftian overtones...[and] the worst ending since 'The Devil Inside.'
Will come as a major disappointment for those who enjoyed the earlier trilogy, a mostly plodding chase movie that revs up too infrequently and then not always excitingly.
Though hardly a crowd-pleaser. it's the sort of challenging, thought-provoking, stylistically striking piece of auteurism one rarely encounters nowadays.
A portrait of the American Dream gone sour so absurdly engaging that you might be ashamed of enjoying it so much.
If even these stars can't elevate what's really second-rate material, they can at least make it easy to take.
Part cinematic tone poem, part portrait of society's marginalized, part painful domestic drama and part Southern-fried hokum.
Nothing but a nihilistic potboiler, but Oliver Stone serves up 'Savages' with the pulpy verve it needs to be a guilty pleasure.
Offers little that isn't familiar....The real glacial era went on for a very long time, but the 'Ice Age' franchise really needn't try to match its longevity. Enough already.
'Heart of Gold' was a great concert film, and 'Journeys' doesn't match it. BHut on its own it's a highly enjoyable ninety minutes of music and droll talk.

Alternately lugubrious and frantic, crammed with incidental characters, plot threads and expository flashbacks that try to explain a numbingly complicated but ultimately silly story, [it]feels every bit of its 164-minute running-time, and then some.
Several steps below the original--which was no great shakes to begin with.

In the aftermath of the Trayvon Martin shooting in Florida, the studio altered the title of this brainless comedy from 'Neighborhood Watch.' They should have kept the name and changed everything else instead.
As drama it offers a fascinating portrait of the Ancien Regime decaying in the face of new 'Enlightened' thinking.
Search out this fine, fascinating, warmhearted documentary.
The rare rom.com that's not just smart and funny but takes risks as well.
Intriguing, if you can take the gore and nastiness that earned it the NC-17 rating...[and] there are compensations, not least McConaughey's mesmerizing performance.
'Dog Days'...unfortunately proves an apt subtitle...maintains the relatively low standards of the earlier [films] without trying to raise them.
movie_title: Diary of a Wimpy Kid: Dog Days (2012)

movie_review_blurb: While an adequate futuristic chase movie...it has no particular distinction. The most notable thing about this take on remembering is how forgettable it is.
Structurally ragged but engrossing documentary [about] a courageous provocateur with a gift for cleverly ridiculing a dangerous regime.
An intriguing addition to the work of an erratic but always interesting filmmaker.
A rude, often crude live-action cartoon...more clown show than stinging satire. Still, in this case the clowns are funny more often than not.
It's too serious for its own good, treating the political-potboiler material as though it were deep and revelatory.

Even a performance as formidable as Streep's can't overcome the unhappy fact that 'The Iron Lady' is a sadly superficial treatment of the life and times of one of the late twentieth century's most influential, and controversial, political figures.
A zero...wants to be sweet and cheeky but comes off sour and tasteless instead. There's a difference between raunchy and tawdry.
Lost in the script's devotion to the romantic comedy conventions is the opportunity to say something pointed about Big Pharma.
Brassy, bombastic and cheerfully vulgar...like a Las Vegas casino show on steroids--a piece of glitzy trash that presumably aims to be campy fun but fails miserably to achieve even that low ambition.
A fascinating investigation of a sad and sorry personal and political scandal, and while it doesn't prove its allegations of conspiracy, it makes a persuasive circumstantial case.
movie_title: Client 9: The Rise and Fall of Eliot Spitzer (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Really nothing more than a high-toned horror film, but an exceptionally effective one that may not equal Cronenberg, but has a great deal that's Cronenbergian in it.
A reasonably effective presentation of the director's feminist view of a fascinating medieval figure, though one that's very deliberate in pacing and visually quite severe.
movie_title: Vision: From the Life of Hildegard von Bingen (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A darkly comic caper movie that's also a frenzied gay romance...not perfect, to be sure, but distinctive.
Tries to turn an inherently melodramatic tale into a serious study of middle-class grief, but doesn't succeed despite the acting talent on hand.
Visually opulent, but episodic and, despite all the action, oddly tame and lethargic.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Voyage of the Dawn Treader (2010)

movie_review_blurb: This plush, evocative slice of British royal history is also an irresistible portrait of an unlikely friendship and a rousing tale of triumph over adversity.
Turns out to be almost as blandly formulaic as its title.
An idiosyncratic but oddly pedestrian take on one of the Bard's more elusive yet entrancing works.
Pure sitcom fluff, a silly story about a romantic triangle [in which] wit, charm, style and comic timing are all absent.
Just another lame, lazy retooling of an old TV title.
There's plenty of unintelligible talk about ultra-complicated algorithms in 'Legacy.' But all you have to know about it is a simple equation: "Tron x 2=Bomb Squared."
A would-be sophisticated frolic so droopy and inane that the plot holes and dull performances almost obliterate the gorgeous visuals.
So slight that it almost evaporates while you're watching it...but if there's nothing really special here, it's not unappetizing fare.
Takes the cake for sheer wrong-headedness...a movie that's likely to terrify children while it appalls adults.
Disney's best non-Pixar effort since the second 'Golden Age' of 1989-92...though the materials may be recycled, the carpentry is better than it's been at the Mouse House in nearly twenty years.
More Perry than Shange, and all the weaker for it.
Has a few sprightly moments but is overall pretty mediocre.
A sound, respectable depiction of an especially disreputable episode in modern American politics [but] it misses the power of a classic like 'All the President's Men.'
More like a narrative nightmare...just lays there on the screen, attractive to look at but horribly sluggish and, in the end, almost criminally stupid.
Fans of Gould--and there are still many--will devour the film, and even the merely curious should find it a fascinating portrait of a unique artist.
movie_title: Genius Within: The Inner Life of Glenn Gould (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A searing expose of the brutality of the Nazi regime ironically made by the perpetrators themselves, and a subtle examination of the process and purpose that lay behind it.
'Morning Adequacy' is more like it...basically an elongated sitcom that benefits from Ford's turn as an acerbic old-timer contemptuous of the turn his profession has taken.
Though far-fetched in the extreme and formulaic to a fault, the movie succeeds as an empty-headed adrenaline rush. It's pure popcorn escapism, and it works on that level.
One of the season's best [with] a performance by James Franco that's impressive in its range and vividness.
Simply awful...like a SyFy Network Saturday night special that's inexplicably escaped to the big screen.
Succeeds in presenting Lomborg's arguments in a cogent, persuasive way...trying to start a civil conversation on climate change that's based on reason rather than fear.
Though small in scope and running-time...deals in substantial human issues, and does so with grace and an odd charm.
movie_title: 36 vues du Pic Saint Loup (Around a Small Mountain) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Of a piece with Wiseman's filmmaking philosophy, and fits snugly into the whole of his work, even if...it's a relatively minor example of it, at least in terms of length.
Though not the best installment of the series...it's far from the worst. For committed fans...[it] certainly won't disappoint.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 1 (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Comes across as borderline absurd...really needs to be tauter in order to paper over the plot holes and logical lapses.
Quote not available.
A portrait of parental grief etched with sensitivity and welcome touches of humor.
Despite some sharp moments, just too messy and uneven to hit the target consistently.
A genuine triumph for all concerned...one of the year's best films.
Anybody willing to forgo the rapid-fire approach of most of today's animated pictures should find this gentle, warmhearted fable a quiet charmer.
A sad little self-indulgence.
A cheerfully adolescent male-bonding movie...as silly dramatically as it is historically, but in this case the silliness is rather enjoyable.

Offhand you might imagine that doing an animated version of 'Romeo and Juliet' with the characters played by lawn gnomes...would be a terrible idea. Now you have unassailable proof that you'd be right.
A thrill-free thriller...which dredges up every cliche of the genre and then bungles each and every one of them.
A varied lot, in both subject and quality. But they're an interesting bunch, well worth taking a lot at.
movie_title: The Oscar Nominated Short Films: Animation (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A varied lot, in both subject and quality. But they're an interesting bunch, well worth taking a look at.
Astonishingly bad...a would-be comedy that's not just cruelly unfunny but sloppily made.
Friendly, unassuming and just a little dull...the sort of movie you won't mind visiting once, but probably won't want to return to again.
Grows increasingly ludicrous as it proceeds, ending up shattering the suspension of disbelief necessary for such thrillers to avoid becoming comically implausible.

A bastard hybrid of 'Smallville,' 'Twilight' and any number of other angsty teen-themed sci-fi shows and movies...feels like a co-production of the CW and the SyFy channel that's inexplicably escaped to the big screen.
Just a variant on the old chestnut about a fraternity initiation gone terribly wrong...but told so tautly that you're swept up in it nevertheless.
A repulsive mixture of smarmy schmaltz and unremitting vulgarity,directed by co-writers Peter and Bobby Farrelly as though they were wielding a bludgeon.
Aspires to be absolute trash, but of the exhilarating sort. Unfortunately, it misses by a mile, winding up oddly dull and ponderous.
An animated picture that can bear comparison to Pixar's best...In attitude and style it's distinctive and witty, walking a fine line between respectful homage and spoof.
The question this exorcism potboiler really raises isn't what's possessing the supposed victims, but what possessed a great actor like Anthony Hopkins to accept a role in such schlock.
A bit uneven...[but] it has fun with the array of oddballs that make up the character list.
Glitzy trash, a violent bauble so ludicrous and over-the-top that it reeks of Luc Besson's influence.
A powerful experience, but a bleak and ultimately dispiriting one.
While not as obnoxious as its predecessor...an uninspired riff on an old formula, and structurally a shambles.
Ersatz Antonioni...The protagonist may be bored with his life, but not as much as we are.
Despite another fascinating performance by Gosling,...Andrew Jarecki's picture doesn't meld its mixture of fact, speculation, psychoanalysis and brooding atmosphere into a convincing whole.
The basic problem with the picture isn't that it's crude or offensive; it's merely flaccid and bland.
A pretty predictable David-and-Goliath (or Diva-and-Goliath) tale, but it employs the rah-rah formula nicely enough to be appealing.
Ultimately even Bardem...can't rescue what's essentially a long dirge from feeling manipulative and forced.
A brilliantly naturalistic dissection of romance and marriage...meticulously observed [and] intensely realistic.
This isn't a documentary about Christine O'Donnell's recent Senate campaign in Delaware. That would be a lot more entertaining...It may remind you of the movies of Uwe Boll.
A hackneyed backstage soap opera...with all the subtlety of the lyrics of the country-western songs that fill the soundtrack.
A dismal dramedy in which the comic bits aren't funny, the more serious parts heavy-handed and contrived, and the scenes that try to mix the two tonally muddled.
While on its own lowbrow terms the movie may work well enough, 'Kick-Ass' outpoints this 'Smart-Ass' cousin by a wide margin.
A powerful commentary on the heart of darkness.
Cinematically raw, untidy and sometimes positively odd, but it's also revealing, fascinating, unsettling and ultimately quite touching.
A film that may mean well but doesn't get down to depicting the real suffering that goes with recession.
A trite romantic plot is rescued by a reliable stream of clever lines, engaging leads and an array of superior supporting players.
Elevates what might have been an adolescent adventure story...with good taste, high-mindedness and elegence, even if the result is just a bit prosaic and emotionally detached.
Both pretentious and silly, a picture that addresses serious issues of fate and free will in the form of a mawkish adolescent adventure yarn.
The best advice is just to watch 'Planes, Trains & Automobiles' again and keep this stink-bomb off your itinerary.
Ultimately 'Monsters' is too obvious by half, but you have to give it credit for trying...for all its flaws, more interesting than a brainless, bombastic big-budget bore like 'Cloverfield.'
While slight, it has the texture and mood of a nice short story, and comes as a relief after so many loud, blustery Hollywood pictures.
If you're in the mood for such schlock, you could do worse. That's what's called faint praise.
A bright, witty family movie that has the added attraction--rare nowadays--of not being in 3D.
A well-meaning but bland picture that shortchanges its subject.

Really little more than a boys' adventure tale done in a style more gruesome than most...too intense and nasty to be sheer dumb fun, and too silly and formulaic to be taken for a serious historical epic.
With apologies to Henny Youngman, take this movie--please.
Mostly mistakes frenzy for fun and too often opts for jarring bits of violence...isn't a complete loser, but at best delivers a modest payoff rather than a big jackpot.
By trying to cover everything the picture manages to make nothing--especially Mesrine himself--seem significant or interesting.
Offering more angst than action, it creates a mood of overwhelming depression that's all too likely to engulf the audience as well as the protagonist.
Coming in midway between 'Up in the Air' and 'Failure to Launch,' this comedy about a long-distance romance neither soars nor crashes and burns...not great and not terrible, just mediocre.
Whatever fascination the character had for him, Richet doesn't succeed in conveying to us.
Though this is a film that will infuriate you from an institutional perspective, it's also strangely uplifting from a personal one.
For about an hour...the silliness works. Unfortunately, the last 45 minutes go south, as it were.
Riddled with as many predictable moves as any pro wrestling match...so trite a collection of cliches that it wouldn't even pass muster as a Hallmark special.

'The Exorcist' meets 'The Blair Witch Project' and gives birth to 'Rosemary's Baby'...a cheesy horror movie in the now commonplace verite style that manages a few easy jolts but overall isn't very scary.
Though the scenes between Bateman and Robinson can't redeem the implausible premise or the disagreeable first act, they do give the second half some affecting moments.
A tale of a crime family much smaller and far less prosperous than...the Corleones [but] as fascinating in its own way as Francis Ford Coppola's epic trilogy.

You know a spoof is in trouble when it's not even as funny as its target. All three installment of the 'Twilight' series...offer more giggles than this excruciatingly prolonged public-access-cable-quality sketch.
This homespun documentary offers an insightful look into one of the earliest eruptions of local acrimony over the issue of illegal immigration.
What was meant to be a wild ride through the seedy underbelly of the early Internet instead becomes a tepid wallow amid a slew of unsavory but resolutely uninteresting characters.
Definitely funnier than other spoofs of the buddy-cop genre, but it's still a very mixed bag.
A film that portrays a subject that could easily have become cloying with an austere, penetrating eye.
movie_title: The Father of My Children (Le pere de mes enfants) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A 'Concert' not worth attending.
Formulaic fluff, amateurishly acted and clumsily directed in the non-musical scenes. But the dancing has energy and verve.
One of the characters...astutely describes herself as 'shallow and narcissistic.' So's the movie.
More Le Carre than Ian Fleming, an intelligent Cold War espionage tale with real humanity at its core.
A film that has the best special effects of all--a well-wrought script, great acting, understated direction and...the needed period feel without showiness.
Lays on the eccentricity too thick and winds up seeming incredibly affected.
Though...an improvement on [Reiner's] recent efforts, it's still too frail and cutesy to be much more than passable.
A ludicrous action flick that...would seem right at home in the 2am slot on ShowTime.

An instant cult movie, and while it certainly succeeds on that level and members of the cult will embrace it for that very reason, the uninitiated--though impressed by its style--will probably be more exhausted than delighted.
Eat. Pray. Love. Barf....A celebration of self-indulgence trying to pass itself off as profound soul-searching.
Presumably the aim was to meld dark humor with passionate ardor and high drama, but the tone here is lumpy, crass and overheated.
While it's interesting to speculate about what's real and what isn't in 'I'm Still Here,' the important point is that the film is utterly riveting.
Crass and vulgar, of course. It's supposed to be funny, too, but it isn't...It makes a movie like 'Superbad'...seem like Shakespeare.
Winds up seeming like a high school musical--not the Disney one, but the sort you're likely to encounter in any small town.
This is war as hell on a small but incisive scale.
A mixed bag...often comes across as simply cute, pushing very hard to too little effect.
Half rape, half revenge and all repulsive...[but] certainly efficiently made for what it is.
Amiable enough, but ephemeral...raises some serious issues, but treats them so fitfully that in the end it barely registers on an emotional level.
movie_title: It's Kind of a Funny Story (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Should really be called 'Life As Formulaic Movies Show It'...nothing more than a second-rate sitcom stretched to unconscionable length by, among other devices, probably the largest number of musical montages in...history.
An unabashed crowd-pleaser of the old school...calculated and manipulative. But it does its job skillfully.
The skill of the construction, and the efforts of the excellent cast assembled to play it, make it an intriguing, fitfully amusing piece, although a rather misanthropic one.
movie_title: You Will Meet a Tall Dark Stranger (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Though the movie's about some sort of eternal killer, the real culprit here is Craven, whose attempt to feed on his earlier successes results in a structurally slipshod and distinctly non-frightening pastiche.
As a thespian duel between two heavyweights...has a good deal to recommend it. But in dramatic terms...leaves a lot to be desired.
This geriatric spy caper provides a showcase for a gray ensemble that's obviously enjoying themselves, but they're having more fun than we are.
Works as a conventionally satisfying docu-drama about the difficult teen years of a musical legend. If only it could have been as unconventional as Lennon was.
Warmhearted. Unfortunately, it's also softheaded...The music in 'Pure Country 2' is quite listenable, but the plot that surrounds the songs is utter hokum.
Essentially a Lifetime Network movie, but a pretty good one...though it's fairly predictable, the general level of execution--especially on the acting side--takes the material to a higher level.
Gives fans what they want--more of the same--but inevitably the law of diminishing returns comes into play.
Unrelievedly somber and slow, giving a gloomily portentous feel to ideas that aren't nearly as profound as the makers seem to think.
Reasonably satisfying, generating some genuine suspense on its way to a...conclusion in which the villains finally get what they deserve.
movie_title: The Girl Who Kicked the Hornet's Nest (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A wispy, evocative piece that...might not have much staying power but will speak to those who lived through the era it so cannily captures.
Isn't in the least smart or scary; even worse, it's deadly dull.
It would have been better for all concerned if this 'Case' had remained closed.
The sort of movie a fanboy might cook up in his garage on equipment borrowed from the local high school...it's not bad enough to be good--just bad enough to be really lousy.
The improved sheen of 'Afterlife' doesn't compensate for the feeling that the franchise has really run out of the little steam it ever had.
Doesn't match Affleck's first film, 'Gone Baby Gone,' in emotional depth or impact. But as an old-school movie about an old-school culture, it's pretty good.
In the high school comedy sweepstakes, 'Easy A' doesn't wind up at the top of the class, but it deserves a passing grade.
Its visual brightness and tonal goofiness are far from the darkness of the Coens' noir, and overall not nearly as successful.
movie_title: A Woman, A Gun and a Noodle Shop (San qiang pai an jing qi) (A Simple Noodle Story) (The First Gun) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: At least this time Dowdle has an excuse--'Shyamalan made me do it.'
Like a didactic episode of 'The Twilight Zone' told in slow-motion...turn[s] what's essentially pulp material into a artsy, pretentious tearjerker.
Though anything is possible, I seriously doubt that 'Use your gizzard' will supplant 'Trust the Force' anytime soon.
movie_title: Legend of the Guardians: The Owls of Ga'Hoole (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Great, thoughtful drama it's not, but it's sleek, fast and amusing enough to serve as the sort of high-gloss, dumb-fun melodrama that holds your interest without overtaxing your brain.
The sort of old-fashioned, slight little-guy-makes-good story that has some really charming moments but can often seem precious and contrived.
A perilous balancing act that the writer-director doesn't quite pull off, though he's populated it with an exceptional cast.
How bad is it? If it were a TV sitcom, it would be cancelled after a single episode.
Ends up more an exercise in bare-bones cinema than a penetrating drama, and though it's been executively efficiently, it fails to be emotionally compelling.
That isn't to say that this film doesn't raise some provocative questions in an intriguing way--it does. But in the end its answers seem just too pat, and frankly unrealistic.

A smart, literate, engrossing parable of genius, ambition, greed, treachery and inconclusive justice that says a good deal about a world undergoing technological revolution but still beset by the same old human problems.
So far superior to the usual run of Hollywood horror films that one can easily forgive the fact that it doesn't quite match its Swedish model.
In purely cinematic terms, it's an effective call to arms, though one susceptible to charges of oversimplification.
Misses the mark by a considerable margin...[Its] failure to approximate the formula it's reaching for leads you to think it should have been called 'You Can't Go Home Again.'
In a clear, intelligent and appropriately caustic fashion...points the finger of blame at those who well deserve it.
Quote not available.
The sort of picture that can be tolerated at a festival like Sundance, where it was warmly received, but is totally out of place when it escapes such a specialized venue.
A brisk, engaging, if ultimately inconsequential oddball police procedural.
An uneven, relatively gentle, rather sweet but only sporadically enjoyable family flick with slapstick the kiddies will find smurfing fun.
Respectful but not idolatrous, this is one 'Behind the Music' piece that even those who have never heard of the group can appreciate.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Cliche-ridden and ineptly made...a period piece that would have been moldy even twenty years ago.
movie_title: The Perfect Age of Rock 'n' Roll (2011)

movie_review_blurb: An earnest but sluggish tale of corruption in the aftermath of the Bosnian war.
Though one wishes it could have addressed the subject without resorting to what amounts to melodrama, young Manyaka's compelling performance makes it worth seeing.

Might not make the grade in strict historical terms [but] works more often than not as an action drama contrasting a demented villain and his right-minded stand-in. [And] Dominic Cooper gives a stunning double performance.
A tight, beautifully made if rather predictable background yarn...that does the obvious well even if it lacks the imagination to go beyond it.
movie_title: Rise of the Planet of the Apes (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A cunningly--but not cynically--manipulative picture...that makes the canny mix of drama, sentiment and comedy a more palatable brew than it has any right to be.
Starts out at high speed, but before long it's running on fumes, and by the last reel it sputters to a stop.
Scores miles ahead of torture-porn trash...and even improves on its predecessors in cleverness and suspense. Of course it's still what it is, and that's not much.
A package that viewers who have made the show a phenomenon will undoubtedly embrace, but is unlikely to convert the still-uninitiated.
Too ostentatiously whimsical to be much more than a weird curio.

A particularly gruesome example of the sort of raunchy R-rated comedy that's proliferated in Hollywood...it's as though [the] scripters were determined to amp up the coarseness and vulgarity with each change of scene.
Fascinating, whimsically humorous and poignant, all at once.
Sexy without being smutty and funny without grossing us out...it's 'adult' in the best sense.
A cool new 'War of the Worlds' set in the Old West...blends western and sci-fi elements with surprising success.
A bombastic, elephantine bore whose lack of visceral excitement is topped only by its excess of stupidity... should really be consigned to the cinematic scrap heap.
A feeble feel-good fable that you're likely to leave with a very different feeling than the intended one.
An empty-headed trifle that's the cinematic equivalent of an advertising spread in a glossy teen magazine.
Though this 'Host' is far from perfect, it does offer incidental pleasures--not least Pierce's exuberant turn.
A drolly deadpan horror comedy...a sly, cheeky movie that shows how an old genre can be successfully resuscitated with approached with imagination rather than just a big budget.
Subtle and evocative...as formulaic in its own way as 'Rocky' (or, if you prefer, 'Searching for Bobby Fischer'), but it's a more cerebral, sophisticated use of the formula than usual.
A lightweight, mildly ribald farce that offers some stray laughs, smothered in a morass of 'Three Stooges'-style dumbness.
A dismal family comedy that even the most charitable child should find difficult to endure.
The sort of thing that will be more at home on Animal Planet than in a theatrical venue. But of its kind, it's solid classroom fare.
Glossy feminist medlodrama, which could justly be described as Ross Hunter Reborn.
Spectacular but also emotionally affecting, it's a fitting capstone to a series that remains unmatched, despite many attempts over the past decade to imitate its magical formula.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2 (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A cheerfully satisfying throwback that embraces the innocence of the comics while adding the spectacle of modern SFX technique.
An elegantly crafted, touching Holocaust drama spanning four generations and a wide emotional spectrum.
A maudlin, meandering soap opera that traverses nearly two hundred years bluntly--and boringly--making the same obvious point over and over again.
movie_title: Snow Flower And The Secret Fan (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Drab and lifeless...pretends to upend the tired conventions of the genre while actually embracing each and every one of them.
Noteworthy...for wrapping a message about overcoming ethnic and political differences in the trappings of a conventional romantic comedy, and being largely successful at such a tricky task.
movie_title: Le nom des gens (The Names of Love) (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Painfully earnest...but Bichir's performance grounds it in a reality it might otherwise have lacked.
Has energy and some laughs, but in the end suffers from a familiar threadbare quality.
A top-notch mixture of horror and dark comedy...a slam-bang popcorn movie that really delivers the goods, if you don't mind the popcorn sprinkled with a little red sauce.
A throwback, but one with a stylish new spin...alternately solemn and explosive, it's a wild ride, though like any such enterprise more notable for excitement than emotional involvement.
A chick flick that feels thirty years behind the times.
movie_title: I Don't Know How She Does It (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Prose rather than poetry, basically an impersonal work without any strong directorial imprint...the new 'Straw Dogs' is superior to most of the home-invasion potboilers produced nowadays, but for real bite Sam is still 'the man.'
Spectacular and spectacularly goofy...Even if you find the story ludicrous, the visuals will keep your eyes occupied--if not your mind.
movie_title: Detective Dee and the Mystery of the Phantom Flame (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Its visual and narrative emptiness is almost beyond comprehension, but there seems to be an audience for such brainless actioners out there.
A sharp, smart script...manages to make [a] potentially dreary subject almost as fascinating as Sorkin did the world of computer programming in 'The Social Network.'
A comic monstrosity...plays like an unfunny idea for a raunchy five-minute sketch that's been cruelly extended to an insufferable ninety-six minutes.
movie_title: Bucky Larson: Born to Be a Star (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The youngsters and the dolphin show that there's life left in the old 'Flipper' formula yet...[a] well-made, gently comforting modern version of a 1950s live-action Disney movie.
May be arresting, but not necessarily in a pleasant or significant way.
There's a better than even chance that you'll find it both funny and touching.

Poorly written, amateurishly acted and cheesily made,...this high school morality tale that recasts the old fairy tale for the 'Twilight' audience...resembles a chintzy Afterschool Special with supernatural overtones.
A minor entry in the director's canon...while not horrible, it might make you a little restless yourself.
There isn't much to Jean Becker's movie, but what there is, is charming... You won't regret spending eighty minutes not only with Marguerite but with Germain, too.
movie_title: La tête en friche (My Afternoons with Margueritte) (2011)

movie_review_blurb: If it doesn't quite go the distance, 'Tucker & Dale Vs. Evil' earns enough laughs along the way that it should be an amusing ride--especially for fans of slasher flicks (or those who have always thought the genre was totally ridiculous).
Furious but sadly silly...visually a slick piece of work [but] so astonishingly stupid in storytelling terms that by the end you'll be suppressing chuckles over its inanity.
A sinkhole features prominently in the final confrontation between man and beast in 'Creature.' It would have been wiser to chuck the negative into it.

Though it's essentially an astronomically silly formula sports movie stuffed with bone-crunching action, 'Warrior' plays so skillfully as family melodrama that it should connect even with viewers who would never think of watching an MMA match.
Tells its story in such a fractured, elliptical fashion that you're likely to leave it more confused than enlightened, as befuddled as the heroine is after her experiences.
A handsome mixture of laughter and tears, part rom-com and part schmaltz but overall reasonably winning.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Has a certain hokey, old-fashioned charm but otherwise proves pretty bland in today's horror climate.
movie_title: Don't Be Afraid Of The Dark (2011)

movie_review_blurb: As sports documentaries go,...excellent, though in a fairly conventional way.
A movie that has a few laughs, but despite its laid-back hero has a forced, oddly strident feel.
Fully convincing neither as pure Cold War thriller nor as rumination on the dangers of deception and the cost of moral repair.
One can imagine a powerful film being made using the brief 2008 'war' as a backdrop. Unfortunately, this isn't it.
Old-fashioned, but certainly not good...hardly the rambunctiously raunchy laugh-fest the title suggests, [but] more like a slightly steamier version of a typical network sitcom.
Heavy-handed and sanctimonious...the advice from this quarter isn't 'See it, feel it, trust it,' but 'Skip it.'

Has the cool, understated tension that marked the suspense films of Claude Chabrol as well as [Patricia] Highsmith's examimations of human malevolence. If their works are to your taste, this should suit it as well.
Although the acting and technical elements...are better than what you usually encounter in a Saturday night SyFy Network flick, that's still where it really belongs.
The stream of jerky, fuzzy, static-riddled and otherwise distressed visuals...[is] a trick that's gone stale, and 'Apollo 18' doesn't freshen it up
If you want a factual primer on Madoff's crimes, you should look elsewhere. But as a portrait of an unusual man, 'Chasing Madoff' is flawed but fascinating.

More a cinematic autopsy than an affecting drama--a cool, detached dissection of an enormous human tragedy; and while it certainly succeeds as a semi-documentary account, it fails to deliver a strong emotional punch.
'Conan the Borebarian'...directed by the guy responsible for 'Pathfinder' and proves as silly and visually overblown as that movie.
On the surface seems to be about a fairly narrow subject, but proves to be about universal human truths.
A morally muddled tale that treats serious issues of faith and violence simplistically rather than with the subtlety they deserve.
A droll, understated, appealing coming-of-age tale...that demands patience but rewards it as well.
An earnest family movie that practically drowns in uplift and good intentions.
Holds your attention over its rather untidily assembled eighty minutes of on-the-fly footage by reason of what it reveals about [Cunningham's] almost monastic devotion to his work.
A solid, unhurried piece of work that doesn't provide the adrenaline rush its subject would seem to invite, but may be all the more powerful for its deliberation.
A fluffy, old-fashioned delight.
Abysmal...a serious miscalculation.
An arid, enigmatic oddity...more an act of cinematic provocation than an affecting drama.
Quote not available.
movie_title: South (In the Grip of Polar Ice) (Southward on the Queste) (Shackleton's Expedition to the Antarctic (1919)

movie_review_blurb: Quote not available.
Another middle-grade piece of computer animation from Blue Sky...neither great nor terrible--just mediocre.
Sober, respectful, but rather stilted and talky...may be long on factual accuracy, but...it lacks dramatic energy.
Like Bier's previous films, it certainly has soap-operatic elements. But it transcends them to become a thoughtful, penetrating drama.
A big-screen version of a Lifetime Network movie--more sharply drawn and powerfully delivered, perhaps, but essentially cut from the same cloth.
Impassioned, but also dramatically disjointed and emotionally parched.
Quote not available.
While definitely a cut above most slasher flicks...not quite funny or scary enough to hit the mark.
Little more than an action exercise, but an extraordinarily skillful one, a well-oiled machine that delivers an adrenaline rush of the first order.
It's been a long time since Hollywood has made a circus movie, but if 'Water for Elephants' is any indication, it hasn't been long enough.
Wretched medieval spoof...a tired cascade of smugly unfunny riffs and gross-out adolescent raunchiness.

Until the misguided last act, 'Insidious' manages to generate some genuine chills and a few chuckles...Unlike the best horror films, though, it probably won't stick with you long after the lights come up.
A muddle of woozy romance and horror-movie cliche...Of course, pictures about werewolves involve the full moon, so it's only appropriate this one should reek of lunacy.
A fascinating, often very funny and sometimes quite insightful inside look at the aftermath of a famous television debacle, as well as a revealing, not always flattering, portrait of a star.
Except for a change of perspective...'Battle: Los Angeles' is just 'Skyline' with a bigger budget but no more brains.
For a picture that really isn't much more than a high-toned soap opera...surprisingly effective.
An interesting if flawed blend of historical commentary and contemporary political-economic diatribe...it raises provocative issues in a dramatically compelling, if obvious, way.
Quote not available.
If it doesn't score a pin, it comes out a winner on points.
While it doesn't match 'Primal Fear' for spellbinding misdirection, it's certainly a skillfully-made if lightweight legal puzzler.
What could have been a keen, witty take on alien-visitation tropes becomes a noisy, strained buddy movie with more lows than highs.

One of the few pictures to take religious belief seriously without getting maudlin or sanctimonious about it...Stark and unsentimental, it's a quietly powerful piece that encourages reflection rather than tears.
The cinematic equivalent of a meal high in calories and low in nutrition...dresses up a weak narrative in a glitzy explosion of technical virtuosity intended to conceal its shortcomings.
A rather pedestrian film, epic in length but curiously pinched in scope.
A more conventional outing than its predecessor, but actually a more likable picture, even if it's of no more than cable-TV quality.
movie_title: Diary of a Wimpy Kid 2: Rodrick Rules (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Will hardly replace the classic gangster flicks, but it's a pretty good little account of an episode in American mob history that had surprisingly wide-ranging ramifications.
Energy alone isn't enough to keep 'Source Code' from feeling thin, repetitive and nowhere near as smart as it wants you to believe it is.
Lays one big, though colorful, Easter egg.
Refined, elegant, and just a little bit too tame to capture the simmering passion of the original...Still, among the features based on the book, it stands quite high.
One of those mediocre computer-animated kidflicks that seem to come along every couple of weeks nowadays...desperately needs more imagination, charm and heart.
Part insipid comedy, part ultra-violent action-movie send-up and all terrible, 'Super' most definitely isn't.
Isn't an easy film to watch, but while a wrenching experience it's also a rewarding one.
Doesn't entirely avoid affectation, but overall it's a touching story of two generations, father and son, each striking out on a new path.
An affected tale centered on one of those ultra-precocious adolescents one rarely if ever encounters outside of memoirs and sitcoms.
Despite its high-mindedness, an almost complete misfire...a lopsided film as well as a turgid, boring one.
Though it won't earn any points for originality, in Abrams' hands 'Super 8' is a slick package of hand-me-down goods, smartly put together and...efficiently executed.
A twisty thriller that keeps you engaged for the duration, but in the final analysis proves not nearly as smart or clever as it thinks it is.
As successful [a reboot] as J.J. Abrams' 'Star Trek' was...a summer blockbuster that's actually worth the price of popcorn.
Slight but funny and at times almost painfully real.
Infantile family comedy...a cutesy, by-the-numbers mixture of slapstick and sentiment.
This affected Wes Anderson clone [is] sheer drudgery to watch.
Especially coming from Pixar, this frantic but uninspired 'toon is a major disappointment.
Both a fitting tribute to a great journalistic enterprise and a warning about what would be lost if it--and others like it--ceased to exist.
movie_title: Page One: Inside the New York Times (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Though sporadically funny, this blackish comedy would have been far better had it been a lot darker...settles for sitcom-level shenanigans and mild raunchiness before coasting into an ending that effectively cops out.
As usual with such one-joke projects...seems a bit overlong even at under ninety minutes, but it offers enough smiles and insights to earn a low passing grade.
movie_title: POM Wonderful Presents: The Greatest Movie Ever Sold (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Visually quite interesting [but] the combination of earnestness and smart-ass wisecracks proves unstable.
A vegetarian infomercial in the guise of a feature documentary.
A pretty deadly affair...exactly the sort of picture one might expect from a reclusive filmmaker who's been told for years he's a great artist and has come to believe it.
Ravishing to look at, but its by-the-numbers story isn't enough to keep even a toddler occupied.
[The] fifth lap of the brainlessly macho series should please fans...while making everybody else wonder why.
Isn't awful, but it is awfully familiar,...coming across as something that might appear on the SciFi Network on a Saturday night.
One of the better examples of the goofy live-action comic book that's come around recently.
A haunting, evocative work...the rare film about art that can be considered a serious work of art itself.
An incredibly shrill comedy...the surface elegance somehow only makes the underlying nastiness more noticeable.

A flawed, erratic comedy-drama that nonetheless remains fascinating because of Gibson's frenziedly committed performance.
An intoxicated condition might be the best one in which to watch this terrible movie.
Doesn't plumb much below the surface of the subject, but remains an interesting curiosity.
Since [Gordon-Levitt's] one of the most energetic and inventive young actors in the business, you can't take your eyes off him. Unfortunately, the quality of the material makes you wish you could.

At once a stirring familial drama, a potent commentary on modern political strife and--more than a sideline--a cracking good mystery.

Copies the original so slavishly that it's the equivalent of a big-screen rerun.

An exciting white-knuckle ride for action junkies and those who like to see the enemy get the raw end of a deal.

movie_title: The Goods: Live Hard, Sell Hard (2009)

movie_review_blurb: 'Adventureland' is a sweet, heartfelt coming-of-age drama with loads of sensitivity and bigness of heart.
'Ghosts of Girlfriends Past' lacks energy and originality, plus the characters are too shallow to care about. But Michael Douglas is delightful.
'Management' is an addictively charming little movie about loosening up and chasing your dreams.
Some scenes in 'The Hurt Locker' are as memorable and iconic as those in 'Apocalypse Now.'
Almost everything first-time director Marc Webb explores rings true here. The comedy never seems forced, and the romance always feels real.
This horrifically beautiful rags-to-riches fairytale is an intoxicating blend of genres that touches on a wide range of emotions.
'Fired Up!' has a great story to tell for sure, but it just doesn't make a good 'PG-13' movie.
'Soul Men' is a mediocre film at best, buoyed by the abrasive chemistry of Bernie Mac and Samuel L. Jackson.

A romantic comedy that's both as sweet and as obscene as anything you'll see this year.
movie_title: Zack and Miri Make a Porno (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Brilliant acting by Crowe and Washington plus Scott's near flawless direction, make 'American Gangster' one of the best films of the year.

'The Ruins' is a creepy-crawly little film that'll get under your skin and bore its way into your psyche if you let it.
There's no thrill of victory and no agony of defeat here -- just more cars flying through the air...and cartwheeling before bursting into flames.
Perhaps if the action sequences were more skillfully woven into the proceedings, we'd get less of a sense that they're included solely as a means of satisfying the summer blockbuster crowd.

The only thing that works in 'Hell Ride' is the throwback style and visual tone it lovingly mimics.
Woody Allen's 'Vicky Cristina Barcelona' smolders with the best of them. It's also one of Allen's most finely crafted films.

There's never a dull moment in 'Quarantine.'

movie_review_blurb: This Rock 'n' Roll love letter comes across as an overlong, jumbled mess of a film that has trouble finding both its voice and its focus.

A clever mix of classic noir themes and commercialized filmmaking techniques.

movie_review_blurb: You'll laugh and you'll cry at what turns out to be Rodrigo Garcia's finest work to date.

tells the story in the most compelling way possible. And since it takes place before Queen, at least here's one sports movie where we don't have to hear 'We are the Champions' again.
