Charts the harsh odyssey of two Guatemalan Indians as they struggle to make a new life for themselves in America as illegal immigrants
A hilarious comedy that offers a clever look at the follies and grief that come to all those who try to milk the institution of marriage for all they can get out of it.
Bus 174 eschews a sensationalistic treatment of a hijacking in Brazil and focuses instead on its root causes of poverty and the plight of the street people in Rio de Janeiro.
Shows how addiction can get the best of a person-eating a black hole in all the departments of life.
movie_title: A Hero Ain't Nothin' but a Sandwich (1978)

movie_review_blurb: Beautifully conveys one woman's journey from dependent security to independent self-confidence.
Walter Matthau bites into his juicy role like a cowpoke chewing on some tobacco and it comes out just right.
Marilyn Hassett shines in this romantic drama.
movie_title: The Other Side of the Mountain Part 2 (1978)

movie_review_blurb: Howard Ziff directs this romantic comedy with a nutty appreciation for its likeable characters.
Robert Mitchum's wry and worldly depiction of Marlowe, an intrepid detective, carries the movie.
Straight Time packs a punch--thanks to the intense and well-modulated performance by Dustin Hoffman.
An interesting social document about a watershed media event as well as a thoroughly entertaining movie.
The Duellists registers on the senses like a pointillist work of art, encouraging us to revel in its symmetry and relish its high regard for small details.
Wendy Wasserstein's drama is an exquisite blend of comedy and incisive commentary on what it means to be a young woman today.
A comic thriller that works.
movie_title: Cat & Mouse (Le Chat et la souris) (1975)

movie_review_blurb: A fine film celebrating the beauty of the human spirit.
Heaven Can Wait shines in almost every department: it in one of those rare movies that deserves to be seen again and again.
The Buddy Holly Story moves us with the joyfulness of its music and the honest sentiment aroused in us by this gawky, shy rock singer and songwriter.
This is a solid and memorable film about American military involvement in Vietnam.
A complicated morality play about the Vietnam war and its lingering after-effects.
Days of Heaven is a compelling adventure story and a riveting meditation on the soulscape of America.
A very funny movie with a gallery of interesting characters.
movie_title: Who Is Killing the Great Chefs of Europe? (Too Many Chefs) (1978)

movie_review_blurb: An extended family sets sail in this drama and it is a delight accompanying them.
Genevieve Bujold puts in one of the strongest performances of her career in this well-done thriller.
Although the film does not tell us how to break out of the plantations we know too well, it does give us a vivid sense of the problems and the pitfalls of those who try.
An illuminating parable about the human condition, giving voice to the yearning we all have for some kind of religious experience.
The gripping story of a true survivor.
movie_title: Story of Women (Une Affaire de Femmes) (1989)

movie_review_blurb: Explores the fine line between small and large deception.
Revolves around the response of a large family to the death of the matriarch.
This comic tale about corruption in pious places packs a lively moral wallop!
The Late Show is a detective flick that modestly delivers more than one expects.
Explores the anxieties and sorrow of an aging man who's trying to come to terms with his loneliness.
Delivers a quirky meditation on body-building as an odd mixture of pain and narcisstic pleasure.
3 Women is an intriguing film by Robert Altman that resides in the netherworld between dreaming and waking.
Filled with the kind of suprises and reversals which are at the nub of all good suspense stories.
A rollicking exploration of one paranoid fellow's tangled world of love and loss.
Recreates this complicated and tragic military venture with breathtaking sweep, historical accuracy and sober-eyed humanism.
Gregory Peck plays MacArthur as an intense and dignified general with an arrogant and well-defined sense of patriotism.
Julia gives us a genuine and affecting portrait of a friendship between two women who confirm each other and strengthen their bonds over the years.
One Sings, the Other Doesn't is a valentine to female friendship and the worldwide family of women.
movie_title: One Sings, the Other Doesn't (L'Une chante, l'autre pas) (1977)

movie_review_blurb: Makes the point that prison is a microcosm of society's bigotries and group pressures against undesirable outsiders.
Sophia Loren puts in her best performance since Two Women.
A wonderful film about the friendship between two women and about the marvels of ballet.
Isabelle Huppert's performance as a prety, tongue-tied girl who can't verbally express her feelings is the best reason to see this French film.
A bittersweet love story by Neil Simon.
Death on the Nile is a fine entertainment that is lovely to look at and easy to enjoy.
Probes the troubled marriage between these two strong individuals.
movie_title: Eleanor and Franklin: The White House Years (1977)

movie_review_blurb: A Wedding depicts the strange way that this ritual has been taken away from families and put into the hands of professionals.
Interiors tells its story so convincingly within the house of negation that it offers us a clear picture of what a healthy mother-daughter relationship must entail.
Rocky II is carried on the strong shoulders of Sylvester Stallone who puts in a stellar performance as a loving husband and a good friend.
Alien is a scare machine that really works.
The In-Laws is a laugh riot.
Meatballs works because Bill Murray's talents as an actor and comedian.
Moonraker is a freefall of fun-filled entertainment.
Winter Kills boasts some exceptional acting by John Huston and Anthony Perkins and Dorothy Malone.
Escape from Alcatraz is an above average prison break flick.
Peppermint Soda is a valentine to the bittersweet joys of adolescence.
Le Cage Aux Folles is a giddy French farce.
The Wanderers does a fine job mapping adolescent rebelliousness.
North Dallas Forty reveals some of the reasons why the fun has been taken out of football.
Apocalypse Now has a philosophical underpinning that sets it apart from other recent cinematic evaluations of the American involvement in Vietnam.
Soldier of Orange offers an involving look at the horrors of war.
movie_title: Soldaat van Oranje (Soldier of Orange) (Survival Run) (1977)

movie_review_blurb: Orchesta Rehearsal is a witty reflection on the human condition--especially our penchant for stressing individual liberty over social good.
Rich Kids does a remarkable job covering Manhattan as a playground for the affluent.
The Seduction of Joe Tynan explores adultery and its manifold complications.
A Man, A Woman and A Bank is a snappy and engaging caper movie.
movie_title: A Man, a Woman and a Bank (1979)

movie_review_blurb: The 5th Musketeer is old fashioned film fare.
movie_title: The Fifth Musketeer (Behind the Iron Mask) (The 5th Musketeer) (1979)

movie_review_blurb: The Frisco Kid works thanks to Gene Wilder's jaunty, sweet and convincing triumph of comic bravado.
Last Embrace is directed by Jonathan Demme and it packs a real wallop of suspense.
Love on the Run is a cinematic valentine from Francois Truffaut to Antoine Doinel.
movie_title: Love on the Run (L'Amour en fuite) (1979)

movie_review_blurb: Saint Jack offers a subtle study of cultural tensions and misunderstandings.
Alan Parker's Midnight Express works like a hammer lock on the viewer's mind.
Goin' South is a gritty Western with plenty of spunk.
The Big Fix is a lively Western in the Dashielle Hammet style.
Despair is a surreal version of a Vladimir Nabokov novel with a poised performance by Dirk Bogarde.
A celebration of personhood with plenty of rousing rock-and-soul-and gospel music.
Richard Farnsworth shines with his portrait of the archetypal cowboy--crafty, self-reliant and industrious.
A respectful screen version of Richard Adams' bestselling novel.
Superman, The Movie is a rousing screen version about America's foremost folk hero.
This French film has nothing on its mind except causing delight.
Days of Heaven is a compelling adventure story and a riveting meditation on the soulscape of America.
Dear Detective is a French comedy with nothing on its mind but causing delight.
Invasions of the Body Snatchers speaks to our national paranoia amd intrigues us with its craftiness.
The Great Train Robbery offers a peep into Victorian society with its strange sports, public hangings and high society rituals.
Murder by Decree is spiffy entertainment for lovers of good mystery stories.
Agatha is a visually rich movie filmed exquisitely by Vittorio Storro.
Real Life is funy in spots but is remarkable mostly for its Socratic open-endedness.
The China Syndrome is a piercing look at the dangers of nuclear energy and the unwillingness of corporate heads to put public safety above economic considerations.
Hair is a zany blend of song, dance and parody with its giddy portrait of hippies.
Manhattan depicts urban trippers whose appetite for variety propels them from one person or job or dream to another.
A hard-hitting drama about one nineteen-year-old Bronx's youth coming of age.
A chilling documentary that compels us to consider the terrible things human beings can do to one another because of fear, ideology, or just following orders.
movie_title: S21: The Khmer Rouge Death Machine (2004)

movie_review_blurb: A riveting parable about America during the Depression.
A funny movie set in contemporary Montana that is rich in oddball characters and a light satirical touch
Zwick (Courage Under Fire) has fashioned another ethical tour de force that reveals his dedication to serious filmmaking.
A rattling good sea saga filled with two first-class performances, a memorable portrait of friendship, and a substantive exploration of leadership.
movie_title: Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World (2003)

movie_review_blurb: War Photographer is a powerful documentary about a gifted and idealistic peace maker in a world torn by conflict, pain and suffering.
My Architect is an unusual and compelling documentary about Louis I Kahn, an unconventional visionary and mysterious man.
This three part film reverently explores the devotional and ethical riches of Sufism, Tibetan Buddhism and Hinduism with beautiful images and poetic descriptions.
Respiro begins as a portrait of a woman who refuses to abide by the conventions of the comunity and ends with a bit of inspired magical realism.
Genesis has the same stark simplicity and narrative power as Pasolini's The Gospel According to St. Matthew.
The Missing is an engrossing cross-cultural drama about a father-daughter reunion under dire circumstances that tests their mettle and their feelings for each other.
Hidden in Plain Sight is a hard-hitting documentary about the U.S. Army's School of the Americas.
A soulful and buoyant portrait of a poverty stricken Irish family's winning battle to move beyond the wrenching, contradictory, and chaotic emotions of grief into a new life.
My Flesh and Blood is an engrossing documentary about a truly nurturing adoptive mother of eleven special-needs children.
A remarkable and exquisitely rendered drama that mixes the raw savagery of war with magical moments of Zen peacefulness and spiritual uplift.
A spiritual adventure story about a Sufi grocer who passes on the wisdom of this path of wonder, love and beauty to a lonely adolescent boy who yearns for something more.
movie_title: Monsieur Ibrahim et les fleurs du Coran (Monsieur Ibrahim) (2003)

movie_review_blurb: A hard-hitting documentary about the injustices heaped on the Mexican-American community of migrant workers by a small Texas town's white power brokers.
Forget Baghdad probes the twilight existence of four Arab Jews who have felt the sting of bigotry both in Iraq where they were born and in Israel where they now live.
movie_title: Forget Baghdad: Jews and Arabs - The Iraqi Connection (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Director Peter Webber has created an erotic masterpiece that shimmers with visual beauty and a deep appreciation of the exquisite art of Jan Vermeer.
A serious drama based on a novel by Brian Moore that explores crimes against humanity, the activities of a right-wing organization in the Catholic Church, and forgiveness.
Big Fish will draw out the story-loving child in you who still enjoys exploring dreams, fantasies, and larger-than-life adventures.
The Cooler challenges us to believe that two losers can triumph against formidable odds, buoyed up by love and their belief in Lady Luck.
Gloomy Sunday is a well-acted German drama about love, death and the grace moments that make life worth the wear of living.
Ends as it began with a salute to faith that accepts mystery, is firm in a resolve to see things through, and is propelled by choices that make all the difference.
This film tallies up the pain, the suffering and the loss that enter our lives when we refuse to acknowledge the shadow part of our selves and choose to live a lie instead.
Good Morning, Night presents a chilling look at the righteous indignation of zealots while at the same time revealing the firepower of empathy and its close relative compassion.
Covers the events leading up to a shooting spree at a high school and in the small details we see pain, loneliness, anger, irresponsibility, cruelty, self-disgust, and violence everywhere.
Crimson Gold is a courageous Iranian film by director Jafar Panahi that conveys the harsh realities of contemporary Teheran and the chasm between the rich and the poor.
Bright Leaves is a smart, ethically rich, innovative and well-done documentary about the tobacco industry. family legacies and the pleasures of filmmaking.
Since Otar Left deftly conveys the unsettling and painful things that can happen in the family circle even when individuals are only trying to act out of love.
Sylvia portrays this American poet's obsession with self-destruction and her futile efforts to exorcise her demons with the force of her imagination.
Veronica Guerin depicts the efforts of a crusading journalist in Dublin who does the right thing for the wrong reasons as she tries single-handedly to bring down the city's drug trade.
Pieces of April revolves around a Thanksgiving dinner and draws out all our mixed feelings about families, memories, nasty grievances and moments of deep gratitude.
A fast-paced legal thriller about the unsavory methods used by the gun industry to protect itself.
An exceptionally relevant and morally thought provoking documentary about America's immoral use of the weapons of mass destruction.
movie_title: The Fog of War: Eleven Lessons from the Life of Robert S. McNamara (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Distant is a thematically rich Turkish film about urban loneliness, the shame of unemployment and the difficulty of practicing hospitality.
Raja is an engaging cross-cultural drama set in Morocco about a wealthy middle-aged Frenchman's yearning for a nineteen-year-old local girl who works in his garden.
A bracing Canadian comedy about all those bothersome forces that unsettle our lives along with those surprising blessings which open our hearts unexpectedly.
A deeply spiritual film exploring the ties that bind a heart transplant patient, a grieving mother, and a born-again ex-con on a journey of guilt, pain, and redemption.
Free Radicals portrays the subtle and fragile strands that link our lives to those of others in ways we cannot even begin to imagine.
Sister Helen profiles a tough, compassionate servant of God running a half-way house in the South Bronx who tried to give others what she cherished most in life--a second chance.
Brother Bear is a fine family film that eschews the competitive and self-centered values of popular culture and proclaims the grooming of one's spirit with love and caretaking.
A glimpse into the lives of two troubled young women who desperately try to forge a new life for themselves against formidable odds.
Shattered Glass is a highly charged moral drama about the deceptions and fabrications of an ambitious young staff writer for the New Republic.
Proves that even aging members of the Baby Boom Generation can become unglued by the palpitations and vexations of romantic love.
A slap-stick devotee's dream come true
movie_title: The Return of the Pink Panther (1975)

movie_review_blurb: This innovative and hilarious spoof on the Arthurian tales is a laugh riot from start to finish; best of all is the pacification program for the Knights who say "Ni!"
movie_title: Monty Python and the Holy Grail (1975)

movie_review_blurb: Calendar Girls celebrates the juiciness of some English women who accept their bodies and innate talents thanks to an innovative fund-raising project in their small town.
A Bob Rafelson film about a young antihero struggling to make sense out of his life and find a new direction for it
A menacing film about the principalities and powers at work in the universe that defy logic
Proves that no one can escape the long and intrusive arm of politics and evade involvement
Recommended for all those who occasionally enjoy their movies with a little cerebral spice added
A spicy French romantic drama
An exquisite screen interpretation of F. Scott Fitzgerald's unfinished novel on Hollywood during the Thirties
A totally believable and entertaining Swiss film about politics
movie_title: Jonah Who Will be 25 in the Year 2000 (1976)

movie_review_blurb: A wonderful valentine to the playfulness and spontaneity of children
movie_title: L' Argent de Poche (Pocket Money) (Small Change) (1976)

movie_review_blurb: An Ingmar Bergman film with Liv Ulmann in a tour de force performance of a woman whose breakdown brings her a close encounter with her inner anguish
A remarkably touching and humane film about Woody Guthrie
A compelling drama about morality under fire in the life of a middle-aged business man
A fascinating animated film about Erik Erikson's eight periods of the human life cycle
Grapples with the moral issue at stake in a country where technology has outstripped out knowledge of how to use and control it
An unusually human movie that ought to be talked about by everyone concerned with the real meaning of education, communication, and a full rich vision of life
Not only a great adventure story but also a touching love story
One of those unforgettable film experiences where everything  cinematography, music, acting  coheres in a unified and rewarding work of art
Stomps all over the games we play to pretend we're important
About a cool gumshoe with a one-track mind  solving the case he's on
An enchanting portrait of Emily Dickerson, one of America's greatest women poets
Returns to the adventures of Robin Hood who is now middle-aged and still yearning for the love of his life
An Alfred Hitchcock thriller with many interesting things happening in the movie's small places
A touching family drama, an exploration of black identity and a moving parable about love
An engrossing drama about the downward mobility of a recovering alcoholic and the yearning for upward mobility of an Iranian immigrant.
Pays tribute to a bohemian teacher who tests her idealism in the conservative milieu of Wellesley College in the Fifties.
A fine French film about a cross-generational friendship between a cranky entomologist and a lonely little girl yearning for some attention.
Cold Mountain is a universal quest story about the yearning for hope and home that enables two lovers to deal with the harrowing menace and the senseless violence of war.
Osama delivers a cry from the heart of subjugated and humiliated women in Afghanistan under the merciless rule of the Taliban.
The Tracker is a deftly rendered Australian parable about white racism and aboriginal survival in the face of the politics of violence and domination.
One of those inimitable small films that squares with human experience in genuine, funny and memorable ways
An unusual detective story that points out that in a world of rampant deception, we can't believe in winners anymore
Offers a fresh twist on winning out and gives us pause to think about our way of being in the world
Stars Robert Redford in a thriller for thinkers probing covert activities within the CIA
A romantic detective story starring Robert Mitchum that harkens back to a time when even gumshoes had their own moral code
A courtroom drama based on a Broadway play that has been brought to the screen with all its bite intact
Gives Orson Welles a chance to explore trickery, fraud and illusion on the screen in imaginative ways
Makes a very strong case against yellow journalism
movie_title: Die Verlorene Ehre der Katharina Blum oder: Wie Gewalt entstehen und wohin sie führen kann (The Lost Honor of Katharina Blum) (1975)

movie_review_blurb: A robust and rousing screen version of one of the greatest adventure stories ever written
movie_title: The Man Who Would Be King (1975)

movie_review_blurb: A fascinating screen interpretation of Daniel Defoe's classic story about the survival attempts of two men from very different cultures
A fine screen interpretation of Henrik Ibsen's play with Glenda Jackson in the lead role as a very unhappy woman
An ingratiating puppy dog of a film by Paul Mazursky about a young man seeking independence in a place synonymous with freedom
A compelling and unsettling film exploring many of the fears, aches and dislocations of contemporary urban life
The Company is a cinematic tribute by Robert Altman to ballet dancers who create poems with their movements across the blank page of the floor.
Both an eye-opening epic and an intimate portrait of a man who never really tastes the joys of freedom.
A riveting drama that reminds us that within each of us there is a a monstrous guard who given the chance could revel in the chance to hurt others.
Warmly human film based on Beth Henley's 1984 play. It will appeal to those who long for liberation from bad dreams and yearn for a place where they can be accepted for who they are.
Here is an immensely touching and compassionate film about the harassed and persecuted Kurdish people fleeing from Iraq towards the Iranian border; it will open your eyes and your heart as well.
Blue Car is a beautifully crafted and well-acted drama about the tug and pull of yearning in the lives of a tormented young eighteen-year-old poet and her high school English teacher.
The Dancer Upstairs is a subtle and sophisticated political thriller marking the directorial debut of John Malkovich.
Double your pleasure with this visually stunning and thematically inventive sci-fi spectacular where mutant humans battle the zealous forces of law and order.
The Matrix is a super-dupper sci-fi thriller that reveals the human imagination as a saving force in the universe.
A Man Called Horse is a mesmerizing film about the experiences of a British aristocrat in 1825 struggling to survive in a Sioux tribe.
A picaresque masterpiece about an inimitable American anti-hero whose wild adventures are delivered into our hearts and minds with the robust vitalities of comedy.
Buffalo Soldiers is a bold black comedy set on a military base in Germany in 1989 that snaps, crackles and pops with the same anti-establishment energy as Catch 22.
I, the Worst of All offers an illuminating and soulful portrait of Latin America's first great poet, who happened to be a brilliant nun in seventeenth-century Mexico.
A fine Latino film exploring the transformation of a conflict-ridden relationship between a Dominican-born store owner and his comic book illustrator son.
The Shape of Things is another hard-hitting drama by Neil LaBute exploring the power plays between the sexes and the clash between art and morality.
The Man on the Train is a marvelously acted French film about two men past their prime who cross each other's paths and yearn for something completely different in their lives.
movie_title: The Man on the Train (L'homme du train) (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Delivers many well-deserved satirical swipes at elitist day care operations that engineer small children for success in the competitive marketplace.
The Electric Horseman succeeds as an ode to individualism with a modern cowboy who makes a stand against a corporation and a New York reporter who loves her career above all else.
This uplifting drama, based on Loretta Lynn's autobiography, shows how her marriage kept changing to accommodate her career as the First Lady of country music.
This sci-fi extravanganza zeroes in on the contemporary mood in America with its relevant look at the spiritual firepower of hope in times when that faculty is battered and shattered on all fronts.
Sweet Sixteen is a gritty film directed by Ken Loach about the spiritual dynamics of hope in the life of a resourceful and brave teenager living in poverty in Glasgow, Scotland.
One of the best films of the year, this French drama is about an industrious young man's experiences abroad in Barcelona, Spain and his awakening to his mission in life and his unity with others.
Only the Strong Survive is a joyous tribute to soul music with some of the best singers of the 60s and 70s strutting their stuff on stage.
Spellbound depicts the unhealthy and oftentimes outrageous national obsession with the positive aspects of competition in the stories of eight finalists in the National Spelling Bee.
Confidence is a nifty caper flick exploring the greed that animates con men and the marks they prey upon with such gleeful abandon.
People I Know hits the mark with its sophisticated depiction of a worn-out PR agent desperately trying to find a way to redeem his sad and sorry life.
Under the Skin of the City focuses on a hard-working, strong-willed mother in Iran who demonstrates big-hearted courage in her life, perhaps more so than a soldier in battle.
movie_title: Under the Skin of the City (Zir-e Poust-e Shahr) (2003)

movie_review_blurb: A quirky drama written and directed by Robert Duvall in which he plays a hit man enchanted with the dance form that most exquisitely gives expression to his soul.

In this complex and soulful documentary, Steve James (Hoop Dreams) explores his caring relationship with a troubled young man and in the process reveals that no one can save another person despite good intentions.
Levity is powerful and poignant drama about a repentant murderer's quest to make amends with the sister of the person he killed years ago. This fresh exploration of forgiveness touches the heart.
XX/XY is a very revealing drama about one young man's indecisiveness and immaturity in matters of the heart.
Phone Booth is a taut psychological thriller about a scary encounter between a vigilante sniper and a self-centered publicity agent who is brought face-to-face with his sins of spin.
The Good Thief is a stylized heist film with an accomplished performance by Nick Nolte that celebrates the whimsical moves of Lady Luck in the lives of those who have nothing to lose.

Better Luck Tomorrow is an inventively delivered cautionary tale about some smart and upwardly mobile Asian high school students who, bored with their lives, embark on a course of violence and self-destructiveness.
Gallipoli is a powerful World War I drama about some Australian soldiers fighting in Turkey that depicts the horror and tragedy of war.
A bitterweet Spanish coming- of- age drama that shows how fear can sweep away childhood curiosity about life's mysteries.
A Chorus Line vividly conveys the anxiety and hopefulness of dancers trying out for a Broadway musical
Pastime is a thoughtfully made and intimate drama about a veteran relief pitcher for a class D professional team who turns to mentoring a younger player as his way of saluting the sport he loves.
Day for Night exudes all the enchantment, zaniness and transitory pleasures of the movie-making business.
Holes is a hoot from start to finish, one of the most deliciously imaginative children's films to hit the screen in many a moon.
Christopher Guest and Eugene Levy have a jolly time poking fun at the folk fads of the 1960s and the nostalgia for the movement's stars. Many laughs are to be had by all.
It is good to watch Chow Yun-Fat step on the stairs of air in his high-flying acrobatic moves, but even more enchanting to listen to his glints of Eastern wisdom spoken on busy city streets.
This compelling and disturbing Swedish film directed by Lukas Moodysson charts the terrors of an abandoned Russian teenager who finds herself an unwilling victim in the global sex trade.
Winged Migration is a glorious celebration of birds in flight, conveying the beauty, the amazing feats of strength and the endurance of their long distance journeys. Here is one to stir your soul!
Gives a worthwhile reminder that it is in the little details of life that parents, grandparents and children find enough sturdy moments of hope, happiness and bravery to make meaning.
This Boy's Life shows how a resilient teenager survives childhood trauma and adversity through independence, anger and creativity..
Psarminder Nagra gives a buoyant performance as an Anglo-Indian girl who has set her sights on playing soccer in a professional league.
Robert Redford puts in a stellar performance as a zealous prison reformer in this meditation on the ardor of idealism.
This wonderful comedy salutes human responsibility for making the world a better place and takes justifiable pot-shots at holier-than-thou hotshots.
Unusual, worthwhile and emotionally affecting film.
Deeply moving drama about two elderly sisters who discover that it's never too late to change.
Zany and thought-provoking social comedy
Touching drama about how the dreams of a mother and a daughter take them in very different directions.
A feel-good movie with some perky riffs on romance, beauty, and the value of an inquiring mind.
One of the most poignant and edifying films made in the 1980s about the blessings and burdens of family life.
Unsettling film about the racial bigotry which permeates every facet of urban living.
Explores the challenging relationship between two sisters and their eccentric aunt who marches to the beat of her own drummer.
Captivating as an ode to individualism.
In his debut as a director, Sam Shepard explores family dynamics and the passing of the male mystique of yesteryear.
Based on a Pulitzer Prize-winning play, this drama examines the complex roots of suicide.
A wacky and wonderful movie about three young women friends and their misadventures with love and sex.
This film adaptation of Margaret Atwood's bestselling 1986 novel heralds freedom as a cherished ideal.
Sigourney Weaver gives an inspired performance as a woman who launches a crusade to save gorillas in Africa.
movie_title: Gorillas in the Mist: The Story of Dian Fossey (1988)

movie_review_blurb: A magical movie about the emotional education of adults in a small Minnesota town.
Delightful caper movie which gives its actors the chance to rise to new comic heights.
Depicts one Afrikaner's journey toward moral responsibility in South Africa.
A heart-affecting look at a challenging father- son relationship.
Rob Reiner brings new life to the fairy tale as rousing entertainment for young and old alike.
A literate, well-acted movie set in 1908 that conveys how difficult and disarming it is to live in a world where no one can be trusted.
Wonderful, perceptive, and original Australian film about the magic and anguish of adolescence.
A sci-fi actioner with a surprising take on America's weapons of mass destruction.
Oh, God! Book II offers plenty of food for thought on the nature of God, the meaning of faith, the limits of psychiatry, and the importance of story-telling.
A rousing underwater adventure set in the Great Barrier Reef that celebrates youthful independence and lances the illusion that parents can make the world safe for their children.
A vibrant and touching Chinese film that tugs at the heart with its deft portrait of the challenges faced by a teenage musical prodigy from the provinces after arrivibng in Beijing with his father.
An enchanting, deeply spiritual, and ultimately enthralling New Zealand movie about the struggle of one ardent young Maori girl to fulfill her destiny.
The spirit of adventure is alive and well in this retooling of the exploits of a legendary hero; it dazzles the senses.
Offers a lively portrait of a marriage that weathers all storms and evolves over time into something more than it was at the outset.
A rambling, emotionally involving, and exuberent movie with flashes of cinematic poetry.
A road movie that transcends the genre with its wonderful offbeat and rounded characters.
Halfway through this fascinating drama, it becomes clear that the filmmakers are less interested in solving the crime than in conveying the spiritual dynamism of the Hasidic community.
A winning and well-acted portrait of America's entry into the Space Age that is awesome, funny, surreal and right on the mark in its depiction of the country's insatiable hunger for new frontiers.
John Houseman takes center stage with his near-perfect depiction of an imposing law school professor.
An incisive documentary portrait of a gifted sculptor and architect whose simple and elegant work has left its mark on these times.
movie_title: Maya Lin: A Strong Clear Vision (1995)

movie_review_blurb: A gritty and imaginative English film offering a grim portrait of societal disintegration during the 1980s in a country rife with racial tensions and a thriving underground economy.
This well-realized English film explores two powerful forces: the shattering consequences of adultery and the healing nature of forgiveness.
A moving tribute to the Christian theologian and martyr; it is really quite amazing to see how relevant the ethical concerns he struggled with are to the moral dilemmas of our times.
Warm Water Under a Red Bridge is a quirky and poignant Japanese film that explores the fascinating connections between women, water, nature, and sexuality.
movie_title: Akai Hashi No Shita Noo Nurui Mizu (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Eat a Bowl of Tea explores the pressures put on two newlyweds in Chinatown to meet the expectations of their community.
An ebullient comedy that will appeal to all lovers of animal's rights, people's democracy, inner flair and a heroine who believes in her own true valiant voice.
A mesmerizing and imaginative psychological thriller about the delights that can come when we explore aspects of ourselves that we have previously ignored or covered up.
This hilarious parable about the opening of a selfish man's heart reveals why all the world's religions treasure the spiritual practice of play.
Touching film about the friendship between a Jamaican housekeeper and a young boy.
Nowhere in Africa depicts the magical ways that Kenya stirs the soul of a young Jewish girl who adapts easily to the local culture and their earth-cherishing practices.
Laurel Canyon explores how the love of a serious and sober couple is challenged by the hedonistic sexuality of those they encounter in this California community.
A family film that contains some hefty thematic material on time, death, eternity, and what is needed to live a rich and full life.
An American masterpiece with Jack Nicholson as an angry and disappointed sixty-six year old whose heart is softened by a moment of grace delivered by a stranger from afar.
Writer and director Otar Iosseliani's pleasant tale about a factory worker who escapes for a holiday in Venice reveals how we all need a playful respite from the grind to refresh our souls.

The alluring city of Paris is a major character in this fascinating drama about a woman in transition to a new life, a monumental traffic jam and the alternative she finds with a stranger to the anger and frustration on the streets.
Almodovar is an imaginative teacher of emotional intelligence in this engaging film about two men who discover what William James once called 'the gift of tears.'
A bold and subversive film that cuts across the grain of what is popular and powerful in this high-tech age, speaking its truths with spellbinding imagery and the entrancing music of Philip Glass.
A refreshing Korean film about five female high school friends who face an uphill battle when they try to take their relationships into deeper waters.
Vividly conveys the passion, creativity, and fearlessness of one of Mexico's most colorful and controversial artists -- a captivating drama that will speak to the nonconformist in us all.

A compelling coming-of-age drama about the arduous journey of a sensitive young girl through a series of foster homes and a fierce struggle to pull free from her dangerous and domineering mother's hold over her.
Depicts the valiant efforts of some working-class residents of London to pull themselves out of a dungeon of helplessness and hopelessness.
A very literary drama that uses two intertwined stories to explore jealousy as a dangerous little mutant that sometimes is life-threatening.
A beautifully acted and emotionally rich film set in Nebraska about the unfolding of love and the damage done to a family by a long-kept secret.
A brutally honest documentary about a much anticipated family reunion that goes wrong thanks to culture shock and a refusal to empathize with others.
Salutes an interracial friendship between two Southern women and the ways in which enthusiasm can be a life-saving gift in tough times.
A remarkably alluring film set in the constrictive Eisenhower era about one suburban woman's yearning in the face of a loss that shatters her cheery and tranquil suburban life.
A light-hearted French film about the spiritual quest of a fashion model seeking peace of mind while in a love affair with a veterinarian who is a non-practicing Jew.
movie_title: God Is Great and I'm Not (2002)

movie_review_blurb: With its fascinating storyline and its adroit insights into human history, identity, and sexuality Star Trek: First Contact is a winner.
A wonderful Korean film that is a tutorial on the miracles that can be wrought by unconditional love.
Offers some fresh twists on the well-worn theme of sexual politics and shows how far some men still have to go to achieve emotional intelligence.
A kick-out-the-jams, no-holds-barred examination of America's obsession with guns and the fear-based culture that is at the core of the nation's rampant and outrageous violence
An intriguing look at the French film industry during the German occupation; its most delightful moments come when various characters express their quirky inner selves.
An imaginative and daring Palestinian film about the fights and feuds in Nazareth that have shredded community life and banished civility under the terror of Israeli occupation.
A winning comedy with its wry observations about long-lived friendships and the ways in which we all lose track of ourselves by trying to please others.
The Runner Stumbles is an exceptionally fine film about the exigencies of a religious calling and a critique of the legalism within Christianity.
A strangely compelling and brilliantly acted psychological drama.
We are brought face-to-face with the compulsions and yearnings which lie behind our alternating love and fear of life.
A bittersweet drama about the limbo of grief and how truth-telling can open the door to liberation.
This bold and cathartic drama deserves to be experienced by those who cherish intimate dramas about individuals struggling against all odds to practice love, compassion, and forgiveness.
An enchanting film that presents an audacious tour of the past and takes within its warm embrace the bounties of cultural artifacts inside St.Petersburg's Hermitage Museum.
This unflinching and compelling film about a Catholic order in Ireland that incarcerated those considered by the community to be fallen women will make your blood boil.
A visually alluring and thematically rich portrait of a nineteenth century Korean artist who defied categorization and was a true connoisseur of wonder.
A slow-paced Chinese drama about the aimlessness and ennui of two nineteen- year- olds who live for the present moment and have no plans for the future.
A marvel not only as a pioneering use of digital video but also as an affecting and multilayered parable about one woman's journey toward inner peace.
A tension-filled and heart-breaking drama about a dark day in Irish history-the massacre of 13 unarmed citizens of Derry by British soldiers out to teach them a harsh lesson about law and order.
Greg Kinnear gives a mesmerizing performance as a full-fledged sex addict who is in complete denial about his obsessive behavior.
A fascinating Italian drama about the clash in values that erupts within a family when their mother is under consideration for canonization as a saint.
movie_title: L' Ora di Religione (Il Sorriso di Mia Madre) (The Religion Hour) (My Mother's Smile) (2002)

movie_review_blurb: A deft morality play about a self-destructive writer who is transformed after a disastrous fall that affects his career and his marriage.
A scruffy and endearing film about the adventures of an amnesiac on the fringes of society where he finds more kindness that he can handle.
A wonderful French documentary about a diligent teacher in a one-room classroom who revels in those magical moments when learning yields insight and delight.
movie_title: To Be and to Have (Etre et Avoir) (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Graphically depicts the impact desire, coincidence, and fate have upon romantic relationships
A spellbinding African film about the modern condition of rootlessness, a state experienced by millions around the globe.
An enlightening documentary in which a 74 year-old MIT linguist and political philosopher speaks out forcefully and convincingly against all forms of violence.
movie_title: Power and Terror: Noam Chomsky in Our Times (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Bringing Down the House is a hilarious comedy about a brassy and bold African-American who helps renovate the lackluster life of a workaholic tax lawyer.
Whisks us away for more adventures that keep us on the edge of our seats cheering for these three young wizards whose resourcefulness in the face of the unknown is awesome.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (2002)

movie_review_blurb: A compelling and thought-provoking drama on the Armenian genocide after World War I and its toxic impact on the spirits and lives of some contemporary Canadians.
Gitai has made a quirky film about the origins of the state of Israel that provides insights into the source of present day Israeli-Palestinian conflict.
This cross-cultural comedy contains several very entertaining song-and-dance routines plus a hilarious use of a Billy Joel pop tune.
A fascinating documentary about English director Terry Gilliam's tilting at windmills in his attempt to make a movie about the impossible dreamer.
Welcome to the CIA where a zeal to battle against evil doers is grounded in role-playing, smooth deceptions and frequent danger.
How to Lose A Guy in 10 Days explores sexual politics in many winning and funny ways and proves that equanimity in a man is a great aphrodisiac.
movie_title: How to Lose a Guy in 10 Days (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Deliver Us From Eva is a funny romantic comedy with the message that we must never drive difficult people away since they have come into our lives to teach us something important about ourselves.
Death of a Salesman, directed by Volker Schlondorff, draws out the multiple meanings of this Pulitzer Prize-winning play by Arthur Miller about change, family and fatherhood, work and love.
Free Willy focuses on the friendship between a troubled 12-year-old boy and an orca at an adventure park. It will appeal tremendously to all "friends of nature," a term coined by Albert Schweitzer.
In this riveting film about political unrest set in Latin America, Costa-Gavras reveals why liberation and order are two of the most blood-soaked ideals in human history.
Stone Reader is a wonderfully imaginative documentary that will appeal to all book lovers since it is really an exploration of the filmmaker's enchantment with literature.
An engaging and marvelously acted romantic drama that is unhurried and at peace with the incompleteness of our understandings of love and life.

Open Hearts is a poignant and well-acted Danish drama that explores the idea that the strangers we meet can alter our lives in ways beyond our wildest imagining.It hits the mark with its many layered depiction of love and loss.
Hats off to Hunter and Hunsinger for their robust and rounded treatment of the emotional education of three vulnerable men who are not used to dealing with their deepest yearnings.
A thought-provoking and gripping portrait of two burnt-out zealots who are willing to do anything to stop the juggernaut of executions in America.
Amandla! is a stirring tribute to the formidable role of black freedom music in the long and arduous struggle against apartheid in South Africa.
movie_title: Amandla! A Revolution in Four-Part Harmony (2003)

movie_review_blurb: A macabre and intense psychological drama exploring memory and the dangers that can ensue from the far-fetched stories we tell ourselves about what is real.
Gloria boasts a tough and tender performance by Gina Rowlands as an ex-gun moll and showgirl whose nurturing instincts come to the fore when she is called upon to protect a little boy in jeopardy.
Bolivia is a riveting slice-of-life drama set in Buenos Aires that presents a harrowing look at urban poverty and the explosive impact of the hatred of foreigners.
An open-ended and minimalist drama about identity, fate and the harsh reality of wilderness experiences for only the most adventuresome filmgoer.

Amen. is a morally provocative screen interpretation of Rolf Hochhuth's controversial drama The Deputy that excoriates the refusal of Pope Pius XII to speak out against the Nazi extermination of the Jews.
An austere and haunting parable about a carpentry teacher's close encounter with revenge in which a moral imagination is met by the surprise of grace.
One of the best films of the year with its exquisite acting, inventive screenplay, mesmerizing music, and many inimitable scenes of tenderness, loss, discontent, and yearning.
An old-fashioned drama of substance about a teacher's slide down the slippery slope of dishonesty after an encounter with the rich and the powerful who have nothing but disdain for virtue.

Belongs in the company of The Year of Living Dangerously and other bold cross-cultural cinematic masterpieces; it couldn't be more timely with its critique of the arrogance of a nation that sets out to be the world's policeman.
These mini-dramas about women trying to find a way into the future point out how difficult it is for people to accept the generosity and kindness of others.
A spiffy animated feature about an unruly adolescent boy who is yearning for adventure and a chance to prove his worth.
A fluid and alluring sc-fi drama that hallows the mysteries of memory, love and yearning.
A wonderful spiritual adventure story about the arduous trek of three Aboriginal girls in Australia, this is one of the best films of the year!
A thought-provoking sci-fi drama that makes the point that the mysteries of inner space are as awesome as those of outer space.
The best movie in many a moon about the passions that sometimes fuel our best achievements and other times leave us stranded with nothing more than our lesser appetites.
An engrossing Iranian film about two itinerant teachers and some lost and desolate people they encounter in a place where war has savaged the lives and liberties of the poor and the dispossessed.
A heart-affecting portrait of a loving father whose nurturing instincts come to the fore in a crisis situation with his children.
Reveals how important our special talents can be when put in service of of others. It also shows how deeply felt emotions can draw people together across the walls that might otherwise separate them.
The values that have held the Enterprise crew together through previous adventures and perils do so again-courage, self-sacrifice and patience under pressure.

A tender and touching drama, based on the true story of a troubled African-American's quest to come to terms with his origins, reveals the yearning we all have in our hearts for acceptance within the family circle.
The Wild Thornberrys Movie is pleasant enough and the message of our close ties with animals can certainly not be emphasized enough.
A truly astonishing movie depicting the surprising and miraculous process whereby a youthful master of deception and a dogged FBI agent are transformed from enemies into friends.

Thanks to his high regard for the dramatic energies and the moral velocities of Nicholas Nickleby, writer and director Douglas McGrath has given us a marvelously entertaining version of the Dickens classic with a first-rate ensemble of actors.
This bold fim shows that racial hatred is a mystery and a moron. Here Adolf Hitler's hostile imagination skitters from drawings to an outpouring of rage against the Jews.
This harrowing drama provides a shattering portrait of the many stages and sides to grief and Philip Seymour Hoffman again demonstrates that he is one of America's foremost screeen actors.
Shows how the kindness of several courageous individuals and one surprising stranger help a worn-out and frightened Jew survive the ordeals of Warsaw during World War II.
A vivid portrait of an enthusiastic young priest who sets aside his ideals and devotion in the pursuit of power and sexual satisfaction.
Creatively covers one girl's coming of age and has more foot tappin' fervor since any flick since "Saturday Night Fever."
A perfect film for New Year's celebrations with its messages about personal renewal and starting afresh.
Revolves around a group of older Americans who face important choices which will determine their destinies.
Powerful drama that reminds us that hope is a precious and buoyant emotion that can give our lives substance and meaning.
movie_title: The Gospel According To Vic (Heavenly Pursuits) (1986)

movie_review_blurb: A basketball coach in a small town proves that lives can be reclaimed even if one has messed up in the past.
A hope-filled film portraying how the individual can make a difference and that humanity is capable of following its best instincts.
Celebrates the wisdom of indigneous peoples and the fine spiritual friendships they offer to us if we open up to a different way of being.
Delightful portrait of cross-cultural love that speaks softly but carries a lingering scent.
A two-fisted slugger, hammering across points about legal and familial ethics.
A case study of the dire effects of an individual's lack of ethical standards.
Examines a marriage under siege.
An inventive and lovely celebration of what director Terence Davies calls " the poetry of the ordinary."
A terrifying psychological drama about a brave modern day woman warrior.
Cautionary tale set in America in 2042
Rfeveals the delights and the drawbacks of small town life.
A behind-the-scenes look at Tinsel Town.
A fetching and enigmatic film about love, money and art.
movie_title: All the Vermeers in New York (1990)

movie_review_blurb: Rosie Perez steals the movie from the two male leads
Charts the life and exploits of America's first real superstar athlete.
Sinsiter and savvy psychodrama
A clever glimpse of the human condition via taxi drivers and their passengers in five different cities
A snappy, scrappy comedy about some of the universal problems which plague romantically involved couples.
Affecting portrait of an English couple whose marriage has hit some rough spots
Mesmerizing Chinese film about a woman who is zealous for justice
movie_title: The Story of Qiu Ju (Qiu Ju da guan si) (1992)

movie_review_blurb: Explores the subterranean emotions which can keep a family together or tear them apart
Charts a Jewish boy's rite of passage into adulthood during 1943 as an Army Recruit.
Riveting and powerful portrait of white supremacists and their virulent doctrine of hate.
Powerful teaching tool for men trying to come to terms with their own wounded father inside.
A soul-stirring movie that will rock you to your foundations if you come to it with an open heart.
September 11 takes a multidimensional approach to this tragedy that tutors us in heartful openness, arouses our compassion, and stuns us with prophetic truths we would prefer to avoid.
Thought-provoking romp by German film director Wim Wenders, a global hopping cinematic philisopher.
movie_title: Until the End of the World (Bis ans Ende der Welt) (1992)

movie_review_blurb: A wonderful cinematic valentine to the life-enhancing and soul-stirring powers of friendship.
Nora Ephron's wonderful adaptation of Meg Wolitzner's novel.
A startling film about a young South African boy's coming of age under the tutelage of three spiritual elders.
Scores some good points with its moral condemnation of an institution that puts saving money ahead of saving lives.
Shows that God moves mysteriously in our lives to work miracles while we are dealing with such seemingly insignificant matters as sausages, card games, ironing, and scrubbing the floors.
Explores the harrowing difficulties of compassionate action
An adult fairy tale challenging us to follow the imperatives of our hearts or risk losing our souls.
An interesting portrait of an artist whose detachment from the world and his own experiences has dire consequences.
Show how the unrestrained pursuit of greed makes people poor in spirit
Film noir about a person caught in a slow dance with danger and death.
Light-hearted English comedy with a hilarious wedding ceremony filled with bloopers.
Speaks to the universal human yearning for someone to watch over us.
Spellbing film about the capriciousnes of human nature and the soullessness of lives enslaved to wealt
Explores the personal and economic lives of a lower middle-class English family in hard times.
Benji's back after a ten-year absence from film, and teh dog star shows us what caring for others is all about.
Offers some interesting new twists on the well-worn theme of father-son conflicts.
A triumphant debut as a film director for Jodie Foster in a captivating tale about a pint-sized genius.
A scary overview of the dark side of the male psyche where paranoia, misogyny, and compulsiveness reign.
Armand Assante gives the most robust and impressive performance of his career as Cesar, a musician whose lust for life affects all those around him.
Thought-provoking and riveting, as both a poltical thriller and a partial problem solver.
Reveals how the consumer ethic has diluted traditional views of marriage so that it is held hostage to our desires for new experiences, self-fulfillment, and endless variety
Shows the aimlessness and amorality of youth who don't have a clue to the rituals that could give their lives meaning.
A compelling, intricately structured, and beautifully acted psychodrama.
movie_title: A Heart in Winter (Un coeur en hiver) (A Heart of Stone) (1993)

movie_review_blurb: Soulfully explores a young woman's journey to transformation
A love story set against the internment of Japanese Americans following Pearl Harbor.
A full-steam-ahead cinematic triumph propelled by the raw energy of a talented cast and the vibrancy of a dozen soul classics.
A fine study of what it means to be a rounded man
movie_title: My Heroes Have Always Been Cowboys (1991)

movie_review_blurb: Probes the value clashes in a middle-class Los Angeles black family
A rousing road movie about the journey of self-discovery of two women
Charts the efforts of a Puerto Rican drug-dealer just released from prison to put the life of crime behind him
A bright, buoyant comedy about an unusual mother-daughter relationship.
Explores the different shades of love in humanistic and hilarious ways
A movie that engages us with its distinctive blend of humor and heartbreak
A stylish political thriller animated by its incisive portrait of secrecy, lying and power in Washington, D.C.
A poignant movie that helps us to see that all moments are key moments and that those who are unable to accept love are lost forever
An interview with Oren Lyons, Chief of the Turtle Clan of the Onondag, who is responsible for passing on and interpreting his people's traditions, legends, and prophecies.
Vivdly shows how important the idea of reciprocity is to those who find themselves dependent upon others.
An old-fashioned film carried into our hearts with breathtaking scenery, a swelling soundtrack, and large-scale dramatic happenings.
A parable about the intellectual vanity of a creative individual who wants to improve society with his vision of the common man.
A mesmerizing interpretation of a Max Frisch novel about a globe-trotting engineer.
A convincing anatomy of urban loneliness.
Explores a volatile Japanese-American encounter in a steel town.
Engrossing French film set in Algeria during the 1950s and revolving around three sisters.
A keenly realized portrait of sibling rivalry, mean-spirited capitalism, and unflinching morality.
A psychological thriller that explores sexual politics from many perspectives
Explores topic of motherhood from many angles.
Depicts of bodyguards as modern day ascetics
Fine family entertainment and crosscultural tale of Haida Indian spirituality
movie_title: White Fang 2: Myth of the White Wolf (1994)

movie_review_blurb: A raucous film about the Beatles before they made it big
A congenial film about art and sex.
Daring movie that will appeal immensely to mystics.
Probes the ways in which the fabric of community can be destroyed by secrecy, injustice, hypocrisy and indifferece.
Hurrahs the vitality and variety of family feeling.
On-target with satirical shots at familiar films.
Probes the love/hate relationship between two brothers destined to follow different stars.
Reveals how only time and love can heal the wounds of grief.
Inventive depiction of the universal quest for home.
Engrossing film about sin, salvation and the End Times.
A British comedy about two mismatched friends.
Comedy starring Diane Keaton about a Yuppie who tries to have it all in life.
A fine gumbo of a movie, featuring a brew of police corruption seasoned by an unusual love affair.
An engaging and modest movie about how individuals in a small town are drawn together through their CBs.
A bold film from the Soviet Union, affirming the ethical values of religion and the cultural values of art.
I Capture the Castle is a well-acted and perfectly realized English drama about the crash course in emotions experienced by a sensitive and imaginative seventeen-year old girl.
The Housekeeper provides a nuanced and inventive anatomy of urban loneliness and the surprising way out that can arrive unannounced, just when we least expect it.
The finest moments are when the nineteenth century literary superheroes demonstrate their unique talents.
Zany and emotionally-affecting story about death, aging parents, reconciliation, and the healing power of selfless love.
An enlightening documentary about Tibetan rituals at the end of life.
An engrossing documentary charting the history of hundreds of Indian nations from pre-Columbian times to the Battle of Wounded Knee in 1890.
A touching love story
A comedy adventure story that reminds us how open and honest communication can break down the walls of fear existing between people and nations.
A documentary of the Dalai Lama's teachings on the Four Noble Truths.
movie_title: Four Noble Truths, The: His Holiness The XIV Dalai Lama (1996)

movie_review_blurb: A bitterwseet comedy about the challenges faced by women over fifty face as they try to put the past behind them and move into uncharted territory.
Shows how our most cherished relationships can wither and die from neglect, misunderstandings and a thousand little betrayals
movie_title: The Last Days of Chez Nous (1991)

movie_review_blurb: A mind-tripping exploration of science, ecology, politics and spirituality.
A paraplegic squares off against fear, anger, loneliness and despair.
A funny and telling look at a group of twentysomethings and their struggles to establish meaningful and intimate relationships.
A richly nuanced comedy of manners about the affect of a foreign country and its culture on two provincial souls.
An engrossing film that challenges us to think about the true meaning of heroism in this age of media-manufactured celebrities.
The Bible devotes more space to King David than to any other person. This fine drama gives us more clues to why this is so.
Australian director Paul Cox has made a brave, bold, and life-affirming film about what Cicero called "our play's last act."
Affectionately eavesdrops on the past and gives everyone a wonderful opportunity to re-imagine what it was like when this communications medium was king.
Depicts the 1963 Profumo affair in England as an episode in class warfare.
Probes the breakdown of moral fiber in one community and its tragic results.
High-caliber film about baseball, sexual politics, and letting go of impossible dreams.
A gritty and depressing portrait of gang warfafre in Los Angeles as an intractable urban problem.
One of the best films of 1987 with its searing condemnation of racism and violence in South Africa.
Fresh and funny film that offers a glimpse of how three members of the Baby Boom generation are handling the challenges of love and work.
Engaging portrait of seven women in a ghetto tenement who are struggling to overcome the hardships of poverty and the disappointments of shattered dreams.
Relentless thriller that quickens one's pulse as it startles the mind.
A hard-hitting morality tale about how the lines between right and wrong are being blurred in the very compettive marketplace.
A piercing examination of a family whose ruling passion is social justice.
The gravity and gaiety of the film makes its coming-of-age theme quite special.
Holds up a disturbing image of a consumer culture where trash is viewed as treasure and excess spells success.
A rousing screen version of the 1983 Tony Award-winning play.
A gangster fable about keeping one's word.
Entertaining and edifying journey into the far country of old age set in Australia.
Celebrates the indomitable spirit of entrepreneurs whose dreams can be dashed but never taken away from them.
movie_title: Tucker: The Man and His Dream (1988)

movie_review_blurb: An innovative and moving portrait of pioneer educator Sylvia Ashton-Warner
An exquisitely beautiful and well-acted film which explores both the dizzying pleasures and the painful dangers of romantic love.
A fetching film about how the closing of a boatbuilding business affects the lives of four men in a small Maine town.
Writer and director Cameron Crowe has taken the hackneyed subject of teenage love and given it some freshness.
Tom Stoppard's 1967 morality play has been translated into a high-spirited and well-acted film.
Reveals America's obsession with the beauty myth and how it violates the self-esteem of women.
An old-fashioned melodrama with equal doses of laughter and tears.
An audacious Belgian film with a creative exploration of the primal role of fantasy in our lives
A visually stunning screen adaptation of Virginia Woolf's 1928 novel.
A spiritually uplifting portrait of New Zealand poet and novelist Janet Frame.
Celebrates the courage and the hope of these refugees who are shamefully treated by both those who prey upon them and those who are quick to close doors on ethnic outsiders
Gives a fresh appreciation of the dynamic interplay between mind, body, and soul in the art of healing.
This compelling tale of adventure set in 17th century Canada is a spiritual classic
A thought-provoking film about cultural conflict, power, progress, and the dire consequences of messianic thinking.
movie_title: At Play in the Fields of the Lord (1991)

movie_review_blurb: A powerful and profound film about what is wrong with our cities and what it will take to save them.
Treating this 19th century novel with tender loving care and just the right emphasis, director Claude Chabrol has made it speak to our times.
Tender and touching film about two sisters whose close relationship is tested by the joy of love and the pain of grief.
Focuses on the mysteries, astonishments and vivid lessons of childhood.
Lampoons ethnocentrism and celebrates the values of cross-cultural experiences
Acomedy about life in the military that has more on its mind than just laughs.
Inspiring film that celebrates one severely handicapped individual's fierce determination
Noteworthy addition to the growing number of excellent films about the beginning of the nuclear age.
Serious film about the ethics of the men who ushered America into the nuclear age.
Charts the vocabulary of love within one household over a period of 80 years.
About a developmentally disabled young man and his compassionate brother.
Starts out as a vivid portrait of the Civil Rights era and ends up a cop drama in which vengeful anger is used against racist killers.
Gives romantic love a good name, thanks to the flamboyant performance of Gerard Depardieu in this classic.
A comedy which celebrates community and satirizes the advertising industry.
A richly nuanced and well-acted screen version of Joyce Cary's 1839 novel.
A light-hearted comedy about one woman's dream to remake her life
This film is a delightful social fable which celebrates the Good Samaritan idealism of an ordinary citizen who actually makes a difference in Washington
A first-class thriller and thought-provoking morality play.
An exquisite screen version of E.M. Forster's 1910 novel.
Miracles cannot be summoned by command, they happen spontaneously by grace, and often to those who least expect them.
A guilt-ridden Secret Service agent sezies the opportunity to redeem himself.
A satisfying screen version of Josephine Humphrey's 1978 novel about the education of a young woman's sentiments about love and marriage.
An intelligent and sophisticated screen adaptation of Michael Crichton's bestselling novel
A winning and soul-stirring exploration of the spiritual meaning of one man's sacrificial death.
A memorable drama about a young man's initiation into adluthood.
A touching meditation upon the spiritual concept of soul mates.
An intense consideration of work, a subject that is routinely given short-shrift by most American filmmakers.
An intense and gripping story of survival and heroism.
Explores the adjustments that must be made to keep a marriage together.
Danny DeVito gives the most compelling performance of his career in a gripping drama about a single parent and his two sons.
Succeeds admirably in showing us just how much love the heart can hold in the face of so many obstacles and so much pain.
Explores the searing power of evil.
Mercedes Ruehl's exuberent performance gives this family drama its staying power.
Rousing comic portrait of a dad who loves his kinds more than anything else in the world.
Offers a flinty portrait of a single mother of six, who is one-of-a-kind.
Should gather a few more converts to the idea that certain people are destined for each other.
A stunning and compelling exploration of the power of the imaginal world--the nonverbal realm of dreams and imagery.
The Piano is the most sense-luscious film to reach the screen in years. It shows how soul is realized through a fusion of body, desire and passion.
All Quiet on the Western Front is a classic anti-war drama.
movie_title: All Quiet on the Western Front (1979)

movie_review_blurb: A tour de force with excellent ensemble performances by the full cast, Platoon succeeds in conveying the multi-dimensional reality of the Vietnam War
French Postcards ambles along with an agreeable mix of comedy, pathos and cross-cultural observations.
A partly funny and occasionally toucing coming-of-age flick
Offers a fascinating look at Japanese tradition under the onslaught of modernism in a story of class consciouness and marriage.
A drama about a rebellious romantic with a stirring performance by Susan Pecoraro.
An excellent drama about female friendship, Secret Places exudes the kind of care and concern that makes intimate dramas so emotionally compelling.
John Hargreaves gives a tour de force performance as a man unhinged by the collapse of his marriage.
An uplifting portrait of one disabled person and his beautiful spirit.
A pensive Australian drama about work and meaning.
movie_title: Annie's Coming Out (A Test of Love) (1984)

movie_review_blurb: A well-acted screen adaption of a thematically rich 1980 British novel by Isabel Colegate about class conflicts.
Matthew Modine's affecting performance makes the coming-of-age flick click.
An engrossing Swiss film that offers a behind-the-scenes look at the cerebral sport of chess.
A snappy, inventive comedy with Chevy Chase.
An entertaining and thought provoking survey of a sport at the crossroads.
Registers as another high-flying James Bond adventure story.
Peter O'Toole's madcap performance is a wonder to behold.
A contemporary equivalent to the Hardy Boys adventure tales.
Clint Eastwood stars as the mysterious stranger who arrives in a town and challenges the citizens to fight evil.
Reveals the health club fad to be a hall of mirrors filled with self-absorbed individuals.
A black comedy about an ill-fated love affair and the nasty politics of a criminal clan.
A slight but quite revealing glimpse of a Yuppie couple's marital crisis.
Offers a breakthrough portrait of the pain and miunderstanding which result from demeaning social hierarchies set up by teenagers.
A gripping thriller that also challenges us to contemplate the ethical responsibilities of journalists.
A fine film about the beat that put bodies in motion from tap to ballroom to disco to break dancing.
