Mephisto is a powerful parable about fame as a disease of the spirit.
Evil Under the Sun is a nifty screen adaptation of a 1940 Agatha Christie novel.
Moonlighting shucks corruption in Poland and critiques the sharp edges of socialism.
The Trout is another example of director Jospeh Losey's fascination with the ambiguities of sexuality.
Eating Raoul is a lively black comedy about the aftershocks of the sexual revolution in America.
The Draughtsman's Contract is a thoroughly entertaining murder mystery set in 17th century England.
The Mango Tree reveals everything a good grandmother should be.
The Missionary probes the world, the flesh and the devil in fresh and funny ways.
Brimstone and Treacle explores the strange interface betwen sex and religion.
Still of the Night is a sophisticated murder mystery drama.
Yes, Giorgio is a fairytale for adults.
The Winter of Our Dreams is an odd Australian film about the dis-ease in two very different people's lives.
Clean Slate is a compelling offbeat morality play.
The Last Unicorn is sure to be a rare treat for lovers of fantasy.
Barbershop 2 is both entertaining and edifying with its funky portrait of the challenges facing many urban neighborhoods across the country.
Explores the twilight realm of longing where three youth embark on an alternatingly intense and playful voyage of discovery.
Disney's Teacher's Pet is a zippy animated feature with some clever musical numbers about a dog who wants to be a boy.
Miracle reveals in the dramatic story of the 1980 U.S. Olympic hockey team that giving oneself up to the Game is the highest calling in sports.
The Seagull's Laughter explores the dark side of a moral crusader's campaign to expose the evil deeds of an outsider in her community.
Kitchen Stories is an inventive and engaging drama about how our hearts are gladdened by the sweet surprises of unexpected intimacies.
Trail of the Pink Panther will appeal to slapstick fans of this comedy series.
Monty Python Live At the Hollywood Bowl displays this zany British comedy team's daffy humor to good effect.
movie_title: Monty Python Live at the Hollywood Bowl (1982)

movie_review_blurb: Lola is a well-acted film which showcases Rainer Werner Fassbinder's laser-sharp social consciousness.
Birgitt Haas Must Be Killed provides a revealing behind-the-scenes look at espionage-a realm where nothing is ever what it seems.
Deathtrap is a literate, swiftly paced and engrossing screen adaptation of Ira Levin's Broadway smash.
Smash Palace is a revealing and involving Australian portrait of splitting up.
Dead Men Don't Wear Plaid is a thoroughly entertaining spoof of Hollywood private eye movies.
Star Trek II: The Wrath of Khan works as both a science fiction adventure story and as a thematically rich drama.
movie_title: Star Trek II: The Wrath of Khan (1982)

movie_review_blurb: Don's Party reveals the silliness and immaturity of male bonding when it remains on the infantile level.
The Escape Artist is a riveting film about a son trying to prove himself to his father.
Making Love salutes the philosophy of different strokes for different folks.
Rocky III is an audience-involving film and it is to Stallone's credit that we cheer for the champ in both victory and defeat.
Annie is a happy--go lucky musical with a happy ending.
Poltergeist delivers real punch in its depiction of a family's struggle against forces they cannot understand or manipulate.
The Road Warrior is a rousing tale of survival set in a grim and violent future.
A Midsummer Night's Sex Comedy circles around the nuances of love-a web that both tantalizes and confounds Americans.
Tempest scores a few points in its treatment of the illusion of solving one's problems by running away from them.
An Officer and A Gentleman succeeds as both a magical love story and as a convincing portrait of one individual's passage into manhood.
Steven Spielberg's E.T. The Extraterrestrial touches the heart, engages the senses, and playfully challenges us to cavort with its allusive meanings.
Barbarosa comes along just when we thought Westerns were extinct: this gritty mongrel saga ought to satisfy all sagebrush devotees.
Tex explores the stressful relationship between two brothers living without adult supervision.
Fast Times at Ridgemont High explores adolescent energy with elan.
The Nest explores a platonic love affair.
Wrong Is Right is a cautionary tale about amorality.
Superman II is a lively spree brimming over with action and adventure.
The Four Seasons is a lively and engaging film about the strain and responsibilities of friendships among married adults.
Outland works as a sturdy morality play set uin an unsual environment.
The Long Riders is well-done film about the legendary Jesse James.
The Big Red One celebrates the lucky and the smart who survive the outrages and terrors of war.
The Great Santini is a convincing portrait of the battles between a military man and his coming-of-age son.
Bronco Billy depicts a genuine screen hero who incarnates the place that cowboys occupy in our slow moving dreams.
Urban Cowboy zeroes in the the desperate night life of frustrated individuals who find neither adventure nor fulfillment in their daytime existences.
The Blues Brothers is packed with lively music, fantastic chase sequences and nonstop slapstick comedy.
Carny is a tightly structured, atmospherically rich little movie that works.
Willie & Phil vividly shows the pain and unfulfilment that comes with the yearning for new experience that is so embedded in the American grain.
Touched By Love is a family film that exudes warmth and promotes the values inherent in trhe unique ability of human beings to care for each other.
The Getting of Wisdom demonstrates the painful aspects of trying to win the approval of one's peers during adolescence.
Middle Age Crazy examines the strange changes that come over a married man after he hits 40.
The Adventures of Picasso...And A thousand Loving Lies is a nimble-footed flight of fancy.
Stardust Memories is a somber meditation on the celebrity syndrome.
The Stunt Man is a brilliant and provocative film about the mad mad world of moviemaking.
Coast to Coast is a robst comedy.
Private Benjamin is a comic fairy tale with a delightful performance by Goldie Hawn.
Hopscotch offers a successful mix of adventure, comedy and romance.
Return of the Secaucus Seven delivers a rueful portrait of a handful of members of the baby boom generation.
Honeysuckle Rose is built upon the excellent music of Willie Nelson and Dyan Cannon's appealing performance.
The Shining goes halfway toward bringing back Franz Kafka's understanding of real horror as the evil that lies within.
The Empire Strikes Back is a total delight.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode V - The Empire Strikes Back (1980)

movie_review_blurb: On The Nickel reveals in a zigzag way the subtle, sneaky and important reaons why life is worth living.
"10" explores sexual yearning in a drama that is both funny and right on target with its depiction of the yearnings of men.
A compelling and informative examination of rape and what it does to the victim.
Time After Time is an inventive comedy-mystery.
Wise Blood is one of the best realized religious drama in many a moon.
The Europeans is an engaging study of manners and morals.
Nosferatu explores the Dracula legend in a way that is both serious and seductive.
movie_title: Nosferatu: Phantom der Nacht (Nosferatu the Vampyre) (1979)

movie_review_blurb: My Brilliant Career is a near perfect film exploring the efforts of an independent-minded farm girl to fulfill her dream of becoming a writer.
Best Boy is quite touching in its own meandering way.
The Marriage of Maria Braun can be seen as the story of a shrewd and ambitious woman or as a parable on the decadence of postwar Germany.
movie_title: The Marriage of Maria Braun (Die Ehe der Maria Braun) (1979)

movie_review_blurb: King of the Gypsies is a fine wedding of craft and creativity.
California Suite offers audiences a fine blend of laughter and variety which is the spice of good comic cinema.
Ice Castles lifts our spirits by giving a glimpse into the human side of an exciting sport.
Hardcore is a vivid and convincing parable about the dangers of spiritual pride.
Star Trek-The Motion Picture is a smart sc-fi thriller whose fascinating characters and thought-provoking plot are emphasized more than special effects.
Cuba showcases Richard Lester's knack for making movies with ragtag plots and colorful characters.
Simon is propelled by a witty screenplay and the energetic brio of Alan Arkin in the lead role.
The Fog is a ghost story with just the right balance of special effects artistry, menacing music and visual poetry.
The Tin Drum is a lusty, volatile, surreal and chlling view of the rise and fall of the Third Reich.
Serial is a whimsical parable about the burdens of always trying to stay up-to-date.
One-Trick Pony offers a satirical look at the music business.
From the Life of the Marionettes zeroes in on one troubled marriage and the ambiguities of human sexuality.
movie_title: Aus dem Leben der Marionetten (From the Life of the Marionettes) (1980)

movie_review_blurb: The Last Metro puts on vivid display Francois Truffaut's humanism and artistic craft.
Loulou is a dance macabre of three individuals trying to decide whether or not they want to change their lives.
The Black Marble is an engaging cop drama that stands head and shoulders above others in this genre.
Clair De Femme is a compelling story about the different ways three strangers help each other deal with the losses which cause grief.
Made-Up is a funny film that catches the different shades of beauty in the lives of a small cross-cut of women.
American Pop celebrates the vitality of music which seems to weather all changes and continues to serve as a vehicle for our hopes and dreams.
Eyewitness is a thoroughly engrossing thriller.
Tell Me a Riddle challenges us to face up to the rewards and pains of old age.
Modern Romance explores the dangers of possessive love.
Back Roads is a love story with real clout.
Fort Apache, the Bronx portrays the men in blue as neither Galahads nor roughnecks but as ordinary human beings who try to cope in a pressure-cooker.
Caddie is an exquisitely photographed film that chronicles the hardships of single parenthood.
Les Cages Aux Folles II is a barrel of laughs.
Charlie Chan and the Curse of The Dragon Queen is a full-throttle comedy starring Peter Ustinov.
movie_title: Charlie Chan and the Curse of the Dragon Queen (1981)

movie_review_blurb: One Wild Moment depicts four characters who dance nimbly around ethical questions in this French film about love.
Thief embues the crime story genre with fresh sophistication.
Nighthawks is a compelling movie with plenty of adrenaline-pumping chase sequences.
Lion of the Desert portrays a heroic figure who understands and exemplifies the spiritual dimensions of freedom.
City of Women reveals Federico Fellini's fascination with the mysteries of the opposite sex.
movie_title: City of Women (La città delle donne) (1981)

movie_review_blurb: Le Voyage En Douce gives the impression that the mind is the most erogenous zone.
Cocktail Molotov explores the generation gap and the sexual revolution in the lives of three displaced individuals.
A Small Circle of Friends is a romantic drama set in the Sixties.
Lost Boys of Sudan is an excellent documentary about the struggles of two African youth to adapt to their new life in America.
Hide in Plain Sight raises some important questions about the rights of individuals in the face of arbitrary institutional policies.
American Gigolo explores the flashy career of a male hustler.
The First Deadly Sin reveals just how crucial citizens are in the solution to a crime.
Resurrection is an extraordinary film about a healer and the power of love.
Raging Bull is a screen biography of Jake La Motta, a searing look at the sport of boxing and a riveting drama revolving around grand passions.
Tribute probes a middle-age man's sudden confrontation with his impending death and the need to reconcile with his son.
The Competition offers a winning examination of one person's struggle to come to terms with his understanding of personal achievement and his capacity to love.
Tess conveys the bleak determinism that makes this young woman's life so anguished.
Mon Oncle D'merique is a philosophical puzzle that lingers in the mind long after the closing credit.
Altered States explores the human drive to leave the body behind, to be born again, and to experience in the mind things that were once thought divine.
Inside Moves is a film that celebrates human solidarity and the true meaning of friendship.
Breaker Morant is a top-notch film about an injustice in the annals of military history.
9 to 5 works as a wish-fulfillment satire on male chauvinism.
The Mirror Crack'd is a thoroughly enjoyable Agatha Christie mystery.
Seems Like Old Times is filled with madcap scenes and zany one-liners.
Stir Crazy is a funny comedy starring Gene Wilder and Richard Pryor.
The Formula is an intriguing thriller that raises many questions about business ethics and the moral bankruptcy of the very rich.
All That Jazz compels us to deal emotionally with our own death and the values which give meaing to our lives.
To Forget Venice is an enchanting Italian film with eye inveigling visuals.
Stay As You Are reveals the challenges facing a compulsive womanizer.
Robert Et Robert is a bittersweet love story.
Foxes depicts the pursuit of happiness as a desperate ritual.
Yanks charts the difficulties of wartime love affairs.
Lindsay Lohan pulls out all the stops in her performance as a talented teenager whose unbridled enthusiasm sets her apart from her peers.
movie_title: Confessions of a Teenage Drama Queen (2004)

movie_review_blurb: The most compelling message of this unflinching, powerful, and haunting movie is that in Jesus' name we are obligated to extend our compassion to victims everywhere.
Slapstick comedies starring a Kalahari Bushman who discovers how strange modern cultures really are.
A robust screen adaptation of Doctorow's novel about class warfare, social change, and the gap between the rich and the poor
Before Sunset is one of the best romantic dramas of the year with a very intelligent and seductive performance by Julie Delpy.
Bonjour Monsieur Shlomi is an Israeli drama that nicely conveys a sensitive teenager's awakening to his own special identity and talents.
A spiritual thriller that holds up thanks to its rich themes and great acting
movie_title: The Name of the Rose (Der Name der Rose) (1986)

movie_review_blurb: Mesmerizes with its bold treatment of thecontroversial theme of class warfare and its top-drawer performaces by Robert Redford, Willem Dafoe, and Helen Mirren.
America's Heart and Soul is a celebration of freedom and individualism that presents a startling expose of our moral blindness.
Brian Dennehy gives a towering performance as a middle-aged architect in Rome on a special project that becomes an obsession.
A summertime love story tinged with dark humor.
King Arthur offers a revisionist portrait of the legendary leader and warrior that expends almost all its energy on one bloody battle sequence after another.
A documentary that tries to cover too much in its praise of big wave surfing.
Sleepover reveals the sad and meaningless goals of some adolescent girls in suburban America who desperately want to be seen as winners.
Reveals the need for unity and cooperation between the world-wide community of shamans.
movie_title: Fire on the Mountain: A Gathering of Shamans (1999)

movie_review_blurb: The Door in the Floor is one of the best films of the year with its mature treatment of loss, sexuality and the emotional education of a young man.
I, Robot is an engrossing sci-fi thriller with Will Smith playing a rebel with a cause in 2035 Chicago where robots are in abundance.
Zhou Yu's Train stars the incomparable Gong Li as a modern Chinese woman going back and forth between two men who feel unequal to her mystery and her beauty.
Touch of Pink depicts the romantic challenges of a gay photographer in London who is carrying on a fantasy life with the spirit of Cary Grant.
Maria Full of Grace contains a tour de force performance by Catalina Sandino Moreno as a courageous and adventuresome seventeen-year old Columbian.
Most of the comic sequences and satirical barbs in this comedy seem to have been recycled from the long ago past.
movie_title: Anchorman - The Legend Of Ron Burgundy (2004)

movie_review_blurb: A fine documentary on the life and work of this great Swiss artist and sculptor
movie_title: Artists of the 20th Century: Alberto Giacometti (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Spider-Man 2 takes comic book yarns to a new dimension of possibility with its sensitive exploration of emotions that help determine one's destiny.
Shows how the Bush Administration and its policies have served the interests of the haves and the have-mores with unjust domestic policies and a terrible and tragic war.
Proves that playing together can bring zest to any sagging long-term love relationship.
Japanese Story gives Australian actress Toni Collette a chance to demonstrate the full range of her acting skills in a cross-cultural tale filled with many surprises.
The Triplets of Belleville is an animated feature with two out-of-the-ordinary superheroes: a zealous old lady and a very fat dog.
Imelda is a fascinating documentary about the glamorous wife of Ferdinand Marcos whose power and wealth have insulated her from the suffering of her people.
Firedancer puts faces on a few of the many refugees from war-torn Afghanistan who settle in the United States and try to make new lives for themselves.
Bukowski: Born Into This presents a spunky up-close and personal portrait of a bohemian, cantankerous writer who stayed the course.
The Corporation is a hard-hitting, innovative and thought-provoking documentary about a beast that has grown too powerful and too dangerous to ignore any longer.
A convincing exploration of adolescence when one is tossed and turned by doubts about self and others and exhilarated by fantastic energy and derring do.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Kounandi, a tender and touching parable about sacrificial love in an African village, is immensely appealing.
Napoleon Dynamite is a quirky and appealing comedy set in Idaho about an oddball teenager who waits patiently until he gets his chance to shine on his own terms.
An underwhelming sci-fi flick with Vin Diesel as the muscle-bound anti-hero who speaks with violent actions.
An unappealing movie based on the popular comic strip character of a lazy, selfish, and cynical cat.
Doesn't have the bite or the kick to qualify as a memorable black comedy.
A flawed reworking of the Jules Verne classic that runs out of creative energy early in the story and relies too heavily on tiresome martial arts sequences
The Terminal is a light-hearted and thoroughly entertaining film about the joys that can be ours when we slow down, practice deep listening, and cultivate the art of patience.
Facing Windows is a top-notch Italian drama about finding your passion and devoting yourself to it with as much energy and enthusiasm as you can muster.
An extraordinary film about two wild tigers and the human beings who are changed irreparably by their encounters with these magnificent and mysterious creatures.
The Notebook explores the ways in which class separates two soul mates who are in love and compels them to dance on the razor's edge.
De-Lovely is an enjoyable musical biography of Cole Porter with a stellar performance by Kevin Kline.
A Cinderella Story misfires as a comedy and offers no fresh twists or clever turns on this ancient fairy tale.
The Day After Tomorrow deserves praise for rightly identifying the human race as the evil-doers who are responsible for the destruction of the good earth we inhabit.
Presents the bad news about the media monopolies and the many ways they are busy shredding the most precious principles of democracy.
A rousing documentary about the radical historian and activist who has risked all to proclaim his call for peace and justice in America.
movie_title: Howard Zinn: You Can't Be Neutral on a Moving Train (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Rosenstrasse is another morally sensitive and serious film by Margarethe von Trotta about women and their special brand of heroism.
Speaks to our hearts with its messages about responsibility, manhood, friendship, hope, self-esteem, and prosocial behavior
Speaks softly but delivers some provocative observations on sexual politics, family pressures, loneliness, single life, love, and romantic fantasies.
A compelling and important film which presents the anguish, stress and anger of one contemporary farm family faced with foreclosure.
Offers viewers an opportunity to clarify their own definition of "the good life," and to discuss some of the challenges of individualism.
A modern fairy tale about a deformed outsider whose innocence and gentle nature make him a freak in the eyes of the community he visits.
Conveys the ancient wisdom of the primitives who relish dream time and have found a way to dignify the different stages of life with meaningful rituals
A provocative comedy of manners
A thoroughly entertaining, fluid and wonderfully relaxed movie that delivers some of the finest ensemble acting to be seen on the screen for years.
A crisp comedy of manners about young urban professionals who, while quite capable at work, find themselves less apt when it comes to relationships.
Watching the suffering, growth, and personal renewal of these likeable characters we gain a fresh perspective on our primal feelings about the family circle.
A telling look at the confusions and challenges facing seven friends who have recently graduated from the same college.
An energetic and authentic portrait of a 12-year-old girl's coming of age that reveals the mixed feelings young people have about sex, rebellion, independence, and self-esteem
Offers ample and telling observations on adolescence, mother-daughter relationships, familial tensions, and the erotic yearnings of youth.
A very entertaining and involving movie boasting a cornucopia of delightful comic moments and scenes which go straight for the heart.
Nothing short of wonderful with its ten-year-old female protagonist and its steadfast refusal to set up a dualistic battle between good and evil.
An emotionally appealing film that taps into our primal feelings about money, power, pleasure, shame, intimacy, and love as a redemptive power.
Focuses on the adolescent struggle to define oneself and also speaks about honesty, risk, loneliness, and self-respect.
Focuses on the turmoil in the lives of a middle aged couple.
Bright Young Things is a frisky screen adaptation of a satirical 1930s novel about London's bohemian party animals.
Red Lights is a gripping and convincing French psychodrama with a tour de force performance by Jean-Pierre Darroussin.
Mean Creek is an intense and riveting morality play that vividly conveys the anger and violence that can result from machismo posturing.
Catwoman is not destined to have nine lives.
The Bourne Supremacy fizzles with its reliance upon a plethora of chase sequences to compensate for its failure to create an engrossing protagonist.
Intimate Strangers is an enchanting French film about listening as the catalyst that brings deep changes into the lives of two very lost souls.
A spunky romantic comedy about an enthusiastic young woman who transforms her lover with the good medicine of her personality.
The Manchurian Candidate does a fine job of reviving the paranoid thriller genre in this engrossing tale of politics, corporate power and mind control.
A timely, powerful, and surprising drama about the dangers of a fear-based culture and the soul-stirring power of love.
Thunderbirds revolves around a boring family of heroic do-gooders.
Code 46 is an intriguing sci-fi work with some unsual twists that have great contemporary relevance.
Collateral is an engrossing thriller set in Los Angeles about a procrastinating cab driver whose life is transformed by his encounter with a merciless hit man.
Little Black Book is a dismal comedy about one betrayal after another.
Open Water is not the terror masterpiece that many are claiming it to be.
Stander profiles a South African cop who turns bank robber, but the story of this rebel-without-a-cause is way overdrawn.
We Don't Live Here Anymore convincingly dissects the impact of adultery on two shaky marriages in a small New England college town.
Danny Deckchair is a pleasant Australian comedy about an inventive man who escapes his unsatisfying life to start afresh in another place.
Virgin charts the spiritual transformation of a rebellious teenager as she opens to her divine center, her nurturing abilities and her empathy for others.
It's Easier For a Camel examines the soul-searching of a very rich woman who discovers that real wealth lies in her imagination.
Princess Diaries 2 charts the selfish quest of a 21-year-old American to have-it-all.
A guided tour into the land of the long lived filled with poignant moments of humor, sadness, conflict, and revelation
Will appeal to children who don't want to grow up too fast and adults who yearn for the spontaneous play of childhood.
Celebrates a natural born lover who brings joy, pleasure, and sexual fulfillment to those who are lucky enough to be part of his extended family.
movie_title: A Home at the End of the World (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Saved! is a scrappy satire that pokes fun at the intolerance of some zealous Christians and makes a good case for the spiritual practice of hospitality.
Raising Helen gives Kate Hudson a chance to sparkle as a determined young woman who gives up her career to raise her deceased sister's three children.
A madcap movie about the risks, the chaos, and the delirium of making an independent African-American film in 1970.
Screenplay writer John Patrick Shanley fails to shed any new light on the thorny problem of senseless urban violence.
An old-fashioned movie about destiny.
movie_title: Manon of the Spring (Manon des Sources) (1987)

movie_review_blurb: An amphibian movie which introduces us to the world of the deaf and then moves gracefully into universality as it explores the difficulties we all face in love relationships.
It is sad to see an actress as talented as Ashley Judd repeatedly appearing in these women-in-distress movies.
Here is a Christmas package that should have been left on the shelf.
Features Robert Downey Jr. as a smooth-talking womanizer who meets his match.
Encourages us to turn our attentions to the art of healing, the choices involved in personal ethics, and the little virtues of life.
The magic is gone without Peter Sellers.
A lot of energy is expended -- and wasted -- in this implausible comedy about opposites attracted to each other.
Espouses a vigilante spirit that is morally bankrupt.
A sputtering comedy.
Filled with tart observations and clever asides on the warps of contemporary culture.
Revels in the discoveries of youth and the gritty and cathartic magic of Mississippi Delta blues music.
Goes the distance as a parable about what is really means to have heart.
The Middle of the World is an unusual road movie that celebrates the virtues of family solidarity and the enjoyment of simple pleasures.
movie_title: The Middle of the World (O Caminho das Nuvens) (2004)

movie_review_blurb: This wonderful Mongolian film is a total delight from start to finish; it speaks volumes about the ties that bind human beings and animals together.
movie_title: The Story of the Weeping Camel (2004)

movie_review_blurb: This sense luscious Korean film provides a luminous meditation on the wisdom of Buddhism and the ways in which life is an exquisite spiritual teacher.
Checkpoint is an unflinchingly honest Israeli documentary about the humiliations of the Palestinians every day and the pressures on the occupying soldiers.
Belson's treatment of this theme is far too heavy-handed.
This has to be the most overrated movie of 1985.
Yet another screen adaptation of an Elmore Leonard novel, but this one just doesn't work.
50 First Dates is another rude and crude stab at romantic comedy with Adam Sandler doing his thing.
Goodbye, Lenin! is a well-realized tale of nurturing love and a witty parable about the fall of the German Democratic Republic and the rise of global consumerism.
Hidalgo is an old-fashioned adventure yarn that works well and will appeal to equine lovers.
Here is a creative parable about a young Christian pilgrim from Africa whose quest to see the holy city is set aside as he undergoes a series of trials and tribulations.
A medieval thriller whose moral themes have great relevance to the crimes of today's rich and the powerful who see themselves as being beyond the reach of the law.
Spartan is a cautionary tale that will appeal to those who have had enough of the unreality concocted by Washington handlers and political power players.
Wilbur Wants to Kill Himself is a bittersweet Danish film that demonstrates that those who nurture others are the most beautiful souls in the world.
Secret Window is an intense thriller, adapted from a novella by Stephen King, that presents a rounded anatomy of resentment and anger.
Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind is a fascinating psychological drama exploring the manifold meanings of memory, love, desire and disappointment.
movie_title: Eternal Sunshine Of The Spotless Mind (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Intermission is an edgy and feisty Irish drama set in Dublin where a lot of angry people vent their rage on others.
Taking Lives is an engrossing thriller about a woman warrior who finds herself lost in the darkness during her obsessive pursuit of a serial killer.
Divan is an engrossing documentary about a father-daughter relationship, a search for roots, Hasidism, and a treasure from the past.
Noi is a quirky coming-of-age drama about one troubled youth's yearning to escape the ice, the snow and the predictability of his home in Iceland.
Wears out its welcome early as an interminably long comedy with a mannered and unfunny performance by Tom Hanks as the leader of a bumbling gang of thieves.
This comedy about politics in a small community must have looked good on paper, with Gene Hackman and Ray Romano on board, but it just fizzles.
It's nice to see a screen male get lessons in being sensitive, but Ollie's emotional makeover just doesn't wash.
It is as if each character is playing an instrument the way he or she wants, and the end result is nothing more than a cacophony of discordant sounds.
A paean to the loveable losers in show biz who give it all they've got but still cup up short.
A gross-out horror flick that reveals a total contempt for human life and ends on a predictable note of cynicism.
A movie so bad that it dares to give the old and worn-out term "the ugly American" new life and vitality.
A riveting documentary by Jehane Noujaim that gives a insightful and diverse behind-the-scenes look at the Al Jazeera news operation during Operation Iraqi Freedom.
An uninteresting saga without a smidgeon of creativity that peddles revenge and heroism based on egotism is not our idea of fun fare for families and little children.
Two vibrant performances by Luke Mably and Julia Stiles don't compensate for the wobbly screenplay and predictable finale.
The United States of Leland is an ethically complicated drama that creatively explores the mysteries of human nature that can never be tied up neatly.
A dramatically absorbing and psychologically rich portrait of a couple whose intimate relationship is falling apart and evolving into something quite different.
movie_title: Scenes from a Marriage (Scener ur ett äktenskap) (1974)

movie_review_blurb: Sherman's March is an extraordinary documentary by Ross McElwee that mixes American history, a romantic quest, and the search for meaning in the early 1980s.
Splash is a light-hearted comedy directed by Ron Howard that sparkles here and there thanks to its fairy tale elements.
Wish You Were Here features a smashingly good performance by Emily Lloyd as a spunky, erotic, and out-spoken teenager.
This psychological thriller about cloning doesn't take us into any fresh territory.
An over-the-top comedy about that unsatisfying emotion that undermines so many relationships.
Sacrifices storyline and credible character development for its single mission: keep it moving and shuck everything else.
Super Size Me is a creative documentary exploring the link between junk food and the obesity epidemic in America.
Valentin is a tender and heart-warming Argentinian film about an imaginative boy who wants to have a real family.
Instantly forgettable thanks to a mediocre screenplay.
An unusual prison movie where a doctor earns the respect of the inmates with his genuine interest in the stories of their wayward lives.
This delightful confection of short vignettes centered around java and smoking offers a whimsical glimpse of American envy, addiction, humor and pop culture.
Strayed is a richly developed psychological drama set in 1940 France as a widow struggles to survive the ravages of war with her two children.
Troy boasts one remarkable and poignant scene: a surprising encounter between a grieving king and the warrior who has killed his son and taken away his body.
Porky's has a good-natured nimble view of its sex-starved and wayward youth.
A funny and rollickingly good movie about the challenges of keeping a band together on the road.
With delightful new characters, Shrek 2 is the compleat family comedy about being happy in one's own skin -- just what we need in a country obsessed with extreme makeovers.
A fanciful French drama that explores the shadow side of games in the lives of two very close friends.
Le Beau Marriage probes the idea that one can make love happen by an act of will.
Mean Girls is a spiffy morality play set in a Midwestern high school about the sharp edges of gossip and the cruelty of cliques.
Against the Ropes is a rousing drama about a pioneering female boxing manager whose gift of enthusiasm is something special.
An engaging behind-the-scenes look at playful creativity.
Tries to justify revenge by hooking it into the myth of redemptive violence -- it doesn't work.
Vividly depicts the changes taking place in the lives of the working poor in Brooklyn now that the traditional safety nets no longer protect them.
This incredibly moving film set in a small village in Pakistan in 1979 explores the religious upheavals that turn a nurturing mother's life upside down.
A rigorous Chilean film about all the challenges faced by a poor teenage girl who is forced to take charge of her own life at an early age.

Writer-director John Hughes' snappy and thought-provoking film about adolescence.

movie_title: Evil Angels (A Cry in the Dark) (1988)

A mesmerizing drama about the potent force of small incremental doses of hope.
An absorbing religious drama.
A bizarre documentary about the worship of technique and the dangers of self-delusion.
movie_title: Mr. Death: The Rise and Fall of Fred A. Leuchter, Jr. (1999)

An expanded DVD version of the classic tale about demonic possession and exorcism.
movie_title: Exorcist: The Version You've Never Seen (2000)

Stars Kenneth Branagh as a vigorous man of action who sets out to accomplish his mission with firm resolve.

Depicts how the ardent Christian faith of a true believer compels his two associates to probe their own ideas and ideals.
A bold and imaginatively realized profile of a defiant artist slowly sinking into madness.

movie_title: The Man in the Iron Mask (1998)

A beguiling Spanish film about the creative process and the transitoriness of the natural world.

An earth-cherishing drama about the restorative powers of nature, friendship and nurturing.
