A spiffy heist flick that spins a complicated web of crime and reveals the importance of secrets to the rich and the powerful.
A quirky coming-of-age drama set in a small town in 1974 that revolves around the mysteries of love, loss, and human yearning.
A joyous and kind-hearted romp with Horton the caring elephant who is on a mission of mercy for the small ones.
movie_title: Dr. Seuss' Horton Hears a Who! (2008)

movie_review_blurb: An extraordinary documentary about the spiritual lessons learned by six blind Tibetan youth on a grueling Himalayan mountain climb with Erik Weihenmayer.
A fantasy adventure with the questionable uplifting message that revenge tastes sweet.
An appealing romantic comedy that will inspire you to retell the story of your own romantic journey.
An enlightening documentary about a serious problem in Ethiopia suffered by poor women who have had obstructed pregnancies.
A mediocre Woody Allen drama about class, money, sex, and crime.
Life in a black Alabama community in the 1950s and the frantic efforts of a juke joint manager to keep his club open.
Probes in a light-hearted way the problems of individuals for whom the yearning of passion spells discontent.
Resnais raises more questions than he answers in this fascinating three-section parable about utopianism, education and love.
movie_title: Life is a Bed of Roses (1983)

movie_review_blurb: The journey to America by an Italian peasant and his family, conveying their yearning for a new life in scenes of magical realism.
An important cinematic work which celebrates the human imagination as triumphant.
A torrid sexual romance between two students at Beijing University set against the backdrop of changes simmering in China in 1989.
A flat and poorly written drama about three buddies who are drafted and have 30 days to report.
A romantic comedy that salutes cynicism over making others happy.
A Brazilian slice-of-life drama set in a working-class household where a disappointed woman undergoes a midlife meltdown.
An engaging parable about the dire effects of giving in to the Western obsession with money.
Four unappealing mini-dramas about happiness, pleasure, sorrow, and love.
An emotionally rich documentary about the extraordinary Bar Mizvah of a spiritually vibrant 13 year-old boy with Down Syndrome.
Five women in a beauty salon in Beirut struggling to find their small share of happiness as they buckle under societal and religious pressures.
An artful and philosophical film, filled with visual riches and mystifying scenes, about change, loss, and the difficulty of letting go.
A powerful and poignant film about an Ethiopian Christian's long and dramatic spiritual journey in Israel.
movie_title: Va, Vis et Deviens (Live and Become) (Go, See, and Become) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: A poorly acted and instantly forgettable supernatural thriller.
An emotionally touching Brazilian film about the spiritual riches and rewards of hospitality experienced by an abandoned and lonely young boy in a strange place.
movie_title: The Year My Parents Went on Vacation (O Ano em Que Meus Pais Saíram de Férias) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: An enchanting and parabolic film by Tunisian director Nacer Khemir about the beauty, grace, humility, and love of the Sufi path of the heart
movie_title: Bab'Aziz: The Prince Who Contemplated His Own Soul (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A hard-hitting documentary against the madness of war and the failure of journalists to speak truth to power.
A depressing drama about a Hollywood shrink who has it all and is experiencing a crisis.
A memorable story about the power of synchronicity to change peoples lives by helping them realize their connection to the great web of life.
An imaginative Israeli film about loneliness, missing persons, and the value of truly being present with others.
A comedy boasting fetching performances by Saturday Night Live stars Tina Fey and Amy Poehler.
A documentary about the last ruling King in Africa which shows that the offspring of absolute political power is injustice.
A poignant and passionately presented depiction of church-sanctioned violence against Jews.
A poignant and heart-affecting screen adaptation of a 1996 novel about suffering and the redemptive power of love.
A riveting drama where the ethics and rigorous idealism of a gifted Jiu-Jitsu teacher are challenged.
A superhero flick with the message that an arms dealer can see the light and give up the business of making a profit on the death of others.
A tedious movie about kids making an amateur film.
Another dreary and predictable romantic comedy centered around a wedding.
The screenplay has an air of unreality and doesn't hang together.
A poignant drama about an Englishman's power games in colonial India that bring havoc to the lives of those around him.
Back to Narnia for more battles and a lesson about how things don't happen the same way twice.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: Prince Caspian (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A parabolic Israeli film which speaks volumes about the nature of devotion to God.
Three generations of Garcia women trying to spice up their lives with sex during a hot and boring summer.
movie_title: How the Garcia Girls Spent Their Summer (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A clever and playful Norwegian film about two friends and their literary adventures.
A gritty and poignant Mexican drama about the search for family.
An engrossing Argentinean film about a 15-year-old intersex youth who struggles with both her masculine and feminine identities.
Impresses with its ability to revive our fondness for this hero and his improvised way of handling all the dangers, challenges, and surprises that come his way.
movie_title: Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Depicts the messy and complicated feelings connected with familial love, commitments, and dealing with strangers.
movie_title: Auf der Anderen Seite (The Edge of Heaven) (On the Other Side) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Dares to explore the creativity and the courage that go into compassionate action during wartime deprivation and violence.
A nifty story about some sympathetic and idiosyncratic characters struggling with love and reaching out for their small share of happiness.
A not very fresh or funny glimpse of power players in Hollywood.
A playful, delightful, and surprising exploration of love's mysterious ways.
A remarkable documentary about inmates at an Alabama prison who do a 10-day silent meditation retreat which opens them to the experience of inner peace and compassion.
Two friends in Rwanda dealing with the fallout from the genocide which lingers in their consciousness and souls.
Explores the rawness of one teenage girl's feelings as she rides the roller-coaster ride of ups and downs in a mysterious and enthralling relationship.
A thoroughly enchanting drama about an up-tight and driven woman who is softened and opened up by the slow and sensuous rhythms of island time and living in the present moment.
A gritty look at the nurturing love of a foster mother in a Manila slum for a three-year-old boy.
A riveting documentary about some impoverished African-American survivors of Hurricane Katrina.

Profiles of Palestinian hip hop groups who are using their music as a creative protest against the injustices heaped upon them by the Israeli occupation.
A charming French romantic comedy that salutes love as the only thing that can truly turn your world around.
A spunky, memorable, and emotionally touching Italian film about the quest for personal transformation through politics.
movie_title: Mio Fratello è Figlio Unico (My Brother Is an Only Child) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A mediocre heist film with a preposterous finale.
Sheds light on a shabby military policy that treats vets of the Iraq war disgracefully.
Story of a strong, independent, and resilient woman who is willing to do anything to save her family and her way of life in Inner Mongolia.
A searing documentary that reveals the courageous antiwar heroism of a Iraq war veteran who is paralyzed from the waist down.
A wild performance by Mick Jagger and the Rolling Stones, who really know how to give it all they've got.
A scrappy and imaginative tale about a resourceful 11-year-old girl who learns how to become the hero in the story of her own life.
An odd hybrid of a sports flick and a screwball comedy that just doesn't work.

Illustrates how the difficult people in our lives can teach us a thing or two about intimate relationships.
Depicts the way a professor's closed-off heart is opened by music, friendship, and love; one of the most touching and impressive films of the year.
A sharp and engaging study of the yearning for academic success; unfortunately, its impact is thrown out the window with a shocking and depressing finale.
Little dramatic flare and few insights into politics or the Presidency.
A soul-stirring film that activates our feelings of empathy with illegal immigrants in America.
An intense and creative dramatization of the midlife crisis of a theater director whose fear of death and physical deterioration compels him into a mammoth project to give his life meaning.
A zany comedy about the unpredictable and tricky nature of love.
A nuanced and fascinating film about a Russian scientist's journey home to Moscow after living in the United States for 17 years.
A brisk and well-acted political thriller about power, friendship, murder, and greed.
A quirky coming-of-age drama that will draw you in with its spiritual undertow and delight.
A poignant and sobering depiction of the struggle of gay Muslims in 12 countries to reconcile their sexual orientation with their faith.
A hard-hitting and distressing documentary about what lies behind infrastructure failures in New Orleans and elsewhere in America.
A top-drawer documentary that provides the perfect occasion for families to celebrate together the wonders, diversity, and miracles of nature and animals.

A deeply spiritual movie about the moral complexities of helping another person, opening one's heart, feeling the pain of another, and letting go of the need to fix that person but instead to simply be present in love.
A moving and important movie about the healing power of empathy in the continuing Israeli-Palestinian conflict.
An Argentinian film that offers some fresh twists and slants on the challenges of middle-age.
A musical adventure that follows an American banjo player to Africa where he discovers the power of music to bring people of very different cultures together.
A sci-fi computer animated film about some nasty invaders and a resourceful teenage girl.
A successful mix of action sequences and exploration of the emotional conflicts of the mutant hero, plus pop culture references.
A dysfunctional Turkish family struggles with the burdens of guilt, denial, and betrayal.
A dreary drama about three lonely and self-destructive souls.
A pretentious and tedious tale of a killer on a mission.

An operatic drama about a power-hungry Italian politician and his nefarious cronies.

A delightful drama about a seasoned mentalist who has seen better days and yet can still engender genuine wonder in the minds of his audiences.
An engrossing documentary on the life and work of Amazonian activist Sister Dorothy Stang and the trial of those involved in her murder in 2005.
A portrait of how an enthusiastic woman brings freshness and novelty into the life of a longtime maid who has sunk into exhaustion and depression

It is obvious that the creative forces did not take the film to seriously and if you do not, you just might find yourself laughing along.
The ending could have worked, but much like the rest of the film, it was a lazy and uninspired effort.

Sadly, it seems that someone thought they could make a buck by releasing one of Aaliyah's last works and have given audiences a film that is insensitive to her passing and is easily one of the worst I have seen.
Quote not available.
The Force is Back in a Big way.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode II - Attack of the Clones (2002)

movie_review_blurb: A Slinging good time
Dig This Groovy Flick.
Jacks Back in this Gripping Thriller.
A good premise that becomes lost in this stale and uninspired film of endless war movie cliches.
The classic cartoon is brought to life in this faithful recreation.
Who am I is the question that drives this tight thriller.
Everyone should run from this film lost it's own absurdity and blandness.
What Would You do with $40 Billion?
How to ruin a movie franchise made simple.
A pleasant if flawed summer diversion.
Ford, Bigelow and Neeson deliever a gripping and entertaining film that makes you think.
A blast from the past in this modern Z-movie creeper.
Sad, Tired, and very uninspired this Austin is all shagged out.
The Best Just got Better.
movie_title: Star Trek II: The Wrath of Khan (1982)

movie_review_blurb: All Signs point to a great Thriller in this Modern Classic.
XXX Marks The Spot!
The laughs are to few and far between to make this film work.
This Tux should remain a rental.
Finally a follow up to Lambs that works.
Sets out to be The Shining at sea but sinks quickly.
Better than the last but still in desperate need of a pulse as it is largely lifeless and dull.
movie_title: Lara Croft Tomb Raider - The Cradle of Life (2003)

movie_review_blurb: An Oscar worthy classic comes to the screen in this gripping and emotional film triumph.
A Very funny and enjoyable third slice of the pie!
While it staggers mightly from the source material, the film is a good rental for fans of Action who do not wants plot to get in the way of the mayhem.
"Walking Tall" is an entertaining film that works thanks in large part to the charisma of The Rock.
Even though it borrows heavily from "Risky Business", "Girl" is a coming of age film that is finally done right.
A plodding mess that does not do justice to the memories of the brave individuals who inspired the film.
A gripping urban action film that finally does justice to the comic.
Not as good as the first but despite the slow pacing, Bill 2 delivers.
Better luck next Time Nia, Connie and Carla is a real drag.
Simply put, Godsend is God Awful.
Stiller and Black are wasted in this uneven attempt to mix a black comedy with social commentary.
What could have been a solid film is rendered lifeless and should be left to fester in a sealed tomb.
While it is a letdown from the original Tippett and crew get the most out of the limited budget and make a mostly entertaining if flawed follow up.
movie_title: Starship Troopers 2: Hero of the Federation (2004)

movie_review_blurb: The Day After Tomorrow is a Chilling Mess that is so devoid of any real entertainment value that it sets the disaster film genre back to the Ice Age.
Slick and Scary this Potter is a welcome treat for the summer movie season.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Ambitious and amazing Riddick is a welcome surprise in what has been a lackluster summer film season.
A dreadful mess that is so bad, it makes The Cat in the Hat look good by comparrison.
Strickly for the family audience as the restrained Chan will probably not please longtime fans.
Hanks and Spielberg are solid and they yet again work well with one another, making the Terminal a delightful stopover.
A pleasant surprise that will leave you laughing and wanting to take the court again.
Despite a plot filled with holes, there are several funny moments in this film. Though over the top, the laughs come at a steady pace.
Regardless of your political leanings, this is a must see film that is captivating to watch and makes you top and think.
Believe the Hype, this is not only the best Comic book film ever made, but one of the best films of the Year.
Although it strives to be the complete story of Arthur, it ends up being an basket of empty promises that leaves you wanting more.
I Robot Delievers everything you want in a Summer film and more.
Watch out Bond, here comes Bourne, Jason Bourne to challenge for the title of superspy of the silver screen in this relentless thriller.
Village of Idiots would have been a better title as this film has huge issues with logic, pacing, and suspense.
Gritty and Intense, Mann has crafted a gem that is one of the best films of the year.
AVP" combines the old fashioned monster and haunted house movies of old to create a daring mix that will delight fans.
While not a great film, "Anacondas" does offer some Bite for late summer audiences and is a step up from the previous film in the series.
movie_title: Anacondas: The Hunt for the Blood Orchid (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Perlman does his best, but the script and direction by Guillermo del Torro is so stagnate that many of the jokes and action sequences fall painfully flat.
Mac aims for a homer but hits a single in this paint by numbers comedy.
A surprisingly good and thrilling update of the 1975 classic that will please fans old and new.
A very Funny Blast from the Past. Still and Wilson have a great chemisty and they keep it light and fun.
In this summer filled with over hyped mis-fires, "S.W.A.T." is an entertaining film that is ready to serve.
Chan slips with this disappointing snoozer.
Slightly better than the first but still lacking anything new or original, this Creep should have stayed asleep.
A few laughs, but the film drags on and comes across as a 5 minutes sketch that is dragged to a feature length, and well past the point of the material being funny.

Banderas is sold as the Mariachi who is driven by his desire for revenge while doing what is best for Mexico. His character is a folk tale that dispenses justice while fighting for honor and virtue like a modern saint. The intense action is handled well b
movie_title: Once upon a Time in Mexico (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Writers Kevin Grevioux and Danny McBride are to be commended for breathing new life into the genres as he gives us a tale that entertains yet expands upon the traditional lore of the creatures and if for nothing else, that alone makes "Underworld" pure en
"The Rundown" a pleasant surprise and should establish The Rock firmly as an action star to contend with.
Kill Bill is a dazzling combination of action and visuals that will delight some and frustrate others who are looking for more depth to the story of old fashioned revenge.
While "Radio" is at times overly sentimental, the fine work by Harris and the Oscar worthy performance of Gooding JR. make the film well worth seeing

Zucker has some good stuff but the film just does not have enough funny material to sustain the momentum as some jokes soars while others crash and burn causing the film to run out of gas far to early
Despite the years, "Alien: The Directors Cut" is a film well worth seeing and a classic for the ages.
Master and Commander The Far Side of the World is one of the best films of the year and a likely Oscar contender not to be missed.
movie_title: Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World (2003)

movie_review_blurb: This cat is little more than Litter Box Fodder.
movie_title: Dr. Seuss' The Cat in the Hat (2003)

movie_review_blurb: A Dysfunction Christmas Classic is here.
Dont let the previews foool you, Paycheck is a suprisingly fun and entertaining film.
The trilogy ends as it beagn. A good film that is overhyped to hysterical proportions and nowhere near as good as it is made out to be.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King (2003)

movie_review_blurb: While predictable, Polly moves along nicely thanks to the charm of Stiller and the fine supporting work by Hoffman and Brown.
A twisted, and creepy modern classic that is not to be missed.
Although parts of it play out like a TV movie of the week, "Mirac;e" delievers in the end.
Pull up a chair and enjoy this funny trip back to the shop.
The chemistry between sandler and Barrymore is great making "50" the years best Romantic Comedy to date.
Easily the best Boxing film since the Original Rocky.
A laugh out Loud romp that is easily one of the funniest films in recent memory.
A spectacularly unfunny film that wastes the talent within.
Gibson has created a well-crafted film that not only makes the audience think but ask questions. Passion is easily one of the most important films of the last decade.
This is one Dreadful mess that drags the worn out premise to the point of annoyance.
A who dunnit that will leave you saying who cares.
Depp is amazing in this bizzare tale of a world turned upside down.
Indy's back for a nostalgic and action packed adventure.
movie_title: Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Lucas has crafted a dark, mature and richly visual masterpiece that is easily the crown jewel of the Prequel Trilogy
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode III - Revenge of the Sith (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Norton and Leterrier have pulled off a solid action flick that mixes in a touch of humanity for a winning summer movie experience.
While it is not as bad as I expected, it is pretty much a guilty pleasure that you can enjoy in parts and then quickly forget as this film is not likely to enhance the legendary status of Godzilla.
It is an action film that actually gives fans a story, solid characters, and an interesting premise.
movie_title: Live Die Repeat: Edge of Tomorrow (2014)

movie_review_blurb: In the end the film does have plenty of visual entertainment but it drags out to the point where even the action and technical brilliance of the film and the 3D effects grows old.
The film attempts to combine a buddy road trip with some deeper human issues but this is not "Thelma and Louise".
A detailed and nostalgic look at how gaming has rose from the days of Atari to be one of the biggest industries in the world.

Taking on such difficult subject matter without becoming overly preachy was a strong point of the film as it not only entertained but raised some very good questions and social commentary while allowing the audience to make up their own minds.

Writer/Director James Gunn has hit the film out of the park with his big-budget debut and clearly shows that he knows his material well and does not let the film become overshadowed by visuals and action.
For the visuals alone, I would say the film is worth seeing as long as you temper your expectations accordingly.
While much of it like the cast looks tired and aging, there are a few no brainer thrills to be had. I just wish they had not sold out for a PG-13 rating as the film suffers from it.
Rodriguez, who acts as his own editor, offers multiple bookends and stacks the climaxes leaving the film as a whole with uneven pacing.
movie_title: Frank Miller's Sin City: A Dame to Kill For (2014)

movie_review_blurb: As it stands the film should delight fans of Smith but also allows him to expand his audience into new areas as this truly is one of the more memorable and entertaining films of the year.
Check out Skewed and Reviewed's take on The Maze Runner.
Check out Skewed and Reviewed's take on This is Where I Leave You.
movie_title: This Is Where I Leave You (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The cast is first-rate specifically Downey Jr. and Duvall who do Oscar quality work in their roles.
The film is very good for budget Science Fiction as the FX work is first rate. This is a take with humanity at its core, and Banderas does solid work.

The film is at best a guilty pleasure because it will be easy to say it was kind of dumb and meandering at points and that the two characters were not given much to do other than an act that was funny 20 years earlier.

In the end "Blackhat" is a good concept but sadly one that is not executed well and tries to succeed passed on the presence of Hemsworth who sadly is fairly monotone and uninteresting in his characterizations of Nicholas.
In the end the film has enough action and interesting characters to make it a fun, if flawed, romp and the cast is interesting enough that I am already hoping for future adventures for the Kingsman.
One would think that this premise would be able to produce some funny moments, but sadly the film is painfully slow and plodding and most shocking of all, very, very unfunny.

Unfriended provides some entertainment for fans provided you can sit through the unusual visual presentation of the film and show patience with some of the leaps of faith that the audience is asked to undergo.
Wheedon, Marvel, and the talented cast have created an epic summer action film which is everything you would expect from a super hero movie and more.
Fury Road is a lavish spectacle that is one non-stop ride of intensity that is as my wife put it, "pushing me so far back into my seat that I am almost in the row behind us".

The big draw is Piven, as he commands every scene that he is in. He he reminds us of why he won three Emmy Awards for his portrayal of the character, and I will honestly say I think he should be given Oscar consideration for his performance in the film.
"Jurassic World" is a welcome return to the franchise, one that for me is the first true sequel to the original as I enjoyed it more than the two films that followed.
The action is solid from an epic bus chase to intense firefights across the timelines the film grabs your attention the way the best summer films do and takes you on an epic thrill ride.

The film takes a bit of time to get up to speed but is as charming and funny as you would wish for. The Minions generate plenty of laughs and there are tons of Pop Culture gags that fill the entire film.

The film does take some time getting up to speed as it is after all an introduction story but with the pleasant comedy and great FX mixing with a satisfying final act, "Ant-Man", is yet another winner for Marvel.
Oculus definitely is a must see for those into psychological thrillers, the ending will leave you wanting more.
Rogue Nation is a fast, clever, and entertaining action film which will keep you entertained throughout.
Brutal, relentless, and intense. The sequel takes the best elements of the original and takes them to a new level. This is one not to miss.
This movie is really charming without trying too hard.
The film takes a bit of time to get up to speed, but thanks to Downey's performance you maintain your interest as you are always waiting for what he will do next.
The cast works well with the material but it does seem like they have run out of ideas and are going through the motions.

The movie requires you to take great leaps of logic and faith even for a film of this type and while it does not work as well as the previous two entries, Director Justin Lin knows his audience and delivers what they want.

The film has a very good concept, good cast, and potential to be a fantastic series but suffers from a real lack of scares. It's a sanitized look at a zombie invasion that greatly undermines the subject and the source material.
The action in the film is solid and The Lone Ranger" was the most pleasant surprise of the summer to date and the only summer film so far that I would pay to see again.

While it is not a bad film by any stretch the imagination, it could have been so much more because as it stands now it is basically in the vein of the Toho Godzilla movies just with a bigger budget and better effects.
If you set your expectations accordingly you may find yourself not only laughing along at the outrageous antics.
The expanded roster of heroes and villains certainly propels the series forward and the exceptional amounts of violence was toned down from the previous film.

Timberlake does a good job as the ambitious Richie and Affleck is very good as the charismatic Block. Sadly they can only do so much with their thinly written characters and scenarios that we have seen many times before.
With its campy banter and intense action scenes; it could turn anyone into a fan of this genre of film.

While action fans may be disappointed with having to wait for the big guns to come out, the film is a very good drama than gets good performances from its stars and supporting cast and is a very enjoyable outing.
This movie works hard to jam in all the questions, but fails to shed any light on the answers.
With another Avengers movie on the horizon and a promise that Thor will return, fans can definitely enjoy this latest offering and look forward to the future for this promising series.
Despite reading the book and knowing the story, I was drawn in and was caught up in the action from the start and was one of the more enjoyable experience at the movies for me in 2013.
Hanks and Thompson are fantastic as is the incredible story of what it took to bring this classic film to life.
Despite Jackson filling the movie with countless scenes and characters not based upon the book, the movie works as an effective adventure tale.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug (2013)

movie_review_blurb: With a weak story, weak acting, and no real star power to carry the film, do not expect much from The Legend of Hercules.
Lone Survivor helps to redefine the action Biopic, as well as, redefine what it means to serve one's nation.

Fans of the original may be critical of this remake in not wanting a movie they love to be remade, however, they will be satisfied with the action, special effects, story, acting, and humor put into this film.
While parts of the film may drag out and some of the plot points stretch credibility, the winning cast makes the film worth seeing and I for one was pleasantly surprised.
While the film at times stretches credibility, it is for the most part a very tight and suspenseful and enjoyable film.

The cast was engaging and entertaining despite being largely unknown and Stapleton does a nice job with the lead as he does not try to recreate the performance of Butler and instead focuses on his own character.
The animation was excellent and the 3D added some depth but was not overly done. I was amazed at how much Mr. Peabody's and Sherman's voices sounded so much like the original.
While not the side-splitter comedy that one might expect, it does walk the line between dark comedy and drama well enough.

Director David Ayer keeps things moving along and is to be praised for not letting the action overshadow the characters but sadly the final act of the film comes up short and undermines what could have been a classic mix of action and drama.
"Captain America: The Winter Soldier" is a spectacular summer event film, as an it is a non-stop thrill ride and a textbook example of how to bring the best elements of a comic book to life.

While it may not be a timeless classic, "Rio 2" still has enough charm and enjoyment to make it an enjoyable film for younger viewers and fans of the first film, just as long as you temper your expectations.
. The movie does drags here and there but if you need a hit of the NFL drug while waiting for the next season, this might tide you over.

Not only is "Oblivion" filled with incredible imagery but it is also a intriguing and at times thought-provoking story that proves you can do action driven science fiction and still have interesting characters with complexity and a branching story.

The entire movie is like watching a Jr. College Fan Film where the cast has a Green Screen and studio funding, but not a clue on how to carry out a story, modern action sequences of character development.
Although better than expected, had it not been for Vin Diesel, this one likely would have gone straight to video.

The film is also moving in a way that one would not expect from a film in the X-men series and if this is truly the last outing for Jackman, he could not have picked a more perfect film as this is easily the best of the series.

While the story is more in lines with the linear and thin plots of adventure films of old, the sum of the parts does add up to an enjoyable film experience for those who like the giant creature films.

The film is at times brutal but not as gratuitous as other films. What it does well is mix characters that many might be able to relate to so you can find yourself wondering how you would react in a situation like the one presented.
The cast continues to be a great mix and Eastwood and Theron both makes a very good entry to the series as it continues onward at top speed.
The new film hits the ground running with plenty of action and humor and gives the characters new and old plenty of great moments that really expand upon their characters.

The film does take some liberties with the Arthurian Legend and does go a bit heavy on the FX especially with the inclusion of giant creatures which made me think at times I was watching something from the "Lord of the Rings".
movie_title: King Arthur: Legend Of The Sword (2017)

movie_review_blurb: From a fans perspective this is much more of the film that I was expecting when "Prometheus" was first announced and hopefully this is a very good omen for the direction that future films will take.

While "Baywatch", may not earn points for originality but it's certainly is light and enjoyable summer entertainment for those who are willing to overlook its shortcomings and enjoy a bit of updated nostalgic fun.
Well I certainly enjoyed this one much better than the second and third films in the series I kept thinking that I have seen this all before.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The film is not as awful as some have reported as it is a CGI heavy summer Popcorn Flick that does offer entertainment.
Things such as a plot, character development, and a brisker run time simply got in the way of Bay's desire to blow more things up and fill each shot with as many FX sequences as possible.

With a strong script, amazing visuals, and incredible performances from Harrelson and Serkis, "War for the Planet of the Apes" is the rare summer film that exceeds expectations and is one of the better films of the year.
movie_title: War for the Planet of the Apes (2017)

movie_review_blurb: More of an "Inspired By" vs "Based On" take on the multi-book series but thanks to the two leads, it does offer some escapist entertainment if you are willing to accept them not following the books.

The strong cast and the winning mix of jokes and action make the film a very pleasant surprise and one of my more enjoyable films of 2017. It was a highly-enjoyable thrill ride and one of the best films this summer.
In the end the film is an enjoyable but flawed effort that fails to live up to the original but does manage to offer some decent entertainment for those who set realistic expectations.
The film does take some serious leaps of logic and science but the strong cast and winning effects make the film more enjoyable than I expected it to be and I was entertained from start to finish.
Marvel has once again set very high standards for comic based movies and has again delivered another winner that you will not want to miss.
Better than expected but still deeply flawed.

Writer/Director Rian Johnson has done a masterful job in crafting a new entry into the series that not only entertains, but gives a deeper and dark look at the universe which makes the film easily one of the best Star Wars films ever made.
In the end "The Commuter" is an entertaining film that delivers some fun thrills and suspense as long as you are willing to temper your expectations and overlook the issues.
The film is over two hours long and at times drags, but does have some good action sequences and does up the action compared to prior films in the series.

While more engaging than the previous films; it is hampered by many of the same issues.The two leads have zero chemistry and their supposedly highly erotic scenes are so routine and by the numbers they lack any form of excitement or real titillation.
The film does take a while to get up to the action but when it arrives; it delivers making the wait worth it. What I really liked was that the characters were well-defined as were their motivations.
"Game Night", is a pleasant enoughfilm that cannot quite determine if it is a comedy or dramedy, but it does enough good things to make it an enjoyable outing.
Death Wish" is a very entertaining retelling of a well-known story that still holds up and still asks many difficult questions about our society and how to best protect the ones we love.
For those looking for a film with an empowering message aimed at younger viewers, than "A Wrinkle in Time", may be just the thing for an enjoyable family outing to the local cinema.
The laughs are back as the Planetary Express crew take on the Beast with a Billion Backs in a brand new Futurama adventure.
movie_title: Futurama: The Beast With a Billion Backs (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The very satisfying action sequences and performances combine well to make a compelling, exciting, and highly entertaining adrenaline rush, and I cannot wait to see what they come up with for the next outing.
If you are looking for a character driven action film with amazing scenery, you will want to make sure to see this film as it is as unforgettable a tale with amazing visuals.
The film's sex scenes are so dull and by the numbers you will soon find yourself losing interest. A big part of this goes to the total lack of chemistry between the leads.
Yes we have seen this all before but the cast and the interesting locale and visuals make the film add up to more than the sum of its parts.

While I'm not sure the film will be a true modern classic, it is still a very enjoyable and entertaining film that will be more than welcome during the holiday season for those looking for some dependable Pixar magic.
This was a very solid and entertaining film that should delight fans of the series as well as sports films in general and was one of the most enjoyable surprises of the year.
If you can handle the slow parts and need some good laughs, then you will want to check out "Sisters' as it is mindless and raunchy fun.
The film is better than you might expect and being the first chapter in a trilogy of books does set up the possibilities of sequels.
"Deadpool" is violent, funny, crude, and a great mix of a revenge and romance. The jokes fly as fast as the bullets and is a real winner.
While it was entertaining to watch, I found that knowing what was to come stopped any tension in the film.

Disney has got another classic on their hands and I hope that we see some future adventures from this crew in the future as I was captivated from beginning to end and with this charming and magical tale.

"London Has Fallen" is a rare sequel that is as good if not better than the original and Director Babak Najafi keeps the film moving at a breakneck pace yet keeps the film a character driven story that never lets up once the action revs up.
Goodman and the cast are very strong and they are able to hold your attention without having to rely on fancy visuals and other tricks.

The movie is setting up the finale which hopefully will bring some advancement and satisfying closure to the series and characters. For now the film is a flawed but at times entertaining entry which should keep fans happy until the final film arrives.
With bad casting, a plodding plot, and bland characters, The film fails to take off. I would be shocked if the next offerings from Marvel are not considerable better than this film.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: "The Jungle Book" is an absolute delight that is not to be missed.
As it stands the film is a good first effort but may or may not be enough to successfully launch a long term franchise.

Directors Anthony and Joe Russo proved that their last Captain America outing was no fluke, as they have delivered an action-packed and gripping film with some very mature content and themes set against some dazzling and intense action sequences.

"Warcraft" plays out like a big budget fan film with solid special effects but a plodding and stale story, bad acting, and a no-name cast who cannot even decide what accent they are using from scene to scene.
While it is mainly a comedy that uses every bit of its R rating, there are enough laughs for those who are willing to overlook some of the issues with the film's pacing and basic premise.
movie_title: Mike and Dave Need Wedding Dates (2016)

movie_review_blurb: This time around everything is cheesy and over the top. Even the equipment, while pretty cool at times, is mostly flashing lights. The CGI is pretty terrible quite frankly, making the old graphic techniques used in the original put it to shame.
This was a very enjoyable summer sci fi flick that I would recommend you go see. Some suspension of reality is necessary but it's a movie about space voyagers... relax and enjoy!
In a summer filled with big budget disappointments, "Suicide Squad" is an enjoyable adventure that delivers what it promises and more.
I found it an informative story, showing a different side to a very well-known disaster.
The cast is very strong and take what could at first be a routine mystery and turned it into one of the best and most entertaining Dramas of the year.
The film is is an action filled thriller that was an exciting adventure filled with twists, turns, and solid performances all around.
The film at times takes some leaps of faith but the intensity and suspense of the film as well as the solid action scenes and pacing make the film a very pleasant surprise and one worth watching.

Marvel Studios has once again proved they have the Midas touch when it comes to their properties. Cumberbatch embodies the Doctor so well that he is a captivating and complex character who like many of the best Marvel characters.
A magical tale filled with charm, humor, and adventure that will delight fans. There is plenty of magic left in this world and I cannot wait to see what comes next.
movie_title: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (2016)

movie_review_blurb: While it is likely not going to be a holiday classic, "Office Christmas Party", is a very fun and enjoyable diversion.
"Rogue One: A Star Wars Story" is an outstanding entry into the series and is one of the most compelling and rewarding.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The film makes a good effort as there are some nice visuals and action sequences, but unfortunately they are too few and far between.

For die hard fans of the series and those who want younger viewers to experience the film on the big screen, then this is exactly what you have been looking for. If you are looking for a significant change to the film, then you may be disappointed.
Despite some casting issues and liberties with the history of the characters, the film redeems it's slow start with a finale that sets up future films well.
A nostalgic, yet highly enjoyable, interpretation of the beloved classic.
State of Play" is a very tight thriller that is filled with twists and turns. The characters are interesting and well developed and the performances are first rate

There are some solid action sequences to balance out the mostly underwhelming action in the film and Jackman does not disappoint. This is not to say the film is bad, simply that it lacks the needed gear to shift the film into overdrive.
Star Trek is a remarkable film that, despite some issues, has a solid new lease on life. Abrams boldly, and triumphantly, goes where fans, old and new, will gladly follow.
It's not pretty, it's not engaging and it's not interesting. Unless you were a huge fan of the original and of the book.
McG keeps things moving at a brisk pace and has crafted a slick and enjoyable film that has many clever nods to the source material without ever being disrespectful to the franchise.

While more character development might would have been nice, the film is a solid effort that shows that Boll should focus his efforts on more original work than his customary video game adaptations, as "1968 Tunnel Rats", is a not only his best film, but
"The Hangover" is a hysterical and highly enjoyable comedy that rarely lets up long enough for you to stop laughing before unleashing even more comedic gems.
What it lacks in plot and character development the film more than makes up for in Action and FX. Bay knows what the audience wants to see and delivers plenty of robot action.
The film was paced well and never overstayed its welcome, and despite some jokes that were better suited to an older audience, the film delivered a perfect summer film for the family to enjoy.
movie_title: Ice Age: Dawn of the Dinosaurs (Ice Age 3) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: In the end, you will either love or hate the film, and much of this will depend on your tolerance for very mature, bawdy, and controversial humor. For my taste, this was one of the funniest films I have ever seen and I could not stop laughing.
This new Potter is a technically brilliant film that despite the magic and wonder is a character driven story.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (2009)

movie_review_blurb: District 9" not only serves as a strong statement from Blomkamp that he is a talent on the rise, and also as a solid redemption for Jackson after the dissatisfaction of "King Kong", and the failure of "Halo".

"Zombieland" almost defies you to categorize it as it is great mix of horror, comedy, and action disguised as a romantic comedy. The winning cast and formula makes "Zombieland" one of the most enjoyable films of the summer and a real treat.
A true holiday classic has arrived in this high-tech retelling of the timeless story.
While the explosions and FX are first rate, there is far to many vast leaps of logic that require the audience to check their brain at the door.
While the film may not come across as a traditional American studio film, there is a lot to like about this new Holmes and the new franchise it launches for fans old and new.

. The amazing blend of story, digital splendor, and characters all combine to make "Avatar" a truly amazing visual film with a strong message of love, hope, and unity. James Cameron has once again proved that he is one of the true masters of cinema and ha
In the end, the strong cast, good action, and story makes this a film worth seeing and a pleasant surprise
"The Wolfman" works as a matinee or a DVD rental, but I would not suggest it as a full priced theatrical experience for anyone other than those looking for a piece of nostalgia.
Thankfully Smiths skilled handling of the cast and humor is what tips the scales in the films favor making "Cop Out" a flawed but at times very funny film.
While it may drag in parts, the winning cast provides plenty of laughs in this loving look back at 80s teen sex comedies.

The new Nightmare is a fairly by-the-numbers horror film that is sadly is lacking much suspense and horror. I was a big fan of the series and I found myself wanting to watch the original Wes Craven classic rather than what was unfolding on the screen.

The film has a frantic pacing that Director Edgar Wright never lets get out of control. Like his great work in Shaun of the Dead, Wright keeps the characters and their relationships at the center of the film.

Strong supporting work in the film combined with the great performances of the lead characters makes The Social Network"a very solid and entertaining film that, for my money, is one of the better films of the year.
While it does not have as much charm as the earlier films in the series, the film certainly has more than its share of funny moments and action that will keep viewers entertained.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Voyage of the Dawn Treader (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Hornet is a hilarious and action packed film that is one of the most satisfying action-buddy-comedies ever made.
Hall Pass is a smart and funny comedy that also provides relationship education.
In the new movie "Adventureland" Writer/Director Greg Mottola has given the audience a winning mix of romance and humor
While it doesn't have the epic feel of Independence Day, Battle: Los Angeles is a film that provides enough entertainment to make it one of the better alien invasion films ever made.

Walker and Diesel make a dynamic team and unlike the previous films in the series, "Fast and Furious" has a plot that does not drag and holds the attention of the audience and serves as little more than filler between action sequences.
While it is not likely to be considered a classic like the original film, it is still a worthy chapter in the series which will provide good nostalgic entertainment for fans new and old alike.
While it takes a while to get going, this Smart has enough humor and action to bring some laughs to the summer.
PIXAR rebounds ina big way from the bloated "Cars" with perhaps their best film to date.
Wanted mixes a few nice plot threads with solid action to give viewers a refreshing new dimension in Summer action films.
A solid start that shows great promise quikcly falls apart leaving "Hancock" the biggest disappointment of the summer.
Awash in visuals and action, this Hellboy is a step up from the previous one in every way.
While this Journey may lack in plot, the 3D adventure is one of the more enjoyable live action family films in recent years.
movie_title: Journey to the Center of the Earth (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The film is a true masterpiece that proves you do not have to sacrifice character development and story to deliver a solid action film.
Mulder and Scully return in one of the most enjoyable films of the year.
movie_title: The X-Files: I Want to Believe (The X Files 2) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: While there are some good laughs, Thunder does not take advantage of the talent it has and plods to a disappointing finale.
While lacking some of the magic of the live action film series, this new animated offering is a welcome addition to the classic series.
With a little more time in shop and tinkering, this could have been a solid action film, instead it stalls at the starting line badly in need of a tune up.
Despite a good start, "Eagle Eye" tips its hand far to early and ends up being little more than a dull movie of the week with few suprises in the end.
Nick and Norah is a pleasant, charming, and entertaining suprise.
Mixing off the wall and over the top humor with a road trip story. Sex Drive is a very funny and enjoyable comedy for fans of teen sex comedies.
Kevin Smith has crafted a raw, funny, and at times, touching film that is one of his most mature and entertaining films yet.
movie_title: Zack and Miri Make a Porno (2008)

movie_review_blurb: As an action thriller it has some value, but as a Bond film, I think Sir Ian Fleming is spinning in his grave over what they have done with his creation.
Like the book, the movie isn't exactly for everyone. But like the the book, given a chance, it could grow on you. At least enough to make you feel 16 all over again for just a little while.
In then end the film is a mixed bag that will appeal to fans of the series but even they will have to admit that the tread is starting to wear thin on the tires of this series.
When the action finally comes it is very brief and restrained and not nearly enough to save the film, which stumbles to a very awkward and predictable finale.
movie_title: The Day the Earth Stood Still (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The promise of the film becomes weighed down by Cruise and a script that plays a bit too loose with historical events for my taste.
While it is not a bad film, I had hoped for more as the premise is rife with possibilities and the film comes across as playing it safe rather than taking chances.
little in common with the book aside from the title and saying yes premise, "Yes Man" is Carrey's best film in years and is a triumphant return to the comedy films that made him such a huge success.
In the end, "Push" has just enough action and originality to combine with the charismatic and interesting cast to make an enjoyable movie experience.

While the film lacks much in the way of plot and is loaded with a cast of largely unknowns, the film is a refreshing update to the series, knowing what the fans have come to expect and providing plenty of gore and scares.
Despite some flaws, "Watchmen" is an exciting blend of action, drama, and an examination of humanity.
It isn't very smart and could have used some improvements across the board but it is not a bad way to spend some time with your children.
The film will shock and dismay some, but few will forget the disturbing images anytime soon.
movie_title: The Last House on the Left (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The animation is first rate, as is the great ensemble cast, all of which combine to make "Monsters Vs Aliens" a fun viewing experience for the entire family, and a grand new direction for animation.

With what could've been a dumbed-down action film, Jones has exceeded expectations and produced a smart and innovative action thriller with a touch of science fiction and romance thrown in, a winning combination that makes for a very enjoyable film.
"Knowing" was a very enjoyable film and reminded me of the type of films that M. Night Shyamalan used to make, and probably wishes he had done.
Scream 4 delivers a welcome return to the franchise and paves the way for future sequels in a manner which should delight fans of the genre and franchise.
The director had so many opportunities to delve further into the Chernobyl mystery and play up the radiation/mutation stab, but failed to provide any substance behind his direction.
From the incredible visuals to the engaging and enjoyable cast, Prometheus is a refreshing and enjoyable film and an extremely welcome and much-needed addition to the alien franchise.

While it is not a great cinematic comedy it certainly has more than its fair share of laughs along the way, just as long as you're willing to overlook the lackluster plot and uneven pacing of the film.

While the film plays it fairly safe with the story, Pixar's first female heroine gives us a very fun and enjoyable tale that offers something for the entire family without talking down to the audience or having to resort to crude humor.
Webb clearly knows the subject matter and gets the most out of his very talented cast and tells a very entertaining yet human action story and lets the FX support the film rather than carry it.
While it tries hard and has a solid cast, "The Watch" runs short.
Renner goes all out for a demanding and physical role while earning the audience's sympathy for the plight of Cross.
Once Dredd kicks into high gear you instantly forget anything else and truly enjoy this movie until it is over.
The team that created the sparkling "Coraline" has really taken the game to the next level.
The film captures the true magic the movies. Taking a fantasy and touching so many people in a deep and personal way.
movie_title: The Odd Life of Timothy Green (2012)

movie_review_blurb: What starts as a raunchy comedy ends up being a sweet film about the complicated dynamics of female relationships.
This film one comes across as a lazy remake of the first and offers little that viewers have not already seen before and better in the previous films.
It might not be the funniest movie of the year, but it is by no means bad at what it does.

Willis, Bridges, and Gordon-Levitt do solid work but seem to be going through the motions as they never really earn any sympathy from the audience. "Looper" has a great premise that starts well and then fails to live up to its potential.

Argo", was an extremely pleasant surprise in one of the most enjoyable films I have seen this year.I would not be surprised to see the film get a few Oscar nods come awards season as they would be in my opinion well deserved.
Seven Psychopaths turned out to be an enjoyable experience and thrill ride from start to finish. The ensemble cast breathes life into the crazy characters that help move along the action.
Pure Disney magic and gaming nostalgia blended to perfection.
I'm extremely happy with the film and especially love the movie's dénouement which, for me, promises a very good and eagerly anticipated direction for future films.

The best thing I can say about the film said if you are willing to overlook the abundance of plot holes and logic gaps, as well as some at times stiff acting and dialogue, there are some enjoyable action seems to be found.
Despite its issues, it's a visually spectacular masterpiece that, if you can endure the long periods of inaction, pays off especially well during the film's battle sequences.
The film cleverly mixes humor, action, and drama with a very credible plot that rarely strains plausibility.

If you have never seen a Cirque du Soleil performance by all means I definitely recommend seeing this film but for those hard-core fans who are regular attendees of Cirque du Soleil, one might want to wait to catch this on DVD.

It's hard not to be impressed with the way Tarantino is able to paint a picture, fill it with interesting and quirky characters, and quickly tear it all apart as things descend into utter chaos and destruction.
Bottom line, renter, unless you love Bily Crystal.
A Dark and captivating look at the world in which we live.
While I enjoyed Schwarzenegger's "The Last Stand" a bit more, I was very surprised at how enjoyable the film was after being underwhelmed by the trailer.
While it will not break any new ground in visuals and story, "Frankenweenie" is a pleasantly fun film that the family will enjoy and is well worth checking out.
From the strong cast to the awesome special effects and humor, "The Avengers" is a shining example of not only how to do a summer action film but how to do a comic book ensemble film right.
you'll find far more thrills and enjoyment busting out the actual Battleship game than sitting through the film.
Lockout plays out more like a direct to DVD release as the recycled plot and lo-res and dated special effects did not warrant a major theatrical release.
Larger-than-life characters combined with larger-than-life action, plus some very sexy cars and very sexy people make for an extremely winning formula.

You won't be missing anything by skipping this film at the box office. It might be worth a rental when it comes out on DVD, but you and your family can still live a full and satisfying life without it.
. I absolutely loved every part the film from beginning to end and in my opinion Thor has set the bar very high for the next series of comic book themed movies to aspire to and is not to be missed.
While the film was not as thoroughly funny as the original, in terms of humor and storytelling, but there are still plenty of laughs and eye-popping scenes that make it an enjoyable comedy

In the end, "X-Men: First Class", for me was more entertaining than the previous ensemble films, but fails to live up to its potential and severely lacks enough action to sustain the early momentum of the film.
"Super 8" played out as JJ Abrams nostalgic homage to the Steven Spielberg movies of his childhood which so clearly influenced him.
Director Martin Campbell and his team of writers have crafted a solid summer action picture that not only delivers but is faithful to the source material.
There are some great laugh out loud moments the whole family will love.
Delivering a much-needed shot of adrenaline to the summer movie season, "Transformers: Dark of the Moon", arrives awash in stunning visuals and cutting-edge 3-D.
Fright Night" just might be perfect for those looking for a dose of nostalgia and some highly suspenseful, fun entertainment.
Contagion doesn't go overboard on pointing fingers instead it gives an honest and unflinching look at a scenario that we can only hope will never happen.
Moneyball is a very enjoyable and realistic look at the inner workings of baseball and one of the best baseball films ever made. Pitt is amazing.
McCarthy has some great lines and moments and Bateman does a solid job as the straight main foil. The problem is, the laughs are to few and far between to justify the nearly two hour run time.
While the film is not likely to reach the iconic status of the previous film, it is still a worthy companion piece that has enough action and effects to keep it interesting to fans of the series.
The action sequences are intense and amazing to look at but never overshadow the underlying storyline of love and redemption.
While it attempts to be a darker and more mature film, it still comes across as eye candy and fantasy for young women when the story and cast deserved so much more.

What really sold the film for me was not just the great chemistry between the cast but the way the script deftly moved the raunchy comedy along while combining character development and depth that is not normally found in films of this type.

21 Jump Street" is easily the funniest movie I've seen this year. I have not laughed this much, for all the right reasons, in quite a long time. Hip and fresh again, there's plenty of bounce left in "21 Jump Street."
"In Time" is science fiction at its best as it allows for timely social commentary and provides a disturbing look at many age old debates.
Directed by McG the film mixes action and comedy with a touch of romance and creates an entertaining formula.

Washington and Reynolds worked very well together and had a very natural, unforced chemistry. It was very nice to see Reynolds take on a grittier and more intense role than we have seen from him previously.

Director Andrew Stanton, who has made a name for himself with his animated films at Pixar, skillfully blends live-action and CGI to create a very energetic and enjoyable action-adventure film that was a very pleasant surprise.
The team has a winning formula that reinvigorates the series giving us what I believe is the best film in the series to date.
The film was well-paced and an absolute thrill ride from beginning to end mixing fantastic action and some great humor for a very winning combination that is not to be missed.
movie_title: Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows (2011)

movie_review_blurb: I found this movie to be a great date movie. It's cute and funny, but without being overly obnoxious as some holiday movies try to be. It is very clever in its story telling, and makes great use of the stellar cast.

I can honestly say this is not only one of the best of the Muppet movies but it is a perfect film to take the family. Just don't be surprised if you find yourself enjoying the magic as much, if not more, than the kids.
The film is a bold and dynamic vision from Fincher and is a deeply dark and disturbing story that is difficult to forget.
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The film definitely fails to live up the original in many ways, but still contains enough surprises to pull itself out of the disaster it was headed toward.
Audiences will not fail to notice that Oreck has consciously and effectively sought to re-frame her long term fascination with American westerns and cowboys as a Nordic western of the Finnish order.
movie_title: Aatsinki: The Story Of Arctic Cowboys (2014)

movie_review_blurb: There are some pretty sadistic torture scenes for the gore hounds -- but ultimately this pointless prequel is about as thrilling as a wet towel.
Interesting, occasionally poignant and perfectly watchable, The Commune is well-paced, well-written and well-made -- but it is far from Vinterberg's best.
As cumbersome a title as it is a movie.

As it is A Very Murray Christmas wants to come off as unique and effortless as its host, simultaneously sad, pensive, spirited and off-the-cuff, but too often it feels as forced and uncomfortable as the Internet's cult of Murray.
There are a few missteps...but at a time when legendary stand-ups are using their multimillion dollar Netflix specials to reveal how out of touch they are with today, Rock remains as potent as ever.
Director Sebastian Schipper has gone into bold territory with Victoria, a pulsating thriller shot over one take lasting 140 minutes on the streets of Berlin.
While a product of its time -- freewheeling, energetic and raw -- Mean Streets is well worth seeing for the brilliance of De Niro.
It's a stronger movie than the two previous installments but, as Yoda would say: an out-and-out triumph it is not.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode III - Revenge of the Sith (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Wilson riffs hard and has his moments, but can't save a comedy with not enough laughs.

There is nothing wet about Daniel Radcliffe as a grown-up wizard. As with Emma Watson and Rupert Grint as Hermione and Ron, his acting has improved out of sight since Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Like a cross between A Clockwork Orange and an extended music video...
It feels as authentic to Maori culture as the haka, with a cheeky and understated charm. As they say across the Tasman, choice.
Inspiring.
An Unexpected Journey has so many pay-offs that most are likely to re-engage with the saga.
Al Mansour's first feature film is a striking achievement.
While there are rough edges, the strength of the central performances carries an audacious film.
Stone proves an accomplished director of actors in his first film.
The story of a great love spanning 15 years, Holding the Man is a portrait of a turbulent time for gay Australia.

With a pulsating final installment that runs to almost three hours, Christopher Nolan has conjured up that most difficult of tricks -- matching the high expectations of dedicated Batman fans and delivering a Hollywood blockbuster with credibility.
While Poltergeist may not reinvent the wheel it's a fairly enjoyable 90 minutes at the cinema.
Big Hero 6 is one of the best animated features to hit the big screen in some time. Forget Frozen. In fact, just Let It Go completely. This is a stunning triumph.
Filled with astonishing, gut-wrenching performances, it brings Northup's stunning story to life in a deeply-affecting way.
This is a romantic horror with sci-fi inflections and it's a stunning example of the power of cinema.
White God isn't for everyone. But it is an unflinching, extraordinary piece of film-making.
The subject matter could have been exploitative or cheapened in the wrong hands. But Herbots deftly weaves an intricate, if somewhat baggy, tale.
De Caestecker is the real star of this show, with an effortless performance full of heart.
A tough, but ultimately incredibly-satisfying watch.

Whedon wastes no time teaming them up for a blistering opening sequence that is thrilling. Unfortunately that segment is a high point in a film that swiftly becomes an exercise in ever-diminishing returns bar a few moments.
This is a film that's pure scale and spectacle, and in that regard it does exactly what it says on the tin.
Nothing fresh is brought to the screen and the stars end up treading water with well-worn cliches.
It's a thrilling summer blockbuster and should be a roaring success at the box office to boot.
From the brilliant synth-led soundtrack, courtesy of Le Matos, to the practical blood and gore effects, it's a nostalgia trip that revels in its many, many influences.
A wonderfully-twisted blend of psycho-drama, suspense and body horror.
There's still much to admire and enjoy.
As a collective, there's great, good and average to be had here. It's always a risk run with these anthologies, but the audience is there for them and Viral is a good addition to the series.
Sometimes the most effective horror films come with the simplest premise and this is certainly the case with Jeremy Lovering's In Fear.
Tales of Halloween... brings together a smorgasbord of horror directors, writers and actors to concoct something that's devilishly fun.
The Gift may initially feel like it's something we've all seen before, but it builds to a tremendous crescendo. This is a dark and twisted gem of a thriller with a gut-punch of an ending.
While it's in no way perfect, there's enough going on to keep you guessing where it's headed.
It may be nothing new, bar a few moments of in-your-face ridiculousness, but The Vatican Tapes is a pretty decent addition to the ever-growing list of exorcism films.
Much like Computer Chess, Results is a study of people and how they interact despite their best efforts to largely remain alone.
Gritty British prison dramas are hardly something new but every so often one crops up that grabs you by the throat and doesn't let go.
While Another is rough around the edges it's an extremely stylish and bizarre entry in the demonic possession sub-genre of horror.
Minihan's direction is assured and slick and it's nice to see some oldschool aliens rock up on screen.
While some of the story may be cliched, it never detracts from what is a genuinely scary horror film that will satisfy the appetites of fans of the genre looking to be given a fright or five.
[A] mind-bending psychological crime thriller.
It's ambitious but, ultimately, a failure.
Sherpa is an absorbing, compelling and eye-opening piece of work that sheds new light on a struggle we rarely witness on the daunting Mount Everest.
A wonderful tale of accepting your past and having the courage to embrace the future you want to have, this is independent UK film at its best.
Near-the-knuckle comedy that proves self-indulgent laughs, when done right, can be hilarious.
Pixar's funniest film to date
Mainstream horror at its best, James Wan continues to impress
Visually stunning, this example of spectacle over story is hampered by a terribly cliched script and poor performances
Despite speculation predicting an on-screen disaster, this is a rather thrilling and fun big-budget zombie film let down by the re-shot finale.
A nightmarish and minimalist work of art that will be admired, loved & loathed in equal measure
A razor-sharp portrayal of the cruel - and sometimes brutal - nature of growing up.
JAMES McAVOY gives a career-best performance in this jaw-dropping adaptation.
Short Term 12 is the kind of cinematic rollercoaster that will make your heart swell one moment and leave you in tears the next. It's simply unmissable.

This is a hauntingly beautiful story of two men discovering themselves -- and their place in the world -- when they are at their loneliest and is worth the money just to witness the joyous drunken scene.
There's something admirable about a film-maker who throws caution to the wind and just runs with an idea. Even one that turns out to be utterly ridiculous.
In a cinema season overflowing with ho-hum rom-coms , it's a delight to come across one that moves off the well-beaten track and entertains at the same time.
The cast all play an integral part in us going along with the science of the story and there's a real sense of disorientation as the group dynamic is put under stress and begins to fracture.
A razor-sharp shot across the bows of Tinseltown.
With a tight running time and no fat to trim, The Captive is a thought-provoking tale of the horrors soldiers must deal with played out as a creature feature of sorts.
Purporting to be a horror film that foregoes scares of any kind for blood-drenched gore and puerile comedy, it's the reason why so many feel that the horror genre is on a slippery slope.
Despite the incredibly meagre budget, Florence lets his writing and the performances of Anna (Louise Stewart) and Him (Richard Rankin) carry the film. And boy does it pay off in spades.
The two leads do their best with what they're given but in the end it all falls incredibly flat.
Man of Steel is spectacular on every level and is what every superhero movie will need to aspire to from here-on in.
Thankfully, amid the sweaty mayhem there's a particularly sweet love story. Baccarin takes the role of Vanessa and clearly has a ball early doors as she matches Reynolds stride for stride.
Get Out is confident and assured and in director Peele, the 21st century has found a new voice in horror.
This is exquisite film-making from a master film-maker.
It won't be everyone but this is a fairytale meeting grand guignol for the multiplex crowd.
It might not be in the same league as The Raid or John Wick, but it makes a decent fist of it.
A riotous delight.
Guardians of the Galaxy Vol.2 is a candy-coated cinematic shot of sugar. It'll provide a short [high but] is ultimately unfulfilling.
It's a nightmarish descent into insanity that's as depraved as it is entertaining.
It might be too dry for some, but for horror fans with patience and a love of the slow-burn will find plenty to chew on.
This is a film that more than matches some of the best war films. It's a movie about strength of character, belief and faith and Gibson has delivered another cracker.
Equal parts heartbreaking, tense and thrilling.
The most frustrating thing is, there's the bones of a decent film here.
See it, laugh at it, love it. And take your best friend -- they'll appreciate it.
movie_title: Captain Underpants: The First Epic Movie (Captain Underpants) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It's as funny as it is relentless and is sure to be a crowd-pleaser.
Ultimately, this is an insidious and deeply unsettling focus on real issues with a supernatural twist.
While it might not reinvent the wheel for slasher movies, it's a decent effort anchored by a great central performance.
An outstanding adaptation of Stephen King's novel, It is a creepy and unnerving coming-of-age-tale that brings a true monster to life.
In the end, it all feels like a polished waste of an opportunity.

The core cast all play a part in making the viewer care. There's panic, terror, confusion and even the odd dry joke to bring some levity to the tension. Everyone (bar Dom) is likeable to various degrees.
We might have reached the end of the maze but what a way to go. Ball has crafted a rip-roaring, action-packed finale and it's going to be exciting to see where he takes us next.
This is a film that, while gorgeous on a surface level, becomes something far more impressive as the layers are peeled away.
This is a fun and exciting execution of an inspiring story. It's beautiful. It's pure Zemeckis.
Egerton is a likeable hero -- as he was in Kingsman -- and the movie can easily claim a respectable third place on the podium.
No amount of spectacle can disguise the movie's lack of substance.

It's a vitally-important piece of film-making that will move you, provoke you and educate you.
Gyllenhaal mixes humour and falling apart incredibly well.
This is masterful film-making and Green Room doesn't pull any punches. In fact, it'll grab you by the throat and refuse to let go until the credits roll.

While the end product isn't perfect, it's a fun and unsettling ride.

movie_review_blurb: Jeff Nichols' has made a name for himself thanks to the brilliance of Take Shelter and Mud. His latest effort is Americana meets sci-fi and it's no understatement to say this is sublime storytelling.
Batman v Superman is a lunking, clumsy, beautiful and thrilling behemoth of a film. The faults are there for all to see. But so are the good points.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

Nighthawks, an aggressively shallow police thriller pitting New York undercover cops against international terrorists.

"Do you think they'll drop the Bomb?" asks a loaded musical question at one irresistibly funny point. Obviously, they've already dropped it, and it's called "The Wall."
