It's all an utter crock, made more insufferable by Ritchie's modernistic go-to moves that just don't mesh with the material.
movie_title: King Arthur: Legend Of The Sword (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Writer-director Trey Edward Shults' sophomore feature won't do much to reaffirm faith in humanity under pressure, but it will put the screws to the viewer for a lean, nerve-wracking 90 minutes.

It works like a charm, especially when Wright's alchemy is applied to some jaw-dropping chase scenes and in-camera car stunts that make the CGI cheating of the "Fast and Furious" franchise look like amateur night.
The movie has heart and an ebullience that is infectious.
The movie could have skated by if the leads were at least charismatic and fun, but DeHaan and Delevigne are stilted and dead-eyed in just about every scene.
movie_title: Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Such a meditative movie certainly isn't for everyone, but it is what an indie movie should be: bold, original, quirky, genre-defying, and boundary pushing.

Fans have been clamoring for one since the 1990s, and versions of it have been in and out of development for a decade. Pity them, for the final product is cheap, shoddy, and bland to a confounding degree.
The movie becomes more relevant than intended; too bad that it's too oblivious to do anything about.
It almost works in a 'turn off your brain and watch' kind of way, but there's not enough to sustain its 141 minute running time.
It's [its] kind of self-awareness and refusal to take itself too seriously (we're looking at you, DC) that helps Marvel's shtick and comic book movies in general maintain their forward momentum.
Most days, "it's not great but at least it's coherent" would be a backhanded compliment; in this instance, it's high praise.
It's the "Amelie" and "Creature from the Black Lagoon" mash-up you never knew you wanted.
The series feels like it is truly moving forward for the first time in decades, and that future now looks more promising.

There's a visual richness that expands Marvel's movie universe much the way Doctor Strange and the Guardians movies did, in this case with a beautiful blend of Afro-futurism and African mythical elements.
It's a mind-bending film, and one that also plays with warping the medium as well, especially during its final act.
The crushing flaw of A Wrinkle In Time: Almost every scene is so saturated with clumsily delivered 'believe in yourself' mantras that it becomes monotonous, meaningless and even creepy.
It's a story told in patchwork, and most of those involved deserve better.

Having an ostensibly smarter group of victims battle an implacable foe in the claustrophobic confines of a delicate spacecraft is a set-up rife with possibility, but in this instance it goes nowhere fast.
Jackman's is a revelatory performance that paradoxically works as a worthy send-off yet leaves us wishing for more.

Though it's not as consistently or as unrelentingly hilarious as The LEGO Movie, Chris McKay's comic book spin-off is nevertheless a clever and enjoyable spoof of comic book movies in general, and the Dark Knight in particular.
A fun piece of throwaway cinema, The Shallows is a sleek, beautifully shot, and mostly satisfying thriller that plays it smart and simple, only faltering by opting for a schlocky climax.
Less pompous than Greystoke but more cartoonish than Disney's 1999 animated version of the material, The Legend of Tarzan is pretty to look at but ultimately hollow and occasionally shoddy.
It's still a fun ride thanks largely to casting.
The movie is open-ended enough to allow for another installment, but what's the point if our hero has nowhere left to go, no more dark personal secrets to uncover, or nothing left to say?
Alas, the result is a surprisingly disjointed mess.
There are so few surprises that, frankly, a few vampires would have been a welcome touch.
One of the most effective parables about religion ever filmed.
LAIKA Studios continues its streak of smart, idiosyncratic, and quirky animated features with the stunning Kubo and the Two Strings.

Scott and company have created tight little throwback to old-school sci-fi and horror movies about the dangers of playing God. It's still a gruesome potboiler at heart, but it's one that strikes some effective chords.
Adam Wingard's sequel/reboot Blair Witch is really just a remake in disguise, bogged down by a bad case of 'same thing, just more of it'.

Lacking in the tongue-firmly-in-cheek melodrama that made Gone Girl such twisted fun, it telegraphs its handful of twists well before the halfway mark and then proceeds to drag itself to a half-hearted conclusion.
It's a blunt-force, but highly effective treatise on the horrors of war as well as those who rise above the brutality to maintain as much humanity as one can on a battlefield.

Nate Parker's ambitious telling of Nat Turner's 1831 slave revolt is a timely movie; it's also a missed opportunity, a tepid tale hamstrung by Parker's limited experience and the constraints of biopic filmmaking.
It proves there's still new ground to tred in J.K. Rowling's magical world -- for now, at least.
movie_title: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Rogue One is one of the best Star Wars flicks to date -- as well as the grittiest, darkest, and most grounded.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Much as he did with The Last Temptation of Christ and Kundun, Scorsese reflects upon matters of faith with artistic courage and finesse.
Live by Night is meant to be an epic tale of crime, prejudice, and opportunism and how they collide with the myth of the American Dream. Too bad it never makes us care.
A gritty, cynical, hilarious, and mostly satisfying bit of L.A. noir, Shane Black's The Nice Guys sees the bad boy writer-director make a slick return to his signature brand of buddy action comedy.
Jennifer Lawrence is the only actor of her age equipped to convey Katniss' burden.
It won't necessarily re-ignite [Apatow's] career, but it does remind us of what he can do.
A messy but intriguing and enjoyably warped slice of modern film noir as only Los Angeles can flavor it.
A number of narrative twists keep you guessing and, while the pace stays strong and steady, building the gory mayhem to a bloody crescendo.
Congenial, mildly anarchic, and generally inoffensive, Accepted feels like it's holding itself back, which also keeps it from being thoroughly engaging.
If it all sounds silly, convoluted, and confusing, that's because it is silly, convoluted, and confusing. It's also a hell of a lot of fun.
Visually arresting but only sporadically enthralling.
Undiscovered is a lifeless affair, as disinterested in its own characters as moviegoers are likely to be.

It may seem that Invincible takes too long to get to the football. But by the time it does get down to it, we've invested enough in Wahlberg and Kinnear to give a damn about the outcome of the all-important Big Game.
The dull and tedious splatter-fest See No Evil is, sadly, not even half as intriguing as its skuzzy pedigree.
Freedomland is a drama that plays like an episode of a TV cop show stretched beyond its limits.
Unabashedly old-fashioned and fantastically pulpy.
[Strikes] a careful balance between quasi-cartoonish shoot-outs and oddball humor, which ranges from droll to silly without ever going too far over the top.
Johnson's performance is one of seething rage camouflaging emotional scars as ugly as the physical ones, a grim, single-minded figure straight out of a Jim Thompson or Richard Stark novel.
Even the most dedicated of Nicolas Cage's fans will find little to enjoy about the historical-fantasy-action romp Season of the Witch.
Torn between establishing itself as a bromantic comedy or a relationship potboiler, the movie meets the requirements of neither. It is unsatisfying in general.
A polished but unremarkable science-fiction adventure, I Am Number Four is the kind of movie you enjoy while it's in front of you but soon forget about.
A thoughtful and thought-provoking romance with a touch of the fantastic.
Limitless is an amusing, clever tale of self-actualization run amok. It's also a surprisingly effective hybrid of comedy, drama and action.
Matt Reeves takes a step toward making everyone's favorite bloodsuckers scary again.
Taking the path of least resistance, the result is a missed opportunity, a lightweight approach to some very heavy material.
It's a navel-gazing meditation on death smothered under excess and ham-handed direction, better suited for late-night cable.
The Yes Men feels padded at only 83 minutes, as if the footage had been stretched to fill the running time, but it gets the point across that humanity is sorely missing from the corporate world.
An almost constantly surprising coming-of-age film with a dark twist that manages to take the high road with what is well-exploited material.
An ambitious, hit-and-miss social satire that doesn't score as many direct hits as it should. But it lands enough punches to get its point across.
A Slipping Down Life would disintegrate in a cloud of cutesy, melancholic whimsy if it weren't for the talent of its two leads.
An enjoyably pulpy sci-fi saga that has rough patches.
It's less of a monster movie and more of a morality play about the dangers of nuclear experimentation.
It's not perfect, but writer-directors Krishna D.K. and Raj Nidimoru deliver some pointed observations and well-drawn characters in their first feature-length film.
Unfortunately, the characters and their motivations are so poorly defined that the story seems vague and incomplete.
A visually impressive, but largely lifeless, limp noodle that strips the details that made the 1960s TV series work and features a bland coming-of-age story and a by-the-numbers revenge plot.
Mr. Kitano slips into the title role like a second skin.
One of the freakiest, most unsettling movies to come out of Japan in the past few years.
A transparent attempt to jumpstart two run-down franchises.
A curious and mostly rewarding tale of a love affair in a world of genetic policing and travel restrictions.
A hokey, old-school creature feature that will appeal to fans of the original and connoisseurs of enjoyably absurd movies.
movie_title: Anacondas: The Hunt for the Blood Orchid (2004)

movie_review_blurb: It's a dreamlike, intuitive movie that has much to say about life and death and points in between.
For a brand-new movie, it feels very dated.
A rehash that takes a timely theme, mankind's obsession with technology, and bloats it to the point of incomprehension, cramming meaning into dialogue that has none.
It's the kind of movie that only a prude could hate.

Criminal-defense attorneys are often viewed with disdain, and while director Brad Furman's adaptation of Michael Connelly's 2005 novel won't do much to change this, it does allow Matthew McConaughey to give his best performance in years.
A chase-thriller for the art-house crowd, Hanna is brisk, satisfying and often surprising.
A grisly thriller that plays like a bargain-basement rehash of other, better movies.

The series takes the curious, surprising and rather brave route of ditching the street-racing shenanigans that defined the series in favor of a more standard action-oriented plot. It's an interesting approach, but the series' shallowness remains

Granted, you don't go into this sort of thing expecting originality - or even coherence - but geez, a bit more effort would have been nice. Instead, we get a Z-grade knock-off of a B-grade cult film with half the style and none of the flair.
An atypical horror movie that could have been great but instead settled for mediocrity and recycled tropes, Oculus is a frustrating near-miss.
The Amazing Spider-Man 2 throws everything at the wall to see what sticks, but most of it just goes "splat." It is an exhausting experience, and one that feels far less than amazing.

Liman takes the movie's "Groundhog Day meets Independence Day" premise (adapted from Hiroshi Sakurazaka's novel All You Need is Kill) and runs with it a way that makes it more compelling than it theoretically should be.
movie_title: Live Die Repeat: Edge of Tomorrow (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Ambitious and epic in scale and intimate in execution, X-Men: Days of Future Past seal[s] the deal on the slow-burn comeback started by clever prequel X-Men: First Class and pulpy spin-off The Wolverine.
Snowpiercer is a rare movie that respects the audience's intelligence, subtly mining Titanic (in a good way), The Wizard of Oz, and Runaway Train for tropes.

There's a lack of articulation in [Michod's] story that there's little in the way of a theme to make The Rover compelling. That's frustrating, because a movie this nihilistic and driven should be about something.
Pompeii is a hot mess of a movie well before Mt. Vesuvius erupts.

It's a rare sequel - animated or otherwise - that expands the story of its predecessor without rehashing it, and an even rarer family-oriented film that manages to be fun and mature without being condescending to its audience. [It] does both.
One of the most pleasant surprises of a mixed-bag movie summer, Guardians of the Galaxy is something akin to Star Wars on Quaaludes.
The formula is officially stale.
The Maze Runner is a slickly plot-driven flick that delivers the basic sense of adventure that is sometimes missing from its relentlessly brooding cinematic progenitor.
It's increasingly difficult to craft a plausible and unpredictable thriller, but Gone Girl actually manages to keep us on our toes.

Unfortunately, the long-awaited sequel Sin City: A Dame to Kill doesn't prove to be worth the wait. Whereas the first film was kitschy, ambitious schlock, its sequel is a monotonous, shallow, parody of its predecessor.
movie_title: Frank Miller's Sin City: A Dame to Kill For (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Ayer makes a stab at spinning the cliches here and there, and largely succeeds in taking a contemporary approach to old material.

Though director Wes Craven and screenwriter Kevin Williamson don't quite generate the lightning-in-a-bottle energy that made their first Scream movie a hit, they manage to awaken a 15-year-old slasher franchise that has been dormant for a decade.
It does succeed at being a very, very dumb movie about being very, very smart - for whatever that's worth.
The Monuments Men positions itself to make a grand commentary on the importance of art and its preservation - and then says little on the topic.
Deliver Us from Evil gets more mileage from its hybrid premise than one would expect, by it quickly goes adrift in before coming to rest with an anti-climactic thud of a conclusion.
The movie is wholly an actors' vehicle, and the cast is largely superb, though Mulroney, Breslin, and especially McGregor are underused.
With Earthling, local filmmaker Clay Liford delivers a pseudoscience-fiction drama short on detail but heavy on brooding atmosphere.
As hokey and tone-deaf as it is implausible, this sloppy romance drama makes for one long, hard slog.
Hollow and pretentious.
There's little to recommend about Zookeeper, a movie that's flat, lacking in surprises and very dull.
Though it aims to upend the increasingly defunct romantic-comedy genre, Friends With Benefits quickly falls prey to the same clichés.
An anemic installment in the decade-old series that seems content with giving viewers more of the same.
Dull and uninvolving, Conan the Barbarian occasionally verges on escaping its rut, but never makes good on the promise. It's busy without having energy, a loud, lackluster mess.
The result is a message is too mixed to be effective.
Paranormal Activity 3 continues to milk the formula of its predecessors, but also manages to breathe some new life into the franchise and maintain its trademark intensity.
An ambitious, almost epic drama that devotes as much time to introspection as it does to combat.
It gets pretty good when it finally does pick up the pace, but by then it's too late.
A tidy and compelling psychological thriller by writer-director Sean Durkin that deftly charts one woman's shattered psyche.
A non-starter that could have been at least a good B-grade horror flick if it had been made with little more conviction.
Standard spy-fi fare presented in a very atypical style.
Man on a Ledge flirts with B-movie greatness but comes up short thanks to the far-fetched plot device used to power a clunky hybrid of heist flick/Hitchcockian wrong-man thriller.
An unusual, lightly surreal and unorthodox documentary by Jarred Alterman, Convento takes an unconventional approach that accentuates its subjects and never exploits them.
There are strong moments, usually on the comedy side, and Robinson does an excellent job of infusing the movie with the right amount of seediness.

It must be said that Blomkamp proves himself to be a capable storyteller, maintaining a gripping pace peppered with impressive, inventive, and often bloody action sequences. Elysium itself is a fantastically rendered place, and one used sparingly.
While at times it's easy to see the great film that Tunnel could have been, that never stops it from being perfectly watchable thriller that it is.
A lean, thumping excursion into the life of a legend.
At its best it is a deeply personal story of hope, love, friendship, and the loss of everything and everyone.
Feels less interested in offering any commentary or adding any substance than in propagating the original myth.
It's hard to resist the joy of the film, the unbridled heart, and Ove's tremendous, hilarious hatred for all the idiots of the world.
movie_title: A Man Called Ove (En man som heter Ove) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Essentially, the film, is a well crafted, well intentioned attempt to highlight a dire problem that all of its viewers will already understand.
Imperium, at its best, is a film about the ideological crisis of seeing the principles your worldview is built upon repurposed for hate and bigotry.
Despite its stabs at an original narrative, these filmmakers ... have yet to find their own voice.
A quizzical marriage of growth and a retreading of familiar themes that never fully coalesce or reach their potential.
movie_title: The Tenth Man (El rey del Once) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The main issue with "Pay The Ghost," is that it does absolutely nothing new - let alone muster up a reason for its own existence.
Where Land And Shade shines is in its outrage, and the heartbroken fury at the center of the film.
movie_title: Land And Shade (La Tierra Y La Sombra) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: For all the elements that don't mesh naturally, "Admiral" still manages to be intermittently engaging and fitfully exciting.
"The Last Man On The Moon" is, more than anything else, an engaging look back at one of the most exciting times in American history.
movie_title: The Last Man On The Moon (2016)

movie_review_blurb: "MI-5" is no action b-movie classic, but it manages to weave a complex and compelling narrative knot, mix in some absorbing musings about the nature of doing right and following orders, and pack in some nail-biting shoot outs.
The directors tactfully navigate the delicacies of death and the difficulties (and guilt) of life with a quiet poise that make for a film that is as enriching as it is disheartening.
...the sensation of seeing men responsible for so much death relaxing with their families is unsettling, while at the same time highlighting some small vestige of the humanity of both fathers.
movie_title: What Our Fathers Did: A Nazi Legacy (2015)

movie_review_blurb: 'Henry: Portrait Of A Serial Killer' still manages to pack a punch. It's arguably still as shocking as it set out to be, and for all its dated '80s aesthetic, it's deeply disturbing and unnervingly complex.
movie_title: Henry: Portrait Of A Serial Killer - 30th Anniversary (2016)

movie_review_blurb: "London Road," on stage and celluloid, is an experiment likely to fall flat outside of the most devoted of cinephiles (and theatergoers), but an exciting one nonetheless, even if only for its boldness.
A startling debut feature that proves Riccobono knows how pose challenging questions and face stark realities.
"The Ivory Game" is a searing look at the cost of ivory and the bravery of the men and women who have dedicated themselves to ending the cycle despite resounding apathy from most of the world.
An engaging and tenderly drawn film that is likely to resonate with anyone who has had to do the tireless work of sorting through an estate of a family member.
The tragedy is that the film ... is so utterly incompetent, so inexcusably bewildering, and so bafflingly hollow.
The true failing of the "Chloe And Theo," is its blatant insensitivity.
It's hard not to feel that something is lacking, that some throughline is missing, that the key narrative entree was lost amid the vibrant but not-quite-filling courses.

"Loveling" becomes a movie of great highs and awkward lows, the sort of film that inevitably becomes a sign of all the great things everyone involved will eventually do, rather than a testament to what they've done.

"This Is Home" is no "City of Ghosts" or "Last Men In Aleppo," it is unlikely to cause the seismic quake required to shake the apathy from the masses, but it is a much-needed reminder that a journey never quite ends when you think it does.

The trouble with figures like Bradlee, though, is that they loom so large, their actions so monumental, that it feels impossible to merely define them by their achievements, which is more or less what Maggio's movie does.
movie_title: The Newspaperman: The Life and Times of Ben Bradlee (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Nick Ebeling's movie sets its sights on adulatory tribute, needlessly venerating films like "The Last Movie" and generally adorning Hopper's legacy with saintliness.
It's well shot but never flashy, and it's well cut, making for a generally rounded film that disappears behind the larger than life personality at its core, a height few films manage to reach.
The documentary form has answered the call and offered up one of the most surprising and thoughtful romantic comedies of the year in "Dina."
Will likely connect best with those already familiar with Toshiro Mifune.
Adam Wingard's film is an incoherent mess of tones and styles, confused character motives, and murky narratives.
while "Mr. Chibbs" never manages to transcend its formulaic approach, it remains a minor key delight, a thoughtful, resonant look at what it means to be Kenny Anderson.

Really, none of In Loco Parentis is particularly new or exciting... But it certainly succeeds in being a joyous, humane look at the role that school, education, and, most importantly, teachers have in the lives of such malleable minds.
"Gifted" is often so divorced from genuine human emotions that it never feels less than phony.

"Cries From Syria," is, in many ways, an expansion on "White Helmets," a feature-length look at the war; a film that, while not especially pronounced in it's structure or technical achievements, is nonetheless timely and devastating.
A deeply funny endeavor that, despite sagging in the middle and never becoming anything close to profound, is a worthy and endearing film that achieves a lot with very little.
"Killing Ground" is a chilling, assured debut for writer/director Damien Power, packed with promise and a startlingly mundane sort of violence which is all the more shocking for its realism.
Succeeds as a joyous, humane look at the role that school, education and teachers have in the lives of such malleable minds.
While "Ocean Waves" never really comes close to reaching the glorious highs that the studio is known for, it is nonetheless a gorgeously realized and deep emotional film of quiet elegance.

Addiction creates a messy, tangled web of anguish, where the hurt is spread far and wide, and while there are several narrative points that are short-shifted, "To The Bone" works hard to do justice to that reality.
"Heart Of A Dog" is at turns a haunting, hilarious, muddled, disparate, and deeply emotional film about a woman, her dog, their bond, and the deaths that continue that haunt her.

(Bertrand Tavernier) has made an intimate epic, as coolly calculated as a chess match, in which blood on the battlefield and on the bedsheets is the fuel of economic and political power and masculine pride.
movie_title: La princesse de Montpensier (The Princess of Montpensier) (2011)

movie_review_blurb: In a brisk 100 minutes, we get to know the conflicted, but driven Hassan so clearly, intimately and, most of all, humanly, that you have to keep remembering not to root for him to succeed in his quest for death and destruction.
Ultimately, this is a film for serious-minded adults with enough relationship experience to understand and accept the unprecedented twists and turns romance can take -- for better or for worse.
An architecture lover's dream.
movie_title: How Much Does Your Building Weigh, Mr. Foster? (2012)

movie_review_blurb: A terrifically entertaining, smartly constructed trip down memory lane with one of the American stage's most legendary troupers.
Catherine Trieschmann's script, based on the novel by Leslie Schwartz, barely scratches the potentially loaded surfaces it serves up.
Ultimately, Kurt Markus, whose low-key narration punctuates the journey, seems to have learned as much about himself as about his titular subject - while enjoyably enlightening viewers about both.
[Although it's] somewhat repetitive and not terribly well-organized, it shines an important light on what the filmmaker deems "the greatest human rights disaster in the world today."
A unique documentary portrait of one of cinema's most quietly enduring talents.
"Pleasures" becomes as enveloping - and sometimes as awkward - as one of the L'Apollonide ladies' heaving corsets.
A highly entertaining tribute to Roger Corman, one of Hollywood's most prolific, enduring and unconventionally influential film producers.
movie_title: Corman's World: Exploits Of A Hollywood Rebel (2011)

movie_review_blurb: There's a lack of real conclusiveness to many of the film's characters and situations.
While hardly an all-inclusive look at this complex conflict, paints a heartfelt, fairly restrained picture of a nation under siege.
A ho-hum drama whose many moving parts feel decidedly recycled.
Although not exactly even-handed, the movie proves a deft look at a reluctant crusader and how financial sway and political override can so effectively trump the power of the average citizen.
Badly paced, ineptly written and filled with superfluous moments, the film is further hindered by awkward performances.
[A] stirring, if inconclusive documentary...
movie_title: A Journey in My Mother's Footsteps (2011)

movie_review_blurb: It flies off the rails in a third act so devoid of logic it could have been concocted on the moon.
It's all presented with equal parts humor and sensitivity...
A grating and witless would-be spoof of religion, male-bonding and, it seems, horror movies.
[It's] given such old-fashioned, kid-gloves treatment that its potential warmth and excitement caves under the weight of writer-producer-director Tim Chambers' good intentions.

Packed with impressive archival footage and rare interviews with dozens of the era's participants and observers, the film remains all too timely given the conflicts that continue to plague the Middle East.
movie_title: Back Door Channels: The Price Of Peace (2011)

movie_review_blurb: These profiles are frank, absorbing and heartbreaking, if also a bit inconclusive.
A work that's less urgent and involving than its intense subject matter might have dictated.
"Toast," is by turns sweet and tart, airy and rich and, above all, a thoroughly irresistible confection.
Though you could fit its story on the head of a pin, "A Bird of the Air" is a gently involving character dramedy with a pair of appealing leads who help give this offbeat movie flight.
The many topics raised - gangs, drugs, immigration, absentee parents, poverty - are examined with didacticism and platitudes instead of by mining their inherent complexities.

The film ultimately works best as a daughter's heartfelt tribute to an enormously devoted and emotionally generous parent. Unfortunately, that's just not enough to, well, connect us to the bigger picture.
movie_title: Connected: An Autoblogography About Love, Death & Technology (2011)

movie_review_blurb: [A] painfully inept, mercifully short documentary.
A once-in-a-lifetime character makes for a fascinating documentary subject in producer-director Liz Garbus' "Bobby Fischer Against the World."
Dolly Parton provides three original songs that suitably match this spottily acted picture's corn and treacle.
A crucial civil rights issue receives dull, inelegant scrutiny in "Iranian Taboo"...

An authentic look at life in remote Alaska (the film was shot with a native cast in MacLean's hometown of Barrow) and at a people grappling with drugs, alcoholism, poverty and the limits of an unforgiving environment.
Movies don't come much worse than "Monday Morning," a rambling, incoherent, ineptly assembled mess...
Proves a sincere, authentic, generally stirring effort.
Campbell Scott's strong narration (well-written by Allentuck) and fun vintage musical selections effectively round out this provocative portrait.
movie_title: Ordinary Miracles: The Photo League's New York (2012)

movie_review_blurb: It all makes for an enlightening and evocative snapshot.
movie_title: Inventing Our Life: The Kibbutz Experiment (2012)

movie_review_blurb: It decelerates into an unremarkable good-guys-vs.-bad-guys tale that ends in a glaringly tension-free showdown.
The film brings us vividly inside the life - and head - of its determined hero, Bud Clayman, as he depicts the process of what he calls "getting normal."
movie_title: OC87: The Obsessive Compulsive, Major Depression, Bipolar, Asperger's Movie (2012)

movie_review_blurb: A simple, richly emotional look at a failed actor's introspective last days in Hollywood.
Even the most forgiving viewers may feel like they've been underestimated - and underserved.
"Crooked Arrows" might involve two lesser-seen screen subjects - Native Americans and lacrosse - but it still can't break free of the usual underdog sports picture tropes.
Between all the flashbacks and flash-forwards, you'll need a scorecard.
"Mighty Fine," unfortunately, isn't.
[A] smart, involving documentary...
There's no real center to the film's potentially insightful topic, with Spurlock never zeroing in on a cohesive message.
This overlong movie never builds sufficient momentum.
Writer-director John Chuldenko stretches a sitcom episode premise to feature-length breaking point in "Nesting."

Morlando has crafted a stylishly shot and evocatively designed period piece. But it's the dashing, quietly charismatic Speedman who proves the main draw, holding our attention even when the movie doesn't.
Despite its grander ambitions, the film ultimately feels minor and superficial.
"Shanghai Red" largely emerges as a tantalizing, involving thriller.
It's a poignant conflict that the appealing Lee handles with deep sensitivity as well as, unfortunately, the sporadic overreaction.
An overlong mishmash of coming-of-age comedy, social satire and spiritual think-piece whose ultimate stance on religion feels awfully fuzzy.
[An] energetic, if overly worshipful documentary.
First-time feature director Kat Coiro gives an oft-tread story a snappy new spin in the hip and enjoyable comedy "Life Happens."
It's impossible not to root for these driven, high-spirited participants - and for the longevity of this invaluable program.
The third documentary in Junichi Suzuki's significant series about the Japanese American experience in World War II.
Poetic, at times profound...
A slam-bang, knock-your-socks-off action bonanza with some of the most peerlessly shot, performed and choreographed fight sequences you're likely to see on screen.
A deft and weirdly affecting portrait of how a drug-addicted man-child knocking on death's door manages an astonishing resurgence.
A frantic, badly constructed, slightly offensive muddle that doesn't so much end as run out of things on a checklist.
A film whose poignancy is hard to deny whatever side of the abortion debate you fall on.
It's all sharp, well-performed stuff until things go from darkly comic to just plain dark, derailing -- and dragging out -- the otherwise absorbing story. Still, this one's a cut above.
Once again, the premature loss of a loved one begets family dysfunction in the strangely uneven, yet occasionally resonant "Around June."
Writer-director and co-star Taika Waititi ("Eagle vs Shark") never builds much momentum for his largely uneventful if sometimes inventive story.

[A] grimly compelling, if slightly padded film with strong archival TV news footage, plus wrenching testimony from the relatives of several innocent bystanders gunned down around the El Paso-Juarez border.
It's hard to embrace this glacially paced, symbolism-heavy film's elusive - when it's not being elliptical - story about a city couple's escape to rural life.
A taboo-busting snapshot of contemporary Tehran - a provocative psychodrama that's part Iranian "Girls Gone Wild," set just before the 2009 elections.
Friedman's inability to successfully reconcile the film's duality undercuts an eclectic cast gamely committed to Mark Lisson's thematically ambitious, if scattered, script.
A highly imaginative if often darkly disturbing work that even at its most seemingly outlandish remains intriguing and involving.
A sadly bland footnote to an illustrious and influential career.
The movie deftly shifts from its initial chase thriller mode to a grueling, offbeat tale of human survival.
Your Thanksgiving turkey has arrived on schedule and it's called "The Nutcracker in 3D."
[A] superbly rendered and deeply absorbing religious drama...
movie_title: Vision: From the Life of Hildegard von Bingen (2010)

movie_review_blurb: More epic than it needs to be and less profound than it should be, "Jolene" remains a watchable excursion into human frailty and foibles.

A classy documentary perhaps more suited to classrooms and the History Channel than to theaters, " Winston Churchill: Walking With Destiny" nonetheless serves as an informative look back at one of the 20th century's most celebrated figures.
[An] involving, well-acted saga of a family torn apart by a devastating earthquake...
It's as if writer-director Israel Luna hatched a startling title and then flailed around trying to match its minor promise.
It takes a while to get there, but Inhale eventually emerges as a tense and morally complex thriller with a devastating twist.
A thrill-free snooze that will certainly rank as one of the least -- if not the least -- effective entries in Craven's nearly 40-year canon of cinematic shockers.
Maybe the whole topic is just too esoteric to warrant feature-length dissection without a craftier firebrand like Michael Moore at the helm.
The most provocative thing about the DIY trifle Douchebag is its title, and even that doesn't amount to much.

Eye-opening, yes, but Ross never ventures much beyond the mega-crop's production phase and into the specifics of its wider sale and distribution, where things likely get even thornier -- and perhaps more interesting.
"Carbon Nation" is an inspiring look at the many recent advances in clean energy and green technologies.
Though its premise seems ripe for a high-concept studio yukfest, The Freebie is all the better for its low-budget, human-scale approach.
An offbeat thriller that is deepened -- rather than derailed -- by its tricky shift from darkly funny to just plain dark.
Music Makes a City, despite its gorgeous soundtrack, historical sweep and wealth of archival material, is weakened by sluggish pacing and an overly detailed, increasingly narrow focus.
movie_title: Music Makes A City: A Louisville Orchestra Story (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Although Gruber's personal life and latter accomplishments are mostly addressed via a few closing sentences, Ahead remains a fleet and fitting tribute.
Just what is writer-director Jean-Paul Lilienfeld's endgame?
movie_title: La journée de la jupe (Skirt Day) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Unfortunately, the resulting film needed a more objective eye and, frankly, a grittier take than the victims' son -- producer, co-writer (with Paul Brown) and costar Brooks Douglass -- was able to provide.
It's an intimate, slice-of-life story in which things move deliberately, character goals are modest, and emotions -- both of the internal and external kind -- take center stage.
Proves unsatisfying not only because of its unlikable characters and often contrived conflicts but for the thoroughly implausible bride and groom at its core.
Bailey and Thompson managed to create a remarkably vivid portrait of a land and its people, while bringing us two unforgettable heroes in Campbell and Freeth.
Manages to mine substantial dark humor from this tragic situation while offering pointed -- and sometimes poignant -- social commentary in the process.
There's a whole lot going on in the Japanese anime fantasy Tales From Earthsea, so why is it such a bore?
Unfortunately, repetitive archival footage, Elliott Gould's dull narration, a lack of stirring punditry and several incongruous reenactments diminish the film's impact and veracity.
movie_title: Fallen Idol: The Yuri Gagarin Conspiracy (2009)

movie_review_blurb: How the genial Sambath remains so circumspect throughout his taut sessions with Chea is remarkable, as is so much of this must-see exposé.
An involving look at an American icon as well as an adept snapshot of our national zeitgeist from the McCarthy era through the Reagan years.
movie_title: Hugh Hefner: Playboy, Activist and Rebel (2010)

movie_review_blurb: In short, it's pretty but dull.
A kind of quiet Scandinavian cousin (OK, twice removed) to Home Alone, in which patient viewers will find sporadic rewards.
An entertaining, emotionally inspired stroll down memory lane -- that is, for Kessler.
A hollow concoction of sex, politics and endless chatter that's just a few camera angles short of hard-core porn.
An occasionally amusing, emotionally sound Belgian dramedy that never quite jells into the winning look at senior citizens - and second chances - that was clearly intended.
Mir gets under your skin in ways that are memorable and poignantly real.
movie_title: The Boy Mir: Ten Years in Afghanistan (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The problem is that, although the staff's and customers' concerns may be of relative import to their characters, their issues largely come off as either mundane or clichéd - or both.
The gripping documentary If a Tree Falls: A Story of the Earth Liberation Front offers an intimate look at the radical environmental group.
movie_title: If a Tree Falls: A Story of the Earth Liberation Front (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Proves a fitting tribute to one of the last century's most enduring children's tales.
Salomé and co-writer Natalie Carter offer some explanatory psychology, but the complexities remain underdeveloped. Still, you won't be bored.
Although writer-director Russ Parr sometimes overstays his welcome - peppier editing would have helped - a generally warm approach helps distinguish his oft-told story.
The filmmaker knows how to gently skew reality just enough to offset the excess cuteness.
Flies off its comic rails after an engaging start, never to land back on solid ground.
"Queen" sheds much-needed light on a disaster in progress.
movie_title: Queen Of The Sun: What are the Bees Telling Us? (2011)

movie_review_blurb: This highly involving film deftly captures the unique physical, emotional and financial aspects of diving into competitive Irish dance, with the participants' addictive immersion the overwhelming takeaway.
Proves an amusing, uniquely unifying effort.
After watching the leaden comedy "The Putt Putt Syndrome," you actually might understand less about marriage than you did going in.
So unsatisfyingly structured and sluggishly paced that its debits far outweigh its potential merits.
The various sleights of hand are impressive even if we're afforded little insight into their actual execution. Still, it's fun stuff.
Cregan covers the basics of character, situation and theme here but never finds his comic footing, resulting in a debut feature that's more tired than inspired.
The doc flags toward the end, but it remains an absorbing snapshot of a daring time.

Better to revisit such memorable Hollywood satires as "The Big Picture" or "For Your Consideration" before indulging Shepard's uninspired whimsy.
This generally involving film is gorgeous to watch thanks to its 500,000 hand-painted frames of vibrantly colored, enormously artistic animation.
movie_title: Mia et le Migou (Mia and the Migoo) (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A forgettable title and a barely there theatrical release don't do justice to the captivating and nostalgic coming-of-age dramedy "That's What I Am"...
Even the ablest performer couldn't sell such slapdash dialogue as "Yo, we gotta get outta here!" or the risibly repetitive, "I'm tired and cold and exhausted!"

A visually and aurally stunning film that brings viewers up close and very personal with several "big cat" families - as well as a dazzling array of other safari-esque species - living in Kenya's sprawling Masai Mara National Reserve.
Captures this brutal time - which led to the country's first free, multiracial elections in 1994 and the end of apartheid - in vivid, often bold, but never overpowering strokes.
The lovely, heartbreaking "Fly Away" benefits from superb performances and a gripping story managed with simplicity and grace by writer-producer-director Janet Grillo.

This often risible head-scratcher never cracks the surface of its muddled ambitions, largely wasting its iconic settings on a series of motley interactions, Tinseltown trivia and self-conscious philosophizing.
Although it runs just a fleet 40 minutes, the film proves a rich and memorable journey.
For a movie literally about "finding the funny," it's ironic that director Jim Pasternak too rarely does in his fitfully lively but mostly awkward mockumentary "Certifiably Jonathan."
Unfortunately, this well-acted cautionary tale is hampered by a lack of visual finesse and a script (by Andy Bellin and Robert Festinger) in need of a narrative rethink and a dialogue polish.
A lovely performance by Ethiopian supermodel-actress Liya Kebede as supermodel-activist Waris Dirie works wonders to elevate this uneven, occasionally awkward but often absorbing film.

movie_title: Saint Misbehavin': The Wavy Gravy Movie (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Whatever does work here - mainly a soulful performance by Liu Ye - ultimately gets lost in the excess.
A thankless lead vehicle for Ethan Hawke who's left largely stranded by writer-director Pawel Pawlikowski's opaque adaptation of Douglas Kennedy's novel.
For lovers of dance, "Never Stand Still" should prove a fleet, enjoyable excursion.

As an aid to better understanding this vital, complex dispute, the film is definitely worth a look.
It's a provocative, absorbing -- and at times dicey -- study.

movie_title: And Now A Word From Our Sponsor (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Although the movie is mostly dominated by ... talking heads, and punctuated by only bits of archival clips and other fleeting visuals, Lockett keeps things moving quickly and enjoyably.
Watching "André Gregory: Before and After Dinner" often feels like visiting with an elegant, genial, slightly mystifying old friend.
movie_title: André Gregory: Before and After Dinner (2013)

movie_review_blurb: At under an hour, the film, which also touches on White House-driven leaks for political gain, can't help but feel a bit incomplete.
movie_title: War on Whistleblowers: Free Press and the National Security State (2013)

movie_review_blurb: A tense, twisty cinematic artichoke brimming with moral complexity and intriguing shades of gray.
If Cronenberg's not yet a dead ringer for his iconic dad, he's taken an intriguing first step.
Writer-director Andy Gillies' shaggy underachiever alternates between the pointless and the elliptical as the movie sputters out its nominal story ...
A vital snapshot of developing world struggles and possibilities.
Observant but not revealing, free-form but not quite experimental, the obliquely titled "Pavilion" is a mood piece in search of a construct.
Something more coherent, masterful - and oddly poignant - than it may initially seem.
"There's something healing about simply watching "Free the Mind" ...
Add one more extraordinary survival tale to the canon of Holocaust documentaries: "No Place on Earth."
A vivid portrait that should satisfy aficionados and intrigue the curious. Ink-averse viewers, however, may remain unsold.

For horror fans, there are ... enough gruesome images, icky concepts and "don't-go-there" moments to carry the day.
It's a fun, nostalgic, informative journey.

Just enjoy its dazzling visuals, dream-like inventiveness and lush romanticism.
A worthy reminder of how much has been done to help heal our planet's ecological woes as well as how much remains to be achieved.

Marquette, aided by Frank Langella's precise narration, has crafted an engrossing and disturbing tribute.

Although writer-director Scott Walker seems committed to not overly exploiting his lurid subject matter, the movie is just too dreary, disjointed and generically creepy to be persuasive.
An engaging look at a pair of New York couples whose love lives intersect, crisscross, circle and backtrack in hip and provocative ways.

Although it favors breadth over depth, the documentary The United States of Autism offers a tender look at an eclectic array of children, their parents and other individuals affected by this ever-increasing developmental disability.
Shines a startling, hugely affecting light on the desperate measures so many women must take to survive in the world's most mercilessly patriarchal cultures.
Involving, thematically rich ... yet also quite timeless ...
A powerful story of triumph and tragedy - and the infamous moment that encapsulated both - gets a stirring workout in [this] colorful, absorbing documentary ...
movie_title: The Good Son: The Life of Ray Boom Boom Mancini (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Tweens and young teens should be sufficiently distracted by the movie's brisk pace and heroic mayhem - if they're not too unnerved by its at times nightmarish imagery.

The lovely and poignant drama "The Artist and the Model" stirringly presents art, life and death as one irrevocably tangled trio.
movie_title: El artista y la modelo (The Artist and the Model) (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Not to be glib, but sitting through the art-centric chamber piece "The Time Being" is truly like watching paint dry.
Proves a vivid reminder of the hand-in-glove importance of right actor/right role - and the indispensability of those casting mavens who helped make movie history. Good stuff.

[It] remains decidedly one-sided. But when that "side" is such a vital, convincing proponent for the greater protection and understanding of such evolved and majestic creatures, it can't help but win.
Offers a strong and dignified look at growing old while maintaining one's long-held convictions.

Though it's not that gracefully told and sometimes seems to exist just to plug eco-friendly cleaning supplies, "A Green Story" holds interest as a gentle, old-fashioned look at achieving the American dream.

A curiously uninvolving affair.

This is an involving, sympathetic film unafraid to wear its sizable heart on its sleeve.
[A] superbly told, enjoyably dishy documentary ..

A cerebral, dirge-paced outline of a father-son dynamic that asks the audience to fill in too many narrative and emotional gaps.
A moving, highly enjoyable, thoroughly absorbing portrait.

movie_title: The Right To Love: An American Family (2012)

movie_title: Holy Man: The USA vs Douglas White (2012)

[An] underwhelming, would-be political satire.

There's just so much one can care about this star athlete and his self-destructive journey.
A painless, if only mildly inventive, animated comedy.
An absorbing, at times heartbreaking look at several former and current denizens of downtown L.A.'s Skid Row ...
movie_title: Lost Angels: Skid Row Is My Home (2012)

The movie's intended audience will likely be satisfied by its parade of gory mayhem, cheap thrills and groan-worthy dark humor. Everyone else: You're on your own.
"Crossroad" builds considerable power as it weaves its pensive tale of life, death and destiny.
A revealing, disturbing look at how political and corporate forces have seemingly undermined the freedom and safety of our nation's equine population.
movie_title: Saving America's Horses: A Nation Betrayed (2012)

movie_review_blurb: A you-are-there slip-and-slide that follows a supermarket chain's pricing department exec whose life gets upended by a whirlwind new boss.
A sunny vacation of a film, a documentary that's as jaunty and improvisational as its colorful subject, prolific Brazilian artist Bel Borba.

A deft snapshot of a worthy nonprofit group as well as a profound tribute to America's brave, often unsung World War II veterans.

Lively and enjoyable.
Introducing the Dwights has its moments -- just not enough of them.
The worst idea for a studio comedy since last year's equally dreadful Failure to Launch.

A special little picture that resonates long after it's over.

Waitress runs on a bit, but with its strong acting, poignant moments, and fair share of laughs, it has the potential to become a modest hit.
Though nothing too earth-shaking happens, the movie is filled with a slew of compelling scenes, strongly performed under director Katherine Dieckmann's discerning eye.
As for the singing, it's pleasant but unctuous and, frankly, made me squirm.
movie_title: Sing Now or Forever Hold Your Peace (2006)

The filmmaker carefully avoids over-sentimentalizing the emotionally charged story, mostly striking a nice balance of pathos and humor.

Much like the television pilot it revolves around, the pale satire The TV Set doesn't quite know what it wants to be.

The Lookout may not be as startling or controversial, but it's a memorable and stirring effort.

[Writer Jonathan Lemkin] never streamlined the plot enough to make this the fully accessible 'popcorn picture' it aims to be. Frankly, I defy any average moviegoer to accurately recount Shooter's knotty story.
A largely unfunny, predictable, and tired crisscross of any number of lowbrow sitcom plots.
Sincere, but insufferably dull.
Forget the generic title, Once is an utterly beguiling, pitch perfect romantic musical that speaks volumes about love, passion, creativity, and hope.

Much of the data presented here is staggering, in both its simplicity and breadth of impact.
[A] lovely, absorbing adaptation of Anne Michaels' lauded novel.
So relentlessly oppressive it suffocates its potentially strong themes and characterizations.

Though it's not the most technically or narratively proficient piece, the film's compelling subjects can't help but inspire, even if we're not always privy to what truly drives them or how their family lives have been affected.

Even if you've never run for anything but a bus, you'll likely get swept up in this movie's inspiring journey of physical endurance and personal achievement.
Pregnant women -- and involved dads -- would be well advised to check out this provocative portrait.
A stupor-inducing, would-be thriller from Japan whose sporadic action and inept storytelling is as generic as its title.
Overwritten and under-directed by Maurice Jamal, the movie contains several honest moments but remains too awash in clichÃ (C)s and stereotypes to take seriously.
Bella is certainly a sweet, life-affirming picture, but it's just not authentic or captivating enough to justify its wildly concocted scenario.
A sweet, life-affirming picture, but it's just not authentic or captivating enough to justify its wildly concocted scenario.
While less successful than the similarly-themed Mystic River -- which was also adapted from a Lehane tome -- is still a cut above, thanks in large part to its many fine performances.

Broken goes a bit heavy on the symbolism (naming the leads Hope and Will, for starters) and tries to stir up sympathy for characters who may not deserve it, but as cautionary tales go, it's worth a look.
Though, for today's movie-going audience, Golda's Balcony may have limited appeal, it's a moving and vital story with many satisfying moments.

Well, it's certainly one of the less blatantly compelling subjects on the non-fiction circuit, and the doc has a lower-octane approach than most, but King Corn is surprisingly absorbing and amusing viewing.
At the film's core is a poignant message about teen male friendships that smartly balances the bawdy nuttiness that surrounds it.
We Own the Night may not feel any more special than watching a rerun of The Sopranos or The Wire, but as a serious adult crime yarn, you could do far worse.
The failure of our current administration to act openly and efficiently in a time of crisis gets another documentary close-up in Alex LeMay's humanistic and provocative Desert Bayou.
This is an impressive, critical film that should be screened for everyone who's ever exploited the Bible to justify fear and prejudice.
movie_title: For the Bible Tells Me So (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Personally, I would have preferred to just listen to a CD of Azerrad's engrossing interview in my car -- then pop in a Nirvana album for the rest of the drive home. Smells like a fine idea to me.
The lack of creative inspiration is at the root of this Heartbreak Kid's frustrating laziness and junky guffaws.
The normally engaging Kinnear is so stymied by his synthetic and ill-conceived role it's painful to behold.
King of California gets an 'A' for effort -- as well as for its fine lead performances -- but the movie just never rises above a trying premise and an unconvincing narrative.
My Best Friend's heart is in the right place, but its grasp on its characters isn't, well, the best.
Simply put, it's the worst film I've seen in ages.
...Angels in the Dust is an important, enormously emotional film that will hopefully have a far-reaching and valuable impact on the plight of Sub-Saharan AIDS.
Though Moving McAllister's heart and soul are in the right place, it's a terrible excuse for a movie.
Though it takes a while to get in sync with its flat style and sluggish pace, the movie creeps up on you in stirring, unexpected ways.
One of the best documentaries of the year.
movie_title: In the Shadow of the Moon (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Note to anyone who stumbles into this snoozefest: forget about taking the stairs-head straight for the nearest exit.

As dumb and redundant as its wink-wink title. Devoid of the charm and wit that's become the hallmark of so many British ensemble comedies, it feels more like some frantic, door-slamming stage farce than an actual movie.
Call it a comic documentary, a true-life comedy, or a Hollywood satire, but however you karate chop this one, it's a kicky, clever, highly amusing romp.
A tale of resourcefulness and resilience, as the often-overlooked female perspective on the Shoah gets its due.

The cast flaps and flounders their way through this mess without a compass. That includes Sissy Spacek as the world's worst shrink, and an extra-annoying Molly Shannon as Gray's co-worker at possibly the fakest ad agency ever committed to film.
The actual Avenue Montaigne may deserve a visit, but the movie celebrating its artsy glamour isn't quite worth leaving home for.
United 93 is one of the most important, necessary, and difficult films of our time.
A good example of a movie about characters who aren't conventionally 'likeable,' but who are sympathetic and engaging nonetheless.
Not only arch and preposterous but a serious con job to boot.
On a Clear Day, though sincere and diverting, is too restrained and conventional -- and just a tad too dull -- to stir up much enthusiasm.
If viewers can just get in synch with the movie's low energy and decidedly minor key, there are many pleasures to be had here, not the least of which is Affleck's affecting, unadorned performance.
Reitman manages his big, accomplished cast with a firm hand and provides enough snappy dialogue, sharp visuals, and droll observations to override the movie's lapses.

The excellent acting and offbeat humor that highlight veteran director Sidney Lumet's 43rd film Find Me Guilty can't make up for an overlong, morally topsy-turvy tale that's more claustrophobic than compelling.
Maybe on the page the lean story had some life, but on film the thing is D.O.A.
It's the lamest idea for a romantic comedy in recent memory, as well as one of the sorriest star vehicles in ages.
Though it aims higher than the average cop thriller, 16 Blocks rarely rises above its far-fetched plot and wham-bang mayhem.
For a film exploring the concept of memory, this well-intended, if slightly sensationalized documentary is nowhere near as memorable as it should've been.
Date Movie is pretty terrible, not because it's so awful to sit through, but because of how much better it could've been in more competent hands.
Firewall is mostly fast-paced and absorbing, at least it until it goes balls-to-the-walls dumb in the third act.
Surprisingly lively and hilarious.
Noteworthy and well-intended, The Lost City isn't exactly a lost opportunity, just a sincerely limited one.
Except for a few nice, honest moments that manage to sneak in, watching Nanny McPhee is like being beaten over the head with a toy mallet: harmless, yet awfully irritating.
It's a distinct and bittersweet story about how romance, however fleeting, can pop up in the most unexpected places.
movie_title: When the Sea Rises (Quand la Mer Monte...) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: It's a one-line pitch in search of an actual script. And, given how difficult it is to sell a screenplay to a studio, much less get it made, it's really sad to see something this lazy and meager actually work its way through the system.
From its challenging opening to its sphinx-like conclusion, Haneke is firmly in command of his material.
Fun With Dick and Jane is a rip-off -- in more ways than one.
The Family Stone is like a festively wrapped gift box that contains that special sweater you wanted - - only in the wrong size.
[The film] rarely bares its claws or its teeth, just its heart -- which, as we all know, can be a sincerely misguided piece of equipment.

While more video diary than polished documentary, it's nonetheless an absorbing, painful, and inspiring look at Ami's impossible trek across the United States to find the misguided doctor who once predicted he wouldn't live past the age of six.
Don't miss Rent.
The acting and the music are the main attractions here, so if you keep a close watch on your creativity meter, you should have a pretty decent time with Walk the Line.
Not every successful book needs to be made into a movie; Bee Season is a perfect example of that.

Unlike [other] war films, this one's not about what it's like to fight, but rather what it's like not to fight. And that alone gives this exceptionally produced and directed drama its own unique place on the cinematic battlefield.
Ultimately a tedious and exasperating look at a domestic experiment gone wrong.
movie_title: Three of Hearts: A Postmodern Family (2005)

movie_review_blurb: North Country can't help but be compared to such other women-against-the-system movies as Norma Rae, Silkwood, and Erin Brockovich, though it easily holds its own with all three.
It's always a pleasure to see a good movie that's simply about real people in real situations.
End of the Spear is so ineptly rendered, it all but erases the importance of the events it strains to honor.

Jim Carrey makes for an unlikely but completely effective lead choice. He brings a nice touch of comic irony to his otherwise serious role, impressively handling a wide range of emotions as an ordinary Joe caught in an extraordinary web.
It remains absorbing even as it frustrates.
It ends up feeling as stale as week-old bagels and lox.
Not that you don't want them to get together, but given how destined they seem to crash and burn, you wonder if it's really such a good idea after all.
A well-acted, truthfully written film -- there's just too much of it (about 20 minutes too much).
Alone With Her is a tense, well-shot little thriller in the vein of 'fatal attraction' youth flicks like Fear, The Crush, and Swimfan.
A stirring portrait of a theatrical sensation, one that should motivate artists of all stripes to break away, follow their bliss, and, most importantly, never take no for an answer.
Enough can't be said about Dench's gutsy, unglamorous work here.
A memorable, deeply felt tribute that scores serious points despite its few fumbles.
If only the movie's story was on par with its grand, charismatic star.
Minghella is aided immeasurably by his excellent cast, especially Jude Law, who seems to get better with every film, and a radiant Juliette Binoche in one of her best performances.
The Quiet's attractive young cast, erotically charged dialogue, and occasional chills make the movie a whole lot kickier than might be expected.
There's so little satisfaction to be had from the derivative set pieces and predictable plot twists that, mostly, you just want it to be over.
The movie is an ugly, self-indulgent, pretentious exercise masquerading as artistic and insightful filmmaking.
World Trade Center is a well-crafted, beautifully acted piece that's better judged on its own terms than as, say, the definitive recounting of 9/11. That film has yet to be made.
A sincere and honest little dramedy for and about Hollywood's most underserved age group: senior citizens.
A dreary misfire.

Despite solid visual effects and a few impressive, if incredulous action sequences (Josh Lucas's high dive into a fiery water pit is a dubious highlight), the movie mostly slogs along to its inevitable conclusion.

Co-directors Jonathan Dayton and Valerie Faris, along with first-time screenwriter Michael Arndt, have fashioned an enjoyably quirky, highly perceptive film that slaps a newish spin on family dysfunction.
Once the plot is actually engaged, all it really is, is a basic damsel-in-distress story with a lame stab at magical realism thrown in.
Burns, without pretense or sappiness, wears a heart the size of Manhattan on his sleeve, and handles the movie's rollercoaster of emotion with immense skill.
The director has created a stylish spoof filled with some razor-sharp dialogue and truly wild, original moments.
It plays like a hodgepodge of barely connected short films that all happen to star the same actor.
Ultimately, the movie is redeemed by a string of well-earned laughs and its trio of bright and engaging leads.
A colorful time capsule of 1970s New York... the doc's jauntiness is enhanced by its many charismatic characters and a funky, wall-to-wall soundtrack...
movie_title: Once in a Lifetime: The Extraordinary Story of the New York Cosmos (2006)

movie_review_blurb: The filmmakers did a masterful job assembling the extensive footage, and creating a coherent beginning (the soldiers' deployment), middle (tour of duty), and end (the return home).
A creepy misfire.
An impressive docudrama that recreates, in gut-wrenching detail, one of the most heinous recent examples of wrongdoing by the U.S. military -- that we know of.
A complex, deeply disturbing parable that's certain to find as many detractors as fans.
Their ongoing one-upmanship is awkward, juvenile, and not especially funny, yet underscored by so much honest pain you understand -- if not condone -- Gary and Brooke's desperate actions.
... it's impossible not to be shaken, stirred, and, finally, thoroughly enlightened by what the man is saying.

12 and Holding is a deft reminder of that fleeting time between childhood and puberty when everything still seems possible, even if getting there may seem virtually impossible. It's a special film to watch, whatever your age.

This comic strip-based bit of silliness isn't quite the ecology lesson it aims for, but it says enough about family values, suburban sprawl, and the over-caffeinization of modern society to ring true.
My Super Ex-Girlfriend is a cheesy bore that makes an airtight case for the 'safety' of internet dating.
The world's most successful ring of diamond thieves is inventively and insightfully explored in the documentary "Smash and Grab: The Story of the Pink Panthers."
movie_title: Smash & Grab: The Story of the Pink Panthers (2013)

movie_review_blurb: A sort of cross between The Shawshank Redemption and an episode of MSNBC's Lockup, the intriguing documentary The Dhamma Brothers makes a cogent case for prisoner rehabilitation over, as one inmate here bluntly puts it, being 'warehoused till you die'.
Despite -- or, perhaps, because of -- his cult status, Sheldon makes a compelling centerpiece for the lively, nostalgic documentary Trying to Get Good: The Jazz Odyssey of Jack Sheldon.
movie_title: Trying to Get Good: The Jazz Odyssey of Jack Sheldon (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Led by the affectless, monotone Ramsay, the cast is laughably bad, making the whole enterprise seem like a Saturday Night Live version of The Bourne Identity, as helmed by Ed Wood.
It soon becomes apparent that there's no real structure or point of view to it all.
Satire aside, what the oddball folks here never feel is real, despite the filmmakers' claims of autobiographical parallels.
There's plenty to recommend.

A picture so emotionally, comically and, yes, karmically out of touch with the real world -- not to mention the sheer basics of filmmaking -- that watching it feels as if you're being Punk'd, movie-style.
Hardy chomps down on his once-in-a-career role with stunning ferocity and never lets go. He's extraordinary.
Although strongly acted and deeply felt, writer-director Jeremy Davidson's arcanely titled Tickling Leo is too theatrically conceived and diffusely told to satisfy its lofty aspirations.
An extraordinary journey of the heart and spirit, and a stirring testament to parenthood.
The film, which is "presented" by Sean Penn, stands as a powerful testament to people like Thompson and Gubernati, whose selfless devotion to helping others is rare indeed.

Unfortunately, though Malkovich remains a compelling and cerebral screen presence, he comes off as too innately detached and prickly to elicit much empathy (not that his character is asking for it, mind you).

Fortunately, the staunchly committed and controversial Ellsberg, now 78, is still around to tell his history-making tale, and he lends the film gravitas as both its persuasive narrator and primary talking head.
movie_title: Most Dangerous Man in America: Daniel Ellsberg and the Pentagon Papers (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Claudia Pryor Malis' candid, compactly informative film, showing for one week to qualify for much-deserved Oscar consideration, examines an extremely complex issue in a laudably accessible yet hard-hitting way.
movie_title: Why Us? Left Behind and Dying (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A lopsided, visually uninspired film that works best when it eschews the complex numbers-crunching of its financial industry pundits and whistle-blowers to profile the everyday victims of the crisis.
It's tedious, dispiriting stuff.
Moss brings warmth and dignity to a part that could've easily slid into stereotype, while Camryn Manheim owns her few scenes as Amanda's best friend.
It's a decent adult drama that should keep you guessing.
Ultimately, Five Minutes of Heaven is stronger as a whole than its individual parts.
Gass-Donnelly tricks up this phony baloney with nervous camerawork and editing while also stranding his actors with scads of second-rate dialogue. A bad time is had by all.
A vital yet thorny approach whose inconclusiveness is bound to sadden or infuriate anyone who's lost a loved one to AIDS.
The film boasts a significant story with several effective plot twists that make it worth a look.
You don't need to be a gamer to appreciate this involving and well-paced character study.
Bring your handkerchiefs.
If their stories don't persuade you to ditch the Dasani, vivid shots of how water bottle refuse is turning our oceans into "plastic soup" should do the trick.
The large cast performs with comic aplomb as McKenzie slowly ratchets up the stakes before going for broke in the final reel. It's jolly good fun.
Somers Town is a funny and endearing character comedy whose extra-brief, 70-minute running time proves perfectly adequate for its slender, episodic story.

It's a kicky, slightly exhausting look at a bygone era of low-rent moviemaking, whose colorful trove of film clips should delight fans of cinematic esoterica, nostalgic schlock and high octane drive-in fare.
movie_title: Not Quite Hollywood: The Wild, Untold Story of Ozploitation! (2008)

movie_review_blurb: These elder statesmen's recollections of their brief moments on the moon, as well as of what preceded and followed, make for vivid and emotional storytelling.

There are no great emotional revelations about the fearless, free-spirited athletes profiled in the film, but these tanned-and-toned folks' deep love of surfing and mostly cheerful demeanors prove enjoyably infectious.

Director Jonas Pate and screenwriter Thomas Moffett have turned this strongly cast, potentially smart tale of personal intersection among a mostly rarefied group of Los Angelenos into an irritating and unconvincing slog.
Kempner creates a poignant reminder of one of the most influential, if now largely forgotten, great ladies of entertainment.
[A] silly and predictable fourth installment in the lucrative thriller series about pretty young people attempting to cheat death.
Though this narrative device can feel a bit gimmicky and grandiose, it also provides a visual and emotional power that drives home this absorbing film's crucial cautionary message.

Blethyn brings tremendous empathy to the introspective, determined Elisabeth, while the tall, gaunt and dreadlocked Ousmane fleshes out his less-dimensional role with a haunting sadness that speaks volumes.

Though the movie is filled with complex emotions and a powerful poignancy, it often manages to be darkly funny, thanks to Holbrook's wily, unsentimental portrayal under Teems' smartly calibrated hand.
[It] loses some of its anarchic steam as it goes. Still, it's a dang good bet you've never met any family quite like the Whites.
movie_title: The Wild and Wonderful Whites of West Virginia (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The film takes an effective, two-pronged approach to tell its enlightening tale.

The supporting players, including Kristen Johnston as Grind's wise production head, Denise Richards as Jody's movie's gentle leading lady and Jamie Kennedy as a sweet but dense porn actor, also deftly rise to the occasion.
The narrative leapfrogging and tonal uncertainty here -- not to mention a slight incoherence -- overwhelm this trifling tale's dark charm and potential playfulness.
The soccer footage, although not the centerpiece one might expect, provides a vivid sense of the game's ardent, sometimes inflammatory fans and its significant place within the Israeli zeitgeist.
movie_title: After The Cup: Sons Of Sakhnin United (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Holy Rollers never quite catches fire ... still, it's an often evocative dip into unique territory fleshed out by a highly convincing cast.
An astoundingly bad memory piece that blows its potential dramatic heft at every turn.
The film is too reverently drawn and self-consciously played to muster any real momentum.
Make time for this one.
Writer-director Allen Wolf loads In My Sleep with so much psychosexual baggage you wish he just focused on one emotional affliction to propel this mediocre whodunit.
It's the terrific music and amusing array of characters that keep the picture afloat.
Though the narrative could use more depth and detail, the film generally absorbs with its strong performances, stirring emotions and vivid imagery.
Benjamin Bratt brings his A-game to a difficult, potentially clichéd role.
Unfortunately, though its heart is smack in the right place, The Greatest tends to play more like a collection of appropriate, well-acted scenes than as a fully satisfying narrative.

Terrific archival footage from a range of seminal civil rights events, as well as affecting narration written by Sarah Kunstler and spoken by Emily Kunstler (who also edited the film), round out this superior documentary.
Succinctly captures the roller coaster emotions of average teens as they navigate friendship, romance, sex, drugs, partying, high school, parents, music and more.
Though this inspirational movie often cuts away too quickly from its characters' stage performances, it's a significant look at a vital, underreported segment of the entertainment world.
Surviving Crooked Lake offers tension and honest emotion while making good use of its clearly limited financial resources.
Chen and Chiu's genuine, rarely cloying performances along with Cheung's urgent sincerity add immeasurably to this timely film's many modest pleasures.
While this tenure-challenged Middle Eastern studies professor is hardly pleasant cinematic company, it's tough to look away.
movie_title: American Radical: The Trials of Norman Finkelstein (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A mostly pedestrian political thriller whose basis in true events adds little to the film's excitement or entertainment value.
By turns frightening, fascinating and eye-opening, this documentary offers much to rouse followers of various religious and political stripes.
The oft-used ploy of forcing an odd couple into a car and sending them off to uncharted territory is trotted out yet again here, but to minimal comic or emotional effect.
This is a deftly acted, generally absorbing cautionary tale with wider allure than its faith-based label may imply.
As a writer-director with five decades' worth of notable screen work to his credit, [Herzog] certainly can't be faulted for taking risks, even if it means now and then, well, falling on his sword.
movie_title: My Son, My Son, What Have Ye Done (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A hugely well-meaning but painfully inept melodrama.
movie_title: Punctured Hope: A Story About Trokosi and the Young Girls' Slavery in Today's West Africa (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Though the cautionary symbolism is clear here, the committee-written film (there were five scribes including Meier), smartly keeps its message quotient in check.
The Vicious Kind upends the heavily tread dysfunctional family drama in ways that are unique, surprising and memorable.
Serves as another critical reminder of one of the world's most horrific periods, even if, cinematically, it's an affecting collection of stories and images in search of an actual center.
If well-meaning people didn't make stupid choices -- and if cellphones worked everywhere -- way fewer vacation-from-hell thrillers would probably be made.
Manages to be fun and informative without tipping too far into the dark side; it favors war stories over horror stories.

Packed with an extraordinary amount of archival material, the film offers a fascinating, if occasionally dense look at a grass-roots movement that became the world's chance to retroactively fight Hitler's Holocaust.
Death in Love is occasionally pretentious but always riveting.

Those undead baddies, allegedly flash-frozen since World War II, are kind of unique, but they don't make up for the sense of déjà vu one feels watching the rest of Wirkola's bloody vacation-from-hell-athon.
Cheesy visual effects involving, apparently, spiders and caterpillars round out the ineptitude.
P.J. is an unconvincing drama saddled with dime-store psychology and a clunky inspirational message.
Perhaps it's the bright, decent, appealing kids seen here, or just the idyllic portrait Suh paints of student life at Manhattan's prestigious Stuyvesant High School that gives the picture its charm.
erhaps a bit of star power, or at least less generic actors in the leads, might have given these underdeveloped siblings more credence or appeal.
A tedious, by-the-numbers raunch-fest that exists strictly because it can.
Summer Bishil turns in a gutsy, quietly riveting performance as Jasira.
If anyone thinks the last two U.S. presidential elections were contentious, they were schoolyard scuffles compared to Mexico's explosive 2006 presidential race.

Parents eager to venture outside the animation or talking-Chihuahua boxes for family entertainment should check out the documentary The Little Red Truck, an inspiring look at a diverse array of youngsters introduced to the joys of stage performing.
Given that this supremely silly satire directed by The Naked Gun's David Zucker plays more like something slapped together to beat an expiration date, it's hard to get too worked up about it.
Though Freebird may prove a worthwhile ride for its motorcycling trio of middle-aged screw-ups, it's a bad trip for anyone stuck watching this tedious drug comedy.
An intelligent adult drama that's especially relevant in these harsh economic times.
A poignant film filled with ample rewards for those who submit to its leisurely pace and gentle observations.

[The] endless string of demeaning apartment-doorway interactions with a convincing cross-section of hungry customers is darkly funny, even if it never snowballs into the After Hours-type obstacle course one might hope.
An absorbing look at how a circle of dispossessed young artists from the 1990s eventually found its way to mainstream success.
It's too bad there was no way around the story's inherent deficit since this effectively unsettling film, directed by Rob Schmidt, chugs along quite well for a while.
The Longshots is a likable enough Cinderella story, one whose heart is clearly in the right place, even if it winds up on its sleeve once too often.
Recent and archival interview, news, war and music footage, which often juxtapose the Vietnam and Iraq conflicts, round out this unflinching, well-constructed picture.
A Man Named Pearl not only makes you want to get out there and play Edward Scissorhands but can, at least for its 78 jazz-and-gospel infused minutes, help replenish one's faith in humanity.
An absorbing, finely nuanced morality tale.
If Tony Soprano had a cheekier, less haunted, openly gay British counterpart, it would be Dominic Noonan, the Manchester crime boss profiled in the stylish and compelling A Very British Gangster.
What the film loses in momentum as the romance takes over, it gains in sex appeal as its two attractive actors make their own kind of magic.

An especially shameful chapter in U.S. history -- the internment of innocent Japanese Americans during World War II -- is sensitively examined in the overly brief but worthy documentary Passing Poston.
Although talented newcomer Christine Horne is ideal as the younger Hagar, letting Burstyn play the character at around 50, despite best-effort lighting, was not the wisest choice.
Rarely has the healing power of sports been as genuinely depicted as in director Susan Koch's perception-altering documentary Kicking It.

Director Adam Yauch tricks up this eclectic look at all-star high school basketball with so much cool high-def camera work and showy editing it's sure to satisfy the film's target youth audience's appetite for zippy visuals and swift pacing.
